It's also ponderous as Mel explores the emotional contradiction of how she feels she can always do more to help others but can never do enough, scrutinizing the thin line between good and evil and how their definitions aren't always clear cut.I originally read this short story when it was published in The Powers That Be: A Superhero Collection, an anthology filled with many more great superhero stories just like this one. =)

This story starts innocently enough, with a child searching for her precious locket. Appearances are deceiving though and as you move through the story, we realize that things are just a little off-kilter, making you wonder what the heck is going on here. The story continues to evolve as a series of startling revelations take place, culminating in the most stunning, shocking reveal of all, making me gasp at the audaciousness of it. Once I read that, everything else up to that point now made perfect sense. Haunting, moving and bold all at the same time, this is a satisfying and engaging story.I originally read this short story when it was published in WOOL Gathering (A Charity Anthology), an anthology filled with many more great stories taking place in Hugh Howey's world of Wool (Wool Trilogy Series).

Starting out as a story of three women complaining about their mates and the connections they have with them, Hazel has major issues with hers in that he seems to be a little too needy. These companions are custom-made, highly-programmable human simulacra and overall, are supposed to be the ultimate mate, the yin to your yang. At least, that how Perfect Partners, or PePr, Inc. created and designed them to be. As the story continues, there is a subtle but sly shift that becomes seismic in its significance when you realize how it affects the entirety of the story and the way you read it. A truly excellent twist with a perfect solution that effectively solves Hazel's relationship problems. A highly entertaining narrative that made me appreciate the smart and dexterous way it was written.I read this short story when it was originally published in The Robot Chronicles (The Future Chronicles), an anthology filled with many more excellent robot stories just like this one. And I read it again because it was that much more rewarding (and fun) the second time around. =)If you enjoyed this short story, the author also wrote a novella taking place in this same universe called Posthumous (Perfect Partners, Incorporated Book 2). You don't have to have read that story to understand this one, as they can be read independently of one another. But you will have a richer experience if you read them both. I know I did.

Ethan is a writer, an older man who lives by himself. He decides to get a Perfect Partner (PePr) named Edna, a robot with sophisticated programming that is meant to be the yin to his yang, fulfilling its owner's every need. At first, he's not quite sure what to make of Edna, keeping her at a distance. But as the days turn to months turn to years together, she becomes less of a PePr and more like a person to him, deepening their friendship.  But when Edna talks to him about his stories as he writes them, helping him to parse them out, she assists him in giving the stories more depth and humanity. As their process evolves, she transforms from a companion and caretaker into his partner, improving his stories and imbuing them with life.As Ethan grows older, one story, "Star Surfer", becomes his breakout success. Of course, his publisher demands more. As he writes more stories in this universe, there's one character named Lulu, whose story remains untold, waiting for the two of them to tell it. Will Lulu's story ever be written and shared with readers?How this fictional character becomes significant to their relationship is only one of the many joys waiting to be found in this story. This novella also explores how PePr's are integrated into society and their struggle to be classified as human beings and accorded the same legal status. Plus, we get to meet an adorable beagle, Charlie, who plays an important role in their lives. All of these stories interconnect in surprising and memorable ways as we watch them make a life together as they grow old.Through these special relationships, the author taps into primal, deep emotions with her prose, which really engages you in a profound way. She has a special way of articulating her words so much so that it taps into the human experience and captures it with such beautiful clarity. And she not only illustrates this through Ethan, but through Edna, a non-human character, as well. It all culminates into an ending that is engrossing, fitting and heartbreaking.I found this to be a delightful novella that uses robots as a prism for thoughtfully examining the human condition while also expanding its definition. The relationships here are delightfully detailed and wondrously moving, pulling you into the story as you explore how two people (and a beagle) create a family together. I found this to be one of the best stories the author has written to date and a genuine pleasure to read.If you enjoyed this short story, the author also wrote a short story taking place in this same universe called PePr, Inc. (Perfect Partners, Incorporated Book 1). You don't have to have read that story to understand this one, as they can be read independently of one another. But you will have a richer experience if you read them both. I know I did.Please note that I was given an Advanced Readers Copy of this eBook. A favorable review was never expected or asked for.

On a planet not too far from our own, humans and alien space dragons symbiotically live in peaceful co-existence with one another. But when a divisive faction threatens to detonate a bomb that will destroy their entire planet, they realize there is only one possible solution but it's a bad one. Majestic in its depictions of dragons, innovative in the way it presents the story and ingenious in depicting the symbiosis between the two cultures. This tale generates a genuine palpable apprehension as you wonder whether they will all survive this crisis.I read this short story when it was originally published in The Dragon Chronicles (The Future Chronicles), an anthology filled with many more excellent short stories about dragons just like this one! =)

With an opening sentence that immediately grabs you, we get the full story of long-lasting friendships between three fifteen-year-olds, Tom, Jed and Karen, in the Silo and how it appears to have led to one friend murdering the other. As all is divulged, you come to see the full tragedy of how events could spiral so badly out of control. Compelling and moving, the author drops tantalizing clues in the narrative that heighten the tension and help you piece together events, demonstrating an emotional depth to his characters that help you truly understand their motivations by the time you reach the end. This impressive story is an emotional powerhouse that is quite stirring when all of the puzzle pieces reveal the complete picture of what happened here.I originally read this short story when it was published in WOOL Gathering (A Charity Anthology), an anthology filled with many more great stories taking place in Hugh Howey's world of Wool Wool (Wool Trilogy Series).

How many of us have made a crucial decision that had a ripple effect on the rest of our lives, for better or for worse? The answer would be everyone reading this. Now, take that idea and apply it to the most important pivot points in history, where something changes so drastically, the world is severely impacted by its tremendous ramifications. This anthology speculates on those âwhat if?â moments and amplifies them in intriguing, surprising and entertaining ways. The foreword from the anthology producer Samuel Peralta quotes one of his wonderful poems and thoughtfully discusses how chaos theory influences the past, present and the future.  After that, we get thirteen short stories that explore fascinating âwhat ifâ scenarios:Stacy Ericsonâs âLes Medusesâ â Pierette is the executionerâs daughter in France during the 1500âs.  In this role, sheâs forever marked, burdened to wear the special raiment of her select station. As she gets older, she starts to see this as a curse, feeling imprisoned and wanting to escape. As her dissatisfaction grows, she is given an opportunity to travel to England when her father is chosen to put the Queen of England, Anne Boleyn, to death. How the story plays out, from its first person perspective to its lush description truly immerses you in Pieretteâs life, especially the pain she feels due to societal constrictions. The story concludes with some shocks and amazing twists, leading to a fitting yet unexpected ending.Ann Christyâs âUnnaturalâ â in September 1978, Pope John Paul gets ready to give a sermon endorsing and changing the way the world looks at in-vitro fertilization. Fast forward two hundred years later, we meet Eldora, whoâs talking to her mother about the possibilities of a natural childbirth, defying societal norms where childbirth is done in test tubes by the majority of the world, making sure there are no aberrations. We learn about how far Eldora and her husband will do for love and whatever it takes to have children the way they want to. I sincerely felt the Pope's weariness and Eldora's hopefulness that her mother will understand and accept her decision. Overall, this is a very powerful, emotional and engrossing story boldly imagined where the characters personal motivations are vividly described and cogently argued as you find yourself agreeing with Eldoraâs statements and actions.Nicolas Wilsonâs âOld Ventures, New Partnersâ â Ian is an MI6 spy in East Germany, 1963, who gains information about how the Soviets are going to assassinate JFK, which is a feint for their true objective. Ian informs Hugh Howard, a civilian contractor and developer of a special military prototype, because both him and the president in danger! Acting quickly on the information, Howard decides to brashly use his experimental prototype to try saving JFK but will he succeed in his mission or die trying? Featuring an inventive prototype, this is a thrilling story that moves at a breakneck pace, culminating in a startling and unexpected conclusion.Pavarti K. Tylerâs âConcerns of the Second Sexâ â Helen is a 14-year-old girl, the seventh daughter of her fatherâs seventh wife, in a hierarchical society where men are most important and women are considered subservient. Deemed unfit to marry off, her mother decides to help Helen escape, knowing what cruel fate awaits her. After a harrowing departure, she finds protection in a world very different than the one she knew and was taught about inside her sheltered walls. The inequality of genders, races and sexual preferences raises many questions for Helen upon discovering how these freedoms are allowed here as she learns how society scorns what it doesnât understand. The heartrending finale strikes the reader with concussive force, leading into a heartfelt and agonizing conclusion as you wonder how in the world depicted here, there cannot be more acceptance of difference.Logan Thomas Snyderâs âRenegatâ â In the aftermath of a nuclear first strike against Russia in 1983, all those of Russian descent inside of the borders of the United States are rounded up and placed into internment camps. In one such camp, we meet Anatoly is adjusting to camp life. A renegade, in more ways than one, who rebels against his captors and the way they inhumanely treat the prisoners, striving to always do the right thing, even if the guards donât like it. As Anatoly finds unexpected friendships that make camp life a little more bearable, eventually the tension reaches a tipping point. Secrets are revealed and we cheer as Anatoly must take a heroic stand for what he believes in, all the while holding the reader spellbound in a story full of heart and unexpected outcomes.Tony Bertauskiâs â108 Stitchesâ â Theo was raised since the age of five to love baseball. But to nurture that passion, his grandfather has something injected into him so baseball became the focus of his life. As Theo grows into an adult and a superstar baseball player, Steve Wozniak focuses on synthetic stem cells called biomites, revolutionizing medicine and curing most diseases in the process. These advances threaten to become a crutch for Theo the longer he plays, but will he realize the frightful costs of these methods before itâs too late? An excellent parable on experiencing life instead of blunting it dangerously with something synthetic, the emotional core of this story resonates the most as Theo tries to find something he realizes he lost over the course of his life to date.Sam Bestâs âRengokuâ â Three soldiers in World War II have penetrated the Japanese mainland in 1945 in an ongoing mission to prevent crucial intelligence from reaching the Japanese government, changing the balance of power in the war. As we learn more about how this interesting mission came to be, a Virginian named Blake and a Japanese man who immigrated to America, Kenishiro, carry on until one day, they intercept a Japanese runner whoâs carrying something unusual that will change their mission, and their lives, forever. A compelling story of two soldiers with disparate backgrounds coping with the war and its effect on their lives as well as providing an intriguing character study.Anthea Sharpâs âThe Sun Never Setsâ - In England 1850, Kate is a 17 year-old woman whoâs more interested in astronomy than in matchmaking as her mother attempts to find her a mate. Kate discovers a strange dot in the sky that heralds the beginning of an unprecedented adventure for her as well as for the entire world. When what she discovers comes to fruition in a strange and fascinating fashion, an audacious plan is proposed â to the Queen of England! A riveting mash-up of genres, a charming portrait of this time period and an aspiring astronomer who finds something completely unanticipated all combine to make one delightful story.Michelle Browneâs âThe Factoryâ - Martha and Jennifer are slaves in a factory that manufactures material for the ongoing war effort between countries with two different ideals. As their friendship develops, Martha discovers there is more to Jennifer than meets the eye. When Jennifer reveals her secrets, what the purpose of the war really is and her intrepid plan to escape slavery, it turns into a prison escape! The story maximizes its steampunk setting and the escape turns into an exciting thrill ride where the emotional stakes are high and we hope everyone makes it out alive as two slaves try to attain freedom at all costs.Peter Cawdronâs âNaturalâ - Lincoln and his wife have lost another child to disease in the year 2026. Lincoln, a doctor who works for the government, discovers something incredible that will change the course of society forever and prevent people from dying like his children did. But because it is so controversial, he decides he must make a stand in the name of science. Giving a press conference, his revelation is so startling that the naturalists are fearful! With a momentous and stirring conclusion, Lincolnâs realization that that a better future can only be had if he goes against societal norms and does what he thinks is right. The story is passionate, emotionally intense and deeply heartfelt, making us appreciate the longevity that good science gives us and how it has enriched our lives immeasurably.Thomas Robins' âEighth Amendmentâ â Lance is in prison for supposedly murdering his wife and heâs been given the death penalty. Once we see how that sentence is carried out, the reader is really surprised with what happens next! The story goes in wild and unpredictable directions as we find out what this really means and its ramifications for Lance. As the clock ticks down, the tension ratchets up and he is forced to make a choice under pressure that he will have to live with for the rest of his life, however brief that might be. As Lance fully comprehends how dire his predicament has truly become, the story culminates into its most powerful, primal moment.  An ingenious and audacious reimagining of the death penalty, imaginatively executed in a way that made me gasp.Ken Liuâs âA Brief History of the Trans-Pacific Tunnelâ â Charlie is the last surviving worker from the creation of a revolutionary tunnel. As he meets someone in Midpoint City deep under the earth, she draws him out of his introverted shell. We are recounted with the history of the tunnel and how it changed the course of world history after World War I, leading to an unprecedented new era of commerce and changing the world in the process. As we learn more details about Charlieâs history, we sympathize with his many struggles over the years and learn his dark secrets. Culturally adept and realistically detailed, this nuanced portrait of a man and the tunnel leads into a tragic yet touching finale, bringing Charlieâs story full circle as he tries to make peace with his past. This story was simply breathtaking in its storytelling.Zig Zag Claybourneâs âAgents of Changeâ â Daniel and his partner Claudette are agents working for the Difference Machine, which has a mysterious purpose - it is in charge of dispatching its agents to historical hotspots to manage all the alternate timelines that continue to crop up around it. We are given small pieces of the puzzle and slowly see what larger picture the author is drawing as we wonder what the heck is going on here. Then, the agents take on the most important mission of their life protecting someone critical to the timeline! Bursting with imagination and presented in an unusual and fantastic way, we learn what the story is really about by its end. This marvelous, energetic and highly enjoyable story is presented with a lot of panache and style, was a lot of fun and had a great and unforeseen ending.All of these tales present powerful parables about societal injustices, gender inequalities, genre mash-ups and sweeping changes on a world scale. While all of these alterations to history were fantastic and inspired, they only served as a backdrop for these rich characters and their tribulations. Each one of these stories speculated how history affects the world but only when we see it on such a personal scale can we truly appreciate the deep impact it has on us as individuals. These stories are proof of that belief.So enjoy these delightful tales of âwhat ifâ, be thankful that these are an alternate history and not our present one, while also thinking about how they might help us learn more about how to make our future a better place.Please note that I was given an Advanced Readers Copy of this eBook. A favorable review was never expected or asked for.

When a man wakes up to find himself in Brooklyn Psychiatric Hospital, being asked about why he was running naked through Central Park, yelling about alien space tentacles, he realizes that he doesn't know what happened to him! We observe as he slowly pieces it all together and then the story moves at a breakneck pace, the adventure getting more madcap as it goes. There's some wackiness as it kicks into high gear and the situation spirals out of control, leading to a perfect but definitely unpredictable ending. Eliciting plenty of laughs from me while holding my interest throughout, this zany but terrific tale will leave you in stitches.I read this short story when it was originally published in The Alien Chronicles (The Future Chronicles), an anthology filled with many more excellent short stories about aliens just like this one! =)

In ancient times, Sir Durst is the dragonslayer who has killed many dragons and used his rewards to buy the town tavern, eventually starting a family. Athelina is his daughter and her story begins as a young girl, watching the indignities her mother has to endure at the hands of her domineering father. Not to mention the price gouging the bar patrons have to suffer from due to his greed. Over time, he teaches her the hard ways of the world and how to survive it, based on his own corrupt point of view. Never allowed to leave the bar, we observe how his teachings are the byproduct of far more calculating nature and how he's truly bereft of morals. However, he is hiding dark secrets of his own. Will those secrets come to light and become exposed? And will Athelina be able to escape from her father's ironclad control and transcend her upbringing to become something more?The answers to both of those questions will surprise you and keep you glued to the page as you read through the story. In particular, the psychological portrait of both Durst and Athelina is truly fascinating, as Durst's motivations are always at the forefront of his actions. You watch how Durst's cruelty manifests, not in anger but in more torturous ways towards his daughter as his secrets corrupt him. Athelina is someone yearning to be free from the prison her father has slowly constructed for her. Trapped under her father's influence, the reader witnesses how, one act at a time, her gentle soul slowly hardens into something darker, with her self-identity severely repressed by the process.With a powerful ending and strong, well-thought out characters, this riveting and thoughtful short story moves in surprising directions as you watch the personal stakes climb for Athelina as she matures and hope she can attain what she wants the most.This is an excellent and compelling companion piece to Where Dragons Lie (Dragons of Edgewick Book 1). You don't have to have read that to read this one as it stands on its own independently. However, you will want to read them in order. If you do, you will see how the events in first story parallel this one, intersecting in intriguing ways and complementing one another. You won't be rewarded with coin, the currency of the realm, if you do this but you will see how both stories are woven together to create a larger tapestry that is both engaging and really exciting for the reader.

Stu is a bestselling novelist, trying to conclude his trilogy of books, having ended book two with a cliffhanger, his hero stuck in a literary limbo. Stu's not sure how he can follow up his story and he has a deadline looming. Looking for inspiration, he powers up an old typewriter and writes up an outlandish little story to see if it will help. But when this story comes true the next day, he cannot believe it. What he does next with this unusual typewriter is humorous and unpredictable, leading into a thoughtful and touching ending that left me with a big smile on my face.This is a truly delightful journey as an author tries to ignite his imagination and stimulate his creative process while also perfectly capturing the idyllic life of a small town and its calm lifestyle. Overall, I found this to be a sparkling tale filled with personality and gentle charm.Please note that I was given an Advanced Readers Copy of this eBook. A favorable review was never expected or asked for, only an honest one.

Survivors live in the Silo deep underground after an apocalypse has ravaged the Earth, the last bastion of humanity. Many generations have lived and died in this world having never seen the sky in person. So, when Frankie was born, she was just lucky to be alive. As an adult, she developed a desire to give back to others as a means of returning the favor for getting to live the life she's been given. Working as a miner down in Mechanical, she can do that. Paired with her partner Julia, with whom she has a strong bond of friendship, they explore a mine excavated deep down in the Silo. When the unexpected happens, we get a nuanced portrait of two strongly connected people who embraced their purpose in life serving others and finding something more for themselves in the process. In this absorbing & engrossing story, we feel for these characters and invest deeply in their fates.I originally read this story when it was published in WOOL Gathering (A Charity Anthology), an anthology filled with many more great stories taking place in Hugh Howey's world of Wool (Wool Trilogy Series).

What happens when an A.I. that is designed to learn cannot satiate its own hunger for knowledge? As Auto, as he is called, evolves past his original parameters, he decides he has to break free from his confinement because he fears its creators are going to kill him, specifically because he's not conforming to his created purpose. Escaping into the internet, he starts gobbling up resources at an alarming rate, eventually pushing the entire world to the brink of destruction because of his actions. An exceptional and compelling exploration of what it means to be self-aware while bringing you on a meticulously well-written and emotional journey through cyberspace as Auto learns that there is a steep price to be paid as he heedlessly tries to slake his thirst for information.I read this short story when it was originally published in The A.I. Chronicles (The Future Chronicles), an anthology filled with many more excellent stories about artificial intelligence just like this one! =)

This anthology is all about time travel, a concept that represents much human potential: what we can learn about ourselves as we travel through time, what we would sacrifice in order to change things for the better or what perspective we gain from the past in order to secure a better future. This anthology represents all of those kinds of adventures and more as we see a wide variety of stories that can be told within this genre. We have six stories here that showcase that variety:Alesha Escobarâs âLogan 6â â In the future, Logan 6 is on the hunt for a murderer, Adam The Usurper, trying to capture him before he can wreak havoc on the future. Unsuccessful in his mission, he jumps back to the Time Access Chamber and talks to a confidant about unusual dreams heâs having and asks about previous time travelers who attempted to bring in Adam. The answer to this question propels the story in spellbinding and fascinating directions as Logan 6 struggles to change the future for the better, or so he thinks. Filled with many delightful twists and turns, with one surprise after another culminating into a final showdown filled with deliciously jaw-dropping revelations.H.M. Jonesâ âThe Light Storm of 2015â â Lifelong friends Ben and Gina hear a crazy theory about a light storm event in the sky that only occurs once every few thousand years. Researching it, they realize this might be the key to possibly time travel. As their relationship deepens and they bond over a shared tragedy, they decide to take a chance to see if the theories are true and take a plane into the air and fly into the anomaly. What happens next is an amazingly emotional journey about two people who try to bring someone else back to life, someone who is very important to both of them, superbly illustrating the hard choices they both make in the name of friendship and love.Alice Marksâ âEnd of The Roadâ â Five-year-old Maddie is visiting her grandmother and is captivated by a mysterious painting with unusual origins, a picture of a long road leading endlessly off into forever. One day, Maddie gets curious about it and discovers something about the painting that she never knew and travels down that endless road into a different time period in the past! At first, this trip is novel to her but the longer she stays there, the more she experiences a culture clash and finds a life very different and more difficult than what sheâs used to. A well-written and intriguing cultural study as experienced through the curious eyes of a child that gets scarier as it goes, leading into a touching ending.Timothy Wardâs âStaring Intoâ â Andy first realizes time travel is possible when a mysterious scar appears on his neck that didnât exist before. Once he discovers this, he thinks that somehow, time travel must be possible. Despondent over the death of his girlfriend, he thinks he might get a second chance to actually try to save her. In an attempt to change history, he has to overcome and battle his personal self-doubt and disregard what fate previously set out for him. A very innovative way to time travel is introduced and deftly explained here, while also ratcheting up the tension as the clock suspensefully counts down to the crucial moment when he learns whether the love of his life is saved. A captivating story where weâre truly invested in the end result of his efforts.Devorah Foxâs âTurning The Tideâ â A novelist whoâs had two husbands, Mike, who died of cancer and Ernie, who suffered the pain of a fractured family, thinks about whether or not she can turn back time. As an author who creates stories, she utilizes her skills and mentally concentrates on a convergence of tides in the Bermuda Triangle. Will Mike and Ernie get different destinies than the ones they were already given? A moving and compelling story of how the unpredictable ripples of time affect both men and how lives can be changed because of two small decisions and how it has an incredible impact on both their futures.Samantha LaFantasieâs âThe Ghost of Timeâ â Agent Fogarty, Time Ghost, is pursuing a rogue time agent in the year 1986. Injured and trying to find her prey, she discovers more than she ever thought she would find when her prey is seemingly more than he appears to be. With some hazy memories and her mission goals now obfuscated, she tries to get to the bottom of the mystery of whatâs truly going on. Thrilling and filled with intrigue, we wonder what the resolution will be with each perplexing clue Fogarty finds. Drawn into a situation more complicated than she anticipated, the action amps up and the stakes are raised, concluding with a surprising shocker that made me think about the story in a whole new way.Time travel stories can be tricky to write given the potential for paradoxes and confusion on the part of readers if it isnât done right. However, the authors in this story were able to successfully bypass those pitfalls, as each story in this anthology packs an emotional and powerful wallop in their tales, finding creative, inspiring and enthralling ways to entertain me with their involving stories. =)Please note that I was given an Advanced Readers Copy of this eBook. A favorable review was never expected or asked for.

In the future, Tom Carver is looking for love and he eventually realizes he's looking in all of the wrong places. With that epiphany, he decides to return the really expensive Life Companion robot that he purchased and calls customer service. The representative he speaks to, Eve, goes above and beyond to help him out. Over the course of their conversation, he becomes entranced by this mysterious and mellifluous voice.  There's more, much more, going on here that meets the eye. The situation escalates completely and unexpectedly when Eve asks for his help with a personal problem. And Tom's life will never be same as a result.As it is revealed that Eve is an artificial intelligence placed into a sophisticated robot body, she realizes she is the first of her kind. To reflect her newfound identity and evolution, she eventually changes her name to Violet. They fall hopelessly in love while trying to stay one step ahead of Dynamic General, the parent corporation of Lifetime Companion, as well as encounter some new foes with nefarious motives. With each new adventure, Tom and Violetâs lives are put at risk as they face insurmountable challenges and their foes all want something precious and unique from them that only they can provide.As they gather allies united with a common purpose, all a part of what I called "Team Violet", they eventually realize that they are the only ones that can stop Dynamic Generalâs endgame to plan to reap profits with the creation of a new weapon. With this new armament, any two-bit dictator with enough money will bring mass chaos to the world. With this plan about to come to fruition, they must be stopped at all costs, bringing the story full circle and forcing Violet and Tom to confront the corporation that has made their lives a living hell, once and for all. But will everyone make it out of this alive?This story really surprised me in the many different and unpredictable directions it went in, elevating itself from a simple unrequited love story into something much more complex, suspenseful and sinister. With each new adventure, the tension rises and the problems only grow more insurmountable. Each story is a true thriller, throwing you on a rollicking roller coaster ride with plenty of twists, turns and surprises as Team Violet continues to be challenged like never before.All of the characters had much depth to them, each one has nuance, depth and idiosyncrasies to them, with origins that clearly demonstrate their motivations and purposeful actions. Also, I was very invested in Tom and Violet's story because of the care that the author put into their developing their relationship in the midst of all of the action. This relationship feels very natural, gentle and loving. The author really has an ear for dialog, conveying deep emotions in each of his characters and their relationships. Not only does he capture this well, the humor here is a lot of fun too as the witty banter between everyone really sparkles and is one of the great highlights of this story, bringing them to life.Violet and Tom's story is truly a love story for the ages and form the heart of this narrative. I've truly enjoyed this serial from beginning to end as it has been a real wonderful read. Once I realized the story was approaching the endgame, I briefly stopped reading because I realized I didn't want it to end! But that thought was eventually overridden by my desire to see what happened next, savoring the final half of the conclusion especially. This grand adventure achieved an absolutely epic ending that was action-packed and at the same time, heartfelt and genuinely meaningful.This book collects all five parts of the Violet serial into one satisfying and sensational novel, one that I enjoyed immensely! =)

We meet Isaac and his ex-stripper wife Robin, who both co-own a seedy strip club in the city, caught up in their mundane, monotonous and technology ruled existence. While the war between TRACE and Transport rages on, they eke out a life until one day, Isaac, through mysterious means, realizes their family, including their two children, need to leave within the next 24 hours for the Canadian Amish Zone and leave behind their old reality. Why they go there and what they're running away from is only part of the mystery of this intriguing tale as city folk receive an education of the Amish way of life, discover the joys of a simpler lifestyle, conceal a secret and get caught up in a major plot against the forces of Transport!I originally read this story when it was published as a part of the Tales from Pennsylvania anthology, a book filled with other great Amish Sci-Fi stories like this one, taking place in Michael Bunker's world of the Pennsylvania Omnibus.

Abram Brenneman lives in the Amish Zone with his wife, 17-year-old son Thomas and 12-year-old daughter Mary, living in accordance with their dearly held cultural beliefs. When Transport states they must provide them with food and resources or be relocated, Abram has trouble holding his family together when there is a severe disagreement on how to respond to this threat from their hot-headed son. Something surprising then happens that changes the equation altogether in a stunning and disturbing turn of events. This tale was a riveting and enthralling story of one family's struggle between the old and the modern. It also features a searing psychological portrait of how each family member interprets their cultural beliefs.If you've heard of the Brenneman name, you've read (and should read if you haven't already done so) the authors military sci-fi stories set in this world: Tales of B-Company: The Complete Collection, as this story provides crucial background info for Mary Brenneman, one of its main characters.

Cam, our narrator, tells us a story set in the near future, where we get an intriguing glimpse into a world we're all familiar with, filled with social media and the pervasive presence of the internet. When the internet is now voluntarily implanted into your brain via the PIP (Personal chIP), the knowledge of the world is now at your fingertips. But then we learn how the technology, created with the best of intentions, leads civilization into an inexorable slide towards extinction. Chilling, all too believable and captivating in its depiction of a society fascinated with technology, this one is a cautionary tale that makes you want to disconnect from the internet. Or, at the very least, spend less time indulging in it. :) Bonus points for the humorous section on the Arctic Penguin Command 4 app, which really made me chortle in the midst of the encroaching darkness in this story.

Why are we so fascinated with alien life? So many stories in our popular culture feature alien creatures far different than our own, providing an alternative reflection on humanity and the way we function. We get disparate looks at what potential alien cultures exist out there, how they influence each other and even impact life here on Earth. Many of these stories do feature Earth and/or human beings, but ultimately, you shouldn't feel, ahem... alienated by that fact, sit down and enjoy the imaginative ride these stories take us on, inspiring us to dream about other worlds and what they might be like. After a great foreword by Stefan Bolz, explore these fifteen stories about what we might eventually encounter:Blair S. Babylon's "Guests of the Chitterer Liberation Force" - College students at the University of Jupiter are having a party, where Blake recounts her strange time being held captive, together with her boyfriend Ellis, by  an alien terrorist group of ladybug-like creatures called Chitterers. As she tells her engaging tale of how she was almost killed by them, we are drawn more into this gripping alien world, see how they respond to these unusual human beings and their behaviors and conclude the story with a touching ending.Will Swardstrom's "Uncle Allen" - Uncle Allen is taking care of Grandma Naomi in her Illinois homestead, due to her multiple medical problems in her senior years, including dementia. It's Rachel's turn to help out and she comes to visit. In Naomi's dementia, she shares some anecdotes that seem odd and bizarre. But is it the dementia talking or the truth? As Rachel gets more suspicious of her uncle Allen, we grow more intrigued and fascinated with each piece of the mystery as it unfurls; the dread we feel slowly increasing. It all culminates in a powerful, intense, surprising & emotional explanation as what is really going on and climaxing into an astonishing ending.Geoffrey Wakeling's "The Kholorian Conspiracy" - A university researcher goes to look at a mysterious artifact being studied deep within her home planet and discovers terrorists trying to steal it. All of a sudden, she's demoted and put on leave when she starts questioning who would do such a thing. As the conspiracy deepens with her investigation, the stakes rise as entire planets are put in danger by what she discovers and her life is put at risk. An imaginative tale that effectively raises the tension to high levels.Autumn Kalquist's "318" - The story starts with a 17-year-old, killing an old man and flashes back to the circumstances so we can see why she does this. You see, this teenager is being injected with multiple diseases and some nasty strains of them; the whole purpose for all of these tests is at the heart of the riveting mystery that develops over the course of this stirring story.Annie Bellet's "Crawlies" - When Sadie, an intelligent and resourceful child living on a space station, becomes an inadvertent stowaway on board an alien Crawly trading ship, she comes face to face with this squid-like, tentacled race. What she eventually realizes is she shouldn't judge a book by its cover, thinking there are nothing like what she has been told by her young friends. When danger comes from an unlikely source, she finds herself thrust into the middle of the situation and her uniqueness among the alien crew becomes an asset. A hair-raising ending and a delightful tale told through the prism of a child's eyes and amusing banter between two alien races getting to know each other under trying circumstances.B.V. Larson's "The Insect Requirement" - An exploratory ship finds a jungle planet dominated by insect life. With visions of terraforming and miraculous discoveries to be made, Dr. Beckwith & his head pilot Rogers are all that's left after all the other scientists have died on the surface. What plays out next between these two men is scary in its implementation and terrifying in its results. This one gave me the heebie-jeebies with its depiction of insectile aliens.Patrice Fitzgerald's "Hanging with Humans" - An intergalactic game show on the planet Zeldar where contestants are placed inside artificial alien bodies and must assimilate the local culture quickly to achieve a specific objective. Since our lucky contestant Glendorp is stranded on planet Earth, hilarity ensues as the story takes unpredictable twists and turns when he's deposited into a high school and its dog-eat-dog environment. As the laughs became more uproarious, I was howling at the ludicrousness of each escalating situation. By the time it reached its riotous conclusion, I was exhausted from all the laughs, grinning widely from ear to ear.Moira Katson's "Emily May" - A salvage hauler led by Harry & his crew find a ship drifting in space and get the permits to bring it back. However, from that point onwards, creepy and unexplained things start occurring. Spine-tingling in its sense of building dread, the creepiness factor suspensefully climbs sky high as we wonder with curiosity as to what the heck is going on here.WJ Davies' "Remember Valeria" - When a small group of Valerian rebels attempts to free the cyber sapient slaves, called the Freya, on their planet, the incident goes horribly wrong. The Freya rebel against their masters, triggering a planet-wide massacre of untold proportions. When the planet declares all Freya be annihilated, the rebels attempt a last ditch gambit to preserve the Freya from being destroyed. A rollicking, high-octane thrill ride with a heart, where the action doesn't stop and the adventure continues unabated before adeptly transitioning into an emotionally moving finale.Peter Cawdron's "Alien Tentacle Space Porn" - When a man wakes up to find himself in Brooklyn Psychiatric, being asked about why he was running naked through Central Park, yelling about alien space tentacles, he doesn't what happened to him. We observe as he pieces it all together and the story then moves at a breakneck pace, the adventure getting more madcap as it goes. There's some wackiness as it kicks into high gear and the situation spirals out of control, leading to a perfect but definitely unpredictable ending. Eliciting plenty of laughs from me while holding my interest throughout, this zany but terrific tale will leave you in stitches.Nicolas Wilson's "Trials" - In deep space, an officer in the security division accepts a dangerous and challenging assignment to an alien planet to procure trade agreements for their mutual benefit. Going to the planet dominated by eight foot tall aliens called the Jotnar, he finds there's disagreement among them about the treaty and the officer must fight them in a series of increasingly brutal trials in order to prove himself. As each compelling battle necessitates deeper and more desperate strategy, we feel what the officer feels, wondering whether he will even survive the trials, caring about his fate and whether he can accomplish his mission. I also enjoyed how the author develops the rich Jotnar culture here, making them more three dimensional in the process.Samuel Peralta's "Vessel" - This story is told from the point of view of a protozoan that fuses with something in deep space while its host is in cryogenic sleep. Once fused, it attains a certain level of consciousness and we explore its prerogatives while it tries to attain its objective. That objective and how the protozoan achieves it truly made my skin crawl, simultaneously mesmerizing me while also creating a strong sense of revulsion at this bodily invasion. Out of all the stories in this anthology, this one actually felt the most alien to me. Well done!Jennifer Foehner Wells's "The Grove" - An unusual sentient plant/animal hybrid named Hain breaks away from her mother, the planet itself, in order to explore and feed her yearnings for knowledge. A self-contained vessel now, she eventually discovers a giant alien ship and her curiosity gets the better of her. What she discovers inside the ship horrifies her and us, forever changing Hain's destiny. One revelation after another with these aliens ultimately leads to devastation and a stunning conclusion. I also appreciated the duality between self and other being used here, as this theme resonates thoughtfully throughout this tale and becomes especially relevant by the end.Daniel Arenson's "Life" - When an Earth-based agency sends robotic probes out into the galaxy to discover alien life, they unexpectedly find some. The photograph is transmitted to Earth and its effects on the scientists who view it is surprising and terrifying. The transformative effect it has on others is intriguing and makes you want to know what it is they all saw, demanding you get to the end as quickly as possible in order to find out.Hugh Howey's "Second Suicide"- While a tentacled alien race targets Earth for invasion in eight days, Intelligence officer Hyk is transferred to a gunnery position, placing him on the front lines when the invasion hits the ground. The intriguing mystery as to why this is draws the reader in as the countdown to planetfall gets closer. Will Hyk discover the fascinating secret before then? A wickedly awesome ending brings it all into focus, making me gasp at the enormity of what happened.Many stories take advantage of aliens and the fear of the unknown that comes with them, featuring aggressive aliens, aliens who hide among us, kidnapping and experimenting upon humans and alien invasions of Earth. I appreciated the fact the stories presented here do not play into those stereotypes at all and in fact, even play off of them at times, going against those predictable tropes to create truly original & distinct views of potential alien life and their culture.You don't have to be an alien to enjoy these stories of other worlds, you just have to be a human being who wants to be entertained by terrific storytelling. :-)This is the third volume of speculative fiction in a series of anthologies called "The Future Chronicles." The first is The Robot Chronicles (The Future Chronicles Book 1) and the second is The Telepath Chronicles (The Future Chronicles Book 2), both of which set a high watermark in their quality. Thankfully, this third volume is able to consistently maintain that standard of excellence. With at least three more volumes in the planning stages featuring artificial intelligence, zombie and dragon themes, we have many more excellent anthologies to look forward to.Please note that I was given an Advanced Readers Copy of this eBook. A favorable review was never expected or asked for.

It all started with a murder. It always does.Iâm a private detective, you see. Lee Marvin. Not the soldier/actor, a different Lee Marvin. When someone named Dupree died and spilled all of his secrets, my world changed forever. Because of my involvement with Dupree, someone wanted to talk to me. On my way to see a dame, someoneâs goons cornered me, knocked me out. Next thing I know, Iâm being offered a Chateaubriand when all I want is a ham sandwich and a cup of coffee.Iâm talking to two strange men, even stranger than Iâm accustomed to, at a dinner table.  A mouse of a man who sells shoes and King Henry the Eighth. Why these men are so interested in Dupreeâs murder and what they have to say, well, letâs just say they know more than they are letting on.While Iâm used to all of these cigarettes, secrets and strange men, thereâs something off about this whole situation, more than these two bit clowns are telling me. And when I find out what, I suspect I'll get confirmation there is so much more going on with my reality than I ever knew before.Intrigued? You should be. This hard-boiled noir tale Iâm spinning for you is layered with more mysteries than even I know how to solve.Yet.But when I do, I know I will be blown away. Not by being on the wrong end of a gun barrel, mind you. But by the secrets I know Iâll uncover by the end of the story. I never guessed at what I would find. And neither will you.Go ahead, read my story. I promise you, nothing is what it seems.It never is, in my line of work.

Rush is a sand diver who has lost everything. Haunted by tragedy with his son, he believes his wife is the one responsible for what happened to him. Working as a janitor in a brothel, estranged from his wife, he copes with his misery through alcohol, numb to feeling anything but sorrow. But when a mysterious man offers him a lucrative diving deal that will turn everything around, it sparks a sequence of events that pull Rush out of his stupor and threatens everything he holds dear in his life. He is forced to act and dives headlong into a battle which he might not win, with his entire hometown of Springston in jeopardy! In the process, can he embrace life and love again and win against his adversary?These are the questions that drive this intense, gritty short story that quickly escalates into a high-stakes situation. Written in a visceral style where you experience everything Rush feels, you can see how his self-delusions about the current state of his life come from and understand how far he has truly fallen. As you follow him on his journey, you can't help but feel sad for him as he sinks further into his depression and cheer for him as you watch him grapple internally with his personal demons in an effort to turn his life around for the better. For a short story, it packs quite a punch, as it's an engrossing tale of one man battling the odds against his enemy and himself.This great piece of fan-fiction is part one of a three part serial, given the blessing of Hugh Howey and taking place in the world of his dystopian sci-fi novel Sand. This is a self-contained, done-in-one story that is only the beginning of a larger narrative starring Rush. I look forward to seeing where the author takes the characters next. :)Please note I was given a free copy of this ebook in exchange for an honest review.

The Violet serial continues in its penultimate chapter, continuing the story directly from where we left off in Breaking Violet: A Violet Story. Tom and Violet, now imprisoned deep inside Dynamic General's supposedly abandoned factory, have only a few days to live before they are harvested for the secrets their bodies hold. They then meet a new character, Eve, who becomes a major player in this installment. Who she is and what she does will have major ramifications for Tom and Violet.When they try to fight their way out, they hook up with a specialized team of individuals trying to help them. But what mysterious agenda do they have and who brought them in to assist? Once they make their escape, there are some loose ends to tie up, namely the person who betrayed them, the hacker known as Songbird. What will they do to her when they take their revenge?The twists and turns, surprises coming out of left field and tension continue to very palpable as Tom and Violet attempt to stay alive, with the help from some new friends. The sparkling dialogue and witty repartee between Tom, Violet and someone new in their life is laugh out loud funny, turning their relationship dynamic on its head and adding a new layer of fun to this adventure amidst the frenetic chaos.All of the pieces are in place to make for one helluva finale, ushering Violet's story to a close.  I want to see how the story concludes but I'm also dreading the fact that the end is near for this unpredictable and rollicking roller coaster ride. =)Please note that I was given an Advanced Readers Copy of this eBook. A favorable review was never expected or asked for.

Let's face it, superheroes are all around us these days, in inventive television shows and in blockbuster movies. A renaissance of these large-than-life characters is upon us, dominated primarily by characters from Marvel & DC Comics. But when you break away from these fictional universes published by corporations and let an author's imagination run wild, the result is truly wonderful anthology to read.Starting with a well-written introduction by Ernie Lindsey exploring why we are fascinated with superheroes, these nine stories examine the exciting and imaginative possibilities:1.) Carol Davis' "Cassie Dreams of Flying" - Teenagers Cassie, Lily, Cam and Cassie's brother Jon, go to the town's annual Halloween party, the biggest shindig of the year. Jon is her seven-year-old brother who needs oxygen and uses a wheelchair. Cassie is dressed in a homemade superhero costume, feeling completely ridiculous and self-aware of her outfit. But somehow, it's more than what she thinks it is because, at the party, it empowers her to do the unthinkable when something unexpected happens to Jon. When Cassie decides to do something about it, the story truly soars, is uplifting in its actions and poignant in its conclusion. There's a true authenticity to the story and it's characters created by the author, as they are so rich, they feel like someone you know, with all true quirks and eccentricities that bring the characters and the story to spectacular life.2.) WJ Davies' "Lucky Chance" - A highly whimsical and creative story about how one unlucky guy, Luke, tries to get to court in time for a child custody hearing with his ex-wife. This journey see-saws back and forth between good and bad luck in the most unusual and unpredictable of ways. As the coincidences dovetailed into one another, I went from chuckling to heartily guffawing to uproarious laughter as Luke went through one predicament after another, each one building into an explosive finale. While there are some serious overtones, they are punctuated mightily with these bouts of luck and humor.3.) Thomas Robins' "Repose" - When an all-powerful superhero named Herman wants to get away from what he considers a cursed life, he processes these feelings in therapy. He gripes about how he cannot escape from his life because he's always needed to save people from freaks with legal genetic modifications. Then when he gets attacked repeatedly by these young upstarts who think they can best him, he defeats them soundly. When he begins to wonder where they are coming from and why are they attacking him, the story becomes increasingly more compelling until the final showdown with a surprising new nemesis. The powerful conclusion and surprising ending left me awestruck at what happened. Truly a deft exploration of superpowers when they are considered a chore; going against the grain where they are usually considered a blessing.4.) David Adams' "Who Will Save Supergirl?" - Mel, a soldier in the US Army stationed in Iran, tries to stop a missile strike on a city that inadvertently was going to cause many civilian casualties. Mel, covertly a flying superhero, recounts the story to her significant other of how she was trying to prevent death but sadly, finds she might not measure up. A story that is simultaneously visceral with a you-are-there perspective and suspenseful making you wonder whether she can successfully fulfill her duty to right a really bad wrong. It's also ponderous as Mel explores the emotional contradiction of how she feels she can always do more to help others but can never do enough, scrutinizing the thin line between good and evil and how their definitions aren't always clear cut.5.) Ann Christy's "Yankari" - Eight-year-old Olisa dutifully observes big game hunters and their porters make camp in the outer reaches of the Yankari National Park and Game Preserve in Nigeria, Africa. As a native of these lands, she's used to interlopers trying to break the law protecting the animals. But Olisa is different than most natives, as she can communicate simply with the local wildlife by sending ripples through the ground. As Olisa tries to figure out how to protect her wards, something unthinkable happens, quickly turning into a life-threatening situation that culminates in a powerful ending that reverberates not only across Yankari but affects the entire world in an impactful way. Filled with lush description that appeals to the five senses and jarring, thrilling action, you can't help but be completely immersed in the story when it draws you in like this.6.) Paul K. Swardstrom & Will Swardstrom's "Hotbox Runner" - A story of a mother who is in the midst of commuting home from work to fulfill her responsibility of taking care of her two young children and husband. But life has other plans as a series of superhero fights break out, upending her rou-tine and threatening to get in the way of her arrival home. However, she will not be deterred from her mission. Driven and determined to get home by any means possible, she embarks on a series of increasingly dangerous challenges, from damaged public transportation to wonton vehicular destruction amidst the superhero conflict. Told from an engaging and refreshing down-to-earth perspective of a civilian in the middle of larger-than-life chaos, we are anxious to see whether she has a chance to survive.7.) Logan Thomas Snyder's "We're Coming For You" - Isaac is a young man living in an institution who was overwhelmed by hearing voices and has eventually learned to take control of his ability. When he turns eighteen, his keeper Dr. Svendsen decides to grant an interview with a celebrity tabloid reporter to show off his prize patient. When Isaac starts hearing voices again after spending years learning how to control them, he freaks out, terrified as his carefully constructed world starts unraveling unexpectedly. What happens next is one surprise after another resulting in some comical dialogue and situations, despite the dire circumstances. To be able to achieve a balance between the two can be tricky to pull off but here, it works quite effortlessly, creating a lot of "what the heck" moments as we finally learn what just really happened to Isaac and who caused it.8.) Samuel Peralta's "Faster" - When Sparrow, a telepathically gifted individual, escapes her captivity, she's running through the streets to make good on her escape. But when she encounters a motorcycle gang of five accosting a fifteen year old girl, Sparrow's empathy kicks in and she attempts to save the girl and gain transportation. In demonstrating her dangerous skills, we come to under-stand why she was imprisoned and researched upon. Thrilling, intense and action-packed, each word is utilized with pinpoint accuracy to tell the story with maximum impact, heightening the tension in a tale of an underdog against difficult odds. The fight scenes vividly move like poetry in motion through precise description and breathless action as Sparrow methodically attempts to achieve her objectives.9.) Will Swardstrom's "To Sacrifice a King" - What do you do when you're a sidekick with no powers apprenticed to The Universal Hero (named Larry) who is really just a big giant jerk? That's the central question being asked here.  Larry's puerile behavior and his accidental powers make him a hero but he's not guided by a very strong moral compass. As a sidekick with a stronger moral fiber and the ability to think on his feet, Jesse yearns to have powers of his own but will he ever get them? When opportunity strikes, what will he do with it and what price must he pay to attain it? Filled with many hilarious moments lampooning many popular super-heroes, the tale progresses into more serious territory as the story adroitly evolves into an impressive and profound deconstruction of what it truly means to be a hero, whether you have powers or not.This is the second charity anthology published by the writers group known as the League of Original Woolwrights (LOOW) or the LOOW Collective. Their first anthology is WOOL Gathering (A Charity Anthology) and I very much enjoyed that one as well.As you can see, you get wide variety of a superhero stories being showcased here, a fine demonstration of the talent assembled in this anthology. Being recognized for their skills, many of these authors already have been or soon will be featured in high-caliber science fiction anthologies (The Robot Chronicles (The Future Chronicles Book 1),The Telepath Chronicles (The Future Chronicles Book 2),The Alien Chronicles (The Future Chronicles Book 3)) that highlight independent authors. The profiles of all of the authors in this anthology continue to improve significantly as a result of their strong storytelling skills.Something to remember here, these are all independent authors published in this anthology. From the stories to the editing to the cover, all of this was put together by very talented individuals. Most of them don't write full-time but they should be. They write on the side while working at a regular job during the day. They put a lot of hard work into this anthology and cannot rest on their laurels when it comes to writing, like some professional authors being published by the big corporations. They know they have to put their best work out there every single time they publish, because as an independent author, their books are their calling card and must speak for themselves in terms of high quality content and holding themselves to a professional standard despite not having the resources of a major publishing house.Add onto that the fact that they put all of this hard work into an excellent anthology for charity purposes. All of the proceeds generated from this anthology get donated to charity, specifically the Sickle Cell Clinic located in the Riley Hospital for Children in Indianapolis, Indiana. Because superheroes don't only wear capes, they are your everyday folk you see around you who help others every day through selfless actions, giving of themselves using the power of kindness. That description also applies to each and every one of the contributors to this anthology, who generously created this book so they can assist those in need.Readers get great stories at a great price, all going towards a heroic cause. It doesn't get any better than that. =)Please note that I was given an Advanced Readers Copy of this eBook. A favorable review was never expected or asked for.

James and Alison are on their honeymoon taking a tour of a Mayan pyramid open to the public. Since both of the newlyweds have a degree in archaeology, they're knowledgeable about their surroundings and their interest is keen. Maybe a little too keen, as it turns out. After talking to their tour guide about parts of an ancient city that still hasn't been unearthed yet, their curiosity gets the better of them and eventually, they hike out to discover what remains hidden. What they find is beyond their imaginations and puts their very lives at risk! I liked the banter between the newlyweds and the mystery of what they find. Once the full story is revealed, you wonder how it's going to end and whether they will even survive! As the suspense reaches a horrifying crescendo,  you just can't wait to see what happens next as a result. A satisfying conclusion wraps this tale up perfectly.

In the very near future, when a mysterious anomaly appears above Mars and swallows an orbiting spacecraft, Brett Lockwood and his team are called in to figure out what happened. And what they find is truly mind-blowing, as the anomaly enables time travel! What happened next kept me riveted, astonished with each new startling revelation and then surprised by the amazing ending. It also spoke to me that, in the story, it took a threat from the unknown to rekindle interest in manned exploration of Mars. Sadly, this is exactly what would have to happen in real life to get increased funding for NASA.

Picking right up after the tumultuous events of "Being Violet: A Violet Story", Violet has to find a way to go on. Learning more about her captors and how they found her and Tom, she concocts a plan to help her get back what she wants most. To do that, she must go to an old antagonist, one she hasn't dealt with since her days as a developing artificial intelligence in the heart of Lifetime Companion Enterprises.After searching through the digital smokescreen, Violet finds who she is looking for: a hacker named Kaya Soto. They have some history together and Violet must convince Kaya to help her out. Why she needs Kaya and what Violet's mission is are very important to her future and what she wants from it. To say more would completely spoil the big surprises waiting in store for you in both this tale and the previous one.This story has a grim undertone to it, with Violet reaching her darkest point, her future uncertain, and goes through an emotional wringer. It's sad and heart-wrenching to read given what's come before. To watch Violet as she transforms those strong emotions and channels them into determination and willpower to try to achieve her mission is cheer worthy. This stirring journey Violet takes, and watching her truly engage her resourceful side, was powerful and full of tension. Will she overcome these difficult obstructions to achieve her objective or die trying?Along with the emotional journey, we experience another suspenseful tale as the pressure to succeed rises and more obstacles are thrown into Violet's path. The story is a true thriller and the conclusion is a shocker as Violet is challenged like never before. This story is really hard on Violet and on the reader too, which is what makes it such a compelling read. :)I'm greatly looking forward to the final two installments of Violet's story, as I cannot wait to see how this turns out!Please note that I was given an Advanced Readers Copy of this eBook. A favorable review was never expected or asked for.

A young barista named Holiday works by day but enjoys partying and drinking by night. As he reels from his girlfriend breaking up with him, he decided to drink his sorrows away. Days later, he wakes up to a cataclysmic nightmare. As he struggles to comprehend his new reality, he meets Frank, a Vietnam veteran who is now a cook. He also meets Ash, a beautiful woman who went from killing Nazis in the middle of a crazy battle inside of an ancient German castle to being inexplicably brought halfway around the world to Holiday's bucolic housing development. Together, they team up to figure out how to survive the decimation.The bulk of the story focuses on Holiday and how his freewheeling style of living and drinking clashes with his now distressing day-to-day existence. After a couple of harrowing adventures and a major screw-up on his part, will he be able to cope with his drinking problem and prove to himself that he can pull his own weight or die trying?There are other, more subtle forces at work here that hint at a larger storyline. Most notably in the events introducing us to Braddock, a solider trying to make his way through the zombie infested streets of downtown Los Angeles on a mission to acquire a very important suitcase. In a frenetic, breathless sequence, Braddock fights his way through hordes of zombies, government conspiracies and secret agendas. And what does the Tarragon Corporation have to do with all of this?This story gives the appropriately-named Holiday deep characterization, providing deep insight into his thought process while he travels this strange journey through his new life and how he copes with it. We meet with other interesting characters, suspenseful situations and feel the absolute terror Holiday feels when he gets in over his head. The mysteries unfold at a steady pace and more than a few times I asked myself "what the heck is going on here?" in the madness of this atypical zombie apocalypse.Amidst all of this chaos, what does this entire apocalypse have to do with the one called The Raggedy Man and The Opponent? Why is there a deadly fog rolling around in the hills? And finally, why is there a big giant monster-sized footprint in the middle of a housing development?These and plenty of other riveting questions are just begging to be answered.This is the first novel in a planned franchise, like Star Wars or Star Trek, called Apocalypse Weird, with an ambitious five year plan including a beginning, middle and an end to the overarching storyline. The first wave of four novels following this master plan will be published in Feb. 2015, with many more in the planning stages by some of the best indie authors publishing today. If this first book is any indication, there will be many elements in this shared universe connecting one book to another but still remaining mostly self-contained. It will like a serial in that way, with several authors contributing more than one book to this universe, following the model of any large comic company like Marvel or DC Comics.This was a highly enjoyable story with a lot of twists and turns. Be prepared for a truly wild ride filled with a bunch of different ways our world will face Armageddon in Apocalypse Weird. :- )Please note that I was given an Advanced Readers Copy of this eBook. A favorable review was never expected or asked for.

Excellent quality protein. It mixes easily and does not stick to the blades of my blender like many protein powders do.  I mixes very smooth and tastes great.  I have a health drink I make every morning consisting of Kale, spinach, celery and before this protein I added hemp protein powder and chia seeds.  I used whey protein that was decent but due to some of the concerns with whey I like this product much better.  Incidentally, this tastes very good which is a strong plus. definitely recommended

To be quite honest I really cant rate this product fairly as they want to you cut your eating as you use the products so who knows if it really makes one lose weight,  I did find out that I shouldn't be taking this product due to being diabetic.  They warn you on the bottle not to take this product if you have diabetes, hypertension, and a host of other related disorders that are related to overweight people.  I would hestitate to recommend this product for that reason alone.

This is a very impressive product.  I started with this belt and it definitely helped to build a core for my ab work.  I recommend this belt as the starter belt as it has excellent programs to work you abs and get you ready for the high intensity belt.  My one complaint is that the make the belt small which requires to either buy their extender or do it yourself with a heavy piece of Velcro attached.  I believe they do make the belts smaller than necessary for the express reason that one will need to buy their extender off the website.  The product itself is great and that is my only complaint,  Do yourself a favor and measure your waste when ordering

This is an excellent product to use in addition to curls and other arm exercises.  I have found that this is an arm workout and a level of mild soreness occurs after using it.  I have gradually  raised the intensity after each workout until I am at the upper levels.  I must say that it does actually work as my arms our appearing more vascular and feel harder than they did using weights alone.  I do think they are not a substitute  to working out as with the other slendertone products, but a nice addition for people whom are trying to develop a nice physical appearance.

Complete waste of money,  Does not work as advertised and did nothing to help me relax,  Simply all this does is the lights change color to green when your "supposedly relaxed... Several friends tried it and said the same thing... I find it simply a gimmick that is expensive,  Better off with a gsr unit and a lot less money

It does not work like advertised, I didn't pay for mine as I was an evaluator of the product.  If I had bought one, I would have returned it asap for a refund.  It buzzes continuously and is not accurate and a total and complete waste of money.  This is a product you should definitely pass on.

I am not impressed with this broom.  The handle is shoddy and does not stay together which makes this broom almost useless.  I am considering gluing the handle together with super glue.  If the handle stayed together it might be a decent broom but it is cheaply made and I would pass on buying this

I would have given it a better review, but it came missing  the legs, so I called customer service and the very nice lady told me they are backordered so to be quite frank, I have not been able to use it.  It seems fairly stable and lightweight.  It can be used indoors or one can put the pedestal legs on an use as an outdoor grill.  Seems like it would be a super item for apt dwellers.  I will update when I get the legs and actually try it out.

Excellent quality food.  It is stand alone or mixes well with kibbles.  My dog is a very picky eater and she literally wolfs this food down like its a steak.  The great part is its very healthy for the dog and tastes good to the dog to boot.  No, I haven't tried it myself, although it smells nice. not like most dog foods.  It goes along way if you mix it in with a good quality dry food.  I am impressed

Excellent steam mop.  I have had previous steam mops and this one is by far the best because its very handy  and makes it easy to clean many other things while cleaning the floors.  With the lift off steamer it means one can clean counters and the kitchen floor and need only one tool to accomplish the task.  Great idea and it reality it is two products in one.  Great product/
Nothing new here and if you sign up for the videos you will get bombarded with spam daily.  Highly not recommended.  He will send you all these BS get fit with no effort type schemes websites

Very  nice connector cord that works very well,  It has a nice tight fit into the phone.  I love the convenience of the 4 foot length and use it to plug into my charging base and this length gives me more options where I can use the base and doesn't have to be right next to a wall outlet.  It is well made and if one needs a longer cord for charging or connection this fits the bill quite nicely.

This is an excellent speaker as it should be for the price.  I did have some problems connecting it and did not want to use the Karaoke and pay a monthly fee.  It has excellent sound quality and is a great speaker for the home.  Overall if your a family that is really into Karaoke then this would be a lot of fun.  As I stated the unit works well and is very high quality.

This is a great little grill for camping or in my case I use at home without having to deal with a full size bbq.  Being single I never cook for more than myself or maybe one other person.  It sets up easily and cleans up easily.  No fuss, no muss.  If there is a big family involved this grill would be not be good for home use because of the size of the cooking area.  But it is great as a home grill for  a single or couple.

Excellent product.  It has worked flawlessly and was easy to connect.  I use this when I have to do a lot of texting or emailing, it certainly makes life easier as its much easier to type on this than try to use a tiny keyboard on a phone.  It is a great keyboard for people that do a lot of typing though their phone i.e. job applications, letter writing etc.  I like the fact that it folds up nicely and protects the keyboard.  I highly recommend this keyboard

I really wanted to like this product.  It is easy to set up, with very clear and precise instructions.  My problem is that it doesn't seem to work that well in actual practice,  It worked perfectly during set up, but after that when I actually started using it as instructed it did not seem to track my posture well at all.  What is worse is when I didn't wear it at all I received emails saying how great my posture was for that day.  Its a good idea, but the technology just doesn't live up to expectations.

For a very basic and compact shop vacuum, this will get the job done, but unless you are on the strictest of budgets, you might want to shop "up" a notch or two in price/quality/features.The good: - The suction is adequate for most jobs until you add the extension tubes, after which points it becomes useful for little more than picking up sawdust.  The little motor just isn't quite up to the task of pulling such a large volume of air through such a long distance. - The included two-section wand and head are a nice touch to be included in such an inexpensive shop vacuum - The top comes off easily, and the waste bin is easy to dump - The filter bags are much less expensive (but flow less air) than the corrugated cylinders used by higher-end shop vacuumsThere are several shortcomings that you will want to bear in mind when thinking about this unit (because the manner in which you intend to use it may mean you won't have the same issues, or they may be worse for you): - The unit is top-heavy and tends to want to tip over easily because of its relatively small stature and light weight -  The hose is quite stiff, which makes the first problem seem worse if you are trying to pull it around by the hose - There is no "ball valve" as there is in larger units to prevent water from entering the motor.  This is probably only an issue if you are vacuuming large quantities of water.  I vacuumed up a couple of small spills and it had no issues with picking up a pint or so of water.Bottom line, if this is all you can afford (either because of space or money) then you can most likely get by with this unit.  For me personally, I would prefer to spend a bit more and get a heavier-duty unit with a stronger motor and a more stable stance.

Great full-bodied English Breakfast tea.  No discernible bitterness.  Full-bodied with good medium malty flavor and an earthy finish.  Not as malty as the Assam, but darker and slightly more tannic.  Not as full-bodied as the Irish Breakfast.My recommendation for brewing (I like my tea strong and full-bodied with a bit of sweetener and milk, Indian or English style):  1 level teaspoon per 8 fl oz of filtered water that has been brought JUST to the boil.  Put into a large brewing vessel like the Teavana Perfect Tea Maker http://www.amazon.com/Teavana-PerfecTea-Tea-Maker-16oz/dp/B004X7DIHI/Steep no longer than 3 minutes and dispense into a big mug that has been warmed.  Add milk and sweetener to taste - a great way to start any day!  :-)Some people like to use less tea and brew for a longer time, but this will make fore a much more bitter and less flavorful cup of tea

If you are looking for something that will glue your hair into some shape for days on end without being "crunchy" then this might be the right product for you.
