As many people have mentioned in reviews (why didn't I read them first... oh, yea - it was only $8 for three tins!) this stuff is THICK and WAXY and hard to work with.  Most thick hair products you can thin out by either wetting your hands or by warming it by rubbing in your hands.  Neither approach works with this stuff.  You just have to take a pea sized glob and hope you can spread it out evenly.  Even getting a comb through your hair will be a challenge after you've put this stuff in it.An interesting product - you can achieve effects that you could not other wise do, but its not something I'm going to be using on a daily basis for my 2" long wavy/curly hair.

As entertaining as  Game of Thrones, but without the  gratuitous sex (which might make it better or worse depending on your preference).  I really appreciate the historical accuracy of the story telling (to the extent that the history is known).  They avoid all the trite stereotypes of "viking legends" which is really refreshing.While the storytelling is great and the action is very entertaining, the most compelling part of this show is the characters.  You'll grow to really care about them.

Cons:-Door is very hard to close (must be forced shut with a loud BANG).-There is no internal light when you open the door.  So if you're using it in a pantry or in a kitchen with lights out, you'll need a flashlight to see your foodPros-Defrost seems to work very well. I can defrost large pieces of fish without cooking the edges much better than any other microwave I've had in the past-Sensor reheat setting also works very well

Easy, and makes great coffee - very easy to program and flexible enough to make good strong coffee for people who want it.  Bottom line, any Keurig based maching is going to be very dependent upon two things - the quality of the K-cups you use and your ability to customize the brew strength and brew temp.  This machine has all the adjustability you need, so as long as you get good K-cups, you'll be happy.And a side note on the adjustability - I bought this as a Christmas gift for my 75-year old Mom who lives alone.  She LOVES how easy it is to use, and can even adjust the cup size settings on her own.  That is a good testament to how easy it is to use.  The only thing I have to remind her about is to change the little charcoal filter pod, but that is also incredibly easy to do and very fool-proof.A final bonus is that it also will dispense hot water for people like me that want to brew a cup of tea and not use K-cups (I have not had a K-cup tea that I thought was any good).  A quick push of the "rinse" button, then hit the "hot water" button for a pre-programmed amount of hot water.  Super easy and the perfect temp (I keep it set at 195º)

Nice looking.  Easy operation.  Yes, the beep is loud and annoying, but not so much that I want to tear the unit apart to block it.  My only complaint with this toaster is that it seems to use a lower temperature (like many newer toasters) in order to maintain a "cool touch" exterior.  The downside is that it tends to dry the toast or muffin/bagel out by the time it is browned.  Using a higher heat would allow the toast to brown without drying it out as much (as was the case with the much older toaster that this one replaced).The automatic "clamping" action (I think they call it "self centering") works well, but because of the design it will occasionally get stuck when a muffin or smaller piece of toast gets caught underneath the top edge.  When this happens its a bit like an elevator with something stuck in the door - it will go up, beep, then get stuck and go back down (without heat) then will try to come back up again, and then repeat the cycle until you get in there and push the button to shut it off, or until it clears itself.  The first time this happened, it was very confusing!The only other complaint I have is that my 40+ year old eyes cannot read the tiny lettering on the buttons without first putting on reading glasses.The reheat feature is nice - it gives you an easy way to quickly reheat a piece of toast without adding additional browning.

I wanted to love this sharpener.  I bought it for the boat, assuming it would be durable and handy to have for those quick touch-ups on the relatively inexpensive fillet knives we keep on board.  The boat is a fully enclosed pilot house boat used for saltwater fishing and spearfishing, and is slipped in California.  I put the Edgemaker on the boat, planning to use it on the next outing.About two weeks later, we were out on the water with fish and i pulled the Edgemaker Pro out of the drawer where I'd stashed it in order to touch up the fillet knife before getting started.  To my disappointment, the steel pins used for sharpening were covered in scaly rust and the carbide or diamond dust (or whatever is on there to create the rough surface for sharpening) was ruined.  I tried a few passes, hoping that the rust was just superficial, but unfortunately the Edgemaker was rendered useless.Note that the Edgemaker has NEVER been immersed or come in contact with the salt water.  It had merely been placed in a drawer on board a boat (inside the cabin) that was in the marina.So a caution to anyone planning to use this for saltwater fishing - make sure you oil the metal parts very well before exposing to the marine environment, and don't plan to leave it on the boat.

If you're looking for the absolute lightest weight and thinnest case you can find, the fit and finish of this case is superior to other similar ones I've tried.  The fit is great-  the phone snaps into place easily, and the case hugs the phone uniformly all the way around.  With this case installed, your 6 Plus will feel pretty much the same in hand (or in your pocket) as without the case.The downside is that this case provides almost no protection other than from scratching.  Also it lacks any sort of texture, so it is pretty slippery in the hand.For me personally, this case combined with a tempered glass screen protector gives me adequate protection while still keeping the svelte and pleasing aesthetic of the phone.  Prior to this case, I tried the Spigen "Armor" case and found it much too bulky.  I HATED the 6 Plus and regretted buying it over the regular iPhone 6 until I switched to this case.

Good quality connectors, works without a problem with the iPhone 6 Plus.  Downside is that the vinyl/plastic jacket feels thick, resulting in a cable that is not as flexible as the shorter OEM cable.  It does not coil easily as it is fairly stiff.  But if you're looking for a setup that will work well and it doesn't need to be as flexible as the factory Apple lightning cable, this is a good choice.

Perfect little device to travel with if you want to be able to have tunes in your hotel room but they only have a radio or TV with a mini-jack.  Also a perfect solution if you have an older Bose table top radio without Bluetooth.  With this little guy you can just create a bluetooth "hot spot" that is connected to the radio and then stream tunes from your iPad, iPhone, or Android/whatever bluetooth audio device.WIth an iPhone, iPad, and Macbook I found it very easy to pair and to initiate music streaming.  There are no buttons or settings on the device to fiddle with, which is great  The only problem is that because the device is so small, the cable connections tend to push it around a lot.  Also, if you want to travel with it, the power brick is pretty large (larger than the device itself).  A battery-powered version would probably be the ultimate device for travel.Bottom line, if you are looking for a super easy and relatively inexpensive way to Bluetooth-enable your expensive (but older) sound system, this device fits the bill!

A wonderful glance into the lives of a quirky family centered on the relationship between a father and his son.  The book is an entertaining read, and you'll gain a lot of insight into the world of autism and Aspergers (a mild form of autism that has a specific signature of symptoms including the ability to focus intensely and singularly on specific subjects and an inability to "relate" socially to other people the way most of us do.The book is in no way a clinical discourse on autism or Aspergers - instead it is a sort of "biography" that takes you through the lives of a father and son as they explore the world together through the lens of their Aspergers.  It is sometimes painful, sometimes hilarious, but always enjoyable to read.  Mr. Robison's writing style is very straightforward, but he keeps a good pace throughout the book.  He provides a good amount of background information without ever becoming pedantic, and so the reader will come away educated and enlightened without ever feeling like they were being "taught".Overall, a fun read, and an interesting piece of non-fiction with a compelling story in the last 1/3 of the book as the author relates the horrifying situation that his son finds himself embroiled in.

I'm a fan of the Dove line of products for Men.  I find that in general they work well, offer a good value, and don't have obnoxious smells.  This shaving cream falls in line in all three regards.  I'm generally not fond of foam-type shaving products, instead preferring to use a cake and badger brush, but I got this on a whim just to make things more convenient.  It works well and doesn't leave my skin feeling greasy or dried out like some other products.  It leaves a pleasant clean smell, but no discernible "perfume".My principal complaint with this particular product is that the bottle is skinny, so it tends to fall over easily when reaching for it in the medicine chest.  It also tips over when sitting on the sink.  The other complaint (and this is shared by all foam-type shaving products) is that it drools foam out of the nozzle after you use it, so that you always have a gummy residue under the cap if you don't rinse it off before putting it away.  On the plus side, the bottom does not rust like some shaving cream's I've used over the years.

Very fast and accurate (about 5-6 second read times).  Nice thin probe makes it easy to check the temp of steaks or even fish fillets on the grill, and the sensor seems to be near the tip, so it doesn't need to be inserted more than an inch or so.  The only thing I can tell that makes the more expensive unit from Thermaworks better is a slightly faster read time and a folding probe that makes it easier to keep in a pocket.

It wasn't super sharp out of the box, but it took an edge nicely and is now razor sharp.  The handle feels great in the hand, and the shape is perfect for a lot of intermediate sized fish, or breaking down really large fish that can be separated into loins.  Inexpensive enough that you can just keep it on the boat and not worry about it (unlike my $100+ Japanese carbon knives).  Also makes a great gift for people that invite you on their boat or for the pangeros that take you out to spots for a day of fishing when you are on vacation.

First unit arrived quickly but unfortunately didn't work.  The female end was VERY tight for any of the headphones I've tried to plug into it and it also only has one channel for sound.  I've tried it with three different sets of headphones and they all had the same problem.  When I filled out a return form on Amazon, it indicated that I would have to pay for return shipping, which would have been more than 1/2 the value of the product, so I didn't bother.========Updated review - the seller proactively contacted me after seeing my initial 1-star review and offered to ship me a replacement.  The replacement unit works well and exhibits none of the problems of the previous one I received.  So it appears I got a bum unit the first time around, and have updated my review to 4 stars.

This combined with the soap from the same company work really well to clean windows.  However, squeegee-ing the windows is much more difficult with the heavy water-logged sponge sitting on the end of the handle.  I recommend you buy the other kit from the same company that has two separate handles - one with a squeegee and the other with a sponge.

If you are looking for an over-sized "cruiser" this is a great solution.  Super stable, big fat soft wheels that glide smoothly over rough pavement (and won't get jammed by pea-sized gravel and pitch you head over heels), and a a kick tail for those sudden evasive maneuvers.  I use this board for cruising to the store, down to the beach to check the surf, and other short runs.  Its got a thick, heavy deck (no flex) so pushing it up hill or carrying it around can be tiresome.A great value for the price and a fun addition to the quiver.

These are the most typical size you'll use for most of your dress shirts, and its a perfect solution for people like me who CONSTANTLY forget to take out their collar stays before sending the shirts off to the cleaners.  These are inexpensive enough to just not worry about.  The only thing I'd improve is a case where the lid would stay fastened even while rolling around in a travel bag (this one pops open and unleashes the contents into your bag).

A seemingly great alternative to those bulky plastic pill cases you buy at the drug store, the Lewis & Clark Pill Organizer is unfortunately a one-trip solution at best.  I travel a LOT and I take a bunch of vitamins every day.  I wanted something to store all my vitamins and keep them organized, but something that would fit easily in my travel bags.  Unfortunately the little plastic zippers on the bags are very difficult to open (they stick and bind), which requires a lot of force to get them started.  Once started, they have a tendency to run right across the zipper and off the other end of the bag (e.g. coming loose).  Once that happens, they cannot be put back on the bag.  After a single week-long trip with this pill organizer, I came home with three of the bags without zippers.  Once the zipper "traveler" (the part you grab onto) is gone, the only way to open the individual pill cases is to pry them open using your fingernails.  This of course requires that you have fingernails that extend past the ends of your fingers, which is not the case for most men.  Unfortunately I now have a nifty black case with a bunch of useless zipperless bags.  My recommendation is that you look elsewhere unless you have the patience and the willingness to be EXTREMELY CAREFUL each and every time you open the pill cases.

I was not sure what to expect from this one.  I chose it mostly because it was a Kindle Unlimited "listen and read" selection.  I am so glad I took the chance.  Super possessive alpha male lead.  Smart, sweet and innocent h.  Entertaining secondary characters--there are a lot, but I think they add the right amount of interest to the story, with a good lead in to the next book with some of the characters.  I found the "villain" aspect a little confusing sometimes, but it really didn't take away from the enjoyment.  I enjoyed the writing style, and felt the intimate scenes were spicy and we'll done.  I also thought the story had a great flow, and I found I had a hard time putting it down.  Going to jump to the next book!

4 1/2-5 stars.  I'm really enjoying this series.  This is the second book, and I think I liked it more than the first.  Very good, strong characters--main and secondary.  The h in this one is especially tough.  I really love the world the author made for this series.  She puts the reader right in all the action (and there is a TON of action) without being overly wordy or descriptive--it's just enough.  I think the main characters are a good match for each other--I can definitely see them together.  I thought their relationship went very smoothly--almost too smoothly--I almost wish there was a little more tension between them at times.  I really like this author's writing style.  Besides the good world building, the overall flow and the dialogue was smooth.  All in all it was a very quick, exciting read.  I'm looking forward to the next installment.

3 1/2 stars. This book started out light and fun--just what I expected from this author.  I'm sorry to say I just didn't love it as much as I wanted to, although I did find it entertaining.  I really did enjoy the h.  I thought she had a great personality, and was a lot of fun.  I honestly wasn't crazy about the H for some reason.  I'm all for cocky, alpha males, but something about him rubbed me the wrong way. In the end, I didn't find there to be much actual romance, and I wasn't crazy about the elements leading to their first "intimate" encounter.  Also, I noticed I found the suspense to be a little "disturbing".  In an upside, I did find the ow to be very entertaining.  I think this is a case of one of my favorite authors putting a new book out, and I jumped on it, not really being in the "mood" for this type of story, but finishing it anyway--so I didn't enjoy it as much as I think I would have if I read it at a different time.

Very enjoyable "bad boy rocker meet good girl" romance.  I really liked the writing  style--the story had a good flow, and was easy to read.  Intimate scenes were spicy, and it had a little suspense thrown in which was nice.  As far as the characters go, I did like the H more than the h in this one.  It was obvious he was very much taken with the h from the first moment he saw her, and the possessiveness was very evident.  In my opinion, the h, although the required "sweet and beautiful girl next door type" seemed to have to many "tstl" moment for my taste.  As far as the romance goes, I definitely can see them together forever--if they don't kill each other first.  I just found their relationship to be very volatile--not physically (although the prerequisite "spanking" came into play), but the amount of arguments the couple had do to lack of actually "talking" to each other makes me a little uneasy.  There is a really good set up for the next book--I am definitely looking forward to that one.

I've been waiting very anxiously for this book.  I definitely liked it more than the last one (Chasing Claire)--mostly because I really enjoyed the characters themselves.  Crow was what I expected--very alpha, bad boy biker, but with a sweet, softer side.  I felt Melissa, the h, was a little more complex.  She had he whole guilty, grieving widow thing going on, struggling as a single mother, but I really liked when she started to come out of her she'll, and her backbone and attitude came through.I would consider it more of a "sweet" romance, and I can see why many readers are really loving it.  The reason I liked it is pretty simple--it's a sweet, enjoyable, love story with good characters, that I felt was well written, and was easy to read.  There are a few specific reasons why I really "liked" it, but didn't "love" it.  The story had a very even "feel" to me--I felt like I was waiting for "more" to happen.  It is just a preference of mine to have more tense moments, and even some suspense of some kind. I almost wish there was more tension between Crow and Raine--something to break up the flow add more feeling.  Although I really did like the couple together, I don't really get that feeling they are the "one" for each other.  It doesn't have anything to do with the fact they were both married before.  I felt it just took too long in the story for them to actually come together, and then they all of a sudden "loved" each other.  Also, there is a part towards the end when Crow wants Melissa to figure things out, but he says "I won't wait forever".  This made me feel it was just too easy for him to move with someone else if they separated--I really want my H's to fight for their loves.I really hope Glory and Jules get the next book--and I hope it's soon.  I really think I'm going to get my dose of "tension" there!

This was an entertaining, quick read.  I would definitely describe this as "fun"--fun characters, fun storyline.  I enjoyed the take on the shifter origins in this one--I thought it better explained human tolerance towards them.  I felt the suspense was good--however, I really didn't get the big deal of the h's special "gift".  I did like the couple together, but I wish there was more one on one interaction between them.  It seemed to me the "I love you's" came out of no where.  All in all, a good start to a new series.

I enjoy this author--a lot.  This is probably my second favorite wolf shifter book of hers behind "Feral Sins" (which is one of my all-time favorite PNR reads).  The h is my favorite kind--strong, smart, with special powers, can fight, kind, sassy--but not cocky--and practical (can see things from everyone's viewpoint.  The H was a good alpha male lead--pretty typical of what I usually see in this genre.  Secondary characters are entertaining, and add just the right amount of interest toe story without taking it over.  I did like how the beginning, when the h first arrived to the pack, there was a lot of tension, and this was not really resolved too quickly.  The suspense was exciting, and the story had a very good flow overall.  I liked these two as a couple, and I look forward to reading in with the series.

I think I liked this one more than I should have.  Why do I say that?  Pretty much because the first 2 characteristics I come up with when I think of the H are "pushy" and "jerk".  I do tend to like my male leads more on the "alpha" side, but this H was so incredibly bossy--never took "no" for an answer (don't even get me started on him making her go to boot camp).  What I think balanced him out was his sweet side--incredible single dad to two small children, and the fact that when he did realize he messed up (more than once) with the h, I thought he was still pushy to get her back, but explained himself pretty well.  The h was a fun character--super sweet and smart, but pretty basic.  I did like her a lot, just I felt the H had more dimensions to him.This is the third book I read from this author, and definitely my favorite.  I feel her writing style has a  very strong "Kristen Ashley" flavor.  I really enjoyed the quick, smart, funny comments sprinkled through the book--there's a part where the h turns in her phone she left off, and I really enjoyed her getting all the missed messages.  There is a good suspense aspect, with more than one suspense subplot that keeps the storyline moving well.  I did really enjoy this couple together, and I'm glad the author didn't make it too easy for them--like a fight over babies wasn't an easy fix.  There is a change of pov between the h and H, but I wish they were labeled.  It was the only thing that I felt was distracting, and took away from the great flow of the story.

4 1/2 stars.  I really enjoyed reading this one--I thought the characters were fantastic, and the storyline was exciting, and moved well.  The h, who is on the run from a cray ex, seems very down to earth, practical, smart, and sweet.  Of course, she is one of those women who attract multiple men, but doesn't understand why, is a great cook, and beautiful, but doesn't know it.  The H is super mean to the h for a good part of the first half.  What struck me about him is the way he doesn't feel he is perfect--he's even unsure, and has the sense to open his eyes and see what is going on, and fix it--taking all the blame on the way.  I'm not saying he's not an "alpha male" lead, just that he seems more relatable to me.  Once he does realize his mistakes, and why he is doing them, he is actually very sweet and attentive to the h--at least for a while.The secondary characters are also entertaining, and there are multiple subplots that I feel only enhance, not distract, form the main plot line.  I liked the writing style, and the switching of pov. Timeline flows very well, and kept me wanting to read on.The only real issues I had with the book was the number of nicknames given to the main characters--I didn't really find this confusing, just sort of annoying.  There seemed to be some unanswered plot line questions that has me wondering if they would be addressed in later books--like who actually did something, and what ever happened to someone.  Also, for as much as I loved the H, sometimes his dreams for the future were "disconnected" from the h--almost like he was going to achieve them no matter what, and the h just fit the bill.

This is the first book I read from this author, and I found it very entertaining.  I thought the writing style was good--I seemed to really enjoy the dialogues between the characters.  Even though the story had a good flow, I found the timeline sometimes moved very quickly--I wouldn't consider it a problem, but I did find it a little confusing in places.  As far as the main characters go, I really enjoyed the H.  He is you typical wealthy, alpha character (which I love) who gets taken with the h pretty much instantly.  The h is sweet, innocent, and beautiful (but she doesn't know it).  I thought the H was incredibly patient with the h, who I found could act a little immature--sometimes I wondered if he was just going to give up on her altogether.  Luckily, her character showed a nice amount of growth throughout the book, and I ended up enjoying her more towards the end.  To me, the growth made them more suitable as a believable couple.  I found the story as a whole far from boring, and I had trouble putting it down sometimes.  I liked how the author kept the reader engaged with quite a few misunderstandings between the main characters (which get resolved rather quickly, but new ones kept popping up) and a nice suspense aspect.*** I received this book from the author for an honest review, but it is definitely something I would have chosen to read myself.

This is one series that I think it really helps to read all the books in order.  Luckily, I really enjoy this author's writing style, and they have all been fast, entertaining reads.  There seems to be an ongoing story arc between the books, with one couple being spotlighted, but the other characters have their own moments within each book.  This one has an interesting take on a VERY heavy subject matter, and I thought it was very well done. The H is incredibly patient, and sweet, and I really liked this couple together.  One of my favorite of this series.

Very exciting romantic suspense.  A little different H than I have been reading lately.  He's very "alpha" but is t always very gentle with the h.  There is a lot of tension between the couple--romantic and other.  I'm glad this book was not told solely form the h's pov.  I felt the author did a good job making the reader understand the H's character, and why he doesn't understand his feelings towards the h--and it makes him seem much more tolerable to me as a leading male character.  The h was very strong in her own way.  I liked the way she really didn't just take whatever the H was dishing out, and even tried to "escape" him.  The suspense was ongoing, and very exciting, with some nice unexpected twists. I did think the ending was a bit rushed.  Part of me wanted the h to make it much harder on him, and part of me gets that the h actually understands the H (maybe better than he does), and I can go along with it.  This maybe my favorite book I read for this author so far.

3-3 1/2 stars.  I'm a huge fan of this author, and given the title, I thought she broke into the "sci-fi" category--um, I was wrong.  However, it was still an easy to read, short, but rather entertaining story.  I really enjoyed the couple.  It started off as just a "hook-up--routine for the H, unusual for the h, and of course, they can't stay away from each other.  There is a lot of sex--especially in the beginning, but I felt the author did a good job "implying" a lot of it, so the story could actually show through.  To be honest, I was not crazy about the last third of the story.  I was really enjoying the relationship, and liking the characters, but there was an incident with a hospital stay, and I am very confused as to why the H acted the way he did after.  Maybe if the story was longer, his character could have been expanded, and I could see things the way he did--but the way it was, I just didn't get it.  Also, I really want my H's to fight for the h--even if he has to "fight" her insecurities.  That didn't happen here either.  I really loved the beginning, just disappointed in the end.

I thought this book was fast, but very entertaining.  It is the second book in the series, about another couple, and I thought the author did a very good job keeping the plots different--this one being much more in the suspense category.  The secondary characters still play a pretty big roll in this book, but it did not bother me here.  I really enjoy the characters--all of them--and I like how the author seems to keep their stories going.  For a shorter length book, I thought the actual suspense was done pretty well, and kept me guessing.  I found I actually felt very bad for the h at the end, and what happened to her.  I am really liking this author's writing style.  Good dialogue.  Sex scenes are spicy, but I found a little predictable.  Actually wouldn't miss them if they were omitted--I liked the plot that much.  One thing that stopped me from giving it a slightly higher rating is------------ENDING -SPOILERS---------the h ends up chasing down the H at the end to make him see reasons why they should be together.  Just a pet peeve for me--I like my H's to do the chasing.  I want my h's to be with fighting for!!!

4 1/2-5 stars. Probably my new favorite from this author--there was not a whole lot I didn't like about it.  The things that stand out to me that I liked were:The couple itself--they were older.  Her was 46, and she was 37--although they didn't really "act" like any particular age group.  The H, Dax, was your basic sweet, possessive alpha male lead.  The h, Mack, was sweet, and quirky.  I can see how some readers may find her annoying, but I enjoyed her character--ramblings and all.  I did not find her TSTL--in fact, I thought she was rather practical.  Together, I thought they were well matched, and made a great couple.Secondary characters were not overdone, and added just the right amount of interest.  I assume Jax's friends will be getting upcoming books to the series.Lately, I find myself skimming over many of the sex scenes in books--they're just becoming to repetitive and stale for me.  There was something about the couple's first time that actually held my interest--it was had almost an "endearing" quality to me.The timeline was interesting, and I did not find it filled with little extra stuff, that has nothing to do with the plot, but put there just to fill pages.  Pretty much the first half occurred over a period of several weeks, showing the romantic buildup.  The second half was almost entirely a suspenseful climax--taking place over the period of I think a day.I thought the suspense aspect was very well done.  I know it's fiction, and not based on real life, but I felt the actions--and especially the emotions--had more of a "this could actually happen" feel to me.One thing that sticks in my head that bothered me (I don't want to give anything away)--but given the situation the h was in at the end, I kept wanting the H--or anyone to realize she should STOP talking.  I do get what the dialog added to the story, but in a practical way, it didn't make sense to me.

4-4 1/2 stars.  I enjoyed this book more than I thought I would.  I'm usually not crazy about the h only interested in the H for a "physical" relationship, but I thought the author did a fantastic job telling, to me, what was a believable story.  Given the premise for the story--the h being seriously ill--leads into all kind of emotional possibilities, and again I thought the author did a great job making the story feel realistic, without venturing into the "cheesy" side which I find sometimes with this trope.  The characters were really good--I especially liked the super alpha, yet sweet H, and the set of friend on both sides were so entertaining, they added a lot to the book--I ended up really liking both groups.  I look forward to reading their stories.

4 1/2 stars.  Very entertaining take on the "Dracula" story.  I loved the characters--great strong, smart h, with interesting powers.  Gruff, stand-offish H who doesn't really understand his feelings for h.  I also found it interesting that the h's scarring made me think of another popular monster, giving this book almost a "Dracula meets Frankenstein" feel.  There is a very nice romantic buildup and LOTS of action.  Secondary characters were also entertaining, and added to prefect amount of enjoyment to the story.  My love for the story wasn't deterred by the fact that it is a HFN, and a lean-in to the next book about the same characters--I look forward to reading on.

3 1/2 stars.  I liked this author's writing style,  it it was just too short for my taste.  The H and h were already into a physical relationship when the book starts, so we miss this "first meeting" sparks and romantic buildup.  I do admit, the fact it is a novella, and the premise is clearly marked in its description.  I just grabbed it from my TBR pile, and wasn't paying close attention.

This was a cute, fast, easy read that sort of had a lighter "KA" feel to it.  I enjoyed the characters--the h was cute, and sweet--the H gruff and alpha to the core.  Their relationship starts off rocky, so we get a bit of a romantic buildup.  There is a confrontation between the H and h that does not go well, and I am very pleased she does not make it easy for him, and we even get a small, but decent grovel from the H.  I was surprised I found a nice little suspense aspect, that unfortunately, I felt ended way too abruptly.  The reader also finds a secondary storyline with the H's brother, and the h's BFF that I did not feel took away from the main plot,  it I felt was entertaining in its own right-- I almost wished they got their own book.

****Possible spoilers ahead**** I can honestly say, I don't remember reading a book where I disliked the characters and their actions so much.  This is surprising to me, given than the H is a powerful alpha male, the h seems relatively smart and sweet, and I usually do enjoy this author.First, the H and his pack literally hold the h--at times, bound and gagged, in a locked room.  She is given to them by her former pack (this wouldn't bother me if it was a "regular practice" but it got the impression it's not) as a "potential mate" to the H who is looking for one, but was recently permanently and severely scarred on his face, and is having trouble finding a female who will want to be with him.  Even later, when the H and h start to get to know each other, he STILL locks her in a room when he wants--even though, at that time, she was able to move freely around the house. The h is scared, and fights back and tries to escape, which makes the H and his pack mad at her.  Then she starts asking questions about why the H won't show her is face, and they get more mad at her.  I would start cheering for the h for her resourcefulness on her escape attempts, but then she later thinks about it, and feels bad for upsetting everyone---um...what?  I also found her "curiosity" annoying--if you are going to go out of your way look at something you KNOW you shouldn't, don't get surprised if you upset someone in the process.  He actually blames her for not cooperating, and hurting his feelings, and she ends up backing down too much when she should be standing up for herself.  I'll admit, I'm an incredible easy-going person, and pick my battles to the point where I let somethings go when I know I shouldn't, but even I wanted to smack the h in the head and tell her to "wake up!"The fact of the way all the pack members treated the h in the beginning did not exactly endear me to the secondary characters.  Even the H's sisters, who were trying to tell the H that he can't exactly hold women against their will did nothing to help the h--in fact they were active participants in the h's captivity.  Then believe or not, one time, out of the blue, they come over and take the h out to a bar to a bar to hang out--instant BFF's.There is a secondary storyline--a lead-in to the next book-- that is sprinkled throughout the plot line.  I actually found it to be intrusive, and kept interrupting the flow of the main storyline.  This definitely didn't help with my enjoyment factor.  I'm also getting the impression the h in the next story is going to be low on the "backbone" scale.  I hope I'm wrong, since I did actually like the upcoming H (probably the only pack member who didn't annoy me), and wanted to give that book a chance.The things I did really enjoy from this story was there actually was a decent build up to the romantic relationship (even if I didn't like the H and h), the suspense aspect--which I found pretty engrossing, and the villains--they seemed to be "true to character", and didn't make my head hurt.I just didn't get it.  I'm all for "fated mates", "love conquers all" and all that stuff.  I can even put up with an H being a jerk and redeeming himself, if there is a believable HEA.  Maybe this couple just deserved each other.  This is one of those books I probably should have put in my DNF pile, but I do enjoy this author's writing style, and I kept hoping for some sort of turnaround.

3 1/2-4 stars.  This is one of those stories where the good guy turns into the bad guy for the h, and the bad guy turns into her prince.  For the most part, I did enjoy the story.  I liked the writing style.  The characters were young, but it seemed much more NA in parts than others.  It surprised me that the story had such a "sweet" feel to it.  I ended up liking the couple together, but I almost wish the buildup and "forgiveness" period was longer.  Probably one of my favorite parts was the relationship between the brothers.  I'll probably continue to read the series to see how each brother gets his own book.

4 1/2 stars.  Not a very long book, but a very exciting story, with tons of action--and I still got a good sense of the romance--yay!  I really liked the characters.  The h was very sweet and caring, but with a subtle, but very impressive strength.  The H was arrogant and alpha, but very possessive of the h.  I also liked them together as a couple, and enjoyed their relationship building.  Characters from previous books make an appearance, but I think this can definitely be read as a stand alone.

3 1/2 stars.  This is one of those books that I feel I would have absolutely LOVED if it was longer.  I did enjoy the authors writing style, and I liked how the H and his friends did not immediately like the h--however I did not even like the h until the story was past the half way mark.  My main issue was the lack of build up to the romance.  The H and h hate each other, then they're a couple( and I mean full throttle) then they have a falling out, then they're a couple again.  I don't have an issue with this storyline, it's just that mixed in were other very detailed events not related to the actual couple, so the back and forth seemed too abrupt--in my opinion, it was just too short of a book to pull it off, and it made me want more.  I do enjoy is author, and I will give the next book in this series a try,

4-4 1/2 stars.  Another very good read from this author.  I really enjoyed the characters in this one.  The h was super strong, but not in an "in you face" obnoxious way.  She still had a ton on vulnerability, yet she observed, and learned for every experience that was thrust her way.  The H was super possessive, alpha male lead, who even though there was instant attraction win the h, was very patient and sweet with her.  This lead up to a great build up to the actual realistic ship.  Although this author repeats her theme of "damsels in distress, facing danger, and seriously hurt in some way" I thought he plot line was different enough to be refreshing--the reason the h went to her grandfather's, and her relationship with her kettle brother.  Probably the only thing that I found to "bother" me about the story itself, were the actions of the villain.  He was so brazen with his actions, that I felt almost confused how this ultra-possessive H would allow him to stay around as long as he did.  It may seem picky, but it really stuck out to me.  I'm looking forward to the next book.

Although I really enjoyed this latest addition to "The Last Riders" series, I felt there was something "off".  This book seemed to be almost like two separate stories put together.  In the first half (which I liked more than the second) we get a ton of tension, and emotions rolling off the characters, spurred on by angry worlds, hurt feelings, and callus actions. I didn't mind this--I read the previous books of the series, so I knew what to expect.  Lucy's "fun" with other women seemed almost normal due to the author's portrayal of the characters through the other story arcs.  All of a sudden, around half way through the book, the story's feel took a complete 180 for me.  In a blink of an eye, Lucky and Willa are a couple and engaged--for real.  They seem like an old married couple (who doesn't actually know anything about each other).  The tone of the book went from angsty to sweet, and it lost the "edge" that I was liking so much.  What was missing for me, was just some kind of "bridge" to show the relationship actually building.  Willa seemed to take everything in stride to easily, and Lucky seemed to change his mind too quickly.  I did like them together as a couple.  I just wish we would get a better feel of that exciting feeling that comes with a new relationship forming--along with Willa giving him a harder time for being such a jerk for the first half of the book.I do like this author's writing style, and also the interaction with the main cast of characters.  I think it would have been a solid 5 star read for me if there was more of a build up to the H and h  in an actual relationship.

4-4 1/2 stars.  At first I was not too crazy about the h--I just could not understand her actions as to her living conditions.  I understand the sometimes, people need to deal with the cards they are dealt, and some situations are beyond rational control, but since she was not in love with the guy she was living with, I just was not finding her actions believable.  I thought the author did a very good job unweaving her story, and I really ended up enjoying her character.  This one actually ended up one of my favorite books of the series.  I liked the H and h together, and I really enjoyed the build up to their relationship.  The reader gets what they expect from this author--protective alpha male leads, smart, strong heroines, lots of suspense and action with the "damsel in distress" thing going on, spicy sex scenes, and an entertaining secondary cast that we met throughout the series.  Although the book stayed true to form with the rest of the series, I did think it had enough of a difference to make it interesting.  I also liked how the extra characters played their role, but did not take away from the main couple.

Although I love this author, and a couple of her books are some of my all time favorites, the last few reads have been entertaining, but just ok for me.  I absolutely loved this one.  I thought the characters were great--super alpha-demon-whatever H and a strong, confident h who really stole the story for me.  Although it's pretty much your basic PNR, (with mystical creatures, and special powers) I enjoyed the take on how the human and demon are pretty much two different pieces of one person.  This aspect seemed a little more pronounced in this book, than other--say shifter-- stories.  Also, I liked the fact that just because the H and h were predetermined "anchors", a physical relationship was not a given--there was an actual development of the romantic relationship.  Action was exciting, suspense was surprising at times, intimate scenes were very spicy, great buildup to the romance, entertaining secondary characters--these facts just wrapped up the story wonderfully for me.  It seems like it's been a while since I was able to give a solid 5 star rating, so I'm happy to do it here!  Another one for my favorites shelf!

4 1/2 stars. A much more angsty and emotional read than other books I remember from this author.  Although there were many emotional ups and downs, I felt the story had a nice flow, and was a good quick, easy read.  It is a second chance romance, and although I really don't get why the h had to leave in the beginning (well actually I technically get why she had to leave, I just wish more of the story was put into her reasons so I could agree with it), I did like the way the couple reconnected, and the build up of their new relationship was believable to me.  I enjoyed the characters--main and secondary.  Storyline with h's mother was very emotional, and I found tears in my eyes more than once.  Very happy I read this and will definitely go in my "keepers" shelf.

3 1/2-4 stars.  This definitely is not your typical MFM romance.  There are no brothers with 3 dads who always wanted to follow in their parents' footsteps--which actually was very refreshing.  I just wish there was more.  I thought the author did a fantastic job introducing these characters, and showing how a love could grow between them.  It's just such a complicated scenario, and it seems more "realistic" for the genre, I would have liked to have seen more of how they dealt with the day to day issue--both good and bad.  There was no real "coming together" for me--and I'm not talking about the bedroom.  It almost seemed too easy.  I didn't feel there was as much if any friction in the new relationship as one would expect, especially given the unconventional circumstances.  There is a big drama at the end that honestly, I didn't get.  I was annoyed at the character who did what they did for the reasons given, and I wish there was more to the story dealing with the aftermath.  It may sound like I didn't enjoy it, I did--a lot.  It's just one of the stories that stayed with me, and makes me think.  There is a really beautiful love story here, with entertaining yet unique characters, and yes, I would recommend it.  I really love this author's writing style, and I can't wait to read more.

4-41/2 stars.  Another very good book from this author.  I absolutely loved the H--Toad.  He was just such an amazing character--perfect mixture of bad boy-good guy.  The h, Sydney, is sweet, but not your totally innocent heroine.  She lead a tough life, is homeless, but still grounded.  Secondary characters are entertaining too, and add the right amount of interest without taking over the story.  Probably my only complaint about this one, is I wish there was more interaction between The H and h.  It is a romance, and you do get a nice love story.  The plot line really kept me engrossed, and to be honest, I didn't realized I even felt I missed having more of the H and h until it was over.  Just thinking back, I really liked the couple, and wanted to see more of the .

Very good writing style, and great suspense with some surprising twists.  I wish there was more interaction between the H and h in the first half.  Also, some of the conflicts were handled too "maturely" for my tastes.  I guess I was in the mood for more angst.  Still, very exciting and enjoyable.

4 1/2 stars.  I think this is my new favorite, and I have liked all the books in this series.  Again, great characters, and a different storyline than the rest.  Really, not a whole lot of different things happening, but I thought what happened was done well--It was fast moving, and I read it very quickly.  Very emotional.  There is not much build up in the relationship, but I am used to it from this series, and I understand the way of this family, so it doesn't bother me.  Really looking forward to the next and last book.

3 1/2-4 stars.  This is one of those books that I liked purely because it entertained me.  It had a really sweet and possessive H, and a nice buildup to the relationship.  It's not my favorite writing style, and some of the situations were highly unrealistic, but that's what I read fiction for.

Really liked the storyline.  It was a nice change from the usual suspense I've been reading lately.  I thought the characters were great, and I liked the couple together.  There was a nice buildup to the romantic relationship that really had me routing for them.  I also enjoyed the authors writing style--loved the funny moments sprinkled in the story, and had nice intimate scenes that don't overrun the plot line.  The only issue I had with it was I felt the ending was way too rushed.  The entire story had such a nice flow, and was building and building up to what the reader could easily see was going to be an emotional climax, then it kind of just fizzled for me.  I really wish the author put more behind the conclusion for balance.  I also would have liked to have known the reaction of the ex-husband at the end.  This is the second book in the series, and Can be read as a stand alone.

3.75-4 stars.  Fun story with a womanizer (before he meets the h) H, and a sweet, social worker h who seems to find trouble.  I thought it was kind of "sweet" and had really nice action/suspense side.  For the most part, I did enjoy the writing style, but there did seem to be a lot of inner dialogue from both the H and h that I felt got too much, and I thought a couple of "sappy" places that I think we're supposed to be "moving".  Besides that, I really did enjoy the story, and thought it was a great start to a new series.

4 1/2-5 stars.  This is one of those treasures I have has in my TBR pile for a long time, and I am so sorry it took so long for me to read it.  There really wasn't much I didn't like--strong h with a mysterious side that surprises everyone.  A good alpha male lead.  Entertaining secondary characters.  Exciting suspense.  Just enough sex scenes to build the heat, but not take away from the story line.  And a good writing style that kept the story moving, and had world building that was interesting, but not confusing.  I definitely recommend.

4 1/2 stars.  I have thoroughly enjoyed every one of the books in this series, but this one is probably my favorite--at least until the 75% mark.  I loved the characters, and it had a much bigger build up to the romance (pretty much because Kane--the H--was a jerk and did not realize the h was his soul mate).  I felt so much emotion from this story, and it probably would have been a solid 5 stars for me, but at the 75% mark, the story seemed to do a complete 180. I felt the last 25% had a completely different feel, with characters that did not necessary grow (well the H seemed to have some development), but the h seemed to acquire a completely different personality.  Yes, I want them together, and yes, I NEED my HEA, but I felt it was a little rushed there at the end.  I just wish the author would have spent more time at that point meshing the ending with the rest of the story.

4-4 1/2 stars.  This is turning out to be such a fun series.  This one, once again, kind of shakes things up, and actually gives the reader a different story, even though it is the 4th in a series.  There was a "romance" like expected, but I felt it actually took a back seat to the h's story.  This usually bothers me, but since I was already familiar with the H, and how the when the brother's find their "soul mate", there is not turning back, I guess I didn't phase me as much.  I did enjoy the couple together, and thought they were a good match.  When I started, I was not so sure about the h--she seemed too tough, too cocky, but I thought her character ended very well rounded, and had some surprises I was not expecting.  I do enjoy this author's writing style, with the good flow, and steamy--but well done--spicy parts.  Looking forward to next book.

Another really enjoyable book in this series.  I really liked the characters--and liked them together.  This one had another feel to it.  The H and h seemed to be a little more subtle than the rest--not so "in your face" personalities.  I felt it had a good buildup to the relationship, and I really the set up of how they met.  A couple of picky things I found a little confusing was some things the H--who was supposed to be an incredible doctor--did not pick up on.  Also, the "villains" role at the end, and his reactions.  It just left me thinking "huh?".  Not enough to take away from me enjoying the story, but just stayed with me.

I'm going with 3 stars with this one solely for the fact I found the suspense aspect very interesting.  I have loved everything else this author has written--I just had an issue with this one.  For me, the h and her "girl posse" was a little too...much.  They seemed over-the-top silly at times for my taste.  The h in general was a little too flighty--I did enjoy the whole "romance writer" aspect, and I liked how the author incorporated the h's book scenes into the story.  I did like the H better.  He was a good alpha character, but he took too long to get things together and start after the h.  I noticed it was about 40% into the story before he made his intentions known.  Intimate scenes were what I expected--not overly done, but still good.  As far as the relationship goes, I thought the H and h had a lot of "lust" going on, but it was hard to feel the real love between them.  I think if they got together sooner it would help with the building of their relationship.  This author is still on my must buy list.  Everything else she has written has gotten 5 stars from me.  I look forward to her next book.

4-4 1/2 stars.  Very fast and entertaining read.  I totally enjoyed the concept of the plot and the characters themselves.  I felt the author did a great job showing the different struggles both the H and h were having--her dealing with the fact she was trying to live what little life she had left to the fullest, and him coming to terms with feelings for the h he did not think we're possible for him.  I thought it got pretty emotional at times, and actually found myself tearing up.  Intimate scenes were super spicy, but I felt, well done.  Writing style was very good, and flow moved very quickly--timeline moved almost too fast in some places.  Overall, I really enjoyed it.  There is a nice set up for the next book I can't wait to start.

4 1/2 stars.  I think this may be one of my favorite books I read from this author in a while.  I really enjoyed the characters.  The H was pretty much your basic alpha male, possessive type, but  I felt the h and her family really stole the book.  She was a good combination of sweet and strong, and her younger brother and sisters were very funny.  I ended up really liking the couple together.  I also thought it was interesting how not everything went smoothly between the h and all the members of her family--there were some twists I really was not expecting.  Also, these was a nice balance of suspense and steam that kept the storyline going.  The reason I could not give it a solid 5 stars was pretty much because I really wanted more.  The timeline moved very fast in some spots, and I really wish it did not end so abruptly--maybe a tiny epilogue.  I know this is the author's style, but I get so into the story, and she is so creative, I would like to see her books longer.

4 1/2 stars. To be honest, I was not sure about this one.  I really enjoy this author, and I love the whole pnr "mates" thing, so I did not know how I would feel about the h being married and actually mated to someone else besides the H, and have a believable HEA.  However, I do feel Ms. Langlais pulled it off--I should have known better!  Typical combination of humor and suspense in this story.  I really did enjoy both the H and h--she was very strong and smart, and could fit right in with all the "guys" when they went in the mission, and he was completely endearing and lovable.  I think he maybe my favorite H of this series.  The storyline moved very well, and I read the book rather quickly.  There is a reason Eve Langlais is a must but for me, and this is a great example.

4-4 1/2 stars.  I think I liked this a bit better than the first one of this series.  The H and h have seen each other around for some time, but never really paid much attention.  Once a situation throws them together, it is pretty much instant attraction/lust-love, especially on the H's side.  Story line moves well, and suspense side is well done.  I thought both the H and h were good characters, but I wished the H was not so blinded by the intentions of his "client".  Sometimes it just made him look ignorant.  I did like them together as a couple.  The previous couple, and some other characters from the last book make an appearance, and just the right amount of entertainment.

This was a good, very fast read for me--it wasn't my favorite of the series! but I still felt it was highly entertaining.  I really enjoy this author's h's.  In all the books I read from her, all the heroine's seem to be super strong, level-headed, selfless, kind, and way down on their luck somehow.  This one is no different, but I do not really find it too repetitive.  The H, of course, is your super good guy, alpha male, navy SEAL.  I really enjoyed the couple together--another case of pretty much "instant love", even though they weren't together very much.  Secondary characters from previous books in the series make an appearance, but do not overwhelm the storyline.  I did like how the previous h's brought this new one into the fold.  Looking forward to the next installment.

I put off reading this for a while because I got the impression from some other comments that the h in this book immediately forgives the H when he comes back into her life and everything is just peachy.  I did not take it that way.  I actually felt the h did a good job holding the H at arms length for a while.  I do feel that when she did "give in", it was kind of abrupt, but I ended up really liking the couple together.  I thought the characters themselves were entertaining--the h was the strong, selfless, hard-working type, the the H was a good alpha male who was very single minded in what he wanted (his family) and would not take "no" for an answer.  I felt the H's ptsd was an interesting addition to his character.  The little girls were cute, but I felt they should have been a little older according to how they talked and acted.  I really enjoyed the H's brother, and I look forward to his story.

4-4 1/2 stars.  This story was definitely not what I expected, but I really enjoyed it.  I was in the mood for a pnr, and since it was labeled a "Dragon Kings" book, I assumed it would be a "fated mates" type dragon-shifter story.  Boy was I wrong.  I would defintely consider it in the "darker" side.  There was not really any "sunshine and cheery" moments, but rather a combination of a very intense and action-packed story line, with a decent romance.  I thought the h was a great leading lady.  She was super strong--both emotionally and physically.  She did not always make the best decisions, but she learns from her mistakes, and grows from them.  I wouldn't necessarily consider the H a "bad guy", but he is what he is, and does what he does to survive in the only environment he has ever known.  When I first met him, his actions towards the h made me go back to the synopsis of the book to actually see if he was going to be the h's love interest.  To be honest, I was very skeptical as to whether the author could pull this off to me as a believable romance, but she did.  I feel there was a growth in both characters that really helped to build the foundation for a growing relationship.  I thought the writing style was good, and had a good flow.  However, I did find some parts confusing, like I was missing some information about this new world the author created.  Not enough to detract from the total enjoyment, but just enough to make me wish for some answers.

4 1/2 stars.  I really love this series, and I am happy to say there really was not much I didn't love about this addition to it.  I thought the characters were great--I'm always a sucker for the quiet, menacing H who only softens for his h.  He has very sweet moments, and his "domestic" abilities kind of surprised me.  The h is a good leading lady too--smart and caring, down on her luck, but not wallowing in self pity.  There is a good balance of suspense, angsty moments, with what I felt an actual build up to the relationship, even though both characters had the instant attraction thing.  My only issues with the story (why I could not give it a solid 5 stars) was I felt it ended way too abruptly.  Not a cliffhanger, but I still felt it needed to be concluded in some way, or an epilogue.  Also, I have read every story as it was released, but the fact these are not released in the actual chronological order is somewhat confusing--especially in the actions of the secondary characters.  Still, it was a fast moving, easy to read, and exciting story.  I hope the author keeps them coming!

3 1/2-4 stars.  Overall, I really enjoyed this book--not as much as the first, but it still was an easy to read, fast moving, entertaining story.  I thought the plot was good, and I felt the dialogue between the H and h was very entertaining.  I really liked the H, but the h gave me mixed signals, and is pretty much the reasoning I did not love the entire story more.  There were parts I loved her, when she acted practical, smart, and strong.  But there were other sections when she seemed too "whiney" and acted too childish for me.  I get that her backstory presents herself with a natural aversion to men being deceitful, but, with all the other stuff she went through with the H, I just could not justify her actions during the last part of the book.  I'm not saying he was right in what he did that facilitated her actions, just that I wished it did not make up the big climatic tension of the book.  Still, I thought it was  a fun read and I will definitely read more from this series.

Solid 4 stars.  I actually liked this story better than the first book.  Where I wasn't crazy about the h in the previous one, I really liked Tess.  Tank was pretty much what I expected--super sweet, yet with a bad boy, alpha edge.  Secondary characters stayed true to their roles, and made the story more interesting.  Suspense aspect was good.  Writing style just ok for me, with a bunch of noticeable typos, but the overall plot-line had a good flow.  I would consider it a stand alone, and the reader does not necessarily need to read the first book to enjoy this one.

The debut release from this heavy classic power metal band from Greece really smokes! In an era where speedy extreme and power metal bands are in abundance itâs nice to hear a band like this that really just loves to bring the good old-school heavy metal. No power/prog, no keyboards here â this is straight up guitar and drum-driven metal with a positive lyrical bent. Think Judas Priest, Jag Panzer, Helstar, Manowar and maybe even a bit of Accept. Guitarist Thimios Krikos (Innerwish) is the driving force here and his collaboration with Yiannis Papanikolaou (vocals) makes up the foundation of Diviner. Yiannis has a powerful lower register voice, but his style reminds me of Blind Guardianâs Hansi Kursch â throaty vocals with no shrieking. While there are plenty of guitar solos as well, I think the appeal lies within the headbanging riffs and catchy melodies - this music is aggressive. Mixing and production quality is very good as well. And while there is a consistency from start to finish (no filler here) I think greater song diversity might help propel these guys to a higher level. Overall, Fallen Empires is a great debut for Diviner and I can easily recommend this for those who love a good dose of 80âs classic metal.

It should be no surprise to see this 2 CD live release from the UKâs unsung heroes of progressive melodic metal. Threshold revitalized their career in 2012 with the release of March of Progress, their 2nd with Nuclear Blast at the time. In fact, the immense success of that album alone â along with the return of Damian Wilson to the vocal helm â propelled the label to reissue their entire back catalog with remastered and expanded editions. Then came For The Journey in 2014 to solidify their firm and consistent standing in the progressive metal realm. Mostly recently they completed a 19 venue European tour and are preparing at this time to go out on the road again in 2016. Good things do come to those who persevere and stay true to their dream as Threshold (and we fans for sure) may finally be reaping the rewards of their faithfulness. The coolest aspect of all this â these guys sound like (some 20 plus years into their careers) like they are having the times of their lives. And there is no doubt from this live CD that they are performing at a level higher than ever before.With a full production sound quality â every voice rules here â this is a highly professional recording which far exceeds what they accomplished with Critical Energy in 2004. The 15 song collection includes the first 5 songs from For The Journey (2014), 4 songs from March of Progress (2012), 2 songs from Dead Reckoning (2007), the 2 lead off tracks from Subsurface (2004), âLong Way Homeâ from Hypothetical (2001) and the biggest surprise âPart of the Chaosâ from 1997âs Extinct Instinct (the most progressive and experimental release in the back catalog and one which featured Damien Wilsonâs first return to the band). The exclusion of the songs from Critical Mass should not be surprising given that the prior live CD/DVD Critical Energy featured those songs as well as many of the songs from the first 2 albums. I am however surprised by the omission of any songs from Clone which is Thresholdâs most underrated but by no means their weakest release. Most of us have never heard Wilson sing âMacâsâ songs but he does an excellent job with those songs, especially the powerful âSlipstreamâ and the ethereal âPilot in the Sky of Dreams.âOne thing that comes across with this selection of songs is just how powerful, yet melodic Threshold remains. This is metal folks. These songs not only feature the epics, but some of the most melodic moments at the same time. âLong Way Homeâ is a difficult song for Wilson to tackle but he sounds perfectly at home. And in addition to the usual seamless and enthralling work of West and Groom on their respective instruments, the younger guys (Morten and James) carry their weight as well. Drummer Johanne James has improved considerably, his pace and intensity a step ahead of where he was a decade ago. Some of his âbig rockâ endings are spectacular and he drives these songs with fervor and conviction. âPart of the Chaosâ is probably my favorite track here. Not only am I impressed by how deep they went into the catalog to deliver this but they execute it with perfection and power.Long live Threshold. Hereâs hoping for a video soon to accompany this live release â¦ and hereâs hoping for North American Journey as the next installment in the series!

APSOG remains a classic within the progressive rock/metal arena and for good reason â these songs still sound moving and vital almost 2 decades later. This 3CD/DVD set is the most recent in the Metal Blade reissue series. Some of this material was never before released and some in other formats. Of note, the booklet has been expanded from 12 pages to 16 pages and while it contains the same âcontinuous flowâ of lyrics, the artwork is different. The 4 discs come housed in a quadruple gate-fold digi housed in a thin slipcase with matching artwork on the discs themselves.Disc 1 (Original Recording)With the release of APSOG in 1997 FW came full circle back to what they had started on Perfect Symmetry. Furthermore, in an effort to avoid a rehashing/repeating of what theyâd done previously (Inside Out too similar to Parallels), they actually expanded upon the creative foundation of Perfect Symmetry and in doing so delivered an epic masterpiece of truly inspiring and original progressive heavy music. With APSOG, FW not only built upon the ideas/styles they had experimented with on Perfect Symmetry but they subsequently firmly established their unique sound and identity. The sound quality was superb on the initial recording so no attempt has been made to add anything to the original master. The following is an excerpt from my review circa 1997:The concept â in 12 âpartsâ â is so beautifully orchestrated in that it flows from one âmovementâ to the next effortlessly over the course of its nearly 54 minute duration.  However, like most classical compositions, each segment has its own autonomous structure, style and tempo. Similarly, there is a theme (lyrical and musical) around which the entire piece revolves with its musical variations. The band plays like an ensemble here with each voice giving equal input throughout the composition. There are heavy movements and ballad-like movements with a full variety in between. The addition of Kevin Moore to the band for this studio release takes the quality up a notch as FW have never really had keyboard in their mix. While it takes a few or 10 spins to really appreciate whatâs going on here, this is not only the bandâs best work to date but likely represents a landmark release within the progressive metal genre.Disc 2 (Live)This disc contains the 12 "parts" from APSOG recorded to DAT in 1998 - which differs very little from the Live in Europe DVD performance from 1997 - and then the sound check "We Only Say Goodbye" version plus the studio cover of Scorpions "In Trance." With the exception of the barely audible opening theme/rain effects the audio fidelity here is excellent so this serves essentially as the CD companion to the DVD video included in this set. For those who own 1998âs Still Life there are some subtle differences to point out. Part I is about 40 seconds longer than the Still Life version because it includes those barely audible rain effects/theme. Also, I think the master volume of Still Life is louder and the crowd noise noticeably louder as well (something many fans complained about with that release). Different crowd chants and background noises, slight intonation differences in Alderâs voice/spoken word and overall sound quality lead me to suspect that the live takes that encompass this version are different from those culled for Still Life. I may be mistaken, but itâs worth noting for fans that may not want to purchase this version for fear of buying the same thing twice. Honestly, in my opinion, the live version is even better than the studio version. With audience participation and loads of cool keyboard effects, the band flawlessly performed this epic and beautiful work on multiple occasions â a testament to their talent, technical skill and creative genius.Disc 3 (Demos)Probably the most interesting disc in this particular collection, disc 3 includes 3 tracks and clocks in at 70 minutes. The first track is the vocal demo (1996) of APSOG - a 15 minute track featuring fragments of different "parts" mostly from the second half of the piece. While Alder's voice obviously stands out in this mix, it is also very interesting to hear the slight nuances here that didn't show up on the final recording. The second track (50 minutes) is really cool and includes pretty much the entire release without vocals. This is the conceptual writing demo from 1995 and so its the earliest version of the album we have and differs in many areas from the final recording - especially the electronic elements and transition points. Interestingly, while the vocal demo track features Zonder on acoustic drums, I would swear the drum track on the instrumental demo features the same rhythms but sounds like an electronic kit or programming. The kick drum has a lot more punch and there is very little resonance on any of the toms or cymbals - characteristics of either an ekit or programmed drums. The final track here is the "electronic remix" alternate version of "Part II," which despite the vocal distortion works pretty well. Honestly these versions are just as good as the original, just different. The more electronic influence may have been shunned by some but with APSOG being what it is, I think all these versions work great.Disc 4 (DVD)Those who never saw the original VHS version of the 1998 Europe tour are in for a real treat. And for those waiting for a hard DVD copy of this, well here it is in all its glory. And while this isn't high definition, the professionally recorded show is well done. Terry Brown's stereo audio mix is spectacular as well, especially in "5 Stereo" surround. For me the highlight is watching Zonder's drum performance - his traditional grip style tooling around on his hybrid electronic/acoustic double bass drum set up quite brilliant. Hybrid kits are all the rage now but in '98 this was pretty revolutionary. It's neat to see how many of the sounds are triggered. Another highlight would be the unison guitar/piano dual with Matheos and Roth in Part VIII - simply brilliant! Love the hilarious Alder "blooper" on the opening vocals which closes out the first recording. The '98 show at The Whisky is essentially bonus material (more stripped down with no visual effects), along with "We Only Say Goodbye" from the '99 Athens show.This set exceeds my expectations in terms of content, despite the fact that the budget digi packaging is a bit flimsy. For those that only own the original disc there is definitely enough here to make it worth the purchase. And the demo disc makes this set worthy for collectors and fans for sure.

Imagine 80âs Iron Maiden/mid 80âs Queensryche metal driven by the lyrical conviction and keyboards of Sacred Warrior and you have a good idea of what Millennial Reign is all about. Yet another fantastic band recently signed to Ulterium Records, these guys lay down the power metal with unabashed fervor. Their self-titled debut from 2012 was more of a solo project of ASKAâs Dave Harvey, but with new singer James Guest (Edenâs Realm) on board not only are they the âreal dealâ band but the guys have also really stepped up the quality â songwriting and execution. Guestâs voice is a good mix of Dickenson, Tate and Parra. A bit heavier, faster and more dynamic than Saint, these guys pay plenty of respects to Sacred Warrior and even Bloodgood with these songs (tons of layered vocals). And while they may lose a few marks for originality (lots of Iron Maiden influence here) there is no denying that if this had been released in 1988 during the peak of the early Christian metal movement this would have been huge. The guitars have plenty of that rhythmic crunch we metalheads crave yet there is plenty of melody, and the solos/leads shred. The drumming balances rhythm with speed and mixes things up pretty well â a nice balance between the more modern double bass driven power metal and the old-school McBrain gallops. Oddly, there is nothing in the credits to indicate who is performing the keyboard parts. I think the vocals overwhelm the mix just a bit, but overall these songs sound really good.Highlights include the inspirational and dynamic rocker âForever Changed,â âMillennial Reignâ (band-named metal anthems rule!), the hopeful âMen Stand Alone,â the Eastern-styled âInnocent Cryâ and the more melodic metal âNot On My Own.â And then finally the soaring âIâll Tryâ may just be the best track on the whole record â what a way to close out the set! Fans of inspirational metal which gives God the glory really have nowhere else to look for a new friend. Along with the new Stryper and Worldview releases, Carry The Fire does just that â keep it burning!

So anytime a band sets off to deliver a 2 or 3 part concept album over the course of multiple years itâs easy to question how consistent and cohesive the project will be by the time of its completion â¦ assuming it actually even reaches completion. So itâs a daunting task to say the least even for the greatest of bands. Even the mighty Dream Theater have never accomplished this feat (Metropolis the closest theyâve come to attempting) Well congratulations to Vanden Plas â a band quite accomplished in the realm of epic concept albums â for not only completing the task within a year but also for keeping the story, the sound quality and the production all consistent. For those not familiar with the first half of the project please refer to my review posted below. For those who have been eagerly awaiting the sequel to Path 1, you wonât be disappointed. As good as the opening act was, Path 2 is fierce, dark and delivers a much heavier collection of songs. One of my reservations with Path 1 was the somewhat more subdued nature of the songs â almost like the band was holding something back. Here, the tempo has been lifted throughout. And while there are still balladic moments throughout, I just think this disc is a much more intense listening experience. And while Vanden Plas has never been a shred band, these songs are crushing at times, yet remain melodic and passionate, which is the Vanden Plas way.Andy Kuntzâs ageless vocals still carry the band but everyone else has stepped up the performance factor as well â Wernoâs  synth contributions  coming to the forefront of the mix. His piano has always been integral to the Vanden Plas sound, but I love the diversity of keyboard sounds he brings forth on this disc. Andreas Lillâs drumming plays a greater role compared to Path 1 where he seemed to keep things fairly straight-forward â much more complexity, more double bass thumping and quite a bit more tempo all around. And the guitars of his brother Stephen Lill just shred â plenty of soloing leads this time around. I love the opening track âIn My Universeâ and the epic âBlood of Edenâ â a perfect song in 3 parts â the middle section with this insane âspeaking in tonguesâ vocal part where Kuntz showcases his talent for seamlessly shifting back and forth between multiple languages. For me this song is the highlight of the entire 2 disc project. Itâs dynamic, heavy, symphonic, melodic and beautiful all at the same time. The slightly commercial âMonsterâ is another hit where the main character realizes what he has become. âWhere Have the Children Goneâ is a dynamic power ballad which echoes back to Path 1 and then the tandem of âThe Last Fightâ and âCircle of the Devilâ serve as the grand finale to the story.With Path 2 not only has Vanden Plas effectively closed the circle on this series (in a timely fashion no less), but they have delivered yet another musical masterpiece â one which may just have topped all of their concept stories to date. Even if you are not a fan of the lyrical content (Iâm neutral not having read the books), the music alone will mesmerize.
