And for those who felt Path 1 was a bit more of a symphonic rock affair (and a bit subdued), I can assure you that Path 2 delivers a much more satisfyingly heavy progressive metal opera experience.For those that care about this kind of thing: the trifold digipak packaging is consistent from Path 1 to Path 2 yet the band pictures and graphics varied enough to give each Path its own distinctive "look."Path 1 - Germanyâs Vanden Plas, who started their career in the 90âs with a melodic metal style (Colour Temple) and then joined the commercial progressive metal genre ala Dream Theater with 1997âs The God Thing  and 1999âs Far Off Grace, have evolved into a progressive metal opera band over the course of the past decade. This new release follows in the same concept metal opera vein as 2006âs Christ O and 2010âs The Seraphic Clockwork.The band line-up remains basically intact with Stephen Lill (guitars), Gunter Werno (keys), Andreas Lill (drums) and Andy Kuntz (vocals) The new release is based on a series by the same name created by renowned German fantasy/sci-fi author Wolfgang Hohlbein who has been a fan of the band for some time and agreed to collaborate with them on this project. This is the first installment in the series. Without going in to much detail, the story chronicles the struggles of an immortal man to choose his destiny based on visions he is receiving from a satanic shape-shifter trying to trick him into giving up his humanity in exchange for the power to become a god.Musically, this follows closely with what has gone before, but I think the songs are better than on the last release. Kuntz sounds great â like his voice hasnât aged in the past 15 years â and Lillâs guitars anchor the Vanden Plas sound amidst the cacophony of choral arrangements, piano interludes and powerful drumming. Itâs basically a formula that has worked very well for this band for years and they remain consistent and engaging on all levels. Multi CD releases are tough to complete over long periods of time so I suspect we wonât have to wait another 4 or 5 years for the sequel. I donât really think there is anyone else out there right now doing the rock opera thing as well.

One of the most enduring and creative forces in the Australian metal scene would have to be Teramaze. These guys have been around now for 2 decades (okay Dean Wells at least) and have survived multiple line-up changes (death of drummer Julian Percy about ended the band forever), as well as multiple stylistic (thrash, melodic, progressive and even emo) and lyrical permutations (Christian on Doxology and Tears to Dust â spiritually neutral on later releases). And just when it seemed like they had strung together two stellar releases with the same singer, out went Bret Rerekura. Never fear, with 2015âs Her Halo we are introduced to the youthful and energetic Nathan Peachey, whose vocal style is clearly melodic and yet doesnât veer too far from the sound of Teramaze at least since 2012âs Anhedonia. Peachey also co-wrote the lyrics with Wells so we have perhaps now the most accessible and emotionally driven Teramaze record to date. And as with all things Teramaze, evolution/change is the word once again. Those expecting a return to the thrashy Anhedonia or even the highly complex and progressive metal outing that was Esoteric Symbolism might be disappointed. But for me, even as much as I love those records (as well as 1998âs Tears To Dust), Her Halo, which represents a whole new side to this band, might just be my favorite to date.First off, this is a concept album â one which is set within the context of a carnival and features a trapeze artist and her complex relationship with the ringmaster/leader of the show (âthe tyrantâ). It appears to describe a love/envious/jealous, co-dependence type relationship but Iâm merely speculating at this point based on my understanding of the lyrics. More importantly, this isnât a âstory-tellingâ concept but instead more a âplayâ of emotions and struggles âplaying outâ in somewhat cinematic fashion. While this isnât symphonic metal by any stretch, there are some moments where we hear the sound effects of carnival music, the crowd cheering, some spoken dialogue (that is difficult to discern without headphones), the girl screaming when she falls (âTrapezeâ) and the fire burning in the end. The music builds in crescendo fashion with the swells in action so there is definitely a dynamic going on here that was not quite as evident on the much more musically dense Esoteric and Anhedonia. And while Her Halo definitely has some really heavy guitar driven riffs in almost every song, these songs are more satisfyingly melodic â almost catchy â and diverse. Think a mix of Dream Theater, Circus Maximus, Evergrey, Seventh Wonder, Kamelot, Conception, Balance of Power and of course Teramaze themselves.Not one to comment on every track â I think the listener should still have some mystery to explore about the music after reading a review â I will mention a few highlights. The opening track is breathtaking in how the music depicts the dream-like and distorted world of performers in the carnival. Keyboards, sound effects, spoken parts, complex melodies and rhythms intertwine in a lengthy track that would definitely appeal to Dream Theater fans. I love how the piano closes out the song with an unresolved chord â brilliant! The title track follows the crunchy âTo Love, A Tyrantâ and is a wonderfully dynamic composition with great melodies and more emotion than weâve ever had from these guys. The keyboard parts are perfectly juxtaposed with the heavy guitars so it almost plays out like a power ballad. The next two songs âOut of Consciousâ and âFor the Innocentâ represent the more melodic and catchy moments on the disc â the songs flow effortlessly with a great pace. The latter song screams Khan/Karevik (Kamelot) in the vocals but is the most inspirational song here for sure. As a drummer, I have to interject here that Dean Kennedy (drums) has outdone himself with this release â the driving rhythms, with just the perfect balance of pedal and tom accents, are prog for sure yet never overdone. The album closes out with the instrumental âTrapezeâ (which to my ears draws on some riffs from the bandâs past), the ballad âBroken,â and the fitting finale âDelusions of Grandeurâ which is similar in structure, yet more stream-lined than the opener.Her Halo is not an album that you are going to pick up and immediately fall in love with based on initial impression. But Iâve come to the conclusion â after many listens â that from a songwriting standpoint itâs their most dynamic, most diverse record to date and Jacob Hansen has given them a sound that can only be described as sublime. Without a doubt, for me, this represents the âsurprise of the year.â

Itâs been a long time since Iâve listened to Def Leppard with a less than critical ear. The only albums that Iâve ever really embraced from these guys are High N Dry, Pyromania and Hysteria. Yeah, Iâve experienced Adrenalize and Slang, but really havenât embraced much since then from them. But one thing I concede is that theyâve always been consistent and persistent. And while Iâve always missed the hard rocking days of the 80âs I can appreciate what theyâve accomplished since those iconic years long ago. So I heard all the hype about this release, about how it was all about going back to the roots.  Suffice it to say, Iâm glad itâs true â this release is basically a âbest ofâ everything Def Leppard collection of original songs. Most of the first half of the album represents the best of the ânewerâ plush side of the band while the second half of the album is a sort-of return to the rock and roll roots of the band. âSea of Loveâ is unexpected bridge with a 70âs rock vibe that is a bit of a surprise but then is followed by the overly commercial âEnergizedâ which, despite its pop vibe, works surprisingly well â the 2 song sequence an exhibition on the dual nature of these iconic rockers.But Def Leppard is a rock band that does it right â great vocal harmonies, catchy phrases, great melodies and great solos â¦ and jangly guitars (âBattle of My Ownâ and âLast Danceâ)! This 53 minute affair is a feast for those who love commercial rock with elements from just about every era from 1970 to 2010. Yes, these lyrics are a bit clichÃ© but so what? More than anything, this album is tons of fun. Joe Elliot is not quite as edgy/raspy as in days past, but he sounds great and the band sounds vital as well. The production/recording quality allows for loud play without listener fatigue. Easily the best music theyâve created in more than 2 decades.

Wow! Every once in a while something comes along out of nowhere that surprises even the most vigilant fan of progressive metal. I keep a pretty persistent finger on the pulse of the genre, but when I heard Marco Minnemann, Mike Lepond and Henrik Bath (Darkwater) were planning a recording with Tom Frelek (who is this master anyway?) I was more than intrigued but I was thinking â¦ what an unusual list of suspects â¦ like how did these guys hook up, right? Symphony X is nowhere geographically in proximity to Sweden â¦ and Minnemann is an extremely talented drummer who plays with the likes of Steve Wilson and many other high profile artist. What is he doing playing on this kind of release? But really who cares? This stuff is great. Those familiar with Darkwater and Harmony will immediately recognize Bathâs distinctive voice, although he does mix it up a bit more on this release with some really diverse singing. Donât think super group because none of these guys are basking in big revenues from their day jobs â and Frelek is the writing force behind this machine anyway â but you can be assured that these guys have indeed crafted music that musicians will strongly embrace and appreciate, as will many fans of progressive music. At 78 minutes in duration, thatâs a good thing.So the instrumental opener âCognitionâ introduces the style â dynamic prog metal with keys (love the piano), percussive riffs and plenty of muscle â these songs veer more to the metal intense side than the smooth, trippy prog rock side. Most of these songs are pretty heavy as Minnemann puts on his metal boots and really slugs out some epic moments here, accompanied by the crunchy yet not monotonous guitars/bass of Frelek and Lepond. There is some shred here but its tastefully articulated into the body of songs so it never feels overdone or over indulgent. And with the first vocal track, âAberrationâ we are assured that melody is indeed the focus of the vocal assault. Without a doubt this is an inspirational album â the lyrical theme in line with âbe awake, be alert, wake up and see, know whatâs going on in the world â¦ yet know there is hope in overcoming the fear that is so pervasive in our minds/in our world.â (My paraphrases). Some of the songs contain inspirational fragments from Martin Luther King, F.D.R., Marianne Williamson, J.F.K. and Timothy Leary. The cool thing here is that while much of this is kind of âproggyâ it doesnât feel that way because these guys never fail to connect with core emotions and truths, and the music never strays too far into the stratosphere either. In fact, there are some really commercial sounding moments throughout (âAcross The Horizon.â) And what progressive metal album would be complete without the epic track? The 18 minute title track delivers in every way.In the end, I love it. I love it when a band comes along and grants us a refreshing perspective and isnât afraid to go for everything despite the current trends in music. This album is huge, and it will take many weeks to unravel everything they have to offer both lyrically and musically. As always, Ulterium Records continue to support and cultivate great independent artists and Waken Eyes is going to do a lot to bolster that credibility.

Review of DMM VinylAfter a long delay in the release sequence in this series (due to production issues) Exit Stage Left and Signals finally arrived almost within a few weeks of each other. While the somewhat highly criticized Exit was a nice interlude in the series, Signals was an album that I was really looking forward to in this series ... probably more so even than Moving Pictures. And while that release was clearly one of the best in the series, I was hopeful that Signals - with its "digital" synths - would sound equally amazing in this new analog version. Suffice it to say, I'm content. Mine arrived in near perfect condition - the only thing that seems askew is the slightly harsh noise between "Losing It" and "Countdown" on Side 2. Then again, there has been some variation in these records since the beginning of the series, some near perfect and others with a lot of pops and clicks. But there is a ton of bass tone on this pressing and at times it may slightly overwhelm Geddy's vocals. Still, it sounds amazing.Signals was a bit of a difficult record for me back when it was released because when you judge this in the footsteps of Moving Pictures it maybe felt like a bit of a let down. In fact, for many years I didn't even listen to these songs other than what played seemingly endlessly on the radio. But over time, as I listened to it on its own merit I grew in appreciation for what was going on musically and lyrically. Peart's reggae-like rhythms on "New World Man" and "Digital Man" really stand out now to me more so than they did back in the day. His role was a bit more of the rhythm driver on Signals rather than a virtuoso percussionist. And those synth sounds that everyone was so apprehensive about in the early 80's still sound perfect (especially on this vinyl) in 2015. This entire album really was/is the perfect blend of analog and digital - the merging of the old school and new (at least at that point in time) and it was quite genius how well they blended the two worlds, making this album the perfect bridge between Moving Pictures and the much more stripped down and commercial Grace Under Pressure. And most importantly, some 30 years later, these songs still move me - "Subdivisions," "The Analog Kid" and the progressive "The Weapon" ...  and then there is "Countdown," with its musical embellishment of the Columbia's history-making launch, which still to this day sends chills down my spine.

In 2013, Stryper made a huge statement with No More Hell To Pay â no longer would they be content to wallow in the mediocre world of popular rock. That collection of original rockers resonated with the history of this band, their sound and their mission â to rock the hell out of you! The fans loved and embraced it, but when queried via social media, requested heavier and louder. So in response the band delivered Fallen, which is in essence, the perfect sequel to No More Hell To Pay. Many of these songs are indeed bold, riff-heavy, filled with shred and, yes with a few exceptions (âLove You Like I Doâ and âAll Over Againâ) they even rock just a bit harder. One aspect that really jumped out of the speakers at me was how absolutely perfect the huge punchy bass drum sound projects â that live kick that literally thumps the heart â and also how the mix really has a metal edge. As a band these guys are gelling in every aspect and that is certainly exciting to see at this later stage of their career. Too many highlights here, but the first 3 tracks, âHeaven,â âLet There Be Light,â and âKing of Kingsâ really do it for me, as does the cover of Sabbathâs âAfter Forever.âLyrically Stryper is delivering the same message/good news that theyâve been singing about since their buzz saw guitars first carved out their niche in the Hollywood metal scene over 30 years ago  â¦ and they do it with a humble conviction and sincerity that is unrivaled. I have to say, though, that Iâm a bit cautious of those touting this as the best and most important Stryper release ever. The enthusiasm over this release is without a doubt well-earned but a classic is defined by more than just a great start out of the gates and only time will tell how well these songs hold up. Consider how many lives an album like Soldiers Under Command or To Hell With the Devil have impacted? Still, there is no denying the positive push Fallen generates. Those who have been ardent fans since the beginning can take comfort in knowing that not only is Stryper committed to the metal cause and to their fans, but most importantly, they are still following their calling.Can't wait to get my white vinyl version next month!

When their first full concept album was released in 2000 (their only on Metal Blade Records) Symphony X was certainly at the top of the progressive/power scene. After two stellar releases in a row it was hard to imagine how the band would improve on their sound, but they did. While there was not a huge deviation or progression from the previous sound, there was plenty to boast of here. The biggest endeavor was to pull off the full concept album. While they dabbled with the concept idea on Divine Wings Of Tragedy, they had never previously devoted a whole album to one concept. Fan of mythology or not,the story played out nicely here and the story was well orchestrated for metal. The song structures matured with more of a 5 piece presentation than just Romeo/Pinella duel soloing. Lepond and Rullo (who returned to the drum throne here) stepped up the intricacy and intensity of their contributions as well. Allen's vocal performance remained as solid and consistent as ever, but as a whole, they had never sounded better. Like a symphony, to this day, the songs really flow effortlessly one into the other, which really gave this work credibility as a total concept piece. The heavy riffs were retained, but the neoclassical feel of the Twilight was replaced with a more pure, more original Symphony X sound. Fans of the old band could still enjoy all of the shredding, but the melodies and intricate rhythms really came to the forefront. And even though the band added some cool effects to the music, this is still metal. At the time I remember thinking Power Of Omens type technical metal on a few of these songs, but Symphony X always has their much more guitar riff driven and powerful sound. The big cathedral sounding vocal harmonies (ala Divine Wings of Tragedy) returned here in grand fashion as well. For fans of mythology and Greek and Roman mysticism this release was lyrically intriguing but was for me the only weakness. Later concept albums Paradise Lost and Iconoclast hold much more interest in that regard. Still, it has never kept me from marking it a perfect album. Clearly, this was at the time (and remains to this day) one of the best power/progressive releases ever, and from a purely musical standpoint it was the bands' best work to date.

It is extremely difficult to follow up a masterpiece with something worthy in comparison. However, Symphony X not only succeeded in this endeavor, but they did so even within the span of one year and while enduring the exit of drummer Jason Rullo. Easy to say, Twilight lived up pretty well to the expectations of the fans, although there was a bit more progressive, melodic here which often lands this disc in a slightly less favorable category than Divine Wings of Tragedy. Despite criticisms, minus the big operatic vocals and choral sections, this disc felt almost like Divine Wings of Tragedy-Part II. Lyrically, however, they did tackle some different issues. Still, there really wasn't much change in style and I wonder if all these songs were mostly written when they released Divine - the song arrangement and selection very similar to the aforementioned masterpiece. Drummer Walling filled in for Rullo in grand fashion, just listen to the thundering intro to "Dragon's Den" to see what I mean. And overall, there was no let down in the quality of songwriting. The only fair criticism might be that they repeated themselves a bit on this release. Highlights include the beautiful ballad "Lady of the Snow" with its Japanese guitar line and "Church of the Machine," which remains a magnificent song with some really cool lyrics and a very progressive vibe. The heaviest tune, "Orion," echoed the heavier moments from the previous release and the epic tune "Through the Looking Glass" once again showcased the diversity and songwriting talents of this quintet. What else can be said, while Twilight stood in the "twilight" of the epic Divine Wings, its still maintained excellence and holds up very well to repeated play this many years later.

From a purely musical standpoint this album was and remains monumental - a testament to the creativity, power and passion of these 5 talented musicians. Listening to this again more than 15 years after I first fell in love with this band I still find these songs incredibly uplifting and powerful. While the progressive and lengthy nature of the songs definitely tipped (at the time) the sound in the direction of Dream Theater, these guys brandished a non-commercial, more classic pure power metal crunch that was second to none. Yet they also weaved this incredible operatic and classical fabric into the songs. In fact, to this day, I still quote this album as one of the best mixes of progressive and classical metal ever produced. And in addition to the new musical direction, Russ Allen hit his stride in this his first fully collaborative work with the band. His performance here is just superb, offering a nice mixture of intense/urgent and melodic styles. Musically, Romeo just shreds and the interplay between he and keyboardist Pinella would become a signature style for this band going forward. Despite the lengthy nature of many of the songs, the continuity during solo and breakout sections is maintained in a fashion that never grows dull. Rounded out by the punishing bass work of Lepond and Jason Rullo's dynamic drumming (the perfect blend of progressive and power metal drumming)this album captured a lot of attention, rightfully so. Some have criticized these songs as not being heavy (in comparison to say Iconoclast or Paradise Lost) but while there are more melodious, open and softer contrasts here, these songs are heavy metal. Just listen to any of the crushing riffs in "Of Sins and Shadows," "Sea of Lies," "The Witching Hour" or one of my favorites, "Pharaoh."While all of the songs here are riveting, 3 songs stand out this many years later (as did they back in the late 90's): the power ballad "The Accolade" remains a fan favorite - a song which not only showcases the bands' diversity but also their penchant for writing a lyric and melody that is quite infectious. And then the tandem of the epic 20 minute title track - replete with choral arrangements and a sweeping tale of epic woe and as much instrumental prowess anyone would covet from a progressive band - followed by the surprisingly beautiful "Candlelight Fantasia" remains a perfect finish to one of the greatest progressive metal recordings ever. With Divine Wings of Tragedy Symphony X set the highest standard musically in this genre and it is no surprise that this has become a classic in the progressive power metal genre.

Eight months on the heels of the promising, yet somewhat anemic debut/demo, the band somehow produced and recorded a follow up. More focused, and certainly better sounding than the debut, the band began to evolve into a real entity with this release, but the vibe was very similar to the debut, largely because all these songs were written by the band with Rod Tyler on vocals, who was replaced at the last minute by Russ Allen, who's vocal performance was solid but somewhat hurried. Fortunately, his style matched the bands' intensity and style perfectly but his input was too late to change the songs much, so in essence, this is what the first album might have been with Russ Allen on vocals. In other words, the band was not a band yet with all 5 members contributing to the overall sound and the result is a less than perfect, yet impressive collection of nicely produced neoclassical metal. This perhaps explains why some of these songs are incredible, like "The Edge of Forever," and others just mediocre, like the title track, which has an extremely annoying chorus where Russ sounds uncomfortable. Likewise, the music on "Dressed to Kill" is good enough, but the vocals just sound awkward. Lyrically,they definitely deviated from the typical thinking man's metal type thought processes so common to the progressive genre. It is, however, this crossover of traditional/power metal lyrics with modern progressive metal that has set them apart from their peers and it is really neat to hear the origin of this style on the first two albums. Still, songs like "Whispers" that have a positive vibe lyrically and musically would continue to appear on later releases. One aspect of this album that is really enjoyable is the more open nature of the vocals. Nowhere else do we hear Russ's voice so exposed as on songs like "Whispers," "Secrets" and to the biggest degree on the "Winter's Dream," a song which really showcases his melodic quality. More diverse and dynamic, armed now with a credible and compatible vocalist, Symphony X would never look back. They had already pioneered a sound unique to the metal world and with this release really got the world's attention. With time and growth as a unit, these guys would go on to deliver classic metal masterpieces like The Divine Wings of Tragedy and The Odyssey.

So this is where it all began for one of the greatest progressive metal bands of the modern era. Inside Out, as part of their Special Edition series, released the band's first 4 discs in this format. Unfortunately, they were not remastered so there are no sound improvements here, which for this debut/demo release (as Michael Romeo refers to it in the macromedia interview contained on this enhanced version) is a big disappointment. While the majority of these songs are very average it is really interesting to hear the concepts and sounds that were present during the genesis of this band that would survive to later define the band's signature sound. Take the Queen-like vocal harmonies in "The Raging Season" or the neoclassical opening to the "Masquerade." Likewise, the heavy, yet lurching riffage at the beginning of "Absinthe and Rue" would become a staple for this bands rhythmic power metal sound in later masterpieces. Even the epic "A Lesson Before Dying," which falls quite short of epic glory, gave hints not only to the bands talent but also to the musical and lyrical direction that this band would travel. The epic neoclassical progressive concept piece was really an original Symphony X contribution to the metal world because at the time no one was really doing this kind of thing in power metal.  Nevertheless, despite the early signs of brilliance, even the band would admit that this album was plagued with mediocrity, most notably in the production department. More importantly, the lackluster vocals of Rod Tyler seem thin and just don't seem to match up with the intensity of the music. For instance, the semi-ballad "Shades of Grey" just doesn't work and from this point the band never delved into the realm of commercial metal again. While the band has toyed with the idea of rerecording this album with Russ Allen on board, it doesn't sound like that is going to happen anytime soon (as Mike points out on the interview) because there are just too many weak moments or songs that just don't fit at all with the bands current musical direction. Despite its shortcomings, fans of the band will want to get this collector's piece because many of these songs may never again resurface.

Basically since 2007's Colors, with the exception possibly of the less than brilliant EP, little this band has produced has failed to enthrall. Parallax II: Future Sequence was, in my opinion, the pinnacle of the band's output in terms of shear mind-boggling technical brilliance married to an elusive, yet creative (sci-fi) concept. With that release they not only cemented their place in progressive metal history (one could fairly argue Colors and The Great Misdirect did the same) but also truly branded their own style.  Honestly, I didn't think it would be possible for them to get any better on that level and therefore am glad that instead of trying to repeat or better the effort, they've in fact, moved in a slightly different direction - one which clearly focuses more on melody yet is no less intense. And unlike Opeth, which went totally 70's prog with their most recent, I think BTBAM have accomplished this without sacrificing their trademark sound - one which they've worked for the better part of a decade to establish.So Coma Ecliptic is a different beast, yet it's comfortably within the scope of BTBAM. For the sake of those who are not familiar with this band (and with no insult to those who've been following them since Alaska days) I would say this is not their most innovative/original work - but it might just be their most accessible. Musically, if you could put the emotional tension (and slightly more melodic leanings) of Steve Wilson, the aggression of Opeth (up through Watershed anyway) and the furious technical brilliance of Dream Theater into one album I think that it might look and sound something like this. Unfortunately, it's not that simple and comparisons like that aren't fair to a band as original in sound as BTBAM. Still, it's a start - one way to depict with words the greatness of what's going on here. Many have speculated on the lyrics and the concept. They are very Steve Wilson-like in that much is left to the speculation/interpretation of the listener. No story here, the concepts of these songs are honestly elusive, and while there is a clear theme (a comatose individual reflecting on a whole lot of things) I don't so clearly see the different possible lives to which some have alluded.  The paradoxical nature of the song titles is however quite brilliant.While Rogers' melodic singing - which has a slight Cynic/Paul Masvidal vibe - comes to the forefront (Mastodon has done the same in recent years), the harsh vocals (still mostly discernable by the way) remain on the majority of songs here. I would argue they are an essential part of the BTBAM sound because the dynamic contrast they invoke is one of the exciting aspects of the band's music. However, songs like the introductory "Node" and the trance-like interlude "Dim Ignition" are perfectly wonderful with no screaming. In fact, it would have been nice to see the electronic ideas in the latter song developed a bit more on this release. Still, while keyboards do play a big role here, this is by no means a negative - there still is a ton of heaviness, speed and aggression.In summary, might be a bit of a polarizing release for the band, but in no way do I find that a negative. In fact, I suspect (as is the case with most "progressive" music) repeated listens will reveal much more than I can comment on here. These guys remain one of the best, most innovative bands in the scene, and they should be commended for their commitment to always pushing the envelope.

Muse certainly has a gift for the unexpected - each release different, yet familiar all in the same. Drones is no exception - the utilitarian packaging and drab colored cover artwork the first indication that this would be a departure (both in presentation and sound) from the slick and glossy nature of the The 2nd Law. And while it's still slick/glossy at times ("Dead Inside") most of this is a return to good commercial rock sensibility. The great riff and catchiness of "Psycho" sets the tone for the rest of this dystopian concept record. And in that regard it's great to see a band with this much influence in the pop music culture make a recording that works best by actually listening from start to finish - the way many of us who grew up in the 70's with vinyl still prefer to listen to music.Muse has always reminded me of Queen in so many ways - in the way they incorporate so many musical styles and cultural trends into their music - and with this very diverse collection of songs  Muse succeeds in this regard, yet all the while maintaining their own style/sound/attitude. "Reapers" is a great example - the song sounds like Van Halen (opening lead solo) meets Aerosmith (riff in the chorus section) but then "Muse" kicks in during the middle section solo section with the crazy effects. Similarly, "The Handler" and the epic "The Globalist" dazzle with quite a bit of musical wizardry. "Mercy" is probably one of the strongest songs on the record where the music perfectly enhances lyrics. The spoken parts are a bit distracting (and at times unnecessary) but I will say that hearing JFK's speech is eerie - very prophetic - and I like the interspersed sound effects on that track. And on the track which follows, "Defector," the Queen-like chorus is nicely juxtaposed to the Muse quirkiness. Of course, Bellamy's love and respect for classical music shines forth with the cleverly and ingeniously arranged version of Da Palestrina's "Sanctus and Benedictus." Overall, Drones easily represents their best work since Black Holes and Revolutions and this just keeps getting better with repeated play.

By nature, instrumental music gravitates toward the self-indulgent, so expectations here should not be for anything less than experimental, technical brilliance with tons of soloing and challenging rhythms. This is now the third installment for Abnormal Thought Patterns (the instrumental trio of Jasun and Troy Tipton plus drummer Mike Guy), the debut release in 2011 and the second in 2013 (Manipulation Under Anesthesia). Furthermore, those already familiar with Jason and Troy Tipton's work with Zero Hour (and their newer, somewhat less technically complex incarnation Cynthesis) are aware that their style of progressive metal is quite unique - complex, rhythmic yet melodic all the same. This time around they've employed the help of Jason Montero (guitars), and guests Tim Roth (Into Eternity), Jeff Loomis (Nevermore), John Onder and the venerable Michael Manring (fretless bass). Most surprising is the appearance of Tommy Rogers (Between the Buried and Me) on the releases' only vocal track "Nocturnal Haven." And while they really aren't treading any new waters here, the production quality and sound is perhaps the best of the three ATP releases so far.Just shy of 50 minutes, there is plenty to enjoy and absorb, but it's worth noting that "Nocturnal Haven," a vocal version and an instrumental version included, comprises nearly half of the disc. Because the vocals give the song such a different vibe, it still really feels like two different tracks, so those who are worried about being cheated out of full length have nothing to fear. I believe the solos are different as well. The vocal version features the dynamic Rogers harsh alternating with melodic vocals fans of his band are already very familiar with. He sounds very at home with the Tipton boys here which should not be surprising given the nature of the mathematical genius of BTBAM. The instrumental version features some amazing fretwork from Jeff Loomis, Tim Roth, Jason Montero and of course the mastermind behind this project Jasun Tipton himself. While this is certainly the feature track here, the other tracks are quite impressive as well, particularly "Synesthesia" - featuring incredible bass work by Troy and Manring - and my favorite track "Delusions," which features some nice percussion work by the unsung hero Mike Guy. He may not be a Portnoy/Peart acolyte but his style of heavy percussive drumming - at times more straight ahead than many prog drummers - suits this music well and he has been with the Tipton brothers since the inception of Zero Hour.Overall, while not the kind of music you rock out to cruising down the highway, the Tipton brothers have managed to once again dazzle with their creativity and technical prowess. Always edgy, progressive and modern, Altered States never fails to engage/enthrall.

Without a doubt, The Skull's debut release is the 2014 wins the sleeper of the year award in my book. Not only did I miss this release the first time around, but when I first listened to this nearly a month ago I was a bit unsure. Safe to say, that initial impression was totally unfounded. Once these doomy hooks and trippy lyrics (just listen to the opening track) infiltrate the spaces in your brain listening to this music becomes a totally immersive head-banging experience. From the heavy, distorted guitar riffs to the wild bass reverb to the plodding and lurching drums to Eric Wagner's "Jim Morrison-like" voice these songs bleed with heavy metal reality.I suspect my initial bias against this may have been partly due to the evanescent nature of the band since inception (2012) with the revolving door of players, particularly drummer Jeff Olson. Also, my doubts about this essentially Trouble "reunion" band being able to pull it all together tainted my initial impressions. Once again, I was wrong. But while these songs echo much of Trouble's early sound (particularly Psalm 9 and The Skull), this band is a different entity with other (Pentagram) influences. In a way, in my head and as strange as it may sound, this music sounds like a mix of Sabbath and The Doors. Perhaps the song "The Door" ironically reminds me the most of the latter band, but even the swingy feel to "Send Judas Down" with the controversial lyrics reminds me a lot of Morrison for some reason. Wagner's haunting spoken word in the breakdown section is akin to something Morrison or even Peter Steele might have attempted. Lyrically most of this album is very consistent with early Trouble, but yet this music feels fresh and full of rays of hope and light. I absolutely love the epic title track. Not only is this an amazing song from the doom metal aspect, but the sobering lyrics are an inspiration as to how we should be reaching out instead of condemning everything around us. It is easy to recommend this to fans of early Trouble, yet anyone who misses the more organic and less processed feel of vintage metal will find this rewarding on many levels.

Now with a permanent singer and this new 6 track EP the band has finally nailed it. They've delivered 5 great original songs plus the Malmsteem cover track. Multi-vocalist releases are fun but to me the band now feels like a very tight unit with their own identity. The songs are hard-driving, melodic and uplifting all at the same time. Plenty of neoclassical virtuosity here and tons of guitar crunch and the new vocalist really stands out with great clarity. I think the biggest improvement is just the great songwriting quality and that these songs are so darn catchy. Along with the new Within Silence release, Eastern European metal is making a strong statement and kudos to Ulterium for putting out such great music this past year. Look forward to hearing a new full length with this line-up but for now will be wearing this out!

Within Silence (formerly Rightdoor) is a high quality melodic power metal band recently signed to Ulterium, and Gallery of Life is their very solid debut. This youthful 5 piece Slovakian band has a very credible twin guitar attack with plenty of heavy, melodic riffing and a singer that has the pipes to carry the music. Martin Klein sounds like a cross between Herbie Langhans and Bruce Dickinson - more like the former due to his thick East European accent ... and the accent/vocal phrasings are the only thing slightly negative about this otherwise very talented and powerful singer. Guitarist Richard Germanus contributes some pretty cool harsh vocals on a few tracks (which works pretty well for the most part but nods a bit to the current trend in metal) in addition to his very competent shredding. Producer Jan Cvercko contributes the keyboards here, providing more atmosphere than melody but sometimes contributing to the melody as well. Expect quality drumming as well, driven by fast double bass as would be typical for the genre. Musically this band really reminds me of Seventh Avenue but there are hints of Iron Maiden, especially with the way the lead guitars drive the melody much of the time ("Judgement Day" in particular). Still, the formula is more Euro power metal than traditional British metal.There are some fantastic songs here, like the aforementioned "Judgment Day" and the entire first 5 tracks (not including the intro which is unnecessary in my opinion) which really shred. Lyrically these guys are unabashedly Christian, and for the most part they steer clear of cheesy material. While "World of Slavery" is a great metal anthem, with a really catchy chorus and Celtic riffing throughout, I think "Road to the Paradise" suffers a bit of a letdown in quality - the vocal phrasing near the end a bit awkward at the end of the song - but it's still a good song. Regardless, Within Silence can be very proud of what they've delivered with this debut and I am definitely excited about their future. Recommended for fans of power metal in general, but particularly those of Theocracy, Seventh Avenue and the first Sinbreed release.

So I had wondered why the second half of the "e" in the Savatage logo was missing from the spines of my Ear Music reissue collection ... and here is the final installment. Little did I know this version of Streets was even in the works let alone with a DVD full of additional bonus material and music videos spanning the years from 1987-1996. Additionally, "Larry Elbows" shows up at the end of the Streets disc as a missing chapter from the opera. First of all, the Ear Music reissues have been a great series with a plethora of insightful commentary by Jon Oliva, sharp-looking packaging and some bonus material. This tri-fold digi-pak is no exception and the liner book contains all of the original lyrics and narration plus extra photos and Oliva's interesting commentary on the 9 videos. It's nice to have all this in one package - especially the videos in one place - but the extra audio songs on the DVD, while nice, were probably not necessary. In any case, the narrated version of Streets is the main reason for the purchase here (other than to round out the collection of course). Oliva explains how he had to alter his voice for the narration but I really think it makes the whole composition feel more cohesive and more like the "opera" it was designed to be. The narrated tracks seem louder than the song tracks but otherwise this works well. One of the highlights would have to be the background "street" noises that were added to the narration giving the story a more authentic feel. Apparently these sounds were literally culled from the streets of NYC. Nice. Not much else to say about one of the most beloved concept rock pieces ever except that now it is nice to have both versions. Essential for fans of Savatage.

It has been a long 3 years since the excellent Tommy Karevik debut (Silverthorn) with Kamelot and so Haven comes with much anticipation for long-time fans. First impressions are important, and on that front this release sounds really good. In fact, these songs sound great. Where Silverthorn was deeply conceptual - both in presentation and in musical continuity - Haven is loosely conceptual (no storytelling here) yet musically no less intense. Actually, these songs are really heavy for Kamelot and this may be their most musically aggressive release since The Fourth Legacy. I love this band because they perfectly meld traditional power, symphonic and progressive metal in a way really not matched by anyone out there. And while the departure of Roy Khan was a big event, Tommy Karevik is the perfect replacement - he proved that on Silverthorn and once again demonstrates his vocal brilliance on this release. To me, the vocal mix is perfect, but the music takes on a much bigger role here which is positive.So there is no big story this time, but the songs do have a lyrical focus - with the brutality of the world around us and our own personal demons where do we go for a haven? There is no fantasy here - these are lyrics we can all relate to. In this regard "My Therapy" is a highlight for sure - "Come and take me off my daily dose of pain/take me off and shelter me." Yeah that.One of the great things about Kamelot is that they sound like Kamelot. This is a compliment of course and probably partly due to long-time producer Sascha Paeth who has been helping to steer the course of this band for over a decade. Sacha Paeth is to Kamelot what Paul O'Neill was to Savatage. So everything from the songwriting to the concept to the presentation to the media is brilliant. And let's not forget these very talented musicians. Youngblood has never been a shredder, yet he perfectly plays his part in this theater, along with drummer Casey Grillo who puts forth one of his best performances to date. In the tradition of cooperation, label mate Charlotte Wessels (Delain) lends her very capable voice in duet with Karevik on the melancholy "Under Grey Skies." Alissa White-Gluz contributes her harsh and melodic vocals on two of the strongest tracks here - "Liar Liar" and "Revolution." Her shrill vocals on these two tracks lends to the heavy nature of both the music and the lyrics. And the choral elements are still present as well so there are plenty of connections with prior works - it all comes together very well.Whereas the first part of the album is pretty much in the traditional Kamelot vein, the final four full length songs really make this album special because they are emotionally and musically intense - dark yet hopeful, the Kamelot paradox. "Here's To The Fall" is a hauntingly beautiful ballad that perfectly encapsulates the themes of the record and is followed by the climactic "Revolution" - one of the heaviest Kamelot tunes to date. Grillo's uncharacteristic four on the floor approach to the beat is a refreshing change-up from the 16th and 32nd note driven speed he so often delivers. The instrumental title track closes things out in cinematic fashion. Overall, while not quite as enthralling as the complex and emotional Silverthorn, Haven is an excellent follow-up and one of the heaviest Kamelot releases ever.This is the jewel case version but Napalm has released this in Mediabook edition with bonus instrumental CD, limited edition versions in earbook, canvas and wooden box versions (all with the 2 CDs) and finally an LP version. Sadly the limited edition versions were only released in 500 quantity counts and were directly sold from Napalm.

Okay so I don't usually review women's shoes but I bought these for my wife as a birthday gift and she loves these. We had bought the same shoe last year from Dillards in another color and she loved them so much she requested them in black. Prior to last year we had never heard of this brand but the shoes are made in Vietnam and are made in European sizes. Lightweight but with much more comfort and support than most dressier shoes, these are one of the most comfortable heeled shoes my wife has ever worn and they look great so work well for casual to semi-formal. One of the best features is the Velcro on all three leather straps which makes these immensely adjustable yet you wouldn't know just looking at it. All of the colors have a slightly different textured pattern - the black (purchased here) has a slightly snakeskin appearance. And from my perspective the shoe is very sexy.

Ambeon = "ambient" plus Ayreon. In 2001 Arjen Lucassen discovered 14 year old Astrid Van Der Veen, combined some of the elements of Ayreon's music to create the enthralling 10 song underground release. Now, he has added a few tracks and included a whole second disc which contains an unplugged concert featuring Atrid, Arjen, Ewa Albering (flute) and Dewi Kerstens (cello) playing most of the songs from Fate of a Dreamer plus Ayreon songs. All this is packaged in a lush tri-fold digipak with new liner notes by Arjen. Pretty much everything the man touches is gold, and these somewhat dark, yet futuristic tunes are no exception. Astrid no longer sings - according to the liner notes - and is now an artist, but her ethereal voice on these recordings is certainly captivating.

Vinyl VersionRush continued to expand their sound with this release. Instead of one long 20 minute opus this time they honed it down to two smaller compositions, the first of which is one of the band's most beloved tunes of all time "Xanadu" and the second the first part of a larger composition that would culminate on the next release Hemispheres. Just about no one was writing in this style at the time especially not with the confidence to record a prequel on one record and the sequel on another. In order to expand their sound, Peart incorporated all kinds of percussion equipment, such as the tubular bells, orchestra bells, chimes and the vibra slap to name a few. Lee and Lifeson also added a few tools to their arsenal as well with the bass pedals, Mini Moog and those ridiculous 12 string guitars. Of course while the epic songs here showcased the band's penchant for prog extravagance, the melodic and moving "Closer To The Heart" - as well as the simple, yet entertaining "Cinderella Man" - nicely balanced the "heady" works to provide the band's best and most diverse recording up to that point in time. "Cygnus X-1" is the highlight and remains one of my favorite Rush songs ever. From the very sci-fi sound effects in the intro to the throbbing bass riffing and stellar guitar leads, this song just is just so cool. Overall, this album - while not as groundbreaking as 2112 - was a refinement in the Rush sound and a definite improvement in song-writing quality compared to its predecessor.My vinyl version arrived in excellent condition and sounds perfect. In addition to the double gate-fold replica (with lyrics printed inside the gate-fold)and the FLAC download card there is a photo sheet reproduction from the original album sleeve. Really, for those that have never heard these Rush albums on vinyl you are in for a treat, and for those of us that grew up on a steady diet listening to these records over and over again, this is not only a great trip down memory but this release has never sounded better.

The magical collaboration of Rob Rock and Chris Impellitteri, which began all the way back in 1987 with the self-titled EP, has long been a successful venture. Ever since I first heard the Victim of the System EP in '93 I was hooked on this amazing combination of Rock's powerful vocals and Impellitteri's virtuoso guitar leads and solos. And although there has been a whole bevy of talented musicians who have worked with the band over the past 2 decades, Rock and Impellitteri have remained the core of the band's success. In essence, their work together eclipses what either have accomplished doing their own separate thing - and that says a lot.Venom picks up right where 2009's Wicked Maiden left off and that's no easy task. Wicked Maiden (the release which marked the return of Rob Rock to the band after a hiatus for 2002's System X and 2004's Pedal To The Metal) was a brilliant amalgamation of elements from their best albums: the melodic hooks of Answer To The Master and the speed, heaviness and progressiveness of Screaming Symphony. Venom is a beast for sure, once again featuring catchy melodies and superb guitar leads. Impellitteri (who like Tourniquet drummer Ted Kirkpatrick is heavily influenced by the classical composers) has such a distinctive style that the music is immediately identifiable - speedy melodic metal with catchy riffs and really fast guitar solos. It's shred and it's definitely not dead. No ballads here. The more than capable southpaw John Dette - who has played with the likes of Killing Machine, Testament, Slayer and Animetal (with Impellitteri himself) - steps in on drums and delivers a performance on par with the style put forth by Glen Sobel on the last release - lots of double bass sixteenth note rolls. Long time Impellitteri bassist James Pulli rounds out the foursome. The culmination of sounds is a melodic metal shred fest - wonderfully produced - that is second to none.While many of the songs are quite up-tempo, there are a few slower rockers like the quintessential Impellitteri "Face the Enemy" with its plodding and mesmerizing lead riff. Chris's solo on this song is short but sweet, every note perfectly placed and executed. "Nightmare" has a slightly modern vibe and "Rise" has a really sick opening riff followed by a great exhortational chorus. The break out/solo section smokes as well. Lyrically this stuff is totally consistent with Rock's prior output of scathing/warning type lyrics mixed with uplifting and powerful praises and metal anthems. The "bonus" tracks - not an afterthought by any means - feel more like a continuation of the powerful pummeling that has come before so definitely worth obtaining the version with these songs.It's easy to recommend this release for fans of the band of course but also to anyone who misses true shred. And if you've never heard these guys before ... no better time than the present to taste this venom!

One of the best releases from 2012Lucassen's second "solo" release continues (both musically and lyrically) somewhat in the Ayreon vein, but instead of employing the help of a multitude of singers, he handles all the vocals himself - oh yeah, and he does it with ease and clarity. The concept here plays off the themes from the Ayreon series as Mr. L. returns to the future from stasis and is guided by Dr. Voight-Kampff (voice of Rutger Hauer) on a tour through "the new real." Not surprisingly, there is plenty of humor here - Arjen never one to take himself (or his music) too seriously. While most of the situations here are pure fantasy/sci-fi, one can't help but marvel at the prophetic nature of the topics presented in songs like "E-police," "Parental Procreation Permit" or even "Dr. Slumber's Eternity Home." Its great stuff lyrically and conceptually and Hauer's "flat affect" as he presents information to Mr. L., just adds to the absurdity (and the credibility) of it all. Musically, this could best be defined as progressive rock with a heavy, trippy vibe. It's classic Lucassen really and no fan of his music will be disappointed by these catchy, clever and melodic tunes.Disc 2 contains five songs that were created for, but not included in, the "new real" as well as covers of some great tunes from the era of psychedelic rock. Of these original compositions, the two standouts are "The Social Recluse" - a commentary on the hazards of living in "virtual reality" - and "The Space Hotel." In the end, though, these songs are not essential. For me, the two highlights on the second disc are the cover of Floyd's "Welcome to the Machine" - a really heavy version of this classic tune - and the cover of BOC's "Veteran of the Psychic Wars" - a long lost classic. Zeppelin fans will love the "Battle Of Evermore" as well, but this version adds little to that classic. And what prog disc would be complete without a Zappa ("I'm The Slime") tune?As always, the production quality on both discs is fantastic, and the hard book digi is beautifully crafted with amazing artwork to boot. Overall, while fans of Arjen's heavier works may be a bit disappointed by the lack of "metal" on this release, most of his followers - as well as any die-hard fan of prog and 70's rock - will thoroughly enjoy this insightful and entertaining project. This man can do no wrong!

Classic Lacuna Coil. Sporting a fantastic cover, Dark Adrenaline revisits the heaviness of Karmacode and the catchy melodies of Comalies. This is simply a divine performance by Cristina and company - perhaps their strongest ever - and definitely one of the best releases of 2012. After perhaps 20 spins of this CD, I've yet to tire of the interplay between Cristina and Andrea - and the riffs feel heavier this time around, a decidedly more metal approach when compared to Shallow Life. The deluxe package version contains a very cool poster of the cover picture, a guitar pick, a "dark adrenaline" sticker and the Dark Passengers DVD. The latter contains 6 very creative, "indie" mini movies with various themes (mostly the horror type) - the soundtrack the instrumental versions of many of the songs on the release. In fact, by listening to the DVD tracks (sans vocals) a greater appreciation of the quality of the music is fostered. For Lacuna Coil the instruments always provide the backdrop for what the vocalists are doing, but with Dark Adrenaline, both are balanced to near perfection.

For those not familiar with Eden's Curse, now is a great time to discover this very talented and persevering melodic rock/metal band. This multi-nation band has been around for almost a decade and despite enduring multiple line-up changes (and almost calling it quits) they have released 4 great albums. Anchored by original members Paul Logue (bass and production) and Thorsten Koehne (guitars) they've managed to craft some really high quality music during that time. Michael Eden (whose style resembles Michael Sweet) was the singer for the self-title debut, The Second Coming and the engaging Trinity, but in 2013 Serbia's Nikola Mijic took over the vocal reigns with conviction and the band delivered possibly their best work yet with Symphony of Sin. That same line-up (sans original band drummer Pete Newdeck) charges through this 18 song set (plus guitar solo and band introductions) with passion and fervor. The majority of the songs (not surprisingly) are from the newest release (8), but there are 4 from Trinity, 3 from The Second Coming and 2 from the debut, and then the digital single from 2012 "Time to Breathe." Mixed and mastered by Dennis Ward (who also mixed Symphony of Sin) this live set, recorded November 28th, 2014 in Glasgow, Scotland, delivers in every way.So how does it sound? Well, this is a great live recording. All of the voices are well balanced in the mix and there is no muddy low-end - the chest thumping bass is crisp and punchy - and plenty of crowd noise. The band really gels and its apparent they were "on" this night which is remarkable given that drummer John Clelland is new to this music. Steve Williams keyboards provide an AOR/rock vibe ala Europe and they nicely support the two guys that really steal the show here - Nikola and Thorsten. Nikola soars above the music like a Steve Perry or Steve Walsh, with vocal clarity, conviction and passion. He does a great job getting the crowd into the show without being obnoxious. Thorsten's guitar leads and solos are fantastic, really giving this band the metal edge that sets them apart - his nearly 2 minute solo a throwback to 80's live show indulgences. Lyrically Eden's Curse has always been positive and that vibe definitely comes across in the live show. Overall, their debut live performance/recording is a huge success. While last year's AOR/rock W.E.T. release was really good, Eden's Curse may have outdone them here. Regardless, it's great to see a band reap the rewards for sticking it out through tough times and staying true to their signature sound.

Revisiting the Rush catalog on this new vinyl (DMM) medium is pretty exciting and the debut starts the collection off with a bang. I have to say that this album was never one of the albums that really started me on Rush - for me it was Permanent Waves. However, in that I grew up in the 70's with vinyl, I have to say this recording (these songs) has a lot of nostalgic meaning to me some 40 years later. For now obvious reasons the rock 'n' roll (non prog) roots of Rush are now legacy and without these groovy songs the band might have never delivered the epics such as 2112 and Hemispheres or even the immensely popular Moving Pictures. Anyway, suffice it to say, these songs have never sounded better.This copy (the in the box version) arrived unscathed with no warping. The weight of the record is perfect and everything in the box in good condition. My immediate impression of the DMM recording is one with more treble presence compared to older versions and more of the "pops" than might be expected. But this is consistent with everything I've read about the process so no surprises there. It retains the warmth of vinyl with a bit more treble than most vinyl recordings putting the sound in a nice comfortable place between the old and the digital. In essence, the sound quality is perfect for vintage vinyl listening.The box extras are icing on the cake. For me, the "family tree" is the most enjoyable "extra" in this set, along with the sturdy box. But everything here is retro all the way which is great. I look forward to all of the vinyl reissues just like back in the day when bringing home a new record from the Camelot store was like opening up Christmas!

This is the perfect table for those that are either new to vinyl or re-entering the vinyl scene (like myself) due to frustrations with the ridiculously overly compressed material now being released on most CDs. And for this price its a steal. Mine arrived nicely packaged by Amazon, but when I saw the manufacturer's box had a slight tear/opening near one corner I was a bit apprehensive given the number of reviews here that have found damaged units. Once I got everything unpacked (this is a well-packed unit for this price range)all parts were undamaged and no cracks in the dust cover. It is very easy to assemble as advertised, only needing to place the counterweight and headshell on the tonearm and the platter/mat on the table. The dust cover hinges come back out a bit too easy when you remove the dust cover but that is a minor issue and probably by design to prevent the platic cover from cracking easy near the hinge insertion during removal. In any case, this unit is also very easy to set up. Balancing the tonearm took about 2 minutes and then the other minor adjustments to the weight and antiskating dial pretty straight forward. I just went with the manufactur's recommendation of 2 gm based on the info provided in the very user friendly owner's manual. One thing to consider before buying may be the playing surface required. This is a big and heavy unit and you need a flat surface with about 18 inches of depth and about the same in width so it doesn't fit into most A/V cabinets because its too deep. And, if you plan to play with the dust cover on then you will need quite a bit of room avobe the unit for clearance. Because the hinge "locks" in the up position at a 45 degree angle you need that extra clearance. Those space issues aside, the wide circular feet suction down nicely on slick surfaces and this thing is solid and well-balanced. Its a little tricky to pick up due to the suction but there are grooves on the bottom sides of the unit that make it really easy to lift/carry.Its a great looking unit as well, doesn't look or feel cheap.I've only been spinning new vinyl (as all my stuff from the 70's and 80's is pretty abused)but am very pleased with the sounds.The cartrigde that comes with the unit is adequate for most rock/metal and louder music - there might be some issues for those that like lighter music or jazz as the volume output isn't high. I don't know if that is the cartidge or the unit itself, maybe a combination of both. The greatest thing here is that there is no listener fatigue at high volume (the curse of modern overly compressed digital rock and metal).The features on this unit are really impressive for a TT in this price range. I love how easy it is to stop/start and change directions. The speed is perfect on quartz mode but easy to change with the pitch variation engaged. One caveat with this is that the little LED light next to the slider stays green in quartz mode and in the center position even when the quartz is disengaged to allow for pitch variation. in other words, the light only changes to red once the quartz is disengaged AND the slider is moved out of that center position. There isn't any indicator on the quartz button itself to tell you that its on or off. I like the strobe light but its not necessary, just looks cool. The pop up stylus light is a very nice feature as well and even the way the 45 adapter fits into the deck is well-designed.Others have commented on the software and ease of copying vinyl but I honestly don't plan to use this function at this time. Nothing I currently own on vinyl is going to sound better copied to CD than the CD versions of those albums I've collected over the past 30 years.Very pleased overall. For the non "audiophile" audiophile this is a great TT and a great way to recaputure the magic of analog music without spending a fortune.

I needed drawers to store sheet music, small drum equipment, drumsticks, etc. and these work really well because they fit nicely near both my kits. I looked at smaller Sterilite (and similar) units but the drawers were too small to store 8.5 x 11 sized sheets/books. These drawers are all of more than adequate size - the inside of the drawer about 15 x 16 inches. The top drawers work great for smaller items and sheet paper while the lower drawer is large(deep) enough to hold cleaning solutions, tools, drum beaters, sticks, etc. The top of the unit is flat about 16 x 17.5 inches so also provides a fairly sturdy storage surface. Keep in mind these are made of plastic. I would have loved to have found a more solid unit like this (with a flat top and pull out drawers) but surprisingly there isn't much out in this size unit (big enough to hold what I describe above yet small enough to fit in a tight space). Most units are much smaller or larger cabinets with pull out bins that take up too much space. But with the weight of the drawers mostly full this doesn't move around much which is great. The wheels work well even at full capacity, but I use the second unit without the wheels (purposely) and it sits more firmly in place as would be expected. I think this unit would be a bit too large to use on a desk top but without the wheels it could work. Would have to put some kind of anti-skid mat or material on the bottom side though if using on a slick surface such as a desktop or smooth tile or hardwood flooring. On carpeted surface it stays nicely in place. Because the clear plastic is corrugated this has a somewhat more "stylish" appearance than the cheaper Sterilite storage drawers, and the drawers are less transparent as well. Overall, for what I needed this is the cheapest and quickest solution. I wouldn't want to take them on the road (not sturdy enough) but for home or studio use they work great.

For those that may not have seen this already I'm reposting since my other review was basically hi-jacked.OverviewHand. Cannot. Erase. is quite different from Raven, both conceptually and musically. First off this is definitely a concept album whereas Raven was a collection of "stories." Second, the jazz elements from Raven are less prevalent, in my opinion, with more straight forward elements of rock appearing. This has the effect/vibe of making the music feel more accessible. There is more of an electronic feel and the keyboards (both electric and acoustic) seem to play a greater role. There are some ambient passages as well so the overall listening experience from song to song definitely feels more cohesive. Those comparisons aside, this is just another great collection of music from probably one, if not the, most relevant and talented, hard-working artists in the scene.Deluxe Earbook Edition (2CD/DVD/Blu-ray)While there is no doubt that the music of this release stands by itself as a work of art, the earbook and the discs contained therein represent a completely immersive tactile, aural and visual experience of unprecedented proportions. Steve Wilson once again collaborates with Lasse Hoile (photography), Hajo Mueller (illustrations) and Carl Glover (design/artefacts). While Raven's Limited Edition book set a precedent of its own, it should not be surprising that Wilson and friends have pushed the envelope further in terms of the quality and depth of not only the music but the art and the visual and tactile presentation as well. This limited edition is better in every aspect.The StoryKarolina Grzybowska "stars" (aka models) as "H" - a woman in her 30's who is estranged from her family and friends. An introvert, she prefers a life of solitude with as little interaction with the busy and somewhat insincere world around her. The story begins with H's childhood/family background and progresses quickly to her adolescence where her parents adopt a 16 year old "sister" named "J." H and J quickly become connected and share some of their experiences, music, friendship, etc. In only 6 months the parents separate and so do the two girls. This is only minimally traumatic - yet significant - for H who prefers her own company anyway. H meets up with a boyfriend in college but subsequently distances herself from him when she feels things are getting too "serious." Further distancing herself from the world around her, H begins to have "visitors" who question her about her attachments and relationships. H develops a fascination with news stories about people who "disappear," and the interaction with the visitors and her own questions about her ability to be invisible to those around her raise questions about her significance and purpose in life. The rest of the story is more speculative and can best be left to the listener's/reader's interpretation. Suffice it to say, there is much more depth provided in the artbook - too much more information would spoil the story. There are still things I've not yet figured out yet as well. I will say that this story was inspired by a real story as Wilson points out on the DVD, but the story presented here varies quite a bit from the true-life version.The ArtbookThis 108 page hard-bound book is a work of art itself. Not only does it contain pictures and art chronicling the story of H, but it contains "artifacts" - such as a birth certificate, childhood journal, newspaper clippings, postcard - which help elucidate the story and make you feel as if you are actually touching the items owned by this young woman. The story is presented in a journal fashion from the standpoint of the woman H. Each entry enhances the meaning and character behind the songs. Additionally, the lyrics to each song are cleverly contained within journal entries, diary entries and other media. It's really quite brilliant. The written words certainly help capture not only the meaning behind the songs but also help enhance their emotional/human connection. This is art at its highest calling - the connection between visual, tactile and aural - perfectly executed.Disc 1/The MusicThe opening song "First Regret" is essentially an ambient piano prelude to "3 Years Older" which is an upbeat, rhythmic piece featuring a driving bass guitar line reminiscent of Geddy Lee, and Minnemann throws in a few Peart-like drum fills as well. The beginning and ending definitely has a Rush vibe but the song middle is a mixture of styles - the dynamic contrast between soft and loud sections pretty extreme. The solo section beginning around the 8 minute mark is one of the few times where the band really lets loose on this release and they ride it out to the end of the track. Lyrically, this song chronicles the early stage of the main character's life and H's interactions with her sister J.The title track follows and is the most easily loveable song on the disc; it's immediately appealing with its sing-along melody and catchy chorus. This is certainly the most radio friendly song on the release. Lyrically it alludes to the main character's "break-up" with her boyfriend and provides a lot of insight into how she views relationships in general."Perfect Life" is a mix of narration during the first half and Wilson repeating the chorus over top of some electronic beats and keys. Lyrically it's a reverie of sorts about H's relationship with her sister - sadly one of the only meaningful relationships in her life."Routine" is another epic song that begins with a haunting piano and vocal melody. The soft guitar noodling the main melody around the 4 and a half minute mark is a highlight followed by ethereal female vocals (Ninet Tayeb). This song, which has a definite Pink Floyd vibe, is probably the most beautiful song on the record from a melody and composition standpoint. It's not really a song about the main character but instead one of the "victims" H reads about in her news stories.The intensity really gets ratcheted up a notch with "Home Invasion" - a song about the internet's negative impact on our lives - and the follow up instrumental "Regret #9" with its incredible guitar solo. This song really showcases the kind of talent Wilson has recruited to realize and execute his musical dreams."Transience" serves as another retrospective type song from H's youth and serves somewhat as a transition to "Ancestral," the most epic track here. Very cool how the song builds in intensity throughout, culminating in an ominous sounding finale. Once again, this song features the band. Lyrically, this is definitely the most challenging song on the recording to comprehend and remains open to interpretation like most of Wilson's work."Happy Returns" - the most appropriately titled song here - features a letter to H's estranged brother ...almost a "goodbye/farewell I have no regrets" type letter. The peaceful album closer serves essentially as a bookend. Once again, the final outcome is open to interpretation. (But X-files fans might not think so!)Disc 2/The DemosThere is a key piece missing from the main story - "Key of Skeleton" - and it is musically found on the demo CD. The book also describes this in some detail as well. The other songs here are different/mostly longer versions of the final cuts but different enough to make this demo CD much more relevant than the demo CD from the Raven sessions. As with all things Wilson, don't think demo quality - these songs sound just as amazing as the stereo versions on the main CD.Disc 3/The DVDFor those who buy the media book with the DVD-V, you get the DTS 5.1 mix and the 24/96 stereo versions of the songs, the photo gallery and the documentary. Most of the photos in the artbook show up on DVD while the songs are playing in sequence. However, neither the Blu-ray or the DVD contains the "artifacts."Disc 4/The Blu-rayHere is the disc for the audiophiles. This one contains the 5.1 master DTS, and the stereo 2.0 and 5.1 mixes. Words won't be able to describe how these songs sound in surround but a better listening experience will be hard to find. The fact that these version contain very little compression means that you can crank this stuff up to the highest volume with no distortion. Every voice can be heard in detail and it truly is one of the best recordings I've ever heard. In addition to these hi-def versions of the main CD music, the Blu-ray contains instrumental versions (all of the songs) and alternate versions of some of the songs. For me, the Grand Union version of "Perfect Life" - where the spoken word is more clearly discernable - is a highlight, along with the alternate version of "Regret #9." A new item (not present on the Raven Blu-ray) would be the piano themes from the release. This is a particularly stunning inclusion from my standpoint as the emphasis on piano and keys on this release was one of the first things I noticed with initial spins that really set this release apart. Of course, the documentary and photo gallery from the DVD are included on the Blu-ray as well. It should be noted that during playback of the DVD/Blu-ray discs, the photos and art from the book - those which correspond to the songs - are displayed. In essence, you can literally watch the video/look at the book and the items therein and listen to the music all at the same time. For music/art/story lovers this project is a dream. The fact that Wilson knows how to make it all connect on an emotional level is merely the icing on the cake!I've yet to hear the vinyl version but I'm sure it won't disappoint. In summary, Hand Cannot Erase is an unrivaled emotional, listening and visual experience - eclipsing even the brilliance that was The Raven That Refused to Sing. Surely this will be enjoyed for years to come. Thanks to Wilson and friends for their commitment to art at its highest level.

Sometimes expectations can jade an otherwise neutral listening experience ... but when you don't have any expectations whatsoever then often you are in the right frame of mind for new music, and often end up pleasantly surprised instead of disappointed. One thing that shouldn't be a surprise to anyone is that these guys have actually released another record despite having "called it quits." Nevertheless, the question many are asking - should they have released this record? I say sure - why not. As Klaus points out in "All For One," "I won't stop till they'll lay my bones to rest." So what about expectations then? Not having heard anything about the music prior to the release, I have to say I like it - certainly more than Sting In The Tail. But some things have to be put into perspective, the first of which is that these guys have absolutely nothing to prove to anyone. Second, with producers Mikael Nord Andersson and Martin Hansen once again on board you have to expect a more AOR (rather than melodic metal) approach, especially considering that the pair of them contribute either lyrics or composition to 7 of the songs here. And while "Rollin' Home" may really irritate older fans, most of these songs are well-composed, they just have an AOR vibe. The exception would be the bluesy rocker "The Scratch." In light of this, it should not then be surprising that some of the best songs here - those that will feel most familiar to long-time fans - are those written by Rudi Schenker - "Rock My Car," "House of Cards," "Catch You Luck And Play," "Hard Rockin' The Place" and "Gypsy Life" (the "Still Loving You" of this release). It's also not surprising that Klaus's timeless voice doesn't sound as if it has aged a bit - his lyrics pretty typical of his output over the past several decades. As would be expected the mix sounds great, although Kottak's drums could stand a bit more punch in the mix. I agree with others that his performance is pretty pedestrian here, but it serves the music. Overall, while RTF isn't going to win any awards it's solid rock and a much more fitting swan song (if it is truly their last) than was Sting In The Tail.

I recently started playing The Trooper and Wasted Years again so thought I would give these sticks another try - hadn't used them in a year or so. I will compare them to my regular sticks which are the Regular VF 5B. Since Nicko plays a lot of fast triplet snare/tom combinations in The Trooper and a lot of quick sixteenth notes on the ride this stick makes perfect sense. Unlike the regular 5B - which is heavy on the tip end - Nicko's stick feels more balanced throughout which allows for quicker movements on the toms and cymbals. While it shares length with the 5B it is a lighter stick overall. Nicko's stick also has a bigger and rounder tip than the more teardrop shape of the 5B and this makes a bigger sound on the ride.
