OH YEAH (lol)....Who doesn't want to read a short romance story about a landscaper and her CEO ex brother-in-law?!?! Cue ... #FANTASTIC! And Victoria Purman delivered! This story had spunk and energy and sexy and it was just FUN!ARC provided by Tule Publishing via NetGalley for an honest review

OK, so this is a short story packed with a lot of sexy sexy. And it's hot!! Mikhail Lysenko is very intense and he doesn't do anything half measure, including pursuing Lindsay Carlisle. I gotta say, for such a short amount of pages, Carole Mortimer managed to pull off a well developed story that was intriguing and engaging. I'm a little impressed LOLARC provided by Tule Publishing via NetGalley for an honest review

holy hell .... 2 am read without even blinking!I was a little apprehensive when I read the blurb of the book because I'm not usually an NA reader. But then I clicked on the author to find out about them and wham ... Kit Rocha duo! #soldA few things stand out to me:~I read this book without stopping. Not because it was overly dramatic or suspenseful or even angsty ... it was easy to read. The language and format used in the story sucked me in from page one. As you can see above, it was 2 am when I finished and I didn't even know it.~The age of the leads and supporting characters never once entered my mind. You see, young people do annoying things (lol), which are totally normal..for their age group that is. But I don't have the patience for it so I try and stay away from books involving this age group. But I never felt it, not once. So again I say ... easy to read.So the story goes like this ... Hannah Casey is back home because Daddy drove drunk. Got himself killed and Mom is on life support. Someone has to pull the plug and Hannah is the last of the line...Sean Whitlow is Hannah's deceased sister's ex-boyfriend (say that five times real fast lol) and he was also Hannah's first crush ...OK, to say that Hannah had a dysfunctional relationship with her family is probably putting it mildly. They were the epitome of small town socialites who put on a facade for the world outside their home opposite that of what their life was truly like. As you read through the story, the past will unfold but it won't be the focus of the story. You will get just enough information to understand Hannah's motivations but it never takes you away from the real story... The story of a girl so withdrawn inside herself and so used to upholding the facade that her parents had created that she has no idea who she is, and the boy who holds her hand while she tears at the layers upon layers of a life she doesn't want so she can figure out who she is.The connection that Hannah and Sean shared was instantaneous and it was electric. The sparks flew right off the page when they were together. The progression of their relationship felt natural and real. There are sub-plots in this story that deal with some serious issues like alcoholism, suicide and personality disorders. They were unfolded in such a way that helped enhance the story but didn't overshadow the romance.The secondary characters already introduced have peaked my interest and I can't wait to read their stories!ARC provided by CrushStar Multimedia LLC via NetGalley for an honest review

And the International Bad Boys series continues ... I have loved every one of the books in this series by various authors. I didn't exactly dislike Claimed by the Warrior, it just didn't do anything for me ...This story itself felt like a hot mess from beginning to end. WAY too much going on for a book of this length. It was just all over the place. And then it ends in a cliffy ... um, what?By the title, you think there's gonna be some claiming, but yeah, not so much....As for the suspense ... well, if you make it easy for me then what's the point of turning the page?So there ya have it ... hot mess (lol)ARC provided by Tule Publishing via NetGalley for an honest review

OK, so ....... NO.I don't even know what else to say. I don't know where the blurb of this book actually kicks in, but it isn't in this installment.And don't get me started on the grammar and syntax ... "I just got to go" ... um, no!Copy provided by NetGalley for an honest review

I know it's kinda early to be reading Christmas stories, but it's Maggie McGinnis!!!This is the beginning of the Echo Lake series and it was a fanfrikkintastically sweet, second chance story :) Every page had me smiling!It's a perfect read for all romance fans and a great start to anyone's holiday reads!ARC provided by St Martin's Press via NetGalley for an honest review

The first AND most important thing you should know about this story is that it is overwhelmingly emotional. Not in your typical, that's a sad moment emotional, but the story itself is emotionally charged. When I was reading this story, I felt this overwhelming longing ... I couldn't quite put my finger on exactly what was causing it until I realized it wasn't any one thing or event. The story is electric, charged with emotion! The second thing you should know is that in my opinion, this is by far, Zoe York's best work yet. She exceeded my expectations with this novella length story. Exceeded because it doesn't read like a short story. It has depth and meaning and purpose beyond anything a short story can normally carry.This is the story of Melissa Vincent and Cade Duncan. More aptly stated, this is the story of Melissa Vincent and the man who walked side by side with her on her journey of growth and discovery and ultimately love.To say Melissa Vincent is emotionally 'closed-off' is an understatement. She's an only child with a very skewed perception of what relationships and love should be all about. No, that's not right ... she knows what it should be about, she just doesn't have a point of reference. Her parent's relationship was dysfunctional at best. Her father was nothing more than a sperm donor and she's never let anyone in close enough because of it. Until Cade .... Cade Duncan knew the minute he set eyes on Melissa, the prettiest girl he'd seen in a long time, that he needed a date with her. It wasn't smooth sailing getting to that date, but he got it ... and then some.The story goes like this ... Melissa and Jared Sutter (her best friend's husband) were scheduled to fly to Hawaii to take part in an endurance race/challenge. But Jared becomes unavailable so Cade grabs on to this opportunity like his life depended on it. Because he knows there's a special girl under all that prickliness and this is his ticket to get to know this special girl. As I mentioned before, this book is more about Melissa than anyone or anything else. This endurance race is not just any race. It's both an opportunity to connect and a journey to discover for Melissa. You'll have to read for yourself the how and the why. But trust when I say this is not your ordinary short story.... it's short and sweet and packs a punch like no other.This is a story embroidered with feeling, hope. vulnerability, acceptance, trust, growth and love ... Easy ~ Beautiful Love :)* This book was first published in the Romancing the Alpha adventure romance boxed set. ARC received by the author for an honest review.

This car mount worked really well for me.It worked for both my phone and my portable GPS system.It's really easy to install (see instructions in description of product) and it is also easy to move from one vehicle to another. I installed and uninstalled five different times to be sure it did not wear and it worked just as new every time.It hold firm and steady in all kinds of situation. I took my car to an empty parking lot and tested all kinds of driving situations with it and it never once wobbled or fell off.I'm very impressed with this product!NOTE: I received this product in exchange for an honest review.

Paul Chapman really REALLY wants his family off his back about his future. He likes his life just the way it is. No commitments or relationships. Just easy going fun! Libby Harris is desperate to get her business off the ground. But it seems the fates are against her and for step she tries to take forward, she ends up two steps back. Until Libby meets Paul. Paul works for his brother who owns a bar. Libby needs a bar to promote her cocktail business. Paul's brother is apprehensive about giving Libby's product a shot. He doesn't think it fits his clientele...Meanwhile, Paul is desperately trying to figure out how he's going to get a girlfriend in time for his brother's wedding so he can get his family off his back. All he needs is the appearance of a relationship and he'll be home free ... So Libby and Paul come up with a plan..she pretends to be his girlfriend and he in turn works on his brother to change his mind about her product.Sounds like a full proof plan to me ... or maybe not. (lololololol)The attraction between them is undeniable. Their chemistry is off the charts and what begins as a business deal turns into a very intimate friendship ... built on a lie. Will Paul be able to let his guard down and allow Libby in his heart? Will they be able to survive the fall out after the truth is finally revealed? ... Go ahead and read the book and let me know! You won't regret it.What a fun little story this was! Paul and Libby both have issues they have to overcome but their journey is truly rainbows and gumdrops. It was sweet and romantic and sexy and just plain fun to read!ARC provided by Entangled Publishing, LLC via NetGalley for an honest review
It's been a long time since I've been left speechless by a book ... and here I am tonight, totally devoid of words yet drowning in emotions.....Just... wow

I am the WORST at keeping my devices fully charged. I am always running into situations where I need a device charged like yesterday. This cable seems to fit 'me' like a glove! I know a lot of manufactures say their cables charge super fast and whatnot, but this one actually does! How do I know? Because I tested this product with THAT specific thing in mind!Other than that ... it's normal length, not too short and too long AND it comes with a 100% guarantee.They said it works and what do you know ... it works! It's a good value for the money #TRUSTI received this product in exchange for an honest review.

So the story of Allison and Robert continues exactly where Stoned: A Billionaire Stepbrother With Benefits Romance left off. She's just found out the big news ... what to do, what to do...I have to give Cynthia Sharon credit because this installment brought the LOL with a bang for me. I absolutely love the direction she is taking with both Allison and Robert's attitudes towards the whole step-sibling matter. It's exactly how it should be! The story had no awkward moments of intimacy, but once again, it does leave you craving and wanting. And altho that is a good thing when it comes to stories told in installments, there also should be a sense of purpose to the story. As of right now, this reader has no clue what the objective or end game is to this story...because all I'm reading are moments in time. There's not enough story being told to even give me an idea of a HEA or HFN ending, if there's even one...The problem with stories told in this format is that, as a reader, the second I begin to get comfortable with the story and/or invested, it ends ... and we play the waiting game for the next installment. In my opinion, this takes away from the excitement of the story .. turns what is an engaging and exciting sexy story, anticlimactic.I still want to make sure all future readers know this: The idea/concept of this story is unique and well told. If you don't mind this type of format, then this story would be one you should one-click immediately!

This is normally something I wouldn't read until fully published because 1. not a fan of cliffhangers and 2. way too shortBUT, Cynthia Sharon asked for my honest opinion sooooo stay tuned ...OK...so here's the skinny *snickers* ... Cynthia Sharon has potential. There's obvious edit problems that bug me because she probably paid well to have this edited but that never influences my reviews. What does influence it is the writing style, the development, and overall voice of the story.This wasn't perfect, in my opinion, the kiss was like reading a boy coming up to a girl in the school hall and stealing a kiss ...awkward lol and the orgasm felt out of place ... like it was just written in there with no lead to it, again awkward.But I'll tell you what was good ... her development of not only the story (so far) and both Allison and Robert. I know where this is going, so that's a good sign. I don't know how it's going to get there, also a good sign because it makes it not predictable in a trope that's been done a thousand times before...hopefully all you future readers will understand what I'm trying to tell ya there LOLThe best part so far is the POV. It's in both Robert's and Allison's so I get to experience them both (always a plus) and Cynthia Sharon made sure I knew exactly who they were. She developed both Allison and Robert perfectly and told me just enough about each of them to hook me into ... cannot WAIT to read more ... that's potential kids.SO one-click this installment ... it's not a full story, but you'll be hooked ;) #TRUST

ARC of this complete collection was generously provided by Ainsley Booth for an honest reviewI've had the honor and pleasure of reading Haley and Cole's story both as originally written in installments and now I got to revisit them in this full length novel of all three parts that make up their road to HEA ... plus I got a wedding!!! ***eeeeekkk***You can find my thoughts on ALL three parts of Hailey & Cole's journey in my review for each installment.A few highlights for you about Hailey & Cole and The Horus Group ...I COULD NOT HAVE ASKED FOR A BETTER ROMANCE STORY ~~ No two people have ever been more suited than these two. Where one is dark, the other is light. Where one is hard, the other is soft. The energy between them is electric and it's powerful. Their love is kismet.This isn't over. It's coming back. And it's gonna hurt. So PAY ATTENTION!The Horus Group has indeed moved The Gladiators aside...it's time to get down to business!Hate F*@k: The Complete Story contains two exclusive bonus epilogues! Here are my thoughts:Hate F*@k: In The Middle of the Night  Cole: "You get so sloppy after you come, baby. It's hot."  Hailey: I wish I'd known that. I wasted ten years after puberty being embarrassed about the awesomeness between my legs.  âª#âfilthyâ¬ âª#âdirtyâ¬ âª#âgoodnessâ¬Hate F*@k: Wedding Day  Cole: I try to live every day like my deeds are my vows to her. I donât always succeed. Sometimes she needs to poke me.  Hailey: âDonât ever think youâre not enough for me,â she mock growls at me when I finally let her up for air. âYouâre my rock, you get that? I donât need you to be anything else, because you anchor me.âDear Ainsley:I hate you a little for the vows, but love you for them more <3Thank you for writing this 'moment in time'xoxo

For testing purposes, I randomly mixed and matched telephones and ipads and tablets and everything charged quite well together and seperate. eBoot really makes a superb product that eliminates clutter and gives you organized space for all your charging needs!With the use of this product, I've gathered all my devices and created one central charging station in my home. It's convenient and organized and I love it!It is also light-weight and very convenient for traveling purposes. Does not come with a protective case, but that really is not that big a deal.A sample of this product was provided for me in exchange for an honest review.

DURABLE ... FUN AND VERY VERY CUTE!Both my dogs have loved playing with it, although Bella being a very small dog can't really carry it back but that's half the fun for us! LOLThank you eBoot for sending me this toy in exchange for an honest review. I can safely say I haven't had this much fun with the dogs in a while!

The power output for this device is impressive. It has 2 advanced super charges and 2 regular charges. Iy also comes with a mini USB cable if you need one for any reason. It's small and not obtrusive and weighs almost nothing.. Great for traveling purposes! The one tiny thing I didn't like was it had no carrier and/or protective case although the device itself is designed to be inconspicuous and sturdy.This product was provided for me in exchange for an honest review

WHAT A PASSIONATE STORY! LOVED IT!Leah was absolute perfection. She was strong and independent, secure in her blindness, passionate, loving, caring .... I could go on. Kudos to Bonnie Dee for giving us a true heroine, in more ways than one! You see, Leah has a disability. She is blind. And her parents have guarded her and taken care of her since the accident that took her sight but she is more than ready to take on the world on her own. And she does! LOVED HER!JD, the neighbor, is our hero. He's no ordinary neighbor. He's been hired by her Leah's family to look out for her, unbeknownst to Leah, of course! JD and Leah actually met BEFORE he was hired and he already knew he was attracted to the 'brunette at the bar'. LOL How they met? Leah and her girlfriend went out one evening to a bar and JD and his friend were at the same bar just out on a night having a good time. When they bumped into each other accidentally SPARKS flew!! When he gets the job as her security 'detail' of course he jumps on it.Leah and JD had passion and chemistry that you could feel thru the pages. As they both form a friendship, JD begins to realize he is in WAY deep and maybe he wouldn't be able to get out. Remember, Leah has no clue that he is actually there, hired by her parents, to look out for her. So the lies start piling up! Will they both be able to adjust to the truth and live HEA? ....This book was amazingly good! We get both their perspectives in the story due to the dual POV. I think that is ALWAYS a plus in a story. It makes the story more well rounded and not so one-sided. We got to feel both their struggles!You cannot go wrong with this story! TRUST!

ARC provided by Entangled Publishing, LLC via NetGalley for an honest review.I'm not gonna lie....the cover really attracted me to this book. Without reading a word of the blurb, I knew I wanted to read it. It was flirty and fun, just the right kinda mix for a quick romance read. And the book lived up to the cover! :) The story was quick and cute and fun. It's my first read by Stefanie London and I am looking forward to much much more from her in the future!Gracie is going to find herself the perfect man and she's making a list of things her man has to have in order to make the cut. The thing you should know, is that Gracie isn't really trying to find the perfect man for herself, but more so for the expectations that her family (mother) have put on her to do so. Cue, our VERY hot bartender/friend, Des. Now Des has had his eye on Gracie for quite some time, but she's off limits to him because he's been there done that in the 'society' world and is not doing it again! Or is he?!?!As he watches Gracie with her many dates from behind the bar, he cant help but fall little by little. Will Gracie see that her Mr Rights are really just SO wrong and the one she assumes to be Mr Wrong is oh SO right?! You're gonna have to read to find out ;)

I wish this book was longer :( It was lively and fun and easy to read so once I started, I didn't put it down and then WHAM, it was done :(The entire book was FULL of witty and hilarious humor! I think it has a lot to do with the 'times', but when I read a historical romance novel, I find myself VERY entertained. The speech is just so 'highfalutin' for lack of a better term that it just makes it laughable! Every scene was FULL of good, sassy, witty banter!SO the story goes like this .... Oliver comes home from war to a title AND he's almost bankrupt ... Thanks Dad! lol Desperate times call for desperate measure so he has to find himself a wealthy wife like yesterday! But the universe has something totally different in mind for good old Oliver :) And now I present you with Grace. Grace has the same circumstances as Oliver. But she needs the money for different reasons. Her mother is ill, grandparents won't help ... it's just a big mess. So OF COURSE they fall for each other! LOL CUE, the wonderfully sweet romance story of Oliver and Gracie :)The things these two will do for each other will put a little mist in your eyes. This is a KEEPER story for me that will be read many times in the future!ARC provided by Intrepid Reads via NetGalley for an honest review.
Bought as a Christmas present for my husband.  He loves it.

Super cool retro item.  Quirky and fun.  Works well enough, but you have to be careful of what kind of case you have for your cell phone....a lot of them don't allow the plug to go all the way into the phone and you'll think the handset doesn't work; you just need to make sure it's pushed in all the way.
Not overly descriptive or informative. You probably remember more from summer camp when you were a kid.
Not a whole lot of recipes, but has basic info about actually baking in a skillet.
Good item for the price, accurate readings (I checked against a doctor's BP machine), and small enough to stow easily.
Cover looks great, fits well, and does what it's supposed to.
If you want to write a book, you should already know the info that's contained in this book. Very basic outline of what to do.

Really great little tale of someone who took control of his life to live the way he wants to. I am inspired to do the same thing, only in an RV and not on a boat. Book needs some editing, but it's not too bad.

Bought this same style of shirt somewhere else (offline) and loved it so much I wore it to threadbareness.  So I came to Amazon looking for the same type, found this, and snatched it up.  While the shirt LOOKS great, and fits decently, the quality of the material is much, much thinner than the other shirt I had, and the difference is evident.  I would still by the shirt in other colors, but would wear them much less frequently because I do not think they would last as long.
Some really great recipes, and the book is very well done.
Flashback to a song from the soundtrack of my youth.....the 80s were rap-dilly-icious. Kicking bass line that hooks you right away.

Very well done.  Quite a few ailments (SEEK A DOCTOR'S ATTENTION FIRST!) can be treated or helped with the use of essential oils, and too many people believe that the drug industry is the be all-end all.  This book is very well researched, and includes helpful instructions on how to make and use essential oils.  It's not as difficult as the "industry" would have you believe.

The WRITTEN instructions in the book are great, and there are drawings, but I think the book would have been more helpful/useful if there were actual photos of actual hair in addition to the drawings. Actual photos would have helped a lot.
Makes the timesuck vortex that is Pinterest be easy, manageable, and a joy to lose hours and hours and hours of time to.
Because seriously, if you want to be successful at writing and selling ebooks, you should pretty much do the exact opposite of everything in this book.

I had another Kindle calculator app that not only works just half the time, but freezes frequently and often won't let me ADD.  This one, downloaded quite on a whim, not only works well all the time so far, but actually makes my kindle fire LOOK like a giant calculator, which is really kind of cool.
I just don't get what the author was trying to do here. Whatever it was, it wasn't done very well, and it was basically pornogaphic.

Informative enough if you like odd drinks ingredients, and sickly sweet cocktails.  I don't.  Some of them are fine for the novelty factor, but I wouldn't want to drink them.  A lot of people would, however.  The instructions are clear and concise, and the book is fine, just not for me.

My power cord died unexpectedly, and I thought I was going to have to pay a fortune to replace it.  Not so.  This cord fit my Gateway laptop just fine and works as well as the original.  No complaints at all.

My wonderful, darling daughter bought her zombie loving mom (ME) these for Christmas.  I absolutely love them.  They are cushy, comfy, and adorable.  I think they eyeballs will probably fall off quickly, because when I walk, my dogs attack my feet and try to bite off the eyeballs, but the slippers are otherwise very durable and have a good amount of cushion beneath your feet.  They are warm too!  Love, love, love these slippers.

There are real people out there like Agnes "Apple" Bailey, the 16-year old girl who runs away from her abusive mother at the start of the film "Gimme Shelter," only to end up pregnant and homeless on the streets of New York. But Apple, portrayed convincingly by a near-unrecognizable Vanessa Hudgens, is only one highlight of this film.Excellent performances are also found with the sympathetic Father McCarthy (James Earl Jones) and the abusive mother (Rosario Dawson) who influence the direction of Apple's life. And Kathy DiFiore, the compassionate social worker (Ann Dowd) who takes in Apple, is portrayed with great compassion. After trading an abusive marriage for homelessness, the real-life DiFiore founded the "Several Sources" homeless shelters for pregnant teens that inspired this little indie film.Bottom line: This movie is the absolute best pro-life film I've ever seen. It's more high-quality that low-budget Protestant stuff like "October Baby." It's also more realistic than "Bella" since it's based on a true story. Although "Bella" is a powerful and moving film, it's also a whimsical fiction, whereas "Gimme Shelter" gets added grit from its basis in real life. It is a labor of love.Both "Bella" and "Gimme Shelter" are Catholic films, but "Gimme Shelter" feels more real, more heartfelt, and more immediate to the experience of young people growing up in a world of haves and have-nots.It's also one of the best social justice films I've ever seen, giving an amazingly sharp depiction of teenage homelessness that riveted my theology students when we watched the film together. They are usually pretty immune to any sort of "care about the world" message. But this film, maybe because Vanessa Hudgens was in it got to them. "Gimme Shelter" has the biting realism of "Dead Man Walking" without any of the moral sermonizing.This DVD includes a brilliant transfer with 5.1 audio, deleted scenes with director's commentary, a "making of" featurette,and the usual Spanish subtitles. It's a great package of a great indie film. I highly recommend it.

I'm not a "Shroud fanatic," but merely curious after seeing a lecture on it, and I was quite impressed by this DVD package from Ignatius Press. It contains three documentaries and special features which include trailers and three additional documentary clips. These films give a good overview of scientific investigations into the "Shroud of Turin," an unusual cloth that many people believe to be the burial shroud of Jesus Christ preserved down through the centuries.The first film is "The Silent Witness," a 53-minute British Academy Award winning (1978) documentary narrated by Kenneth More. This film ignited worldwide interest in the Shroud, but is a bit disjointed and dated, being more of historical interest nowadays for its fascinating exploration of a few well-known discoveries. The second two films -- "Shroud of Turin" (2008 BBC documentary, 59 minutes) and "Shroud (2010, 48 minutes) -- are more contemporary and include recent items like the carbon dating that cast some doubt on the Shroud's authenticity. They are also never dull. What I love most about this product is that it has all of this stuff on ONE DVD rather than a multi-disc set, making it a convenient package. I recommend it to anyone interested in this topic.

Father John Kavanaugh SJ, the late Jesuit philosopher at Saint Louis University, was one of the most accessible philosophical ethicists of modern times. Author of the "ethics notebook" in America magazine, Kavanaugh is still best known for this little paperback on the ethics of being a Christian in today's materialistic consumer society. This book is definitely on the side of applied rather than theoretical ethics, but it will really make you think in the way it applies humanistic ethical principles to contemporary life. It's a book that deserves to be re-read in the era of Pope Francis, one of its spiritual bedfellows. I highly recommend it.

Father Dan Harrington SJ, the late Jesuit scripture scholar at Boston College, is one of the most accessible scholarly writers in the Catholic tradition when it comes to Sacred Scripture. Harrington, a defender of the historical critical method in biblical criticism, gives you a great overview of this perspective on the New Testament. He includes a particularly strong grasp of the "Q" source theory in the formation of the gospels. It's getting harder to find this little paperback and its Old Testament companion book, but hopefully they will be reprinted again soon. Highly recommended.

Father Dan Harrington SJ, the late Jesuit scripture scholar at Boston College, is one of the most accessible scholarly writers in the Catholic tradition when it comes to Sacred Scripture. Harrington, a great defender of the historical critical method in biblical criticism, gives you a great overview of this perspective on the Old Testament. He includes a particularly strong grasp of the J, E, D, and P documentary hypothesis on the original sources of the Torah. It's getting harder to find this little paperback, but hopefully it will be reprinted again soon. Highly recommended.

This ABC News Special DVD features only a "play" option on the menu. It is simply 1 hour and 24 minutes of news coverage from the last days, death, wake, and funeral of Pope John Paul II in 2005. I found the disc to be a great historical record of an event I remember very vividly from television in April 2005. It's a useful disc if you are teaching history or religion or journalism and want something to show students to evoke the legacy of Pope John Paul II, recently canonized by Pope Francis on 27 April 2014 as Saint John Paul II. The commentary by ABC News commentators is occasionally superficial, but does a nice job of recalling key moments in the papacy and in the international appeal of history's third-longest papal reign. I also like that the disc includes some moments where the commentators are silent and let the images speak for themselves. Everything is stock footage, without any retrospective added. Not just for Catholics, but for anyone who wants to learn about John Paul II's legacy, this disc is a great slice of recent history.

The "Confessions" of St. Augustine of Hippo, beloved by Catholics and Protestants alike, is probably the most well-read Christian autobiography of all time. Augustine, whose 76 years (AD 354-430) saw the final decline of the Roman Empire, went from a hedonistic youth (where he made a brilliant public speaking career and drifted through several eccentric philosophies of life) to become one of the greatest Christian thinkers of all time. He even fathered a child out of wedlock with one of several women he seduced, praying to God for "chastity and continence -- but not yet." His father was a pagan, but his Christian mother St. Monica and St. Ambrose the bishop of Milan made fruitless efforts to convert him to Christianity.At age 32, Augustine finally picked up the Bible and read a passage (Rom 14:13-14) from St. Paul's letter to the Romans that exhorted readers to "put on Christ" rather than drunkenness, leading him to confront the unhappiness that had resulted from his life choices. He quickly obtained baptism from St. Ambrose, rising to become a priest and later bishop in Hippo, where he died in AD 430 as the Vandal barbarians besieged his city's gates. The Roman Empire fell shortly afterwards.Recognized by Roman Catholicism as a bishop and doctor of the Church, St. Augustine is one of the most influential writers from the first 500 years of Christianity, with his "City of God" defending Christianity's influence on the Roman Empire and his brutally honest "Confessions" describing how God fulfilled his deepest desires after years of restlessly searching for fulfillment. When I read the "Confessions" in college, I was blown away by its heartfelt narrative and deeply theological passages, but I never thought it would be visualized in a movie. This production proves me wrong.The film "Restless Heart" is directed by French Canadian director Christian Duguay ("Joan of Arc," 1999) and originated as an Italian TV miniseries. This Ignatius Press two-disc DVD set includes one disc with a feature-length cut released in U.S. churches and the original three-hour cut on a second disc. The first disc with the theatrical cut is vastly superior, featuring enhanced picture and sound in addition to special features that include a little EWTN television documentary on Augustine hosted by Franciscan friar Andrew Apostoli CFR. The second disc features just the original film cut in washed-out colors, appearing untouched from its television premiere. Having seen both versions, I believe you get the gist of the story on Disc 1, while the three-hour cut from Disc 2 mostly includes fictionalized elements that add nothing to the story.The story is told in flashback by an elderly Augustine awaiting the barbarian attack on Hippo in AD 430, building to a moving climax. Flawlessly dubbed, it looks like it was originally filmed in English, and I still can't believe how well the voice work matches up with the actors. Believe me: I utterly DESPISE dubbing on foreign films, particularly as found in most of the Italian RAI-TV productions released on DVD by Ignatius Press in the United States. But this film is actually awesome in English, defying conventional wisdom about dubbing.I showed "Restless Heart" (theatrical cut) to 16-year old students in a scripture class and they were astounded at the high quality of the film, very different from many other titles in the Ignatius Press catalogue. Many of the scenes, particularly the conversion sequence of Augustine and final scene with his mother, follow the "Confessions" so well that they will move you to tears. Other more historical sequences, including the final assault on Hippo in Augustine's last hours, are brilliant in evoking Christianity's final triumph over the Roman Empire and role in preserving the best of its heritage throughout the coming dark ages. The production values and special effects are extremely good here. If you love St. Augustine, you'll love this movie. Also, if you enjoyed the "Saint Barbara" DVD from Ignatius Press, you'll also love this film since its visual style and music (same composer, Andrea Guerra) is the same. I highly recommend it.

This intriguing 56-minute National Geographic video follows explorer Robert Ballard, famed for his discovery of the Titantic wreckage, as he searches the Black Sea for evidence of the Great Flood and Noah's ark. Since the bottom of the Black Sea is poisonous, wood is preserved at the bottom, and Ballard seeks ancient shipwrecks there. Ballard follows a geological theory that the Great Flood created the Black Sea and inspire the Noah story. For a NatGeo special, this video is pretty involving, and is respectful of religious beliefs without relying on them. I suspect that even younger people would be fascinated by this video, particularly in the wake of Russell Crowe's role in "Noah." I recommend it for anyone who wants to learn a little bit about the scientific and historical evidence of the Great Flood.Like many NatGeo DVDs, this disc has no menu, but simply plays the movie when you insert it into your player. It's like an old VHS tape in that regard. Filmed in 2000, though, the video and audio quality is very high.

This 93-minute 1977 television film tells the story of Father Eusebio Kino SJ, a 17th/18th century Italian Jesuit missionary to what is now the Western United States. Despite the excellent cast and Fulton Sheen narration, the film on this DVD is of dreadful quality, with sound and video quality resembling something from 1970s public access programming. It feels much longer than its running length and is very hard to watch..Even if you're able to pick up the dialogue, the film's narrative is so muddled that you will simply be lost through most of it. Father Kino, played by a thoroughly American-sounding Richard Egan, starts churches and deals with tensions between Indians and European settlers. But everything unfolds in vignette-style without any clear transitions or context for what we are watching. Although a California Jesuit historian seems to have consulted on this film, and it appears to be the only movie on this significant man's life, nothing quite comes together.If you're looking for some visualization of Father Kino's life, this film is pretty much your only bet. You might find some way to enjoy it if you've done a lot of supplemental reading that helps you understand what's occurring in the movie. But in almost every conceivable way, this movie is an amateur and lifeless production, unlikely to inform or inspire anyone at all. You may want to pay to stream it online, just to see it, but I recommend avoiding "The Father Kino Story" unless you have a very strong interest in this subject.

This 2-hour documentary on the archaeological roots of Jerusalem covers its history as a Jewish, Christian, and Muslim religious center. Like most PBS documentaries, it is richly produced and beautifully filmed, being flawed only insofar that it is tremendously boring. Ray Suarez ("The News Hour") is a good host as he addresses the camera during the film's journey through the city, including some lovely camerawork. The scholars are on-target and insightful.But boy oh boy, is this video dull! It's like PBS dopes its programs with a special chemical that induces sleep. I love this material, but PBS turns it all into a monotonous drone, and I'm afraid public television still hasn't learned the tricks of digital special effects and cinematic editing employed by National Geographic and History Channel. The style here is a classic documentary approach, interlacing thoughtful interviews with static photography and location footage, without any stylistic flair at all. The problem is that this film is a 2009 documentary using 1979's videography techniques. I strongly recommend this video for its content, but not for its style, and I would caution anyone against using it with young students accustomed to modern visuals. Older adults and people with a special research interest in the topic will enjoy it, but younger people will either zone out or bang their heads against a wall.

Father Harry J. Gensler, a Jesuit priest and philosopher, packs a lot of material into this large glossy paperback logic textbook. Covering both traditional and contemporary logic, he also provides a history of logic in addition to logic exercises for each section that correspond to an online logic program at his website. If you want a comprehensive overview of logic, this is the book for you. Since I don't know a lot of math and am generally intimidated by logic, I thought this book would lose me pretty quickly, but I was pleased to discover that I could follow it (even when I didn't take time to do all the exercises) very easily. You'll learn a lot and become more logical as you read it, but it takes a lot of time to go through the text fully, if you really want to immerse yourself. It's a rich text. Gensler's online logic quiz, meant to be taken as a logic gut check at you start the book, is a particular highlight.

Peter Kreeft, Jesuit-educated philosopher at Boston College, is a well-known popularizer of philosophy for undergraduate students. This slender and glossy paperback is an introduction to philosophy through the Apology of Plato. Rather than giving a technical overview of philosophical areas like epistemology, it lists essential characteristics of philosophy (the love of wisdom) as evidenced in the life of Socrates. The book proceeds with narrative passages from the Apology, making it a fun companion to Plato's dialogue for an intro to philosophy or ancient philosophy class. Some of Kreeft's vast output is so-so, but this book is one of his best, and is a truly fun read. If you want something that will make philosophy taste a bit less like bad cough syrup, this is the book for you.

The Ceremonial of Bishops contains liturgical ceremonies and guidelines for all Roman Catholic services involving a bishop. It also includes sound liturgical principles that may be used at any liturgical event, even those without a bishop, since pontifical mass is in some sense a model for all liturgies in the Roman Rite. This hardcover book is an essential resource for every pastor and parish in the Roman Catholic Church, both for visits by the diocesan bishop and for general liturgical planning.

This first encyclical of Pope Francis is a sequel to Pope Benedict XVI's encyclicals on love and hope. Written mostly by Benedict with a few additional thoughts from Francis, according to the introduction, it is a beautiful meditation on the meaning of Christian faith in the world today. If you love Pope Francis and Pope Benedict XVI, you'll enjoy this unique collaboration between the two of them, started before Benedict's resignation. This slender paperback from the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops (USCCB) with glossy cover is quite readable, with bright and large text. The text is more readable than the Paulist Press edition of this same work.

The French Catholic, Jesuit-educated 19th century writer Honore Balzac is a sublime and haunting writer. This Dover Thrift Edition is a very cheap razor-thin paperback containing one of his best short stories, about a painter who labors for years over the fiercely guarded titular masterpiece, as well as some other delightful tales. These Romantic stories are simultaneously deep and highly satisfying in their grasp of human nature, without devolving into the grotesque flourishes of a Gaston Leroux or the eye-rolling melodramatics of a Victor Hugo, and you'll be surprised at the sparse beauty of his narrative. He's just a wonderful storyteller. If you've never read Balzac, I recommend starting with these stories rather than his epic-length novels, and see if you feel moved to read more from that point. This volume is such a great bargain because it contains such brilliant writings in a lucid English translation at such a great price. It also includes a nice introduction.

The pianist Alfred Brendel is a sensitive and nuanced interpreter of Catholic composer Franz Liszt's Hungarian Rhapsodies. For depth and tonality, this album is one of the best recordings you will find, particularly if you're looking to perform Liszt yourself. Brendel is no flashy or risk-taking performer, but an accomplished and relaxed master of the keyboard, which comes through very strongly in this listening experience. His performance is confident and robust, but also balanced and consistent, remaining faithful to the music as Liszt wrote it. The sound on this CD recording is a bit quiet at times and may require some volume boosts, but overall it is a highly satisfying rendition. I recommend it for all lovers of Liszt and all lovers of great classical pianists.

After years of being dissatisfied with different paperback editions of Plato, I finally stumbled across this Dover Thrift Edition of Plato's four most essential biographical dialogues. Focusing on the life and person of Socrates, this razor-thin paperback volume is the most affordable and accessible introduction to Plato that you will find on the market. Rather than plunging you directly into the Republic and other more abstract writings, it wisely focuses on what we all love about Plato: His dialogues centering on the eccentric life and Christ-like death of his great teacher Socrates. This English translation is the old standard one, of course, but it's a wonderfully slender little volume that gives you enough Plato without overwhelming you. For those of us who like our Plato in small doses, rather than in a fat trade paperback (i.e. Signet Classics) or big expensive tome of collected writings, this volume is wonderful. In our electronic world, there's little need to have all the writings of Plato in one hardcopy edition anyway, as one will easily find several free and inexpensive translations of his entire corpus in electronic formats online.

This thick paperback volume contains selections from the "Summa Theologica" with glossary, commentary, and heavy footnotes from Boston College professor Peter Kreeft. If you're looking to dive into the medieval Catholic philosophy of St. Thomas Aquinas, you may find this book a good starting point, as it explains technical terms while doing its best to make the Angelic Doctor's massive tome accessible for students today. It's still a very formidable text in its own right, presenting the dilemma of whether to read through the text first and then the footnotes later, or to undertake the painstaking process of reading through both at the same time. Kreeft's writings are sometimes a mixed bag, as he is not always wholly successful in popularizing philosophy, but this particular book (like "Philosophy 101: An Introduction to Philosophy") is one of his stronger efforts. Personally, I stopped reading after awhile because I realized I could ingest more by reading through Aquinas directly and looking things up at my leisure. That's very easy to do in an electronic age where you can easily search electronically for terms and other technicalities. Nevertheless, this book is invaluable for those who want the guidance of a great teacher like Kreeft, whose books are probably the next best thing to taking his classes at the venerable Jesuit institution where he has been a fixture for many years.

Just in time for Pope Francis to canonize Saint John Paul II on 27 April 2014, we have a new book on the saint by popular Catholic youth speaker Jason Evert. Evert, Jesuit-educated at Brophy Prep, has made a career with his wife Crystalina as a popular fixture on the Catholic youth and young adult speaking circuit. Speaking in the U.S. and beyond, they emphasize the value of chastity and of saving oneself until marriage, frequently citing their inspiration from JPII's theology of the body. As such, it's highly appropriate that this new book focuses on the "five loves" of a pope who focused a good part of his ministry on recovering a self-sacrificing notion of human love for the public square. This is a reverential book written with style and humor in an accessible, non-technical style. If you've read Evert's other books on sexuality and relationships, you'll know what to expect here, but there's a more warmly personal focus in this book on the pope whose love for humanity inspired so many. If you want uplifting spiritual reading for Easter, I highly recommend this paperback book as a simple love letter to the "pope of the young" whom so many of us still recall with deep affection.

This hardcover book with ribbon markers is the standard cheap English edition of the "Book of Blessings" revised under Pope John Paul II in the late 1980s, approved for use in the dioceses of the United States. It is indispensable for any Roman Catholic priest or parish. Although it's possible this book's translation from the original Latin will again be revised in the distant future, as Pope Benedict XVI did with the Roman Missal in fall 2011, this revision will not happen anytime soon. We Latin Rite Catholics must simply substitute "and with your spirit" for the old response and continue using everything else here for the foreseeable future. There are also abridged editions of this book ("Shorter Book of Blessings," etc.) that include only the blessings used outside of mass, being more suitable for pastoral work on the road. This larger book is the one to get for your parish sacristy or priest's personal library. It includes all of the special blessings that one may use within mass, i.e. Mothers Day blessings and blessings of liturgical items. If you know a newly ordained priest or parish that needs an extra copy of this book for blessings, or perhaps a new one to replace a tattered old copy, then I highly recommend getting this book. It's the New York Catholic Book Publishing edition, not the Liturgical Press edition that is a bit more expensive, and it's quite durable as with all products from that company. It will enhance the liturgical life of your community to have a copy handy whenever needed.

I have always used Spry and loved its product line, including their gum and pastilles, for their taste and to reduce cavities in my children and myself.  It seemed to be effective because whenever we used Xlear toothpaste, we seemed to get no cavities compared to the years we used regular Crest or Colgate fluoride toothpastes.  During those years, cavities abounded, and our diet has not changed appreciably since then.  If anything, I think we probably consume even more sugar today than we did years ago."Xylitol cannot be metabolized by plaque bacteria, contrary to sorbitol and other 6-carbon polyols, and may thus favour mineralization."  This is from the European Journal of Dentistry.  HOWEVER, this same source also indicates:  "Studies with low daily doses of xylitol are known as a rule to fail to show any caries-preventive effects. To obtain beneficial xylitol-effects on mutans streptococci, on plaque and caries occurrence xylitol must be consumed three times or more per day, with a daily dose of 5-6 grams."  (Eur J Dent. Apr 2009; 3(2): 81-82.)How does xylitol work to prevent caries?  It inhibits growth of the oral bacteria Streptococcus mutans.  (Incidentally, it also prevents periodontal disease and has been shown to be effective at reducing the risk of ear infections.)Other studies I saw indicated an optimal dose for cavity prevention in the order of 4.3 to 10 grams per day.  So how much xylitol is in this toothpaste, and how much are you getting when you place a small amount on your toothbrush each day?This is difficult to quantify since everyone uses a different amount of toothpaste.  However, some smart people have already done the math for us at xylitolpreventscavities.com.  Basically, Spry contains 25% xylitol, and it is not the first ingredient after the active ingredient, which is fluoride.  The first ingredient is water.We are getting around half a gram to a gram of xylitol each time we brush our teeth with this product.  Therefore, the more xylitol in the product, the closer we get to the optimum dose.  The highest concentration is found in Squigle toothpaste (which you can find here on Amazon; I have it and will use it more than Spry now that I know this).  To obtain the optimum dosing of xylitol in your diet for caries prevention, you would probably need to chew Spry gum and pastilles at least a few times a day.Moreover, the controversy around the harmful effects of fluoride has been widely published, and certain cities in the United States have even removed it from their water supplies, I have steered clear of fluoride toothpastes.  Ah, but Xlear Spry has fluoride in it, 0.243%, according to the label.  This is why I removed a star from a potential five star rating.  Xlear makes a non-fluoride Spry toothpaste, and that one I would give five stars.I like the taste of this toothpaste.  It is very minty without being overwhelming.  It did take me three days to get used to its different minty taste, but afterwards, I liked it more and more than any commercial fluoride toothpaste I had ever used, including Tom's.  My children like the taste, also, and this is important to promoting brushing.  Overall, I would recommend it, but not over its non-fluoride counterpart.  Despite its lengthiness, I hope this review has helped people make an informed decision.

These fit my husband's Sonicare perfectly, and were easy to go on.  He is an avid coffee-drinker, and these Intercare brush heads are the only ones that remove the coffee stains.  I think his teeth would be brown without these brush heads.  He has been using them for nearly eight years.Even though they are supposed to be replaced every three months, we get by perfectly well on six months without undue wear and tear on the bristles.  Highly recommended!

So, the fine folks at Mezzati asked me to review my purchase of these bed sheets, and I am happy to comply.  I won't waste space or your time writing a lengthy review.I LOVE these sheets.  I poked round Amazon looking for a nice, affordable set of basic king bed sized sheets.  I saw many other sheets for more money than these babies, and their reviews were slightly lower.  I thought to myself, "What gives?"  I thought it was the pricier the better with bed sheets!  Not so.  Unlike most other sheets I have bought in department stores, these sheets do NOT PILL, do not have hanging threads, and do not smell bad when you unwrap them.What DO they do, then?  They provide a super-easy bed-making experience courtesy of their extra-deep seamed pockets (no more re-tucking sheets or re-making the bed after a night of sleep when your big husband manages to untuck every corner on his side).  So, sheets stay tucked.They are supremely soft.  I was surprised at how soft they are.  They are very comfortable against the skin.  And when I wash them, I have a feeling they will wash well - but I'm using cold water just to be sure.Bottom line?  These are excellent sheets for the price.  Beyond excellent.  Highly recommended.

Where have these been all my life?  I explain to my daughter the myriad types of inferior, bulky, and useless pads that existed when I was a teen in the eighties, and she and I heave sighs of relief that she doesn't have to go through all that mess.  "How did you ever have a life during your period, Mama?"Well, I sort of didn't.  Those were the days when heavy flow gals like us curled up with a good book and stayed home, or in bed, or anywhere they could always be near a bathroom.  But those days are gone.These pads are amazing.  Heavy flow is directed to the bottom of the pad and well-distributed throughout, so when you can't get to a bathroom for a couple of hours, you needn't worry.  The pad can handle the extra flow, and even better, the top lining manages to stay dry, so you don't even feel the moisture against your skin.Watch out, though, because these pads are so efficient at trapping flow that they can trick you into thinking there is less flow within them than there really is.  To demonstrate:  after it has had a chance to absorb quite a bit, next time, turn the pad over when you remove it.  You will see that the entire pad is drenched, with the blood occupying an area much larger than the smaller stain visible to you on the top lining.I have had days when I wasn't able to get to a bathroom for hours, or when I (very often) forgot to place extra pads in my purse and gone out for the day, and these babies never let me down.  Such times used to create a major mess in my pants, accompanied by several panicked minutes in a bathroom stall trying to figure out how to ditch my companions, steal someone's sweater or jacket, AND/or race home sitting on a towel, grocery bag, ANYTHING to protect my car seats, but not with these Radiant Infinities!  I have not had a single leak or accident with them yet, and I can flow up to 10 ml per hour on my heavy days (measured with a Diva Cup).  That's a lot.  I would estimate that these pads can hold 20 times their weight in liquid.They are the ONLY pads our family of women uses.

My husband uses these on trail marathons, and they provide quick, usable energy for him.  He says that he likes the strawberry and citrus flavors more than this tropical punch, but he still used these up fast!  Clif Bloks are the go-to energy source for distance running and cycling (which is what I use them for).PROS:  nary any stomach upset with these babies; the carb-delivery system is super-fast -- around 15 minutes -- so you don't have to wait long for bioavailable energy.CONS:  for high demands like racing and anaerobic efforts, the energy is quickly assimilated, but also fast-burning.  It doesn't last very long, so you need several Bloks, but at least it keeps you from bonking.

I ordered these boots for my husband who is a construction superintendent.  In today's lean times, he has had to perform more and more labor with his guys due to severe layoffs of workers.  He has always done a lot of labor, anyway, so he always requires specific features in his work boots, namely, that they have steel-toes (OSHA requirement), are waterproof, do not lace higher than 8" due to chronic Achilles issues caused by this type of footwear, and during winter months, are insulated.These are not the finest of the boots he has worn over the years, but they get the job done.PROS:  they are what they claim to be; they fit well; they are heavy-duty; and they are moderately comfortable.  They also seem to have non-marking soles, an important feature for walking on light-colored floors in his high-end, custom made homes.CONS:  He claims that they are not truly waterproof, which makes sense.  His 100% waterproof boots in the past have had a layer of Gore-Tex or other waterproofing.  I think these are merely chemically treated, not seam-sealed, for waterproofing.They do not have a reinforced covering on the toes, so the steel toe covering on these will wear out for him in about five months, exposing the metal.  This has occurred in the past.  Since he is superintendent, this is unacceptable to him, for safety reasons as well as regulations.Overall, a good work boot.  It will get the job done.  However, for people like my husband who go through boots quickly, they won't last a year.

EVERY single time I order a product from Anker, it works seamlessly for me.  I bought this cable (actually, I bought two) so my daughter could have one in her computer backpack and another in the car so that she is never without juice for her favorite device - iPod Touch - because she cannot live without music.This cable is nice and long so that it can reach from front seat to back seat charger and vice versa.  With our high-speed dual USB car charger (TopG), this cable can charge a nearly dead, 5th generation iPod in about half an hour.I wouldn't hesitate to recommend it to all you people looking for another lightning cable for your Apple device(s).  Peace!!

I recently got braces at age 46, and this mirror saved me from tears of frustration when trying to floss.  As those of you with braces know, it really takes two hands, a good magnification mirror, and a great deal of patience to floss effectively, especially those dark crevices in the molars and premolars.  I was able to cut my flossing time in HALF with this mirror.I looked at several others, but their magnifications were not as strong as this one . . . 2X-7X magnification just doesnt cut it as well as this wonderful 10X.  The padded, scratch-free base is narrower than the diameter of the mirror, small enough to take up very little space on your bureau, table, or vanity, yet large and heavy enough to be sturdy.  The diameter is around 5 1/2" -- about the length of a woman's hand -- and the base is around 4".You can hold the mirror as far away from your face as the length of a toothbrush without any distortion.  It also great for tweezing, makeup application, and teaching children about mirrors and magnification.  I just wish it came with a light.  Then it would be perfect!

I am a 46-year-old woman who just got braces.  It has been quite the journey during the first week getting used to them and all their "friends":  the sores in my inner cheek, the difficulty eating food and eliminating certain foods I used to eat, and especially the challenge of keeping my teeth and gums clean.I did a lot of research on different orthodontics flossing devices, and I ending up buying Platypus orthodontic flossers along with Oral-B Superfloss, G.U.M. Go Betweens Proxabrushes, regular floss to be used occasionally with the threader from my orthodontist, and a 10X magnification mirror.  I went from being in tears trying to floss my teeth to finally heaving a sigh of relief with a smile once I figured out how to keep my teeth clean.  Here is what I have found works best:The Platypus flossers are wonderful, easy to use, and the easiest of all the flossers in terms of "feel".  That is, I don't have to look in the mirror to use them.  I can easily tell by feel where to place the Platypus under the wire between my brackets.  However, these flossers do NOT work when the brackets are placed very closely together.  This is the case with my bicuspids and cuspids.  Due to how my teeth need to move and rotate properly, my orthodontist placed the brackets on two adjoining teeth (on each side) very, very closely together, so the Platypus flosser does not fit at all in between these teeth because the space between the brackets is too narrow.  It won't even fit under the arch wire!In that case, the Oral-B Superfloss is my perfect solution.  I can easily thread its tiny, narrow, stiff end right in between the narrowest of crevices (under the arch wire) in order to floss.  It works even better than the stiff threader my orthodontist provided.  I wouldn't be able to floss everything without it.  It is so easy to use that I tend to use the Superfloss more often than the Platypus flossers.  I also love how this little box fits neatly in my purse, and that the strands are pre-cut.For my premolars and molars, both the Superfloss and these Platypus flossers work almost equally well.  Again, the Platypus flossers work best in the rear of my mouth where the brackets are spaced more widely apart due to the larger size of the molars.  I use the G-U-M Go Betweens back here, also, because they are perfect for clearing packed food from between my brackets and around the arch wire.Finally, the other indispensable part of my flossing routine is the stand-up 10X magnification mirror. Before I ordered it from Amazon, I wasn't able to see in the way back of my mouth where I needed to floss because my jaw is so narrow.  I needed both hands to separate my lips and cheek from the flossing area, and I couldn't do that while holding a mirror.Right now, with all of these tools, I can floss faster and more easily!  I hope this helps all those frustrated souls who, like me, struggle with very crowded teeth and newly placed braces and who were beginning to think flossing effectively would be impossible.  It's not if you have the right tools.  Don't give up, and you will find the solution that is best for you.

This is a perfect primer for someone who has little knowledge of Persia at all.  It does do a great service in acquainting the reader to the multiple forces at work in this region. If there is a quibble and it is a small one is that too much attention is placed on the Alexandian conquest which really changed Greece far greater than it did Persia. That said, I have lays wondered the true rationale as to why the Palavy Shah chose to change the country's name from Persia to Iran (we still speak of the Persian Gulf and the Fars predated everyone else). It also manages to explain stereotypes  and modern perceptions without standing on a soap box, a scholarly work.

Without a doubt this timeless classic is always a challenge for translators since Virgil's meter never changes but each new generation's does.At best, a translation hints at the flavor and spirit of a work. This modern translation seems to do the trick and with the exceptions of an interlinear translation or a academic study is as close as you will get.

This story abut some rather wayward Englishmen who contrive a club to hide their amourous activities would certainly be rather flat fare if done by another writer.  Kingsley's gift in writing a story based on several absurd premises would seem nothing but burlesque if it was not for his brutally effective sense of the absurd behind the absurd.  If you enjoyed him in the past, this story will not disappoint nor surprise you.  Aside from the captions at the beginning of each chapter, I do wonder what Mr. Conquest's contribution was.

Perhaps the greatest story about French society, as seen through the prism of the Indochina experience, or a war story, military tradition, modern warfare, and even this is scant praise. If you want to experience what occurred to France in the post WWll period and especially its military men this is the book. This book impressed me so much that it would take pages to describe why, suffice it to say that it is great literature and each character from Colonel Raspequy, to Esclavier, Glatingy, Boisfeuras to the lowest enlisted man, is arresting and true to life.Beyond the French milieu, as literature it addresses many human universal concerns and that is why I call it great literature. If I find one fault in the book, it is this, although it concerns young fighting men and their view point, I find that the women who play only supporting roles or props for the men are too simplistic if not seen through a misogynistic men but I can prescribe this because we are seeing them trough young men's eyes who are being brutalized by war and captivity.Not only is the psyche of the French fighting man examined but the process by which he became politicized and the conflicts which this generated not only in the army but also vis a vis the civilian population. I read this in 1964 originally and it haunted me from then on. The first time reader will ask himself many questions looking back at history French and American and ponder about current events.To realize how traumatic a period this was for France, think of it as the American Viet Nam experience raised to the third power.

This is simply a collection of ideas that may be of some use to an art teacher with little or no imagination. It reminds me of the old saw, those that can do, those that can't teach. Curious as to why the book was written when there are so many competent art books of all types and prices.

I must say that this book is disappointment as a sequel. The plot is too contrived and the solution to all the murders in the story is merely literary conceit. I won't add more on this because it truly would ruin the book for other readers. Unfortunately, all the personal relationships are one dimensional especially between Sebag and his daughter. Perhaps Mr. Georget will get back on track with his next book by forgetting this one.

Why read another mystery or write one you may ask. Well the narrator or hero must be interesting and not too overwhelmingly concentrated. While mid-life angst is apparent here, our view of him is reasonable, his quest for justice is really rather rational. Two murders that may be interconnected but may be overlooked will pique the reader's interest. Inspector Sebag's gradual realization that he is being toyed with and the stakes are too gruesome to imagine drive the reader's interest which I admit was somewhat slow in coming.Particularly interesting or infuriating depending on your point of view is the fact that while the crime is solved, there is no resolution to Sebag's personal problems which I found refreshing.

This really should be a primer for those students in high school who wish to become historians or at the very least history majors in college. While discussing the history of prehistoric Europe or the Mediterranean basin it does take the reader away from the ancient Egypt classical Tigris and Euphrates orientation and brings to life a whole new way of looking at the cultural development of that region.Dated though some of the factual information is, the concept of prehistory in Europe is one that is still ignored in education today. Aside from the fact that it is a pleasantly accessible book, it is in its own way rather revolutionary.

Aside from the fact that it is a dated work (for the scholars and specialists) this book is if interest because it shows how little an impact has been made in the popular culture especially the past 50 years. What a book such as this is help illustrate how women were viewed as well as men in their particular cultures and times and how fruitless it is to attempt to view femininity through the prism of contemporary times and prejudices.So the problem with Sappho has little to do with Aspasia and let us not even begin to consider Alexander the Great's problems with women , began with his mother ended with Roxana. So let historical research's fresh air into the room.

I think it a fair question and perhaps the most important one to ask when one judges a book, is to ask is "Did the author succeed in what he what he attempted to do?". In this case it safely be answered in the affirmative, a very emphatic affirmative.I hesitate to call this an experimental novel and I certainly do not think that "stream of consciousness" may be applied to this novella. I can understand the urge to use these terms because they suggest a certain type experience that a reader feels when he reads an unorthodox or nontraditional work.  Why not a stream of consciousness?  Well if we look at James Joyce's "Molly Bloom's soliloquy" we find a string of reminiscences that are not driven by external events, while "experimental" connotes uncharted forms, this is definitely a traditional manner of story-telling.This is the a story that begins with a death and through the reminiscences of an inmate in a mental institution examines those life experiences which formed his character and led him to his fate. It mangers to avoid mawkish sentimentality and all too clever literary devices. No grand denouncement, no Eureka! by the reader, just tense, well-crafted story-telling. You want, not only to like the character but also to understand him. Sympathize with him, yes but decidedly not empathizing with him. Surprisingly, all fits together in a most believable way and this reader did not feel cheated in any way. Let us say that this is an interior dialogue which the read overhears.Written in the first person narrative, I must say that I enjoyed meeting all the characters and that is saying much since I personally loathe the type of self-indulgent upper Manhattan elitist poseurs. But then that is what makes a very good book.  So put away your fears that you will have to do Borges inspired machinations to understand what is happening.

OK if you  like war stories, love stories, mythic story-telling, political thrillers and the best damn classical Latin epic you will ever come across. The contemporary reader who gives this classic a chance will find himself captivated by a world where history was spelled with a capital H.

If you were impressed and moved by Larteguy's "The Centurians," you will more than satisfied by this book. All those fascinating characters are recreated and their tortured lives and destinies are finally put to rest if not in peace. Raspeguy, Esclavier, Glatingny and their friends and enemies are dealt with. There is even a believable leitmotif about Esclavier's capablilty to love.The main theme of this book is about what happens when apolitical Centurians become very political Praetorians. For the average American reader, the constant ringing of the May 13th bell may not resonate until the very end but the reader will definitely see post war France in a very different and truer light.Misogynistic perhaps but the heroes of this book are young men and act and think with the passions and concerns and wants and needs of the young.  Read the book at 13 years of age and reread at 65 it still fascinates and rings truer still.  Hopefully the reissuing of "The Centurians" augurs in a revival of all of Larteguy's works.

The e-edition is as perfect as the book. It is a classic about, fill in the blanks, New World versus Old World, innocence wounded by hypocrisy, too many themes to innumerate unless one wants to beat the proverbial dead. This is possibly the aesthetically accessible book for the modern reader of James and it is a good pace for the uninitiated to begin their reading of this master.

This book is fascinating for several reasons aside from the obvious fact that it is a brilliant introductory course in pre-Minoan history. Without belaboring this obvious fact, it is interesting in that it was written at the dawn of an era which was applying modern scientific methods to that field and as far as fields such as these go we are truly just progressing to the next level added by continual archiological discoveries as the author reminds us even back then.  If the reader wants a sense of how exciting this field and its ideas were, than this is the perfect place to start.

One of the classic poems of the twentieth century and probably one of the more readily accessible to understand, this poem has been studied to death, deconstructed, reconstructed, ravaged for hidden meanings and trends that his enemies hope to "discover," so what should a reader do?Pound would answer simply "Read The Poem." There are a multiple sites and books that will aid the reader in the many allusions and historical references to increase his enjoyment. What I particularly like about this poem is the presence of his friend's aesthetic relationship so evident inthe second part.

The remarkable Mr. Pound continues to bring the past to modern relevance, in this work it is his past-our modernity. While talking about French poets little known to most but the modern American English major and only in context of influences on Eliot or Auden and their like, he does us a great service by his critiques of among others of T S Eliot and Henry James.  Writing when he did, these essays have the benefit of and the fascination to us of learning how these works were written before their authors works became encrusted with the patina of fame and acceptance or placed in the pantheon of literary gods who no one can critique.What critic or student would spend time and effort to discuss Eliot's "The Hippopotamus" with same level of scrutiny of his other works,  As for Henry James the section is remarkable for among other reasons in that it sheds light on Pound's himself view of the artist and the world even if an unintended manner and oblique manner. Savor the irony of 'the past is prologue" sentiment of Pound's understanding of Henry James' renunciation of his American citizenship and future events.Mote to the point is the excitement of having Mr. Pound give his personal opinions of many of James' works and compare the to most readers today. I find the opinions the "The Aspern Papers" and "The Spoils of Poynton" to be inferior works in the James' canon of works.fascinating.Even his friend's discourse, included in this work sheds light on the direction of Pound's artistic interests. Well that said if you appreciate Pound you will feel rewarded to see a master at the height of his powers at work and thought.

There is no doubt that this book meets almost all the criteria that a good summer should read should have. The machinations of the Soviet spy services are believable and and if the plot and conclusion are a bit too much of a strain on belief (a military putsch in Russia) there is enough background information and historical allusions to keep the reader engaged.We don't expect a book such as this to have characters that are complex but at least they must be interesting and if there is one interesting character is the KGB agent who is ambivalent during much of the book but has several inteesting quirks e.g. a belief in the Russian Orthodox Church. Not a great book but a very enjoyable tale.

If you have ever wondered where all the stock movie cliches about evil, ghosts, death, then look bo further. Walpole will take you through an Italianate world that is light on fact but lush in imagery.  The book seems to know just where it should end.  Great literature,no, but a great influence on a particular pop-genre.  Far superior to much of what passes for horror stories today.  This ain't no Cujo.

This is certainly a book of immense ambitions and as such I feel that any attempt to "analyze" a book such as this, in this forum would be pointless. However a few impressions that I hope encourage the reader to purchase this work.It may seem at the outset that the book is a bit too heavy on narrative descriptions of Venice, masking the reason why the author this site.  This really would apply only to those who have visited Venice many times and I put myseol in that category (even to the point where I could direct the author to a direct vaporetto ride to Torcello).This is a story told in black and white not shades nor colors which might make think the characters are too one dimensional if seen from a certain perspective, however I tend to feel that the point of the book is not a tale of people but rather a tale of ideas like taking a gondola through the dimly lit streets and being by an idea.The two story thread is a bit disorienting and the character does not wring true, he has too many modern sympathies and thoughts but I assume this was not the point and much that he relates could have been edited out.If you have read other stories about Venice, you will delight in the allusions.  My favorite being the supremely obnoxious Fred who one can't help but recall several characters for Mann's "Death In Venice.  As for its readability whatever that is, the action flows swiftly, the tension builds and the reader will enjoy it immensely if you let it take you on a gondola ride through history.I thank the author for sending me a copy and it has inspired me to purchase(!) his other works.

One realizes immediately that if one is not an Anglophile of a certain type that that individual would not have the patience to follow the endless machinations and intrigues of what is a pitifully small world. The essential saving grace of the book is the absolute clarity and incisive examination of the characters psyches. Let the professors plot and contrive to elect a new Cambridge master what matters is the motivations. The final chapter is certainly a downer but the end of any era is such.There is no question that if you find this book appealing, then you should immerse yourself in the series.

I loved this book because it shows how far Dante scholarship has come in the past 150 years.  This book is a good introduction for the reader who has no inkling of Dante, not just his work but his times. The reader will begin to realize why the poet is such a big deal if a bit ethereal for present day tastes.  Also the author does not make the mistake of being obsessed with the first third of the poem which as a problems with the Victorian era.

What more needs to said about a touchstone of western literary history? Being more accessible to modern day sensibilities the first time reader would have less trouble approaching this work. If there is one facet of the work which is overlooked it is the role of Telemacus, Odysseus' son.  Take this translation in stride and if it is not to your liking,there are many more.

Pope's translation is particularly important aside for the obvious reasons but for the poetic muse he let loose in the poetry of his contemporaries. Anyone who wishes to start to become a literate reader would do well to acquaint himself with the work and not to rely on synopses.  What else is new?
