This is a fine introduction to the world of drawing for the total neophyte (like myself) who wish to acquaint himself with drawing and perhaps or not continue. If you wish to advance beyond doodling and learn to take a pen and paper and create something that gives you a sense of accomplishment or pleasure, if only you, then buy this delightful and concisely written book.In the early part of the 20th century, the well educated Englishman was instructed in drawing.  One need only think of a Max Beerbohn or even the simple sketches of an Evelyn Waugh to see this fact.  Why did they do it? They liked to do it. So join the literati and start to scribble.

This novel written by whom some call the Italian George Washington is a more of a political tract under the guise of a novel.  Everything is either black or white, good versus evil, freedom versus slavery and damn the moderates!  If you want to experience a period piece of story telling you will find this a rather entertaining.  You won't be experiencing a cathartic experience but the chapters are short and the characters numerous.Garibaldi was certainly a child of the Enlightenment and his profound anti-Romanism, nationalism, and a profound belief in neo-platonism are evident. The book most possibly sheds more light on the novelist's state of mind and it should be required reading for students of that particular period Italian history.  It gives a great deal of insight how the times were viewed by a certain class of people.  As a curious aside, in the book Garibaldi forecasts a united or federated Europe. Sometimes dreams come true.

Pity poor Ford Maddox Ford.  He is in the unenviable position for a writer of having one pen in the past (19th century realism) and the other in the nascent Modernist future.  Stylistically the novel seems to adopt a modern tone but unfortunately quickly descends into 19th century romanticism.Thematically, the story really is a stretch for modern readers. Do we really a man would marry and tolerate the adulteries of his wife who he describes as a libertine, and remain friends with her latest lover not only until his wife's death but beyond.  If the psyche of women are too implausible to believe, then the view of male motives borders on the absurd.Such is the fate of Ford that he was no Hemingway but a budding Jack London.  Why he really never developed as other writers he championed is a mystery but the book does show a Dickensonian gift for relating a an epic tale with varies characters.  Enjoyable reading if you accept the initial premise, gentlemen don't tell or care too much.
Certainly this is a seminal work about not only the founders of this country, but also a signpost as to what the Europeans think about the American experience. Enough said about this classic.

This book is one of those seminal works that anyone who wants to be considered well-versed in American history must read.  The observations nd predictions of trends are truly astonishing. Briefly, it took a rather brash young Frenchman to accurately take the pulse of a most brash young country.The prose is captivating and pleasant to read and the style is something that certainly and aptly conveys its ideas to the contemporary reader.

This a play about Christian love versus secular sentimentality. The statement certainly makes this play irrelevant in today's world.  The subtleties and the philosophical musings will infuriate the contemporary reader as most certainly the miracle that occurs. Yet the questions posed and (surprising) answered should resonant in each generation.The contemporary reader may find this play too didactic and stylistically the characters do present an aesthetic problem, three major characters, three great problems, all are resolved. Yet that was his worldview and certainly works better as a play than a reading experience.

If there is a moment of despair in a writer's career, it is when he comes upon another artist's work and asks the question "How does he do it?"  I can only say that Sarah Hall continually causes much despair in the artistic community. Her latest work "The Wolf Border" illustrates that she is one of those few writers whom the reader can say that he is privileged to have read.This is a complex concoction of themes and personal relationships told in a very, almost traditional, natural style think Hemingway, Jack London or any naturalistic writer. This is a story about the relocation and reintroduction of wolves into the Cumbria, England.  The relationships of the personnel between themselves, the locals, the the relationship between England and Scotland. Rachel the protagonist, and Binny, her mother, Rachel's new born son, her brother, to name just a few are profoundly explored.The descriptions of the Cumbrian countryside are Turner-esque and must be experienced to be appreciated. In short, the style of this novel is perfect.There are profound observations about what this book is all about, and that is "Borders." This book should certainly be placed in the pantheon of great works of writing, it is that good.

This wily novella or short may disappoint those fans of the Montalbano series since it is an alteration but not a profound change in the interplay of characters in the series. The most notable is the interplay between the inspector and Catarella.  It is less comic and more realistic than previous appearances of Cat, while retaining some of the tension between the two. This can be said of the entire story and how much is the author's intention and how much of it is the result of a different translator is open to question.Enough (basta) it is a typical Camilleri story with all the secondary characters as complex and challenged as you would expect. Just don't expect a short version of the novels and enjoy it for what is offered.

I imagine that the biggest difficulty with approaching this book is that it must be read as part of a series and loses much if it is the reader's introduction to the series as it is with me.  Even given that fact, I find that this book never rises above the level of boilerplate mysteries.The chief character and his relationships with the other characters are so shallow, trite, and predictable that they just about insult the readers' intelligence.  The plot and the premises and the list of characters surrounding it are so extraordinary for a small village that they defy belief.  The ending and final denouncement seem to be tacked.No this is no French mystery but a  transported Hollywoodesque parody of the real thing written by a reporter and not a novelist.

What a centrifuge of a mystery, faster and faster until the reader reaches the center of the vortex. Light on personality and human inter-reaction it is plot driven, absolutely. Who dun it? I don't know, nor will the readers and who is Le Fur when Jobin is the main character?  It is difficult to to detail the plot without ruining the story but this chase across Europe about a serial child killer runs on pure energy. A very promising start to a (I hope) unpretentious series.

This seems to be a rather slapdash affair written in a pseudo-Victorian jargon with no other purpose than to extract mild curiosity in the reader while promoting a series. The characters are one dimensional (even the Ice Demon is uninteresting)  And the reason for all the hub bub well I won't spoil it for you but really is banal. The exposition and description which should really be top notch in setting a Victorian era atmosphere just isn't there.  All in all a waste of time that points to a lack of talent or discipline.

It is nice to back in time and experience the intellectual curiosity, arduous scholarship, extensive travelling that was inaugurated by people such as Mr. Williamson in a long past era. If you wish to study about Perugino, painting by painting, fresco by fresco. medium by medium and even town by city he visited or worked in, then this would be a good place to start.If you wish only to appreciate, there are more modern studies which will satisfy your desires.  If such is the case, peruse this study and appreciate the eye of Williamson since it is as though you are standing next to him as he observes each work.  This is a very fine series.

The better the book, the shorter the review. The story of a most uncommon, common woman who devotes her life to a genius mathematician from pre-WWII Austria and ends up at Princeton University. May as well talk about Dante and Beatrice.Yannick Grannec forms does seem to be Dantesque since she handles so many complex human relationships, so well, that the reader may think that her sections on mathematical theory are a distraction but I believe they are not. I say "believe," because it will take another reading to fully understand what the author hopes to accomplish.  So try it because it will certainly stretch your intellect.

Tipping my hat to Nicholas Ponticello, I will try to be understated, a bit wry, and well, ornery.  This is the story of a man looking at the his past life, while his daughter convinces him to have his memories put on a computer so he will live forever.  And then the reminiscences start.  There is no center of gravity in this story.The future is bleak, there is famine, starvation, curiously non-evils scientists, love, death, copulation and death. What makes this satiric exercise so enjoyable is that the author takes this tale with a pithy sense of comedy.  How does the protagonist ... forget it its too complex and absurd but entertaining (the protagonist's sister becomes a saint, a one sentence mentions the nuclear bombing of Atlanta, Ga.and then no more.) The Past, Present, Future all are commented on and everything seems to be lacking.So if you are looking for a second level Kingsley Amis from California and a good time treat yourself, but only on Kindle, its cheaper and will last forever.

I must say that is almost impossible to write a synopsis or critique of the novel without introducing "spoilers" (a term I dislike) so I will try to be as oblique as I can since the only saving grace of this novel is the apparent surprises. I should not have been surprised since the description of this book refers to Venice AD 1106 as a "backwater" is the first howler of this book(Venice circa AD 1100) was the financial and trading hub of Europe but don't let historical accuracy get in the way of a period piece.  Also to treat the island of Torcello (in the book its Latin name is used (Torcellum) as a secret island known only to a few Venetians is another anachronistic howler (Torcello was the site of the first cathedral in Venice and the founding island).If the author is writing an historical novel, there must be a miasma of the era surrounding the book, this has none and it could well have been written about a city in the desert. The characters one dimensional, but modern day one dimensional.  There is a slave yearning to be free, a deformed hunch back monk, nice monks, crafty monks, Glass blowers of all types (Hurrah it is Venice) an obese Syrian trader and his morbidly obese wife (sounds interesting, it isn't).Several murders with eyeless corpses, the eyes replaced with glass eyes found in the canal or the salt farms (see it really is Venice) which really have little to do with the theme of the story.  If it seems I am going beyond the pale, it may be that I had such high hope for it since it was released by Europa Press. This book is not formulaic but a very tedious and unsuccessful attempt to mimic the Umberto Eco's "The Name of The Rose."  The last 25% of the book will not only disappoint you but will insult your intelligence assuming you are not one who sees the world through books.

I think it necessary to mention at the beginning that there is one minor annoyance in this e-book and that is the formatting of the book which for some reason indents whole paragraphs and that this gives the impression that it was the author's intention and that for probably the reason or problem there are a few sporadically placed mis-translations e.g. "in feet" for "in fact" or "retracing his legs" when it should be "retracing his steps" etc.  Not a major problem but this is really only acceptable in free ebooks or those at a lower cost.However that does in no way diminish the delight of this short story collection by an artist more renowned for his plays than his short stories or novels. These chronically arranged collection of stories, although not complete, is certainly a showcase of the author-playwrite's development philosophically and not artistically. In the most edifying introduction by Felicity Firth, she points out the fact that there seems to be a different set of dynamics in male suicide and female suicide.  I must say that had I not read this observation this would not have occurred to me.What did catch my attention in the collection which spans a good portion of the author'd life is the change from a D'Annunzio type of realism or naturalism to what we later call Absurdism.  From Ciunna's death in "Sun and Shade" which is draped in the imagery of nature, to Candelora's death in the eponymous short story which is framed by poison and a revolver we sense how such a writer could produce a "Henri IV."I find the only unsatisfying story to be the last "A Challenge" which is set in Brooklyn and Manhattan. The reader would be well served to read a story or two a day, several times to appreciate the subtly and complexity of this collection.

This e-edition has apparently been reformatted for the better since most of the earlier complaints have been addressed.  That stated, the next question is why we should concern ourselves with Mr. Pope's poetry in the contemporary world.  One can write tomes about this and still not touch upon all the reasons.What can be said without fear of contradiction is that for the contemporary reader Mr. Pope's use of the heroic couplet makes the perusing reading quite comfortable while at the same time making him, the reader, pay close attention to each word and to HEAR the poem and to APPRECIATE the chosen words.  In these poems the profundity is there almost obviously but the BEAUTY is subtle and sophisticated (want the other extreme try e e cummings) So poetry lovers give him a tumble.

This product was one of the easier products to review because I have been using it for nearly my whole life and keep finding new uses for it.  I recently found that I could put about  3 scoops (the bag comes with a scoop that is about 1/4 of a cup) into my laundry with 3 drops of lemon essential oil and a tablespoon of liquid ecological soap and my clothes comes out feeling fresher and cleaner than they ever have before.  When I first did this formula, it also made my old washing machine smell better.  It seems that alkalizing the little bit of standing water left after the washing was over made some bacterial smell go away.  In a pinch, too, if you had too acidic a meal, 1/3 of a tablespoon of baking soda in an 8 ounce glass of water might soothe it (though in the long run it may be too much sodium).  My mother would put an open box in the fridge to get rid of odors and change it every few months.  My favorite use is to put 3 scoops into a hot bath.  It seems to alkalize the skin and make it feel fresh again.  I like it better than the the bath salts, which can actually feel a little drying afterwards, and which are more expensive to use.I am giving this wonderful product 4 stars, rather than 5 stars because it seems that the package had a small leak and arrived with some of the powder over the outside of the package and in the box.  Not much.  But I did notice that another reviewer found the same thing.

I got this product from the Amazon Vine list because it seemed similar to Floridex, which is also a vegetarian iron supplement.  Unlike the Floridex, it does not have any yeast product or wheat extracts.  It does have some honey, though, and so it may not be suitable for all Vegans, as some Vegans choose to not take honey.  I try to avoid taking honey also, but some seems to slip in through a few products and I make some exception for them.  Other than the honey, it is very suitable for vegetarians and some vegans.I found that I could feel some good energy after taking this product and this feeling was consistent each time I took it.  I like the range of herbs that were used:  Elderberry juice (400mg), Sea Buckthorn juice (100mg), Star Anise pod juice (90mg), Acerola (40mg), Rice bran extract (40mg), Beet root juice (40mg), special blend (2.4g of parsley, nettles, dandelion, fennel, and yellow dock).  I like the combination, like the Vitamin C hit from the Acerola natural source.  Nettles is very good for Chlorophyll.  The herbs themselves feel very nutritional and I imagine support how this product helps us to absorb the iron.Because it is a juice of veggies and fruit, it has a limited lifespan when opened, the package says to finish using it in 30 days and to throw away the remainder after then.I mixed the liquid in with a tea or a smoothy, and wove it into my routine this way.  The box says it is "non-constipating" and is "appropriate for pregnant and breastfeeding women".  I have seen warnings on other iron supplements that it could be constipating and that they are not suitable for pregnant women, breastfeeding women, and even just warning women in general to just be careful.  I suspect that the herbal matrix makes it safer and more absorbable.  I can verify in my own experience that I did not get constipated, but I cannot double check the other claims because of being a male.To be honest, I did take about double the recommended dose (which I do not recommend doing) and found the energy level increase easier to feel.  I often do this when reviewing products, because we have less than 30 days to feel out what it does.  I have found a few products show their effects more easily on a higher dose than what is on the label.  The fact that I did not get constipated at the higher dose is significant and shows it probably would be fine at the regular dose.Having said this, I will probably not get this product again, because I would rather not take something with honey.  I look for a product that is similar in quality to this that does not have honey as part of it.  I still give the product 5 stars, because it did not say it was vegan, but vegetarian, and therefore represented itself well.  I wish that more product pages would have full ingredient disclosure and have the honey mentioned.  I am choosing to disclose the more of the ingredients in my reviews so that people can make better informed decisions on whether or not to get a product.

This is the second product I got from the Amazon Vine list that mentioned that it was "suitable for vegans" or had veggie caps that did not have animal gelatin.  The product page says, "Suitable for vegetarians/vegans," and yet the label says, "Capsule consists of gelatin".  The product page needs to reflect the truth of the product accurately because when ordering online that is what we have to go on.  When I am buying at a store, I can read the label for myself and find out, even though I guess even labels might not always be accurate.I am generally happy to see Jarrow products because they do seem to have a vegan line of very good nutritional products.  But since this is the second time I have been fooled by the write ups, I am getting wary and cannot give the product 5 stars.Other than the above issue, this product worked.  I found I got a nice deep sleep.  I like the ingredients:  400mg of Valerian Root, 300mg of Tryptophan (apparently a high grade "TryptoPure" version, suggesting it is probably pharmacy grade or near pharmacy grade), 100mg of Hops, 100mg of Lemon Balm, 100mg of PharmaGABA, and 3mg of Melatonin.  I sometimes have made a nice sleep tea with Kava (which has GABA in it), Saint John's Wort, Lemon Balm, Lemon Grass, Mugwort, Valerian, and Mint, with some Stevia for sweetening (although this tea is very safe normally, if you are on prescriptions of some kind, you may wish to check with a health professional before trying.  I am not recommending this tea, just sharing my experience as a way of sharing by experience with this product by contrast).  I find the tea works better and stronger at causing deep relaxation.  But it takes some time to brew it right (I use Lemon Balm fresh from my garden and this helps a lot).  The capsules are convenient and work well.  It is a good combination of ingredients.  Valerian, Hops, and Lemon Balm are good relaxing nervines that I feel also help heal the nerves as well.  Melatonin helps reset our sleep cycle after we are throw off a good schedule.  GABA and Trytophan (when it converts inside to Serotonin) are both necessary for our brain to relax and let go.  They are nutrition for the brain.  While I still prefer my tea over this product, I find it is good to take a break from anything so that the body does not get too dependent on it.  The product has the advantage of being easy to take and having good and comparable quality ingredients.As mentioned above, I would have given it 5 stars if it were not this confusion about vegan vs non-vegan capsules in the write ups.  What I do when this happens, if I cannot return the product, is to empty the capsule into a liquid so that I do not have to take any gelatin into my body.

I got this product off the Vine list because of a book called THE EDGE EFFECT by Eric Braverman.  This book talks about 4 main chemicals that are needed for the brain to be fully healthy:  GABA, Serotonin, Dopamine, and Acetyl-choline.  The book also lists the supplements that are precursors to them so that we can synthesize them for our brain.  The Acetyl-choline part has Acetyl L-Carnitine mentioned (and which seems to metabolize better for brain purposes than L-Carnitine).  When I read up on the research regarding this supplement, I found it seemed to help support a fairly wide array of healthy functions in the body, from help build up ATP, recovery from fatigue, increasing stamina, boosting memory function, blood sugar balance, and the ability to handle oxidative stress.  The book says that one of the signs that we are deficient in Acetyl-choline is that we will be a little careless and misplace items (and the book goes into four personality prolifes of each deficiency of the said brain chemicals as well as what healthy functioning looks like).  I like to consider that these brain chemicals are like earth, fire, air, and water (GABA earth, Acetyl-choline fire, Serotonin water, and Dopamine air), with Acetyl-choline and Dopamine (from Macuna Puriens as far as an herbal source) being related to feeling more energy as well as functions like improved memory.I found that I could notice an increase in energy from taking this supplement and a little bit more brain alertness.  I tried about 4 capsules a day, emptying the contents into a smoothie (banana, coconut juice, apple, water, stevia, chlorella, and mint) and drinking it.  Just to be clear, I am not recommending the dosage that I took, just reporting what I did and what results I got.  I recommend people in general follow the dosage on the label and if they have any doubt of whether it is compatible with the biochemical individuality or some other part of their program, to check with a health professional.I put the ingredients into a smoothie because, for some reason I made a small mistake when ordering from the Vine list.  I usually only get what is in the veggie capsules and thought I had read that this was in veggie capsules.  The ingredients list said:"Cellulose, magnesium stearate (vegetable source) and silicon dioxide. Capsule consists of gelatin. No wheat, no gluten, no soybeans, no dairy, no egg, no fish/shellfish, no peanuts/tree nuts."And had so many vegan things like "no dairy", "vegetable source", and "no fish" that I overlooked the "gelatin" being mentioned.I give the product 4 stars because it is a high quality supplement, has good research behind it, and seems to give noticeable energy.  My one reservation is that it is not in vegan capsules and therefore is not suitable for vegetarians.  I wish the labeling of this would be clearer.  But for many people this is not an issue and this reservation does not apply.

I like this formula and am enjoying taking it.  The ingredients are:  Rhodiola rosea, Holy Basil leaf (two kinds extracted differently), Ashwagandha root, Wild oats milky seed fresh (Avena sativa), and Schisandra berry (Schisandra chinensis).  I like that they used CO^2 extraction to bring out the potency of the Tulsi Basil and validated the potency of various ingredients.  Ashwangandha is a tonic herb that I respect a lot and often have as tea (water infusion).  I like, too, that they use vegetarian capsules as I am a vegan and avoid gelatin capsules.  The company seems committed to making a quality product.  Having said, all this, I cannot verify in my experience that the capsules are doing anything, even when I took a double dose.  I give the product 4 stars, because the company seems to have taken care to produce a high quality product with very good ingredients.  I have not given it 5 stars, because I would have liked to feel more from taking them.  I am going to continue to take the capsules and if I notice anything in my experience I will update this review.Update:  I tried five capsules at the same time and bit into them to release the liquid inside.  I found that I could feel the tonic quality (first two herbs) of the herbal concentrate this way.  It seems that tasting the liquid helps the body to utilize the herbs.  I found this true for a number of bitter herbs and there are some in this formula.  At five capsules, I could feel the energizing qualities of the Schisandra herb.  (I do not recommend taking such a big dose, but I wanted to do this to see if I could feel something from these capsules and it worked.)

This product came in the mail and I opened it put some on some sore muscles and felt immediate relief.  It feels like it does not merely provide relief, but seems to help speed up recovery time some too.  I have used Homeopathic Arnica Gel before and am happy to use it again.  As mentioned in a review of the Homeopathic Arnica cream, I tried the Herbal version of Arnica (in a gel form) in a product and did not find it as a effective as the Homeopathic version.  I also prefer the clear gel to the cream version of this Homeopathic product.  While the cream and the gel both seem to work, the gel seems to work noticeably better and faster.  I would recommend this product for mild sprains and sore muscles.  While it would probably provide some relief for serious sprains or bruising that shows up as black marks, there are Homeopathic gels that have Hypericum (the Homeopathic version of Saint John's Wort, though the Herbal tincture also seems to work very well too) may be more effective.  There is a Homeopathic product called Traumeel that has both Hypericum and Arnica and a number of other Homeopathic preparations that is good for this kind of bruising.  I sent a tube of this up for my father when he slipped on some rocks while fishing on a jetty.  When I sprained my back severely he sent me a tube of the same thing.  In both my case and my father's case, the preparation provided some welcome pain relief, helping speeding up the healing, and seemed to help the overall healing program.  All in all, the product seems to be a useful addition to a medicine chest and I miss it when I run out of it.

I got this lap guitar as part of a set with an Ebow, a delay/reverb unit, and a looper in order to play a synthesizer drone sound.  This unit works for what I want it to do.  The guitar feels sturdy, all the controls work and add to fine tuning the sound (volume control and a bass/treble tone control).  The metallic blue color makes the guitar look good.  For 99 bucks, I feel I got a bargain, and it even included a case and legs that set up it to sit in front of (and the legs even store in the case in a separate compartment).  The case even has a free compartment where I am storing two thick and long cables.  The case feels sturdy and not cheap.  It feels like it will protect the guitar very well during transport.  I am playing the guitar unconventionally, more as a drone instrument.  It is kind of like an electronic Tamboura or Hurdy Gurdy, but with a lot of rich textures and sounds.  This is mainly due to the Ebow which magnetically vibrates the strings in a very long sustain (I can use my left hand to change the texture of the sustained note by gently touching in for a moment in a few ways or sliding it along the string).  I can even modulate the vibration by dialing the tuning pins and through this to find the desired tightness for optimal Ebow expression (as a drone instrument).  The reverb unit, of course, adds to the richness of the sound and the looper allows harmonics to form (the Ebow can only play one string at a time).  All in all, a good set of tools to work with.  I do feel that the lap guitar holds its place in the set and has no noticeable weakness performing with the Ebow as an effective drone instrument.  I give it 5 stars because it does what I want it to do and looks like a serious instrument.  FYI Guitar does not have a resonance chamber, it is only electronic.  It can sound without an amp, but is very low volume then (and then lacks the richness a good resonance chamber gives).

I got the Ebow in order to play a lap guitar like a synthesizer.  I got inspiration from an old CD that used a lap guitar, an Ebow, a delay/reverb unit, and a looper (duplicated the set for myself).  There are videos on youtube that are helpful to study to learn how to use the Ebow.  The best one was a long animated cartoon that went into detail about it.  The device works by magnetically vibrating a guitar string when it is held over it.  The main purpose is to create a very long sustain.  I found I got a much richer sound from this device than a Theremin, which I was also considering.  I found that I could generate a very long sustain and modulate with careful touch on the strings with my left hand.  The pressure does need to be very precise, too much dampens the sound to zero, too little can send the sound rapidly to a high volume.  The device itself is also a little fussy in that if it is too far from the string there is very little sound or no sound, and if it is too close you risk touching the string and creating a metalic reverb sound that can be a little sharp and high volume.  Even when you have the right distance, the string can increase its vibration and sometimes hit it, so you have to move it away a little once the sound gets going.  The flip side of the coin with the Ebow, though, is that the precision and fussiness rewards you with a lot of good control over the texture of the sound.  You can create highly textured long sustaining notes that change in subtle ways across its time horizon.  I found with just a little practice that I could lightly touch the strings and make "notes" in the tone wave.  I could also gently hold down the string and rev up the vibration to a good volume and then gently slide my left finger across the string to create gradual changes in the sound that enriched the texture of the sound, especially with a delay/reverb unit set on max.  With a little practice, too, you can control the metalic shimmer when the unit touches the string (or do something similar with the left finger) and also make this a rich sound.  I also could modulate the sound by dialing the tuning pins very slowly (and create an interesting tuning for the strings that maximizes the effect of the Ebow) and get an effect similar to sliding the finger across the string.  I also found that the blue LED light was enough to guide the right placement of the Ebow over the string and it is centered in line with the "sweet spot".  It is cool to play it in a dim room with this blue LED shining the way!I give the device five stars because it does what I hoped it would do and a little more.  I find I can emulate a stringed drone instrument like an "electronic" Tamboura or Hurdy Gurdy, and even have a richer set of choices.  The battery, too, seems to last a very long time.

I have liked net books ever since they first arrived on the computer scene.  It seemed a smart move to eliminate the DVD and CD read/write drive.  This part is one that goes out often on many notebook computers.  By eliminating this part, the netbook can be small, light, and still have all the capabilities of a notebook computer.  It seems that the tablet pc then took over the market and the net books lost their popularity, even though the Android tablets are not real operating systems, but more like "app loaders" where you are limited to the apps that are possible and cannot always tweak the software and settings as you can with a real operating system.I was happy to see Acer bring out the next generation net book at a very affordable price (around 200 bucks, give or take about 20 bucks).  They switched from the Intel Atom processor running at 1.6 ghz (either dual core or mono-core) to the AMD C-60 chip.  The former is rated at about 13 watts (very low power chip) and the latter seems rated at about 7 watts (even lower power).  This means several things.  One is that the battery lasts a very long time (this one is rated for about 7 hours and it is not even a big long life battery).  Two is that the chip will not overheat.  It seems to stay cool even without a fan (unless there is a super quiet fan that I do not know about) as result.  Because it has "hyperthreading", it can even act a little bit like a quad core computer.The CPU power is rated less than the Atom processor, but it seems to run as fast in practice.  It has a turbo boost that can go up to 1.3 ghz if needed.  Part of what makes these processors run faster than you would expect them to is the video cards have a "GPU" which can take some of the processing load of the CPU.  In this case, the GPU has 256 gb ram of its own, which makes the video experience very smooth and up to the task for everything but gaming (the most high demand of any application) and video editing.I really like that they fitted this netbook with a full size keyboard and a bigger screen.  It is still feels compact like the smaller net books.  But for me it works great, because I type very fast on a regular keyboard and feel a significant slow down when the keyboard is smaller.  The screen is 11.5 inches and this is a decent size for more serious computer tasks.  The touch pad is very responsive and has a smooth scroll function.  A few earlier models were passable here and would require me to repeat a stroke now and then.  I also like that it has an SD card slot (replaces the DVD/CD reader/writer) and find it useful for transferring data to and from a desktop.I tested this unit to work on Linux Mint OS 15 and it worked perfectly.  The Mint OS recognized the wireless card automatically, without configuration.  It also recognized the internal microphone, which is great.  I find that the loss of the internal microphone was common with many netbooks when using a Linux OS.

The spinner is light enough to be easily put up on the ceiling and a simple cup hook is enough to hold it.  The unit was light enough to not even need to hook into a structural beam and is just held by the panel.  The spin slows down predictably as the battery weakens.  It seems an alkaline battery can last almost 3 weeks or so if continuous 24/7 use.  They would be perfect if they were all quiet.  I have two of them, one has been quiet from the beginning and perfect, while the other makes a noticeable but low volume noise.  One is spinning a wire icosahedron, while the other is spinning a double tetrahedron.  They do their job very well.I give it four stars because it does the job, but have two reservations.  One is that they are fragile (I broke one noisy one trying to fix it).  Two is that if they do come a little noisy you cannot do much to make them quiet.  I have one quiet and one that is a little noisy but acceptable.Update 1/4/2014:  The second spinner stopped working.  I tried to fix it, but was unable to.  The little plastic belt seems to be a design weakness and once it starts slipping it seems very hard to repair.  I got the plastic belt back on twice, but it stopped spinning within 30 minutes.  Given that this is the second one that has stopped working and given that two of them were noisy, I am deciding not to replace the unit (for the third time).  They seem to be cheaply made and not designed to be easily serviced.  However, one of them is still working silently and well.  It is really quiet perfect really.  It seems, though, that the odds of getting one that both works and is silent is not too good (1 out of 3 for me).

I have used a homeopathic Arnica gel from this company before and was happy to see it come up on the Vine review list.  Homeopathic Arnica has often given me immediate relief for muscle soreness and body aches.  In fact, out of all the homeopathic remedies, this one seems to be the most consistently beneficial (I have it rubbed on my neck and feeling relief right now as I am writing this!).  It is the one that is most used by all my friends who are open to homeopathic remedies and who describe its action in a similar way ("immediate relief").  What I find interesting, too, is that the homeopathic Arnica works better than the herbal Arnica for me.  Thinking that the actual herb might be better, I got an herbal Arnica gel and it was not as immediately effective as the homeopathic version.  In fact, I was not sure the herbal form was really working at all.  The Arnicare Cream feels much like the clear gel version that I had used before, but has a different set of carrier ingredients.  The clear gel felt cooler when applied, which is nice when there is a hot area of inflammation.  This cream feels like a good skin cream and feels nice to the skin, but less cooling.  It seems that the same healing action is common to both of them.  I give it 5 stars because it does what I expect it to do, which is to provide some immediate relief from muscle aches without merely masking the pain.

This product is a generic version of Sudafed PE and has the same active ingredient "Phenylephrine HCL".  The product works as good as the non-generic one.  It helps the dry the sinus passages and synergizes well with an over the counter anti-histamine.  I prefer the anti-histamine "Chloropheniramine maleate" in a generic version to save money.  In both cases, the generic version is comparable in action to the name brand ones.  I find, too, that the ideal time to take these two is right before a reaction is setting in or immediately upon noticing a reaction is starting.  The histamine reaction is a chain reaction that feeds on itself.  The sooner one stops it, the less the medication has to work.  Once the chain reaction is at full strength, then it is much harder to stop and make take repeated doses.I give this product 4 stars rather than 5 stars because of one reservation.  I found a generic Phenylephrine HCL at the nearby Dollar Store (Assured brand) for a dollar which has the same active ingredient in the same concentration (10 mg) only differing in the filler ingredients (which did not seem to make much difference in how they feel) and the amount of pills in the box.  The Dollar Store version was 24 for $1.00, while the GoodSense version (on Amazon) 72 for $5.26 plus postage (with free shipping if you get over 35 bucks of stuff at the same time).  This means that the Dollar Store one is 4 cents per a pill versus 7.3 cents per a pill for the Good Sense one (the 18 count and 36 count version are still the same per a pill).  The Good Sense version is probably a good price for an online transaction, but it is not the best value.  My brother uses the decongestant and anti-histamine pair very often to manage his allergies and this small difference starts to add up fairly fast.  I will, however, keep the GoodSense version in mind, because sometimes the Dollar Store runs out of stock.

This particular D-Link works "plug and play" on Linux Mint.  I have directly tested it with a large number of computers and operating systems, including Linux Mint OS 9, 11, 13, and 15.  Since Linux Mint is an overlay operating system built on top of both Debian and Ubuntu, the odds are it will work for those operating systems as well (especially Ubuntu).  The tested range had been about 15 percent stronger than the internal wireless card in the laptops and netbooks that I have been working with.  I use this D-Link wireless N-150 Mbps usb wifi network adapter (DWA-125) often when installing Linux Mint on computers for friends who wish to get into Linux.  I have found that the HP laptops and netbooks, using the Broadcom wireless cards, often have internal wireless cards that Linux does not recognize easily, and so I use this D-Link usb to workaround this.  The usb stick usually comes with a little usb stand for better reception for a desktop computer, but it is not really needed (I use it, though, for holding usb thumbdrives and plugging in my usb headset with microphone, it is a convenient access since it is meant to be on a desk and therefore I do not have to lean down to the tower).  For desktop computers without wireless, I have learned to like this usb D-Link better than the PCI wireless cards, because I do not have to worry about the different types of slots (PCI, PCIe, full, half size, etc.), and also I can put the usb adapter on the end of a usb extension cable and hang it up on the wall, where it usually gets very excellent reception (like a kind of antenna).  In short, I can rely on this adapter as a problem solver when there is either no wireless card or Linux cannot find/recognize one, and even get a little extra range.I have had a bit of trouble with some usb wireless cards that are considered Linux compatible but end up not being when I try them (I think they sometimes switch to a different internal chip that is not Linux compatible, when the company bulk buys and mass produces them).  But this D-Link has been consistently usable and is the most tested/verified one in my experience.  I will update this review if I find an exception or if it stops being compatible (in my experience).  My main commitment in giving a computer part review is to the Linux community so that we can know what really works.  The wireless adapters are ones that I have had some challenges with and I am happy to pass on this information about one that has worked again and again.

Firstly, I would like to share that I am impressed with the effort this company has made to (1) use vegan capsules, (2) get non-GMO verified status, and (3) use third party clinical trials to verify the health claims.  The first two, in particular, mean a lot to me.  I will not knowingly buy something that is not in vegan capsules and will choose the non-GMO verified over the lack of this label, and will try to avoid anything that has a high probability of being a GMO or having some GMO ingredients.  I have also experienced noticeable results with this company's other products that I have been happily reviewing thanks to the Amazon Vine program.  I clearly feel their WEIGHT LOSS GOLD formula with its 7 patented ingredients inside it and love their RESVERATROL GOLD which I take with PTEROSTILBENE (from Jarrow) since they synergize noticeably well.  I also like this company's Vitamin C and like that it is verified non-GMO.  I can feel their vitamin C, but am still personally evaluating it compared to HEALTHFORCE NUTRITIONALS TRULY NATURAL VITAMIN C which also seems non-GMO (but which has not taken the time yet to get the non-GMO verified label), both in terms of quality and cost.  Both seem very good and I am still exploring which one I like better.The present product GARCINIA CAMBOGIA GOLD feels good to take, but I am not noticing anything I can verify subjectively or objectively (on the weigh scale).  I chose the product from the list because I noticed a lot of herbal formulas have this ingredient in them for weigh loss.  In a write up that I read when I purchased the pure dried fruit form, it made only a modest claim about what it could do for weigh loss.  It does seem to have some minor ability to metabolize some fat and mainly seemed to say that it would prevent us from making more fat.  WebMD says, "Developing research suggests that garcinia might prevent fat storage and control appetite; however, whether these effects occur in humans is unclear."  This seems to fit the modest claims I read online about the herbal version.  In other words, it may help in a small way within a larger program, possibly by assisting in not creating any more fat as your body is shedding what it already has.  This is going to be hard to notice on a program like what I am on where I am choosing to diet in a slow and safe manner.  I like the capsules compared to the dried herb for ease of taking.  The dried fruit is as tough as leather and it takes a fair amount of boiling to make a liquid tea to drink.I still give the product 4 stars, because it seems to be a good and pure version of the herbal medicine.  Whatever limits this product has are probably the limits of the herb itself, not how it is prepared by this company.  If I notice anything as I continue to take it, I will post what I found in an update.  I am giving this product a chance within an overall program.  I would like to share that I consider intelligent weight loss to require a fair amount of skill and commitment, the elimination of certain foods (mentioned in my review of the book THE VIRGIN DIET) that will prevent almost any diet approach from working if they are not eliminated, drinking good pure water in larger amounts, distinguishing hunger from thirst and not eating when you are thirsty, lots of fruit and veggie juices, etc.  It will take more than a good product or two to pull off, and this one seems to be at best a modest support.

I have been studying herbs in general and been studying Tibetan Aryurvedic herbal medicine in particular.  It is hard to find in depth literature about Tibetan herbology.  Many of the key texts either have not been translated into English or have been translated only recently.  This one was done in 1999.  The book has large paintings, covering one whole page for each of the herbs and a few paragraphs describing them.  There is a 44 page summary of the Tibetan herbal system in the beginning which is concise, clear, and well worth reading.  The only drawback of this book is that herbs may be hard to find outside of Tibet or the Himalayas.  The book does not always give the equivalents, both in name and alternatives, to the herbs mentioned inside.  I would recommend ANCIENT METRIA MEDICA: Sowa - Rigpa (Tibetan Science of Healing) by Dr. Smanla T. Phuntsog M.B.B.S., M.S. to cover this weakness.  The latter book is very complimentary with the first and each has many things that the other does not.  The latter has small one inch by two inch (approximate) pictures of many of the herbs and extensive lists grouped according to their use.  The latter book I find a little challenging to navigate sometimes, but I have found good information nonetheless.  Both of them are fairly technical, though the introduction to the Clear Mirror book is accessible to everyone.  For a more general introduction there is THE QUINTESSENCE TANTRAS OF TIBETAN MEDICINE by Dr. Barry Clark (with a forward by the Dalai Lama) and HEALTH THROUGH BALANCE BY Dr. Yeshi Donden.Through the Clear Mirror Book and the Ancient Metria Medica, I was able to find some correspondence with more familiar and more accessible western herbs in order to brew some healing formulas for myself.  I am mainly focusing on making general health tonics (Rasayana).I would also recommend that a person who is interested in Tibetan Aryurveda also study some Hindu Aryurveda (the books by Vasant Lad and his students are very good for this).  There are a lot of similarities and some curious subtle differences.  The Medince Buddha Sutras explain the Tibetan system in depth, like the Heart Ambrosia Tantra.  The main difference is a chain of interesting associations and connections that link the physical diseases to the three poisons of the mind (addictive craving, judgmental negativity, and obscuring delusion), with the herbal remedies assisting both physical healing and meditation practice.

I have been very happy with the Nutrigold products and have been selecting a lot of them from the Vine review list.  The two main reasons have been that the company has made an effort to get approval for the "non-GMO verified" tag to get put on their product and also they have a lot of products that are in vegan capsules.  Since I have a vegan diet, I appreciate both these gestures a lot.  In the company write up, they share that their Maca is "Maca Gold is also independently certified by a third-party lab to be free of soy, milk, wheat, gluten, eggs, and shellfish."  This fits the non-GMO label.  I like the commitment to third party testing.  It also signals to me that the company has a commitment to a certain standard.  There are a lot of products that I would not take that fall below this.As far as the Maca itself goes, there is a summary write up I found useful in the company literature:  "Maca has been an important traditional food and medicinal plant for over 2000 years. Although Maca is unrelated to the ginseng family, it has been dubbed Peruvian ginseng because it is often used as a folk remedy to enhance stamina, energy, and sexual function. Maca is naturally rich in essential minerals, especially selenium, calcium, magnesium, and iron, and fatty acids including linolenic acid, palmitic acid, oleic acids, and 19 amino acids, as well as polysaccharides. Maca's reported benefits for sexual vigor and health could be due to its high concentration of proteins and vital nutrients and the root's unique nutritional profile, which provides optimum levels of nutrients utilized by the body's endocrine system without adversely impacting hormone levels."  I found this paragraph to pretty much sum up the research on Maca.I have been taking a lot of herbs as part of my health and longevity program.  To be honest, Maca was one that I was going to take off my list.  I had bought the Maca powder from the health food store (and a health food section of a coop) twice and could not feel much happening for me with it.  I do not think that it means that the herb is bad or that its claims are off, but just that the herb does not address my own biochemical individuality and needs.  But since I have been very happy with the products from this company, I decided to give Maca another try.  This is the first Maca supplement that I can actually feel something from.  It feels like a little extra energy boost.  Nothing too big or too grand, but noticeable, enough for me to want to continue to explore this product.  I will update if I notice anything else.  I do not have a theory about why this product allowed me to feel something and the other Maca did not, even when I took some fairly large doses of the other ones.  I have gathered that some herbs lose some of their potency when they meet the stomach acids, and the capsule form may bypass it.  It could also be that the powder form of Maca I took before, from two locations, were in the bins too long and lost their potency by getting oxidized.  Or it could be that my body is in a different place and can benefit more from it now (I had some dental work recently).  I would suspect that other sources of Maca are probably very good too.  But it does seem like this product works.  All in all, I give this product 5 stars, because it seems to be what it supposed to be, a good quality Maca supplement.

I chose this product off the Vine reviewer list because I have been interested in the healing benefits of Turmeric.  My interest started with a book called THE OKINAWA DIET PLAN by Wilcox, Wilcox, and Suzuki.  This book was a landmark study of cultural longevity based on diet.  They studied cultures in terms of longevity by determining what percentage of the population lives past 100 years, with the Okinawans, at the time of the study, having 7 percent of the population achieve this (sadly it seems that fast food chains and a system of cafeteria food in their schools may be subverting their dietary culture now, with this culture now having a teenage obesity crisis).  The study also confirmed that it was the diet, since it also studied groups of Okinawas that moved to other places in the world and adopted other dietary cultures and thereby did not achieve the same longevity result.  In studying their diet, I found it had several unique features, like being near vegan collectively with many vegans within the total population, being low fat, low protein, and rich in good quality carbs, and also an unusual proportion of eating sweet potatoes and having turmeric tea.  I found that turmeric may be the best anti-inflammatory one can take on a regular basis.  When I researched further, I found that many cultures, like India, use turmeric as a spice in their food.  While this is very wise, other diet cultures do not have an optimal dose of this good ingredient.  We can use more turmeric than is present in these diets.Jarrow literature summarized some of the effect of turmeric in their literature this way (I liked this write up and thought I would quote it here, I do not always find descriptions of herbal actions so well described on a biochemical level):"Turmeric (Curcuma longa) is a yellow spice and a traditional remedy that has been used as a medicine, condiment and flavoring since 600 BC. The rhizome (underground stem) is the part of the plant that is harvested and ground to make the spice. The key bioactive constituents found in turmeric are three kinds of curcuminoids: curcumin, demethoxycurcumin, and bisdemethoxycurcumin. Once in the body these curcuminoids are known to interact with various mediators of the inflammatory response such as 5-lipooxygenase (LOX) and cyclooxygenase (COX) enzymes."This Jarrow product is one that I happily give 5 stars to for a number of reasons:  (1) They use vegan capsules.  Since I am on a vegan diet, I appreciate this, since I will not buy supplements that are in gelatin capsules.  (2) You get 500 mg of "Curcumin Phytosome" (curcumin extract complexed with phosphatidylcholine) which is intended to enhance bioavailability.  It seems that this extra absorption may be lab tested, but I did not find documentation to fully verify this.  It seems that the action of phosphatidylcholine acts similar to a transport herb which helps herbal potencies to be delivered where they are needed. I did find this write up on their action in the Jarrow literature:"But the phytosomes do more than just help overcome the poor water solubility of curcumin. They also appear to directly impact absorption by shuttling the curcuminoids inside enterocytes. This occurs because cellular membranes, including intestinal enterocytes, are largely composed of phospholipids, such as the phosphatidylcholine found in the phytosomes, allowing the phytosomes to act as vesicles that can be "folded" into the cell in a process called pinocytosis or cellular captation."One of the health claims made about turmeric and this product is increased joint health and flexibility.  This seems to be related to the overall anti-inflammatory action of the source herb.  It does seem that this product may be enhancing its bioavailability.  My subjective experience with the product is that it feels "smoother", fairly easy on the intestines, and I feel cleaner inside after taking it.  I intend to update this review if I can feel anything else that seems specific to this product.  I also brew tea with turmeric, intestinal soothing herbs like mint, lemon balm, marshmallow root, ginger, and cardamom (and sweeten with stevia).  I usually prefer taking my herbs through well brewed teas.  I usually do not try to take them in capsules.  However, I have found the effect of these capsules feels similar to what I get through the turmeric tea and it is a little quicker to take (the brewing process that I use does involve about a 15 minute time commitment, bringing it to boil, letting it simmer for five minutes, and placing a glass lid on top to recycle the essential oils back into the brew).  When I have a busy morning I have been grateful to have the option of taking a capsule.  I would say that it does seem like they have helped its bioavailability so that it is at least on par with the tea (though the tea is actually a larger dose than the capsule).  I recently had some dental work where I got a root canal, a tooth pulled, a crown, and a bridge in one zone in my mouth.  There is a fair amount of inflammation there.  I have been gargling with mint and hydrogen peroxide, with a touch of clove oil, and then taking turmeric as a tea (even swishing it around near the dental the work).  It does seem to help quite a bit, especially before going to sleep.  I am grateful to have the option of taking some bioavailable turmeric vegan capsules to supplement this.  I would like to keep my dose optimal.  I plan to continue with turmeric as part of a long term longevity program that I have been evolving.All in all, I have no complaints about this product, like that it has vegan capsules, like the purity of the product, and can feel some difference in my experience.  I happily give it 5 stars.

I have been happily reviewing nearly all the Nutrigold products that were listed on the Amazon Vine review list.  As before, I have been very impressed with the quality standards of this company.  The Vitamin C product that I am reviewing now is (1) organic, (2) 100 percent natural, (3) Kosher, (4) certified organic, (5) food based, (6) non-GMO verified, (7) uses veggie caps, (8)meets cGMP standards (I had to look this up, but it refers to a quality control standard that is subject to third party verification by the FDA), (9) free of possible allergens related to soy, wheat, peanuts, shellfish, milk, and eggs (via 3rd party lab testing), and (10) free of solvents, herbicides, and pesticides.  Behind meeting these criteria voluntarily is a commitment to make a high quality, high standard product that can deliver a tested level of potency.  For me, the non-GMO verified is important, as well as the veggie caps, because I am vegan and want my supplements to not come in gelatin capsules.  I also like that make their products without the usual fillers (artificial ingredients, preservatives, stearates, sulfates, laurates, and dioxides).  I remember that another company that I got some products from also did not use fillers and their capsules were a lot smaller, even though their active ingredient amount was larger than other brand names.The Vitamin C product that this company makes is food based and from natural sources.  This makes three companies that I know of that offer completely non-synthetic vitamin C (the company that makes Vita-Mineral Green being one of them and the superfood company that puts out a Camu Camu powder which is high in natural vitamin C).  When studying this product, they included a write up about how much of the synthetic vitamin C is synthesized from GMO corn glucose in China.  This has given me some cause for concern, because it seems the GMO Corn and its products may be unusually toxic because of inheriting the BT pesticide producing DNA and generating it internally inside the corn itself (as opposed to natural BT pesticide which is put on the surface of the corn where it can be washed away).  Given that GMO Corn and its products currently do not require labeling in much of the US, I am happy that a company like Nutrigold is voluntarily submitting itself to a high enough standard so that I can know that it is not derived from what may be toxic sources.  The write up that was sent with the sample has given me some food for thought about vitamin C and analyzed the various kinds of vitamin C on the market and what kind of potency has been found in them in scientific studies.  I am planning to research this further, because some of the information questions some earlier research.  For instance, I was under the impression that Ascorbic Acid vitamin C was harsher on the liver and by converting it into a polyascorbate lessened its impact on the liver and made the vitamin C more absorb-able.  While the impact on the liver part still seems true, it seems that we may be getting the same amount of vitamin C from either way.  In a similar analysis, Ascobyl Palmitate was also found to be as absorb-able as Ascorbic Acid.  It seems that these products may only be less harsh on the liver, but do not give us anymore vitamin C, and also are still derived from GE corn glucose.This plant based vitamin C comes from a variety of high vitamin C natural sources like camu camu, acerola, amla, oranges, asparagus, and avocado.  The product includes the bioflavanoids, too, that are necessary for absorbing them.  It does seem like the natural sources do absorb better, though I would be curious about the amount of vitamin C that you get absorbed versus the higher cost.There is one quote from the write up that the company gave that I am going to think about for a while:  "The method used most often by the ascorbic acid industry in China, which supplies 80% of the world's ascorbic acid, involves the use of a genetically modified microbe species that oxidises sorbose into 2-ketogluconic acid (2-KGA); this then undergoes the ring closing lactonization via dehydration producing ascorbic acid."  In other words, they start from GE corn glucose and use another GE microbe to synthesize vitamin C!In summary, I am enjoying the vitamin C that this company makes and feel it is high quality.  It does seem to absorb better and feels lower impact on the body.  Regular vitamin C has felt a little harsher when taken for me.  I may update this review later on if I experience anything else that is noticeable for me.  I may also compare this product with the Vitamineral one.  It already seems more effective than just camu camu alone (which I had been using before this one).

I have been exploring a number of products from the Nutrigold company and have been very impressed with them.  This one is no exception.  Resveratrol is an anti-oxidant that I first learned from a few Life Extension groups which proposed that it was a longevity factor.  The Nutrigold company seems committed to include all the synergistic compounds needed to fully utilize Resveratrol, like the polyphenols from red wine, grape skins, and seeds, and is standardized in potency to 1,500 ORAC units.  This means that one of their capsules contains the trans-reservatrol content of 50 glasses of red wine.  Like most of their other products, the company uses veggie caps, is verified non-GMO and has the third party verified label to show this, and does not have the usual binders, fillers, and preservatives (like stearates, sulfates, laurates, and dioxides).  Reading their label and flier you can tell that this company is committing to a standard of purity and potency, and are willing to have their claims verified by third party lab testing.  I like this very much and appreciate their effort.  I am a practicing vegan (been so for over 22 years) and appreciate their standards.I mainly got this product because I wanted to see if it would synergize with Pterostilbene, another Resveratrol-like anti-oxidant, and one which I was also very happy to try out and review through the Amazon Vine program (and which I bought two bottles for myself after getting one free from the review program).  As mentioned in the other review (the Jarrow version of this product), I found that I got the result of feeling a "clear headedness" from taking double the normal dose (two capsules rather than one).  Happy to say, when I took one capsule of the Nutrigold Resveratrol with the two capsules of Pterostilbene, the clear head effect was more immediate, stronger, and more noticeable.  I could also feel a more subtle clean feeling throughout my body about 30 minutes later.  I have been taking the capsules with very pure water that was from a well and then filtered through a Zero Water filter or I have been taking the capsules with an anti-oxidant tea that I brew for myself and which usually contains (a vary the formula a little from day to day) Pu-Erh, Cardamom, Foti, Astragalus, Ginseng, Black Seed, and Gotu Kola.  While the capsules feel very synergistic with the tea, I concluded that it is better to take the capsules with pure water first, wait about 30 minutes, and then take the tea next.  It may be that this way it is just easier to feel the effect (FYI, I am only sharing my experience with the products, and am not prescribing or recommending this to anyone, it is up to the readers to determine whether or not it fits his or her on biochemical individuality, and if in doubt to check with a health professional, in general, I do think that these products and the teas are very safe IMHO).In summary, I am very impressed with this product and very happy with the results I have gotten from it.  I intend to purchase from them when I am done with the sample.

This is 3rd product from Nutrigold that I have gotten from the Amazon review list.  I am impressed with the product line in general, because of (1) having many of their products in vegetarian capsules, (2) having pharmaceutical grade research into their herbal products to verify their potency and effectiveness, (3) that it is organic and allergen free (and even third party tested) and (4) having taken the time to make their products "non-GMO verified" (though this one is still pending).  My brother and I use Fenugreek all the time.  We usually blend it in a tea with Pu-Erh and Cardamom where it helps to open and heal the sinuses and helps to dissolve a sinus headache.  Fenugreek, in this context seems to lubricate and heal the sinus passages.  Both my brother and I noticed that this product produced a very rapid and noticeable feeling of healing in the sinus passages.  It seems that the product has had a lot of research in helping mothers to be able to lactate (give milk).  This is something I am not able to verify, but seems believable.  It seems Fenugreek has been documents to help with blood sugar levels, cholesterol, colon health, and digestion.  I give the product 5 stars because the company behind it shows great care in making this a quality product and because both my brother and I felt good results almost immediately.

I got a Ninetendo DSI Lite for the sole purpose of using the DS-10.  I had already tested the newer version of the DS-10 on the Ninetendo DSI XL and knew, for the most part, what to expect.  The DS-10, in both its old and new version, is an emulation of the Korg MS series analog synthesizers.  It emulates the some of the key circuits of these synths in a digital software version.  The DS-10 emulates them well enough, including the software dials and even software plugs, for a person to get a living feeling for analog synthesis.  A person is able to craft a lot of sounds and tweak them in a large variety of ways.  The Nintendo unit has a speaker that does do a decent job representing the sounds, though there is more detail and richness if you use good external speakers or a good headphone with good bass response.  There are some limitations of the DS-10, too, that are worth mentioning.  One is that it mixes two monophonic software synth "engines".  The keyboards that display on the touch screen can only play one note at a time and you can only play one keyboard at a time.  You can, however, program a sequence on one engine and play live on the keyboard of the second engine at the same time.  You can also do two sequences on both synth engines and play on one keyboard live, and even add a beat rhythm.  This means that the upper limit of simultaneous "notes" is four, though with digital delay and reverb it might seem to be even more than this.  Two is that you are not able to dial in a "sine wave".  This was common for the early MS series.  It seems that a sine wave is more challenging to emulate with either digital software or analogue circuitry than the sawtooth, triangle, and square waves.  It is possible to emulate a sine wave but it takes more circuits and/or programming lines to do this than the others and is often skipped as a result.  It is possible to partially emulate a sine wave by taking a square wave and softening it with slow attack and long decay, and other digital tricks, and they are fun to learn.You get two oscillators per a synth engine and can mix the sounds of each oscillator.  You can add white noise into the mix to create a more ambient wind or ocean like sound.  There are three "kaoss pads" possible with each synth engine (again you can only play one pad at a time) where you control two parameters.  They are "gate/note", "volume/pan", and "peak/cut-off".  They can be re-assigned and there is a function that records the movements that you make that you can then play back in a loop.  The hidden dual "kaoss pad" is a bargain, considering the cost of the usual kaoss pad series.  You are able to tweak the sounds very well in a way that emulates the kaoss pad series well.  There are limits here too.  For instance, you cannot import sounds from an external source and modify them.  The pad tweaking is only for the sounds that you generate.The sequencer is very important and covers about 16 notes.  The usual creative process is to put in some notes and loop them, and then tweak the sounds by hearing and dialing until you can the gets that you like.  Otherwise you would have to go to the keyboard play a note, dial, and go back to hear it again.  This would be an awkward and time consuming process.  I usually start with a D and A note harmonic fifth chord.  I alternative a low D and corresponding low A, alternating the notes so that there are 8 of each in the sequencer, adding enough "release" (decay after note off is activated by lifting the stylus) so that it spills over into the next note.  This way I emulate a two note chord on a monophonic synth.The patch chord screen gives you new possibilities for routing sounds and can make some very creative and rich sounds.  It takes a while to master this screen and see what works.  Most of the patches do not do much or make useless frankenstein sounds, but after a while you find a sect of patches that enhance the sound in many interesting ways.All in all, the synth is very versatile.  You can also save your creations in a memory sector.  The newer DS-10 has more memory than the earlier one.  But both give a fair amount of room.  You can also manually record your settings by drawing the dials and writing notes.  There is no way of exporting the creations to an external memory file.  The only easy export is recording the output sound.  The lack of importing and exporting has inspired some reviewers to say that the DS-10 is not a full music studio option.  I think that they are correct in this assessment, but this does not detract from how much the DS-10 is able to do and at such a low cost.All in all, I am happy with the capabilities of the DS-10.  There are few other observations that I would like to make about it.  One is that the lettering is a little harder to read on the DSI Lite.  The XL has a larger screen and is easier to navigate.  The DSI Lite seems to drain power at a slower rate and therefore you can play it longer before recharging.  I like the size of the DSI Lite and, since I am only using it for the DS-10, it is very ideal.  It boots up the DS-10 faster because of this.  The XL can handle the DS-10 version 2 and handle more memory.  This may be useful to some, but I have not exhausted the capacities of the earlier version.I got the three different Korg Monotrons (the original, the duo, and the delay versions).  The first two I returned because they have a clicking sound that happens when you lift the stylus off the ribbon keyboard.  You cannot hear the click on the built in speaker, but can hear it on headphones or external speakers.  I found that the DS-10 emulates these two Monotrons very well (with even extra capability) without this weakness, and is about the same size when installed on the DSI Lite.  The delay version of the Monotron does not seem to have this issue.  I think it is because it defaults to a kind of ambient background instead of a silence that highlights the clicking noise.  It is possible through a stereo plug that is about 7 bucks at Radio Shack to link the DS-10 with the delay to combine their abilities.  Together they make a very small portable synth with quite a bit of options.  I might update this review when I have had some chance to explore this in more depth.

I got a used Ninetendo DSI Lite that came without a power supply.  I was happy to find a replacement power supply on Amazon for such a low cost.  I ordered it, it came fairly fast, it was well packages, and it works as expected.  I like the way that electrical socket part folds back into the power brick part.  It makes it less able to be damaged during transport.  No complaints.

I have been ordering this Pu Erh one at a time from the company and was happy to find this 3 pack.  It saves a significant amount of money being ordered this way, especially on postal costs (paying for one delivery versus three deliveries).  Each package has one "tea brick" that is about 7.5 inches in diameter.  I mainly got this tea for my brother, who has acute sinusitis.  When this tea is combined with fresh ground cardamom seeds, it produces a medicinal tea that has been very helpful to his condition, usually ending his morning sinus headache within 30 minutes after drinking a cup or two.  Because he drinks this tea daily, this 3 pack is very affordable.  We found that Pu Erh tea varies significantly in quality, trying quite a few brands.  While all of them felt good to drink, I found some were not as medicinally potent and did not work in my brother's morning brew.  This brand has been the best.  We found it was best to grind part of a tea brick right before adding it to boiling water.  It helps to bring out all the potencies inside the tea.Pu Erh has become my favorite way of taking the basic tea leaf (camellia sinesis), with Oolong being my second favorite.  Both of them are fermented tea leaves.  It seems that fermenting the tea leaf adds some natural antibiotics, enzymes, and other medicinal potencies.  I notice I feel better, too, after drinking a cup and feel my sinuses are a little clearer and more open.  Sometimes Pu Erh tea has been enough to knock out a mild cold and at the very least to help mitigate the symptoms of a strong flu.  Some literature suggests that Pu Erh tea helps natural weight loss and it seems from my experience to be true (though by itself it would not make a complete weight loss program).  The flavor of this tea feels heartier and fuller than most teas.  I suspect it has a thickness, aroma, and fullness that some expect from coffee, but it is definitely still a tea.Pu Erh tea seems able to be boiled longer without bringing more bitter tannins into the brew.  It seems that the tannins are transformed through the fermentation into something less acidic and less bitter.  Boiling helps bring out the medicinal potencies of Pu Erh tea better than just steeping (which works better for green tea, white tea, and black tea).  Only a few minutes are needed and it seems to bring out flavor, medicinal, and fullness out of the leaf.  I sweeten my Pu Erh tea with Stevia (in clear liquid drops).  Only a drop or two is needed per a cup.I give this tea five stars because it is my favorite brand of my now favorite tea.  The only reservation I might mention is that you do need to brew this tea from scratch.  It does not come in tea bags (there are other Pu Erh tea brands that do).  It takes a little bit of skill to brew it properly, but it is worth it.

I watched a lot of youtube videos about this product and the Monotron product line.  I like many things about it.  I like that Korg resurrected the MS series analog path and made the many of the most important paths into these small versatile portable pocket sized keyboards.  I like how they made them easy to modify for the circuit benders too.  It seems that there are two weak spots in the design.  One is that ribbon keyboard.  It plays fantastic sounds as you slide your finger across the ribbon, but when you lift your finger or stylus off the keyboard, you will usually hear a clicking sound.  It seems that the ribbon keyboard is an on/off controller when you touch it or lift your stylus off it.  I tried dialing the knobs to see if I could eliminate the sound, but only succeeded in softening it some.  What is interesting is that when you play the synth through the built in speaker, the clicking sound does not appear very often.  But even with cheap headphones, the clicking sound is more noticeable.  On good headphones, it is very noticeable, at least to me.  I have read through a lot of reviews, but I have not found any one else mention the clicking sound.  But I got a regular monotron and now a dual monotron, both had this clicking sound.  It was stronger on the regular monotron.  The headphones pick up some white noise in the background, but it seems that usual play covers it well.  Other than these two weaknesses, it is a very powerful and versatile synth engine for its money and size.  It has two oscillators that can be paired off as OSC1 to LFO or as mix OSC1 and OSC2 together, the frequency cut off and peak are very responsive, and the middle dial changes the pulse width.  You get a rich tapestry of sound.  But the clicking is enough for me to want to return the unit...

I do healing work as my vocation and often need to share information about diet as part of the healing process for someone.  I have found only a small percentage of books on diet as being really useful.  I have found that there are a lot of illusions about diet, physiology, and how food actually works that are often perpetuated by diet books, outmoded science, and sometimes by corporate funded scientific research that is really more like spin than hard data, or which does not present a large enough picture for us to understand how our bodies work and how a diet can help us or hinder us.  THE VIRGIN DIET already feels different from them.  It tabs up with other reliable chunks of diet information that I have gleaned from other sources.  It affirms that need to stay away from gluten foods (wheat products mainly), from soy, from eggs, from corn, and from peanuts.  It talks about the perils of sugar and describes how even a lot of health food alternatives are still high glycemic and harmful (like Agave).  It does into healthy oils (Olive Oil, Sesame, Walnut, Coconut) and which ones to avoid.  It also gives recipes to try out.  Recipes are useful, because when changing diet, it helps us to imagine an alternative and bring our mind out of the theories and into something we can actually do.Having shared this, I am not automatically agreeing with everything that the author says or feeling that her book is completely comprehensive about what is needed.  I respect that she made her diet work for her and this by itself puts it into a small group.
