I remember seeing a video that showed many of the popular diet authors and how they were all overweight even after many years on their diet (assuming that they even followed their own advice) or, in one case, having died from a possible diet related cause.  But having come to many of the same conclusions from my own experience as the author did, I am encouraged to check some of her ideas in my experience.  Perhaps I will post an update about what I find to this review later on, as I intend to seriously try out some things that the book recommends.There are a few differences already.  The author is not vegetarian, though I gather she has reduced her meat intake (a wise idea even if one does not go vegetarian or vegan).  A lot of her meal suggestions will not be useful for vegans because of this.  While I respect her views on sugar, she does not go into much about just getting good quality fructose sugar from fresh fruit (not juiced but just fresh fruit).  This is something I am exploring and I may update what I find.  I have also found that cleansing herbal teas are very helpful and have found them an easy start for many people who need something useful and gentle to start with.  I usually have suggested that people cut out the processed foods made from flour, sugar, and bad oils, and to take Triple Leaf Detox tea (which I have found powerful and gentle with no adverse side effects for anyone who I have recommended this to).  There are more powerful detox programs, but I have found that it is better to be gentle with ourselves and see what the gentle detox teas can do first.  They are also better for daily support, while the powerful ones you can only use for a short time and can be unbalancing.  I am also not sure if soy and corn are bad for one or if it is just the GMO soy and corn (and some of the very hybridized ones as well).  But given how much soy and corn is GMO these days, it might be playing it safe to just avoid them anyway.All in all, I feel there is more solid advice about diet in this book than many that I have read.  I give it four stars rather than five for some of the smaller reservations and question marks that I have about some things (mentioned above).  In the long run, we still need to find out what works for ourselves in our own experience.Update:  I gave up my hot air popcorn popper, supply of popcorn, and my popcorn bowl in preparation for doing this diet.  I came to the conclusion that the author was right about popcorn being a "trigger food", a food that when eaten makes you want to eat more food.  Much to my surprise, I found I have lost 4 pounds in 3 days and I have not even really started on this diet.  I also have not had any gluten grains (as part of another diet process) and no soy (also since reading this book).  I have lost 4 pounds before, but not as easily as this (it felt accidental) and not without a small struggle to keep it off.  I did not even notice that I was eating less (not being triggered) until I spontaneously decided to weigh myself.  It has been encouraging.  Plan to post again a little further down the road, when I have gone through the author's checklist even more.

The book is a well written interweaving of scientific, philosophical, and ethical reflections about animals combined with stories and interviews about events and experiments related to whether or not animals think and feel.  I like the way that the author shows a kind of methodological bias that predisposes the researcher to not believing that animals can think and feel, a criterion that would make it hard to prove that we can think and feel (similar to the behaviorist arguments of B. F. Skinner proposed in BEYOND FREEDOM AND DIGNITY).  The author further goes into several select experiments to do prove, to me, that animals can think and feel.  There are some choice quotes seeded throughout the book and are designed to provoke some thinking of our own about the subject, like (page 50):"Intelligent circuitry can be assembled in any brain, that's my big belief," Schuster said, where he did several of his archerfish studies.  (He's since moved to Bayreuth.)  "It's not limited to those animals with large brains and many neurons," he said.  "if evolution requires it [this kind of intelligent circuitry], it will be assembled--even with a small number of neurons."And (page 96):"People have wondered about this for centuries," Berg said.  In captivity, he added, parrots do not simply react when humans speak to them (as dogs, cats, chimpanzees, and other animals do); they also articulate responses, almost as if talking back, and sometimes even use words in the correct context; as Alex did.  "Those kinds of vocalizations absolutely send a shiver up the spine of cognitive scientists," Berg said, because they suggest that parrots have some innate understanding of the purpose and functions of words as sounds that convey meaning.  When a pet parrot uses the words 'hello', 'good night', or others appropriately it is probably not communicating about sex or violence.  It is calling--and, most importantly, apparently meaning--"hello" and "good night"."Each main chapter focuses on one animal, fish and pain, elephants and memory, dolphins and intelligence (there are two chapters on dolphins), and rats and laughter.The author uses the narrative approach to writing that I like, taking the relevant details of the experiment and weaving them into the story, some parts revealed in discusses, in quotes, and material coming from learned sources (like quoting Darwin's thoughts on the subject and thinking about how his thoughts fit into new experiments and research that did not exist in Darwin's time).  Although the author states her bias that animals do think and feel (though why and how is another interesting story), she gives enough data for people to make their own conclusions.  The scientists that the author meets are described in very human terms so that it is easy to empathize with them and to feel their excitement at what they are discovering.The book has an extensive set of notes and an extensive bibliography for further research.  The table of contents is well organized so that it is relatively easy to find subjects and themes.  The edition that I have does not have an index, but I suspect the final one will.I would recommend this book to anyone who is interested in animal ethics who wonders if we are the only species of animal that does think and feel, or wonders how do you go about researching this issue in a way that does not metaphysically presuppose a yes or no answer (the approach of science is to verify a hypothesis by designing experiments where some possible observation can confirm or not confirm the hypothesis).  I can see this book as a useful one for an college class discussion on animal ethics.  By itself, it does not go into animal ethics very much, but it touches upon many issues that are relevant to this subject.  How we see animals, whether we see them as sentient beings that love, nurture, and protect their children or as merely cellular clumps with neurological reflexes programmed to respond to the environment in rigid robotic ways (aka "no soul" worthy of moral consideration) is directly related to this issue and this book offers some very relevant material to fuel this kind of discussion.I enjoyed reading the book, because it feels "convergent" with other books that I have read and with personal experiences I have had with animals.  My feeling is that when something is on track and accurate, it tends to confirm and be confirmed by other books and experiences that are formed in the same way, with the same "scientific curiosity."  I am not surprised at the implied conclusion that animals do think and feel, but I am surprised at some of the things discovered that tend to confirm this.  I am also happy that the author writes well, in narrative style, because it makes what could have been presented as dull research into something enjoyable to read.  It also makes the information easier to remember, since a story is a good way of giving otherwise isolated facts a kind of cohesion that allows them to be remembered as whole packet.  I wish more of my college books had this.

The battery worked on my Acer Netbook and was compatible with the software on Linux Mint OS 11 that monitors the battery power and the charge controller.  The battery is very thick and causes the keyboard to be more slanted.  It is actually a kind of bonus, since it is easier to type on at this angle, but other people may want to factor this ergonomic issue in terms of their own needs and preferences.  The battery power is almost 3x the power of the original battery and almost gives me about 8.5 hours of use (according to the battery power read).  There is a slight delay in the read.  It gives a more accurate reading after about 2 minutes that is usually higher than the first number it gives.  I give the battery 4 stars instead of 5 because of two things:  (1) The keyboard slant changes the ergonomics and may not be preferable for everyone (though it works for me).  This thickness may also mean that it does not fit every carry case that is designed for it.  (2)  The thickness actually blocks easy movement of the LED screen to best angle for viewing.  I have to gently push down on the middle to slight bend the plastic so that it moves to the right position.  It is just off by less than a millimeter, but I notice it the plastic edge blocks the free movement it had before.  It is not hard to push down on the plastic to move it past the resistance point.  I am thinking of getting my dremel and shaving off just a little bit of the plastic edge to fix this.  All in all, I like the battery life and can live with the rest.Update 12/31/2012:  I did get dremel out, added the sander cylinder attachment, and shaved a very thin layer off the edge of the battery casing that was getting caught when I was opening the netbook.  It worked.  It now opens smoothly, without catching (except for a small gentle click).  I have found the battery power of this battery very enduring.  Even after over a month, it has held enough charge for the times that I have needed it.  It registered almost 9 hours and even after much use and over a few months it still registers about 8 hours (using it for about 5 to 10 minutes at a time).  It has exceeded my expectations.

This Optimal Plant Protein Supplement is an excellent vegan protein source.  It derives the protein from Pea, Brown Rice, Hemp, Chlorella, and Chia.  All of these are excellent plant sources with other useful nutrients besides protein.  It has a little bit of xylitol for a sweetner.  Xylitol is also an anti-plaque and helps remove plaque from the arteries.  It has some natural french vanilla flavor, bacterial metabolites (I assume to help digest and utilize the protein), Lo Han Guo, Rebiana, and Erythritol (another natural sugar substitute).  I assume that these extra ingredients are either good natural sweeteners and/or things to help utilize the protein.  I have had some prior experience with the two natural sweeteners mentioned and feel they are fairly healthy to use.  They do not sweeten very strongly, though, and I suspect make the strong taste of these concentrated plant proteins less bitter.  The flavor of the supplement is very powdery and a little gritty.  I gather the ideal way to use this powder is in a fruit smoothie.  It is excellent this way and boosts the protein taken to a good level.  I give it 5 stars for being an excellent product with very good ingredients, and minus one star for the grittiness and powdery quality.  To me, it is still very good, provided you put it in a smoothie rather than take it directly or with water.

I have been interested in getting an energy pendant of some kind for a while.  I stumbled on this pendant on Amazon while looking around for something else.  I was tempted to get something similar to this for over 40 dollars and felt it was low risk to get this Quantum Scalar pendant at the lower price.  The item arrived quickly and was well packaged.  I tried to feel the energy by waving the pendant over my hand and putting it about one inch from my forehead.  I can usually sense some energy from quartz crystals and other energy items this way.  The pendant, however, was more subtle than the others.  I had to hold it for a longer time to feel it, though when I placed it near an area of my body that held some tension, I found it relaxed it quickly and well.  The indirect effect on my body was more noticeable than feeling the energy directly.I experimented with adding an "orgonite hemisphere" that fit perfectly on the pendant disk and immediately noticed the two items synergized very well.  The energy felt very noticeable and much stronger than either separately.  I decided to hot glue the orgonite hemisphere to the pendant to make this permanent.  I am wearing it as I am writing this review and am noticing a beneficial effect on my energy field.  It feels like a trickle charge on my internal battery and feels nourishing to weak spots in the energy field.  It feels like it is smoothing out the energy flows.  It feels good to wear this.

This RCA PCHSTAB2R USB Charging Dock with Device Cradle works the way you would expect it.  The unit has two USB ports for recharging any item that recharges by plugging it into a USB port on a computer.  It also has a standard two prong electrical outlet (ungrounded).  When I opened the package, I was a little surprised by the empty docking cradle.  I had been used to seeing them with some kind of electrical insert that goes into some kind of unit.  But it is apparently just a place to hold a smart phone or ipod when it is recharging.  I assume that the electrical socket is so that you can plug in a small electrical adapter to attach to the recharging device that is docking cradle (if it is not USB powered).  The unit comes with some black foam inserts that are designed to put cushioning around the smart phone or ipod type unit, so that it is held more securely.  The intention is to adapt to different sizes of units to be held in its cradle.  I felt the cradle feature to be both interesting and a little awkward for two reasons.  One is that, if you adapt it with the sticky foam pieces for a smaller unit, then it automatically becomes unadapted for a larger unit.  There is an assumption that a person is only going to charge one unit in the cradle.  If you have a thick ipod and a thin smart phone, the foam pieces are not going to help.  You can still adapt them with some skillful use of cardboard pieces that are removable.  I am not sure if the cradle is designed to hold some of the adapter pieces that come with some ipods (I do not, at this time, have an ipod).  The instructions do not mention this design intention.  The instructions, too, are minimal and loosely fit just one side of a sheet of regular 8.5x11 inch paper.  The second reason the docking station is a little awkward is the implication that you are going to plug in the wall electrical adapter for the unit into the electrical plug that is on the unit.  No matter how small the wall adapter is, it is going to make the unit look a little thick and unbalanced.  If the wall adapter is big, given the angle of the base and the one inch clearance from the desktop, it may not fit and will require you to plug in the adapter on a separate power strip or extra wall outlet.  The smart phone cradle also makes this unit about four times larger than my other two USB chargers (5Lx2Hx3W inches approximate).Having expressed some of the curious limitations of the docking cradle, I still give the unit 4 stars for a few reasons.  One is that the unit is weighted and does have two USB ports and an extra electrical outlet.  For my purposes, all these outlets are useful.  The extra weight had a very useful side effect.  I was able to plug in one of those USB LED lights into it and squiggle it over my computer keyboard.  This allows me to type on it without turning on a lot of lights (useful late at night or when I am watching videos that look better in the dark).  The recharger in this case acts like a power supply for this USB LED lights.  I can also read fine print by putting it very near the LED light.  The USB LED light was something I bought at the Dollar Store for just one buck.  Because there are two USB ports, I can still recharge something while still using the charger as an LED lamp!  Since I do not have any ipod like unit or a cell phone, the docking cradle makes a decent place to put a few USB thumb drives (or paper clips).  The shiny black plastic unit looks elegant enough on my desktop too.CONS:  Unit is about 4x bigger than other USB rechargers.  Smart phone docking cradle may need to be adapted to fit the smart phone using the foam inserts or even some cardboard pieces, and may not be able to fit two phones or ipod type devices of different thicknesses very easily.  You may also have to put the smart phone in upside down in order to plug in the power adapter and it might look awkward with the wires attaching one to the other (I guess you could wrap them with a twisty to get rid of the slack).  Electrical outlet is ungrounded, but most power adapters do not use a ground anyway.PROS:  Has two USB ports to charge two units simultaneously (my other USB rechargers only do one at time).  Has an extra standard electrical outlet to plug in a power adapter for a smart phone.  The extra outlet is useful for other purposes.  The heavier weight allows this to be a sturdy desktop item and can even hold a USB LED light (just for the record, those wires do have some trouble holding a shape, it might be good to get a block of wood to put into the cradle with a notch to hold the LED in place, I have mine held in place on top of a raised flat surface below the monitor being held down by a quartz crystal cluster, it works and I am happy with it).I gave the unit 4 stars because it does what it is supposed to do and looks elegant.  I did not give it 5 stars because it seems there is a design element that still feels a little awkward and makes the unit take up more room than the other USB rechargers.  I tried to give enough information in the review so that a person could determine if this unit would work for them or if they should get the smaller ones with only one USB port.  All in all, I am happy with the unit and consider its weightedness and ability to hold a USB LED light to be a bonus.Update:  This is a minor point, but I found that the dock of the iphone has the perfect dimensions for holding business cards.  I put them into the slot and now the charger feels functional on the desk.Update 5/7/2013: A friend gave me a USB LED mini-lamp with an on/off switch.  It is a simple device that has a USB plug on one side of a large thick cable about 1 foot long and an LED lamp with on/off on the other side.  When I plugged it into one of the 2 USB recharging ports, I found that it would act as an elegant mini-lamp for my computer keyboard (so I could work late at night at the kitchen table without disturbing anyone in the household).  The thickness was not enough to hold the lamp by itself, though.  But I took my cue from a handmade musical device and got some thick wire from an electronics store and wrapped the colored wires about the USB plug and the whole wire (to reinforce it).  It now holds its shape very well and makes an elegant LED lamp.  I can leave it plugged in without draining the power supply thanks to the simple little on/off switch.  The nice thing about this addition is that I can still use the remaining USB port to recharge items (I rarely charge more than one thing at a time) or I can unplug the LED lamp in a pinch and use both USB charging ports.  The base is heavy enough to hold this new "lamp".  So I now have something that holds business cards for me, has an on/off LED lamp overhanging my keyboard for night time computer work, can recharge USB port powered items (or just power them), and has an extra AC socket for regular electronics and power adapters.  Having this LED lamp bonus justifies the space this takes up on my computer desk.  I am very happy with this item.

After deciding to keep my head closely shaved, I bought a Wahl Super Close in September 2012.My first foil lasted about 26 months and then one day blooey in November 2014 there was a whacking great hole in it as it is easy to exert too much pressure.Ordered this replacement and after seven months it's still working, though these days I only use it occasionally and have found a Schick 5 blade "Schick Hydro Silk Disposable Razor" faster and more efficient and never cutting my skin. I estimate my Schick will cost about $3 per month delivering better shaves.

Pros:== When set to rain mode and with water restrictor removed, this product delivers a relaxing and enjoyable shower.== Product looks a lot more expensive than its price, and is stylish and nicely finished.Cons:== With water restrictor present, I found the shower decidedly underwhelming.  So this product is a good choice in localities where there are no water shortages.Note:== This product was provided to me free of charge with the agreement that I would provide an honest and unbiased review.

I found these quite addictive and delicious.  As mentioned by another reviewer, eating a really large quantity can loosen the bowels. (I must have eaten about 40, and some hours later had a mild dose of the trots).  I liked these so much that I have ordered two more jars.

When a high quality removable vagina is put into Sabrina's cavity, like a Tomax Lilith Uterus (about $40 on Amazon and worth every penny), she is an absolutely wonderful lifelike experience.  I've been trying to persuade the seller to adopt my modifications and start selling her on Amazon, but he doesn't seem too interested.  Without those modifications, fat guys would start writing terrible reviews saying she's no good in the sack.Anyway, with my various toys, I usually manage nirvana every day.

I got Carmen because I wanted to lie in bed and have missionary style sex, horizontal, because doggie style kneeling or standing was on the verge of creating repetitive stress syndrome using the same muscles every time.I was very pleasantly surprised. She occupies the same space as a well put together five foot tall woman, not skinny, not fat. She gives really good oral sex once her mouth is properly lubricated with a good quality lubricant like ID Glide (avoid the cheapos like Equate).Seen at a distance she is unrealistic. But when I hold her close I feel her realistically shaped Cyberskin breasts on my chest with firm little nipples and when I hold her close face to face I see her quite realistic eyes and not her rather scary mouth. The mouth may be scary to look at, but it is very very good at oral, even with a limp Johnson, because the mouth is already open and can easily be entered, even if one is not stiff.Her face is not vinyl, instead it is made of a material that is smooth and unyielding enough to feel like a real human head. Also it really helps that I feel her hair on my face. After holding her for five minutes her body absorbs enough of my body heat that her body feels almost real.Another important feature, true of all love dolls, and unlike other sex toys like vaginal sleeves,is that the love tunnel is held in a constant position that you have to adjust to, but can derive pleasure from through even slight differences in position that cause different pressures on the different surfaces of one's member.The main problem with this product is that after five or six encounters it tends to develop leaks. Avoid lying on top of her because this really shortens her life. Instead, have her lie on top of you. Or sideways. Or standing up. It is also important not to overinflate. After the leaks got too much I threw away the body and kept just the head, which, like I said, offers remarkably good oral sex, and is very durable. It has a long love tunnel that can be washed, with a squeeze bulb at the back of the head, that offers quite delicious suction.Because of my very positive experience with Carmen, I decided that love dolls are really great, and have graduated to a very rugged TeddyBabe Deluxe love doll, made of fabric and fiberfill stuffing and a strong metal skeleton, five foot four tall, who after two years of frequent encounters, in many positions --- on top, underneath, sideways, standing up -- still is working just fine, though I had to spend a few very well spent hours with needle and thread relocating her love tunnel cavity so as to fit my large beer belly (search for SabrinaModded on www . dollforum . com for the whys and wherefores and exact methods of the mods.)I didn't much like the removable love tunnel supplied with Carmen. I found it too squishy. A far better love tunnel for Carmen is the Vibratex Maven (available on Amazon) which is small enough to fit the vaginal cavity, and that remains a fine source of sexual release after Carmen's body becomes too leaky to be useful.Anyway... I think love dolls are useful because they give me a different kind of physical workout than doggie style, using different muscles. And Carmen Luvana convinced me that love dolls are really really great sources of good feelings and of sexual release. And Carmen as a huge added plus offers great oral, better than the $150 F*ck My Face Silly offered by PipeDreams.Carmen can be easily stored because of her light weight, either standing in a closet between clothes or lying flat on the top shelf of the closet. Personally I bought a $13 electric air pump from Amazon that allows rapid inflation and deflation that makes storage easy.Some vendors sell at a higher price than others so look around a bit.

I really like this keyboard except the caps lock light does not work, which is very annoying when typing passwords.  This problem has been noted in previous reviews and one would think the vendor would have got the manufacturer to fix the problem by now.  I returned the first keyboard because the caps light did not work and ordered a replacement.  Just today (May 12 2015) I received the second keyboard and guess what ?  Caps lock indicator does'nt work. Grrrrr.Otherwise this is a really nice full size keyboard with large lit keys that I can see in low light and even with my glasses taken off.

Our old Dustbuster bit the dust about 6 months ago. Finally I replaced it some weeks ago with this product. In the 5 or so months without any Dustbuster I started using a dustpan and brush, $7.99 from my local Target.  Since the arrival of this item I've come to realize that 90 per cent of the time a good old fashioned dustpan and brush does a faster and better job.  And provides more exercise.However this item is useful in crevices and with certain kinds of spills, like powders, so I am keeping it for these reasons.I like the fact that like the old Dustbuster it suspends from a hook on the wall.  But the old Dustbuster connected to electric power whenever I  hung it on the hook. Whereas this one requires an extra step, namely taking a wire with a male plug and plugging it into a receptacle on the handle.In summing up, on balance, I would still buy it, to vacuum from crevices and for spills that brush and pan do not handle.  But I have learned a dustpan can be a more efficient method for clearing dropped bits of macaroni crumbs and other flotsam and jetsam etcera etcera from the kitchen floor.UPDATE: Maybe it's because I kept it plugged in all the time without using it often enough.  But using it daily for the past 5 days I've found it vacuums briskly for about 40 seconds, then gradually dies so that by 90 seconds it is no longer picking up.

I cannot get this to work under Windows 8.1 Pro when installed as an internal SATA drive in a Dell 755 Optiplex mini-tower.BIOS recognizes that it exists, but Windows 8.1 does not even deign to recognize that it is present in the computer.Ubuntu, on the same puter,  recognizes it  and reads from it with no difficulty.On the other hand, Win 8.1 Pro does recognize my Samsung USB 2.0 Ultra Portable External DVD Writer Model SE-218CB/RSBS, also called Samsung Ultra Thin DVD Writer, an external drive connected by USB port, so I am able to read DVDs.  But not with this baby.Maybe if I put this drive inside an external USB housing it might work.

Based on the XL size I received, XL corresponds to size 9 to 11 man's shoes and maybe size 7 to 9 man's boots. The ad needs revising. The vendor should provide a table showing correspondence between the item sizes (S, M, L, XL, XXL) and the corresponding sizes of men's and women's boots, and shoes.The product looks well made (4 stars) but is badly described (1 star). So I award 2.5 stars, rounded to 3.

I bought this in 2009 in hopes it would last a long time, unlike the plastic versions of this sprinkler I had been buying.  It was okay from 2009 to the end of last year.  But some days ago I hooked it up and .... it no longer oscillates. So it gave 5 years of service.  In my experience the plastic versions last between 2 and 3 years, and cost about $20 each.  So the cost is between $10 to $7 per year, whereas the cost of this has been $6 per year.  So.... this is a little bit cheaper to operate than the plastic version.However this product has one major advantage over the plastic version, namely a water flow control valve, which is very useful.

I have a fairly heavy airconditioner weighing about 80 pounds and have found it quite a struggle to  keep pulling it out, hauling it up to the attic, at the onset of winter,  then putting it back in the window when the summer heat begins.This last fall I purchased this item and was very pleased at the result, after I took the additional step of putting insulation in the surrounding window area.  The migration of cold through the airconditioner housing into the room was minimal, buffered by the large volume of inert air within the body of the a/c.

My wife and I did not enjoy it at all.  Was too dark for me.  Streetwise money-strapped hottie sees her doppelganger commit suicide.  Burgles the dead woman's apartment and starts thinking maybe she should try to impersonate the dead woman, since they look identical.  That stopped us right there.  Totally implausible script.  Most of the time BBC does great stuff.  Not this time, however.

This bag beautifully fits my Lumix FZ200 camera.  I measured the interior and it will take cameras or videocams up to 3.25" x 7" x 6".A crucially important feature to me is the rapid opening bag, using a single quick release clasp, instead of having to fumble with a  zipper, though one can deploy the zip as well.The design is handsome and compact, the materials are excellent quality, the padding is good, and the bag is well finished.

This product looks to be well made.  However, when I unpacked it I discovered that the heels of my boots will not be covered because these boot covers have half soles ... where the front part of the sole of the boot will be covered, but the rear part is left exposed.  No doubt this is fine for motorcycle riding, but I bought these boot covers intending to use them for gardening, to prevent the soles of my boots getting dirty.

This drive is a bit slow but it works under Microsoft 8.1 Professional when other drives do not.Recently in a Dell Optiplex 755 I installed a new internal drive, a Lite-On Super AllWrite IHAS124-04, a really mainstream product.  It is recognized in BIOS.  It is recognized by Vista and by Ubuntu.  But WIndows Professional 8.1 refuses to even acknowledge that it exists, much less allow me to access it.This Samsung USB drive, on the other hand, is recognized, and works, under Windows 8.1 Professional.  So, I recommend it if you have difficulties with DVD drive access under Win 8.1 Pro.P.S. I have a strong suspicion -- perhaps quite unwarranted -- that Microsoft wants to prevent end users from accessing DVD drives, because they allow unsophisticated users to load old software that Microsoft wishes to obsolesce, so they can sell new software. Maybe this suspicion is enitrely wrong, but I am really mystified why I cannot access a mainstream DVD drive using Windows 8.1 Professional .

I've had this product since June 2010 and it's still functioning just fine, so I give it five stars for reliability.  It's hooked up in a concealed position where it remains all the time, and it starts every time I start the car engine.  On at least 10 occasions it has warned me of police presence on roads with ridiculously low speed limits, and probably saved me at least $2,000 in tickets, and points on my drivers license and rises in my insurance payments.I explain to friends that I have it in the car not so much to speed, but to reduce the boredom of driving the same route every day.  With the detector in place, I keep seeing cunning speed traps half a mile before the actual police vehicle.  Since installing the detector I have not had a a single traffic stop for speeding.There are many rural roads in my state (New Jersey) that are in my opinion deliberately tricky, with speed  limit signs hidden by shrubbery, so the limit varies between 50 and 25 without any change in road quality, in the interests of boosting town revenue through pouncing on non-residents.So, I am happy with my detector. It is great entertainment and helps keep me awake.  After 53 years with a driver's license, driving is usually pretty boring. Buy one for your dad or mom, if they don't already own one. You can always return it if they don't want it.P.S. Maybe I am a bit paranoid, but I understand that some police have the attitude that if they see a radar detector, they see a driver who intends to break the law by speeding, and will ticket you for the slightest infraction. So I have taken steps that make the detector virtually invisible. One thing I did was to cover it and the power cord with a fabric that matches the interior of my car, and then mounting it so that it lies between the car ceiling and the rear view mirror.  This took quite a bit of thought, the purchase of a special clip, and the purchase of a long cord which runs from the dashboard power point (formerly called cigarette lighter power supply) behind the moldings beside the window and above the car ceiling, so that the wire cannot be seen.I rarely exceed the speed limit by more than 10 per cent, and when the road warrants it, I travel below the speed limit, because there are some roads where the limit is actually too high.  Though there are a lot more roads where the limit is set too low, because the residents have enough political pull to discourage thru traffic by setting the limit at 25 when the natural limit is 40. So -- I'm glad I bought it.

I wanted a computer with a full size keyboard and a nice big screen that could be moved easily between different rooms unlike a full desktop.  I find that laptops are fine for traveling but really uncomfortable with poor ergonomics  for sitting at for long stretches of time, while this machine is as comfortable as a regular desktop because of the full keyboard and regular mouse that can be separated and placed wherever you want.Also I wanted a computer with a touch monitor small children can use. The touch monitor is excellent, and Windows 8 is especially designed to use touch technology.Also I wanted a reliable machine, and have over the years come to trust the Dell brand more than any other personal computer maker, because they use good components and  are well engineered with designs that do not get too close to the edge and have excellent documentation on the Dell website.  My first Dell, an XPS 1000, was bought in year 2000, and is still working.  And I have not had any hardware trouble with the five other Dells I have used in four different locations, a GX280, an Optiplex 745, Optiplex 755, Optiplex 7010, and a Latitude 830 laptop. So I expect this machine to be very probably reliable.This item is not a cutting edge puter that is super fast or super duper or suitable for gaming.  Instead it's a good old inexpensive workhorse that is not likely to let you down, and is good for touch screen users.

I see that a great majority of users of this product have awarded either 4 or 5 stars, which means that for them, this product really works well.You may indeed fall in this category, and certainly this product is well worth trying, because it is relatively inexpensive.I am awarding 2 stars, because in my experience, this product is way inferior to SeaBond Denture Adhesive Wafers, in two important respects.  First, this product does not hold my teeth in place half as effectively as the SeaBond wafers. Second, this product leaves a nasty goop on the roof of my mouth.I purchased this item for $5.99 from my local Walgreens, which is quite a bit higher than the $4.28 per tube from this vendor.

A full size love doll including head, arms, legs and torso is an entirely different experience than a vaginal sleeve or a doggie style ass.  I find it so very different to have a face with eyes to look into.  If the doll occupies the same space as would a human partner, has the same contours as a human, has hair that gets in my face sometimes, has a reasonably nice skin, and the doll has been warmed by my body, I find the feeling is remarkably good.Viewed at a distance, Jamie Lynn does not have the realism of a $6,000 RealDoll, but she is surprisingly real where it counts, which is how she looks and feels when she is being held close to you, face to face.When you are up close, you do not see the gaping mouth (which is very good for oral sex and french kissing).  Instead you see her eyes, and you feel her remarkably real forehead, and her hair, even though there is hair only on the front part of her head, and you feel her breasts, which are formed of a semi rigid rubber-like material, and which are close enough to real to feel good.  Also, a RealDoll weighs at least 70 pounds, and unless you are in really great shape, is rather a hassle to move.  Jamie Lynn, on the other hand  is almost weightless, which might sound unreal, except that when a real woman lies atop a man, she can support herself so he does not bear her full weight.  Also, one can simulate the weight of a body by hugging.Jamie Lynn is suited for missionary position on  top. Do not try lying on top of her because she will develop a fatal leak very quickly, and do not overinflate.  To inflate and deflate her more efficiently, I purchased an electric air pump for $13.I am giving Jamie Lynn five stars not because the doll is perfect, but because she convinced me that love dolls can be very pleasurable, and because her mouth is very good at oral sex, and unlike her body, is very durable, and gives better oral sex than the $150 âPipedream F*** my Faceâ, which is much more realistic to look at, but less good where it counts.I have since graduated to a much more durable product, a 5 foot 4 inch tall, fabric covered TeddyBabe love doll called Sabrina, who weighs fifteen pounds, has a soft velour skin and is very rugged and nice to hold and caress.  With a first class vaginal insert (see my review of Tomax Lilith Uterus on Amazon) she has given me great pleasure for hundreds of encounters, though I had to modify her using methods described in my review of the Tomax Lilith Uterus.  However she is quite pricey.If you want a really good view of the love doll market, from $100 to $10,000, visit the www dollforum com website, as Amazon right now is only selling products on the lower end of the sex doll market.In any event, the Jamie Lynn product that I am discussing here is, IMHO,  worth acquiring just to find out whether you enjoy a love doll, and for her wickedly good mouth. (Caution: Three of the four Topco inflatables I bought from Amazon have excellent mouths that fit my 1.25â diameter member; the fourth, a Jamie Lynn, second purchase, had a smaller mouth that was too small for me.  To be on the safe side, stick with Carmen Luvana, who is very much like Jamie Lynn except for coloring of hair and eyes.  If anyone encounters too small a mouth, please tell Topco, and also tell me through a comment).P.S.  The Jamie Lynn that I received was 60" tall.  Another reviewer reported receiving a 54â doll.  If the doll does not conform to the stated size, I would hope Topco would give a refund.

On March 4th 2015 I had my six upper front teeth pulled and a full denture installed, one that relies only on suction, with no anchoring teeth or anchoring posts.  This was my first denture so I am a denture newbie.(NOTE: About 8 weeks before my six upper front teeth were removed, I had my eight upper rear teeth extracted, leaving a coverup of six front teeth.  This maneuver means that I always had front teeth in the mouth, sometimes real, and sometimes fake, so that I never appeared to be embarrassingly toothless.  It is quite remarkable, but six front teeth is enough to convince others you have a full set of choppers.)For about a week the denture stayed in place without any adhesive.Then it began to get loose and to fall out uncontrollably, I tried Fixodent Denture Adhesive Cream claiming "Strong, All Day Hold, Food Seal, Comfort".  It worked well for about a week and then started to be less and less effective, and had the strong disadvantage of leaving a lot of scummy feeling residue on the roof of my mouth, that took quite a little while to remove with paper towels and toothbrush.Then I tried Super Poligrip with ooze-control tip, claiming "Super strong, all-day hold".  Results were very similar to Fixodent except that it wasn't effective from day 1.Then on March 23 I saw my dentist, 19 days after the fake teeth were put in place, and told him of my problems with the denture being unstable and falling out.  He recommended the Sea-bond product.  Additionally he said that some patients combine the Sea-bond wafers with denture adhesive cream like Fixodent or Poligrip.I followed his advice and purchased the Sea-bond immediately. What an improvement !!  I bought it from Walgreen for $9.99 for 30, so 33 cents each, which is 50 per cent more than the price from this vendor, $20.32 for 90 wafers, which comes to about 23 cents per copy, or $84 per year.Yet despite the improved adhesion, I am not finding the denture painful to remove, though maybe this is because I did not start using it until 19 days after the front teeth were removed, so the gums had more time to heal. (At first removing the denture was a pretty ouchie experience, but now it does not hurt at all.)A few hints to denture newbies:==  Before any teeth are removed, change your diet to an all liquid diet.  Before my rear molars were extracted I started on a 100 per cent liquid diet, which in my case has been absolutely wonderfully better than my previous solid food diet in terms of energy and weight, because I chose carefully what I would be having, which was about 50 per cent Soylent and 50 per cent high nutrition soups made out of fish and kale and other good stuff and blended until silky smooth in a strong blender (I purchased a Blendtec after considering VItamix and Ninja).This meant I did not make my gums sore trying to eat solid food. Also my weight declined from about 195 to about 180, and has remained there.  My dentist tells me that my gums have healed beautifully, and thinks that the pure liquid diet has helped a lot.== Try to manipulate the wafer inside the denture shell so it covers as much area as possible, especially the front vertical section; it takes quite a bit of maneuvering the wet wafer to make it conform to the front vertical section, but I find it makes a huge difference in terms of stability;== Cut as little as possible from the wafer;  I have quite a small head and a small mouth for a male, but I've found it beneficial not to cut the wafer at all, and instead to make sure I cover every bit of the denture surface, even with a little overlap beyond the denture edge.== The instructions on the package say "moisten" the wafer and do not saturate. I started out gently moistening. Now I am moistening a lot more heavily, and finding better results in terms of adhesion.== Under pressure from my better half, I have been very slowly learning to consume little bits of solid food, so as to vary my diet a bit more.  I have found it helps tremendously to cut food into little itty bits.  Take too large of a piece and it's likely to dislodge the denture.So... to sum up... I find the Sea-bond superior to the other two products I've tried.  Someone tells me that powdered adhesives plus Sea Bond work well for them, but I have not tried this so far. It's early days yet. Hopefully the re-line of my denture in about 5 months time will create perfect suction and I won't have to use any kind of adhesive. (The re-line improves the fit of the denture to the gums).  But in the meantime, Sea-bond is doing a pretty good job.UPDATE: October 6 2015For the past weeks the Sea-bond has been less and less effective and my choppers have been loose much of the time.  A friend told me a very good remedy. Namely, apply two layers of powdered dental adhesive, one layer to the denture (that should be moistened), then lay the Sea-Bond patch on the powdered denture, then apply a second layer of powder, on top of the Sea-Bond patch (that should also be moistened.  Then stick it in the mouth.  It works !!!!!  Right now I'm using Fixodent Extra Hold Powder.  Makes the teeth feel cemented in.

I've spent quite a long time looking for a camera bag with two very important features:  first, and absolutely crucial, I wanted a bag that opens  by rapid release clasp, so I can get to the camera real quick and not have to diddle around with zips; second, I wanted a compact and good looking bag with good fit to my Panasonic Lumix FZ1000 camera.  This bag fills all these requirements.My Lumix FZ1000 is an intermediate size.  Sitting on its base, it has a footprint of 5.5" wide, 7" long from back of camera to front of lens hood, and 4" high.  This bag gives a close to perfect fit, but is about an inch longer, so it could accommodate a camera up to 8 inches long from front to back.This bag opens and closes using  a sturdy rapid release single  clasp, that lets you get the camera out much faster than bags using zippers.  In addition to the clasp there is a zipper to close the bag, for extra security.  But the clasp is pretty strong and I cannot imagine it opening accidentally, so I do not bother to use the zip.It has zippered pockets at both ends to hold battery and small items, and a zippered front pouch, about 3 inches by 6 inches.The padding is good enough for my purposes; it will not protect from a major blow, but it will protect from minor impacts; if it were any thicker it would make the bag fatter and less compact;The build quality is excellent -- it does not look or feel cheap.There are two carrying modes:  [a]  a handgrip and [b] a shoulder strap that is adjustable from quite short to quite long, long enough to put the bag over your shoulder while the bag hangs on the opposite side of your body.Note to manufacturer:While this is a really excellent bag, there are three improvements I would like to see. First, add a stretchy net to the back of the bag, could be up to 4 inches by 8 inches. This would be useful for carrying a camera manual.  Second, add stretch nets to both end pockets, useful for doodads.  Third, enlarge the front zippered pocket.

This camera comes with a detachable lens hood and the manual recommends the hood be installed. The cord of this lens cap is exactly the right length when the lens hood is removed.  The cord needs to be one or two inches longer to allow use of the lens cap when the lens hood is in place.  It would be a real hassle for me to locate a replacement cord since these cords are of a high quality material that is both quite thin and very durable.  I have no problem with the lens cap, which fitted well, and is well constructed.

This is a popular item with many stellar reviews and an average of 4.4 stars.However, I bought it to replace a wall mounted DustBuster, and was less than pleased when I unpacked this product and found that it cannot be wall mounted, that its only possible position is standing upright, standing a hefty18 inches high and occupying a fairly ample  footprint.  It is very handsome in a bulky sort of way, but unfortunately our kitchen is crowded and there is no unused counter space, and the wall beside the microwave is the only feasible place to put a hand vac.All of the many other Dustbusters that I have seen are wall mounted.  Scrutinizing the ad on Amazon, I find that buried way down on the page there is a teeny weeny photo showing the item sitting on a base, and not wall mounted.  But there is no explicit statement âcannot be wall mountedâ.When I buy a car I expect a spare tire, without having to find explicit mention in the advertising.  Similarly when I buy a Dustbuster, a product that in my experience always came with a wall mount, I expect to find a wall mount, unless the advertising clearly states âno wall mountâThe Black & Decker CHV1510 Dustbuster does have a wall mount,  and I have ordered one, and am returning this product.NOTE TO VENDOR:  Please, please, prominently advertise that this is not wall mounted.  I really resent having to pay shipping to return this item that was inadequately described.

First of all,  let me state how much I love my Blendtec Classic 570, a relatively low end Blendtec, $299.99 at Costco.  Just now I made a fruit smoothie deluxe comprising: 16 ounces Kirkland nutrition drink;  3 cups of ice; 3 bananas; half a cup of blackberries; a cup of strawberries; a 10 oz can of apricots. That's about two quarts of ingredients put into the three quart Blendtec WildSide jar. I hit the "lo" button and let it spin for about 30 seconds. Lo and behold !  A gorgeous 64 ounce fruit smoothie.  My dear 10 year old Black & Decker could not do anything like this, with its 1.5 quart (48 oz) container, and its peenie weenie little motor, which would be emitting burning smells after this kind of stress. Plus. I love the Blendtec for its nice blunt blade that I can't cut myself on, unlike Vitamix and unlike the Ninja products.  And love the design of the top of the jar, that efficiently evacuates air pressure build up, so that the top does not pop off spewing ingredients all over the kitchen, and, also,  gives plenty of warning of potential overflow, because it has a highly visible reservoir on top that will flood before the jar begins to leak its contents onto the countertop, giving the user plenty of time to stop the Blendtec before it makes a mess.Second, however, I wish to castigate the Blendtec corporation for a critical defect in their product.Blendtec claims their product is easy to clean.  Hah !! My dear 10 year old Black & Decker is much much better in this regard, because you can take it apart completely, and submerge it in warm soapy water, and scrub every single surface until they are all squeaky clean. The Blendtec WildSide jar, on the other hand, cannot be taken apart completely, and, according to the manufacturer, should not be submerged because it will damage the bottom side of the seal.  Please, Blendtec Corporation, redesign this so that the rotor assembly can be removed, and like my dear old Black and Decker, can be submerged for washing.I guess I can get the blendtec mixing jar clean enough to avoid food poisoning.  But it is very difficult to get it anywhere near as squeaky clean as my dear old B&D, with not a speck of soap residue, as clear as a well cleaned window.  I know, the jug is made of plastic.  But in these days where universities have Materials Science departments, surely Blendtec can find a coating that will simulate the beautiful cleaning properties of glass.  And, probably much easier and cheaper, redesign the rotor and seal assembly so it can be routinely removed for cleaning, and submerged in water.One other defect. I do not like the design of the buttons on the control panel, which allow liquids to seep in between button and panel. Now most likely there is waterproofing there, but it just makes me very uneasy, as electricity and water can together deliver nasty electric shocks.I do not know how easy Vitamix jars are to clean.  I rejected Vitamix because the blade is sharp and I just know I would lacerate my hand in one of my klutzier moments. For the same reason, I rejected the much cheaper Ninja, which most likely is much less durable than either Blendtec or Vitamix.

I bought this Syba device because I wanted to install an IDE DVD burner onto a Windows 7 computer, a Dell Optiplex 745. which has only SATA ports on the motherboard.  After several hours trying to make it work, I gave up, sadder, but no wiser.The DVD burner was working perfectly well on a Windows XP computer with IDE connectors on the motherboard, so it it is not the fault of the  drive.  And I tried several different working DVD burner drives, including a Sony, a Pioneer and a  Plextor.After several hours of trying to connect the DVD burner to the Dell Optiplex 745,  I concluded I had tried every possible angle, and that quite possibly the Syba device is a dud that had not been properly tested.  Or maybe it is just incompatible with the Dell 745 Optiplex.Here is what I should have done at first, but did not do, because the user manual is carelessly written:[1]  Use the orange SATA cable supplied with the Syba device to connect the SATA1 port on the computer motherboard to the black SATA port on the Syba (the Syba also has an orange SATA port, to be used if you have the female Syba IDE connector plugged onto an IDE male on the computer motherboard).[2]  Plug a full size 4 pin Molex power connector to the DVD drive power point.  The user manual fails to make this clear !!!  Indeed, the manual tells the user to connect the computer power supply to a 4 pin mini-Molex power port located on the Syba device, which makes no sense whatever, because the Syba device's only connection with the DVD drive is through its 40 pin parallel port, and the parallel wires do not carry any power.[3]  Turn on the computer and go straight to BIOS.  Set the SATA1 port to active and look to see whether the DVD drive has been recognized.  I tried numerous times, and sadly, it was never recognized.  If the computer BIOS does not provide this functionality, you would have to start the computer and then test whether the drive is recognized.This should work.  But it did not work for me.  The manual that comes with the Syba device implies the DVD drive  jumper settings can be any value, either Cable Select, or Master, or Slave.  I tried all three and none worked.CONCLUSIONFrom the 230 or so reviews done so far, I gather that the Syba device has worked for many people.  It is inexpensive, so I think it is worth trying.  In my own case I had a good reason for trying, because I have an old Plextor 760A DVD burner that came bundled with a super duper early version of Roxio burning software, that can only be installed if the Plextor is present, and is  much easier to use than Nero or any other DVD burner software that I have yet encountered.If anyone reading this has any ideas on anything else I might try, I'd appreciate hearing from them.

This item has a sleek minimalist design and is solidly made of good materials. The design includes a high quality clear perspex type plastic square 3/8" thick and about 8 inches by 8 inches, that looks tough and durable,  sandwiched between two stainless steel plates, very important in localities with hard water, where stainless steel offers good resistance to corrosion.On the surface of the shower head, there is an impressive array of 88 soft plastic nozzles which form a square pattern of about 5 inches by 5 inches and a diagonal of 7 inches. I think these nozzles will do a good job dealing with hard water and will not corrode.The water stream remains about the same dispersion  throughout its journey to the floor of the bath, and is about 5" x 5" at waist height rather than widening. The flow is relatively gentle. I could not find anywhere a statistic on gallons per minute.My wife likes it very much.Personally, I prefer the more vigorous and torrential feeling provided by our Moen Vitalizer 7 inch chrome model that we had in place in the master bathroom before replacing it with this item.  The Moen's 73 nozzles provide a wider dispersion of water, to about 9 inches at waist height. The Moen ad is explicit about water flow and advertises a maximum flow of 2.5 gallons per minute (our water company provides a water pressure with maximum flow about 6gpm). The Moen is clunky looking and much less attractive than the AquaFlow.I note that the vendor asked me to review this item and provided me with a free sample with the agreement I would provide an honest and unbiased review.  My assessment is that the AquaFlow is handsome and provides a nice gentle shower with a concentrated stream of water.My wife likes the AquaFlow, but I prefer the Moen, which costs a bit more ($44 on Amazon) and seems to throw the water at a higher speed, but is chromium plated rather than stainless steel. Chromium has the disadvantage of being more prone to deterioration and needing to be polished frequently, while stainless steel needs almost no maintenance. I am awarding the AquaFlow 4 stars, my wife gives it 5.OTHER OBSERVATIONS:== On the copy I got, the balljoint was too loose and I could not adjust the angle of the head --- instead the shower head just flopped so the bottom edge rested on the wall of the shower.  Suggestion to manufacturer: one inexpensive modification to prevent a floppy ball joint is to introduce a thumbscrew that the user can tighten to prevent the shower head from flopping around.== The nut on the AquaFlow that attaches to the water supply pipe needs a larger flat section to allow use of a smooth jaw wrench. Also it would be helpful to emulate Ikea and supply an inexpensive wrench.== I totally agree with the reviewer who stated that installation has to involve tools, in  order to sufficiently tighten the joint between shower head and the water supply pipe.  To tighten the joint I first tried using a smooth jaw wrench, to avoid marring the finish, but this did not work.  I wound up using pliers with teeth, but since the affected area is out of sight, it did not bother me one tiny little bit to mar the surface a little.  In actual fact, when I examined the affected area, there were only faint marks, that certainly would not be noticed by anyone.== By the way, I did not bother using the plumber's teflon tape, since there had already been a shower head installed on that pipe, which provided enough sealant. There has not been any leak.

UPDATE JULY 5 2015The FZ200 is a great cam but after owning an FZ1000 for several months I must say the FZ1000 is better because of its large and  bright  viewfinder that makes it easier to see what you are taking and that makes it much much  easier to take pictures outdoors. With your eye to  the viewfinder and the other eye closed there are no distractions because nothing else is visible except the image and the indicators like F stop and shutter speed and ISO, which are all much clearer than on the flipout monitor.  With my eye to the viewfinder I find I can manipulate the knobs much better and in my experience have better access to the menus because I can see them better.  So... if you can afford to spend about $300 more, the FZ1000 would IMHO be a better choice, because of its superlative viewfinder.EARLIER TEXT FEBRUARY 2015[1]  One of the things I like most about the FZ200 is its awesomely strong image stabilization, that allows me to take good hand held shots without a tripod under low light and at long telephoto ranges.I have taken photos of Verrazano Bridge from 14 miles away, from Laurence Harbor Beach in New Jersey.  Image 1 at the end of this review shows the bridge using a telephoto setting of 960mm  and reveals remarkably little camera shake, though the photo is rather hazy because of humidity and shimmer.  I have taken the same scene with a tripod  ... and noticed very little reduction in blur.Also I have taken indoor pictures at night-time of friends and family under normal living room and dining room artificial light, with no bright lights and no flash, and have gotten super images with good reproduction of colors, at incredibly low shutter speeds like one eighth of a second, because of the profoundly good image stabilization.  A discovery that totally surprised me is that when people are seated in a social situation, they tend to remain still, except when speaking or eating, so that low shutter speeds very often give good photos.Image 2 at the end of this review shows a map of South America.  The pic was taken indoors at 600mm in fully automatic mode without a tripod.  The camera selected an incredibly low shutter speed of 1/15 of a second, and an ISO value of 400.  The picture was taken under artificial light provided by a shaded 23 watt CFL light bulb. This is given as another example of the FZ200's enormously powerful image stabilization.  The pic also shows excellent color balance and comes very close to reproducing the true colors of the subject.[2.1]  A second thing I like about this cam is its performance in fully automatic mode. After taking many many images, I have concluded that 9 out of 10 times, fully automatic mode gives better settings than I can achieve under semi-automatic or manual.It is crucial to realize that in fully automatic mode this is a WYSIWYG camera.  What you see on the LCD is almost exactly what the image will look like if you take a picture.  For someone who used a 35mm film camera, this is magical. In the old days you took pix at various settings and had to wait many hours or days before seeing the results.  With this wee beastie,  you actually get to preview the final picture, exactly the way it will look, before you take it.  And this means you can keep fooling around and  repositioning the camera until you get the best possible (or least bad) image.A camera that takes great photographs in automatic mode is a great camera because  it means you can concentrate on the substance of the picture, rather than being distracted by the need to set the camera controls to the right setting, which consumes time, and often means that you miss a lot of good shots, because one is too busy fiddling with the cam.[2.2] I keep running across reviews by people living in the past with a 35mm mindset, like:  "One needs a tripod";  "Automatic mode is strictly for amateurs who don't know better";  "One needs flash to fill in shadows."I think this is totally nuts.  This is a 21st century electronic camera that amplifies light so it sees better than the human eye, designed by a collaboration of engineers from Leica and Panasonic, and most of the time, when set in automatic mode, will take something very close to the best possible image, that seldom needs a tripod, that almost never benefits from using flash.There are some important exceptions where semi-automatic is better than fully automatic, and it is useful to know the manual controls well enough to deal with such situations.  When faced with  rapidly moving subjects under low light, I find it necessary to use shutter priority mode in order to select higher shutter speed and higher ISO than the FZ200 will choose in full auto mode.  But I am still letting the FZ automatically control the other settings.But in general I get excellent pictures by starting out in automatic mode, and accepting it if the picture looks properly exposed, and only trying manual when I'm not happy with the automatic mode picture.What this camera does - the beautiful thing it does - is let me grab a properly exposed shot of a far away object before it goes away.  The bird is on a twig 50 feet away, with its head cocked at an appealing angle, and one wants to get the shot before it flies away, and one zooms in to frame the bird just right, and one clicks, all in a few seconds.  And voila, a really good pic.[3] As noted in other reviews, and super important to me, this camera calculates focus and exposure very very rapidly, so there is only a tiny time lag between pointing the camera and shooting the image, much much faster than my beloved Canon pocket camera.  Also, it will very rapidly take multiple images.[4]  I have not used the competition to this camera, namely the similarly priced superzooms by Nikon and Canon and Sony and Fuji.  So I cannot say this is superior to any of those.  What I can say is that I find myself taking amazingly good pictures with this camera under low light conditions, and at very long range telephoto.[5] If you buy this camera, I would strenuously recommend that you also buy Graham Houghton's "Panasonic Lumix DMC-FZ200 - User's Manual".  I bought the hard copy for $35, but you can download a copy for free if your conscience will allow, or you can do the right thing and pay $5 for the download.  Also check out Graham's stuff on U-Tube, and his website at www.grahamhoughton.com(The user manual that comes with the camera contains useful information and is worth reading but is not very user friendly, and Graham's book explains things much better).[6]  Some reviewers put huge emphasis on very high resolution and very low "noise" in pictures, and quite rightly point out that the FZ-200 is not the best of the best in these regards.  If high res and low noise is very important to you, you might think of looking at cams priced at $800 and higher, such as the Sony RX10 and the Lumix FZ1000.  Personally, I find the FZ200's picture quality pretty damn flawless for 5x7 and 8x10 photos, though at higher sizes I would expect to see minor weaknesses./-----------P.S. I do own a tripod, a great big Star made in Taiwan, that weighs nine pounds and whose maximum elevation is 78 inches.  In the old days it was used for image stabilization with my 35mm film cameras.  I occasionally find it very useful these days when I have a static object and am willing to spend serious amounts of time pondering the best angle and the best light and where the tripod is very useful in helping me to be more systematic and more thoughtful.  But 99 per cent of the time with this camera I have no need for a tripod.

I initially gave this item 2 stars because it had real low download speeds on my brand new quite fast Dell 7010 quadcore running Win 7 Pro, speeds like 7Mbps when my three other machines were getting 14Mbps.But when I removed it from the 7010 and put it in an 8 year old laptop running WinXP, all of a sudden downloads jumped to 16Mbps.So there seems to be a problem with the 7010.So I am changing rating from two stars to four stars.  I do not think this item deserves more than four, as it does not download any faster than my MediaLink MWN-USB150N, that claims a 150Mbps download speed. Also, the Panda's media interface is much skimpier and less informative than the MediaLink's.

PROS == By far the most important thing that makes me like this camera  is the viewfinder, with a large and bright display that provides WYSYWIG when in automatic mode (i.e. what you see is what you get).  It is a gianl improvement over LCD monitors, both flip-out and on the back of the camera,  for several reasons:First and foremost, I can see with significantly greater clarity through the viewfinder than on an LCD monitor.  And... very very crucial ....  photography is all about seeing.Second, I find that when I use the viewfinder, the camera is easier to control, because when it is pressed up against my face, my  fingers are much closer to the camera than when I am using an LCD monitor.  Unlike with an LCD monitor, my fingers are in a constant orientation with respect to the camera, which helps me to better access the controls without having to look at them.Third, I find it easier and faster to navigate menus and to change settings like F-stop and ISO and shutter speed when the camera is pressed against my face.Fourth, very very important, it's easier to take photos outdoors with your eye pressed against the viewfinder excluding extraneous light than it is with an LCD monitor,  especially under bright sun..Before closing my comments about the viewfinder versus the flip out LCD monitor, I should note that  the flip out on the FZ1000 is nice and flexible -- and remains very useful under certain circumstances --  if you want to shoot from low down in a situation where you don't want to bend, or high up if you are in a crowd or need to see over some other obstacle.  But most of the time these days  I find myself shooting from the viewfinder, because I can see so much better..== Excellent performance in indoor photographyI originally got this cam because I wanted to take pictures indoors under normal levels of artificial light with ultra rapid focus and exposure control.  By "normal levels of artificial light" I mean no light coming in from windows, no special artificial lighting, and no flash.  Just the amount of light you would get in a normally lit windowless office or in a living room at night time or in a furniture showroom.This cam is very good at doing this when it is in automatic mode, yielding amazingly good hand held pix in poor light,  at incredibly low shutter speeds like a quarter of a second, without a tripod, because of superlatively strong image stabilization, and this happens even at substantial zooms like 200mm.  Any camera without image stabilization would be showing huge amounts of blur and shake.  And I should add that color balance in low artificial light is good, when in automatic mode.With candid pictures of people under normal living room lighting at night time, the FZ1000 usually  does surprisingly well in automatic mode.  I was enormously surprised to find that with exposure of one quarter second, most pictures of most people come out quite well, because with most people, there is much less movement than I expected to find - except when the person is speaking or eating.As might be expected, under low light the FZ1000 in automatic mode does not do well in capturing rapidly moving people or other objects. But setting a high shutter speed and a high ISO value this camera copes quite well.  It's true that high ISO's make photos more grainy, but in pictures of people it's the expression that counts, IMHO.In this regard, shooting in low light, the FZ1000 and FZ200 are about equivalent.==  Crisp controls that are not mushy or muddy.== The camera is the result of a collaboration between Leica and Panasonic, and has nearly identical hardware to a Leica V-Lux Type 114 that costs a lot more, though the software is different.== High capacity  zoom lens immensely improve the ability to take good pictures, because one can often get closeups of subjects that would be hard or impossible to get close to, and because one has much more flexibility in determining what to include and what to exclude from the picture. On the FZ1000 the 400mm optical zoom magnifies images to  eight times a normal 50mm lens and with digital zoom to 1600mm you can get 32 times normal magnification. Picture quality is excellent up to 400, and in my opinion remains quite good at 800mm when there's plenty of light.== Fast focusing and fast determination of exposure settings and almost zero shutter lag, which allows the capturing of fleeting events.==  In my opinion feels solid and well built.== Allows me to display live images on a Panasonic Viera TV set via HDMI cable.  I don't know whether it will do this on other TVs.  This is really helpful for portraits where you want the subject to be able to see their image on a TV screen so that they can adjust their expression.CONS== This camera is a bit of a power hog.  If you want to shoot a lot of footage Take several spare batteries with you . I think it gets worse when image stabilization is switched on.== In SCN mode there are far too many presets that differ only by tiny amounts.  And one very valuable preset that was in the FZ200 has been deleted, namely the "Through glass" preset, that improved images taken through glass windows.CONCLUSIONSThis camera is very flexible and takes excellent pictures in automatic mode in a huge variety of situations.  Some folks sneer about "point and shoot" automation,  but I really like a well designed automatic mode because it allows me to concentrate on the content of the picture rather than worrying about settings, and lets me grab shots that I would otherwise miss.  I think that about 9 times out of 10, automatic mode on this camera does a better job than I would do if I spent time fiddling in manual mode.P.S. I attach a  hand held photo of the moon taken with maximum extended zoom of 3200 mm, leaning against a car for the hand held shot.  This shot demonstrates the incredibly good image stabilization offered by the FZ1000. This image has had no postprocessing and is not cropped.  To achieve maximum zoom, I set Program mode, electronic zoom enabled, picture size of 5MB (and not the 20MB option).

PROSI agree with the highly positive reviews stating that this pitcher is stylish and beautiful, with a large maximum capacity of two liters, and a very small footprint.  It has a very good seal, but watch out, it will be damaged if you over-tighten the cap, and it will then leak.CONSMy only problem with this product is that the interior of the jar does not dry quickly after washing, and is subject to clouding.  A lot of effort has to be expended to clean it so there is no streaking.  Glass pitchers are easier to clean.SUGGESTION TO MANUFACTURERI would prefer a square bottle topped off with a screw top, to maximize the amount of storage.

These "Lazy Glasses" give a very wide angle view when I lie flat on my bed, with my head resting comfortably either on the mattress or on a pillow.  This allows me to see the television set and many other objects.  This is both  a strength and a weakness.  The strength is that you can see a whole lot of things while lying flat, because of the wide angle view.  The weakness is that all objects are smaller than they would be if viewed without the glasses.They are well made.  The packaging provides a nicely sized storage box.  And I find  I can use these "lazy glasses" while wearing my regular eyeglasses.  They are well-suited to watching large screen TV sets, but not great for small ones like the 22 inch set in my bedroom.

This is a very well designed calendar.  I'm retired and no longer keep a daily diary. This calendar has 8 lines per day, and is enough to record appointments and events for the three people in my home. I especially like the generous 11 line space at the bottom of the calendar to record phone numbers and other bits of info, which is 12 inches wide.Especially useful is the space for notes on the December page, where I can record appointments for next year, during any time in the current year. This is handy if, for example, I see a doctor in June 2014 and need to record an appointment in 2015, in a place where it will not get lost.In my kitchen I have a large hook on the wall that allows me to hang calendars for three previous years, which is useful if I need to look back over the past several years.

CONS== One huge con, a dealbreaker for me, is that the controls of this radio are complex and require the user to read a manual.  Even then, I have to re-read the manual to remember what to do.  Also the controls are inconveniently placed.== On the top of the product there are 13 separate buttons. Ten of these are teeny tiny. This is too many tiny buttons.  Then there is a long narrow button whose label is the same color as the button, except it is embossed, and visible only when viewed from a certain angle.==The radio tuning buttons are placed on the back of the product and are hard to reach while tuning: the user has to be touching tuning controls on the back of the clock/radio while observing a tuning indicator on the front of the radio.==  Sony decided to achieve a small footprint by making the unit much taller than prior Sony clock radios that I have used, about twice as high.  However, the height makes the 13 controls located on the top deck hard to reach relative to the top of the night stand where the product is kept.  This is not ergonomic.PROS== One huge pro, compared with my prior Sony clock radio, is that reception is markedly better in the presence of CFL lighting and LED lighting.== There is digital radio tuning on this high end version (not the lower ones).  I really like this.== It has lots of bells and whistles including 5 types of nature sounds to wake up by, separate alarm times for self and for significant other, and  the ability to project the current time on a darkened ceiling.SUMMARYIf you want a simple clock radio that is a no-brainer to operate, do not buy this item.  If you don't mind reading a manual and learning to program the radio, and keeping the manual handy, this offers a lot of neat features.NOTE TO MANUFACTURERThis product has much worse controls than my prior Sony clock radio, model ICF-C218 "Dream Machine", where the alarm is set using two elegantly simple controls located close to each other on the top of the unit, so that changing the alarm time can be done very quickly. First you turn a dial to point to alarm setting mode. Second, you push a prominently located lever either to the left or right to make the alarm time go forward or backward, in an accelerating manner where the longer you hold the lever, the faster the time spins by.  On my old clock radio, the radio is tuned using a convenient wheel on the right side of the unit, together with a volume setting wheel located just beside it, a lot easier to find and manipulate .

As a mostly retired person close to the big seven zero, I know it's very important to keep moving to preserve health , and for me the purpose of an activity tracker is to help remind me to keep on trucking, so that I don't slack off.The Fitbit has been making me keep track of how much I move, and is providing a useful benchmark to make me conscious of how much exercise I'm getting.I have tried both Fitbit Flex and FItbit Zip.  I find myself preferring the Flex because it is worn on the wrist where it can remain at almost all times except during baths and when being charged.I am now trying out the Garmin Vivofit, another wrist activity tracker and will report back later.

My spouse has strong opinions about pillows. During the last decade her job has taken her on the road maybe 10-30 days a year, to many destinations, and as a road warrior she encounters numerous hotels and numerous pillows, and has become somewhat of an expert. She is highly sensitive to pillow quality, and finds that a good pillow helps her sleep better.Her verdict is that these are grade A pillows.  She says:They are not too soft and not too firm. They deform just enough to conform with her head. They compress much less than a lot of pillows. They give sufficient support. They quickly rebound to their original shape.They are well made with good stitching and high quality fabric. There are a lot of cheaper pillows available, but she definitely prefers these. The pillows she has bought include Ralph Lauren, and she thinks these are better.I should add that this product was offered to me for free by the vendor, with the agreement that I provide an honest and unbiased review. My wife is much better qualified to review pillows than I am, so I decided to rely on her opinions.

Fell in love with this product editing Thanksgiving dinner photos, for a dinner with 14 people.  I found two features really absolute winners.
