If you have children in school, day care, or any group setting, at any age, there is a high probablity of their acquiring head lice.  So it behooves you to have the knowledge to know what to look for, and the tools to deal with adult head lice, and their larvae, and eggs (nits).  RobiComb is one good tool that I have found useful -- and it works, for children and adults.  Also, it is easy to use on long or short hair -  as long as the hair is dry and untangled.  However it is not easy to use on that is tangled, or tangles easily, such as in some dry, fine hair.About the only way to prevent head lice infestation is to have very short hair -- so short the scalp is exposed to light (head lice abhor light.)  Any longer, and head lice will target it -- the longer the hair, the better they like it.I was introduced to lice treatment in the Philippines, where we employed house girls from the small villages.  Invariably one or two would come in with head lice.  And when one household member is discovered with lice, EVERYBODY (including adults) needs to be treated.  But head lice is just as prevalent in the US as it is in the Philippines.  So don't think that just because you live in a first-world country you are somehow immune.  Head lice is endemic world-wide.KNOWLEDGE:One of the best sources of information on treating headlice is the paperback publication "Head Lice to Dead Lice," by Sawyer and MacPhee.  This paperback is avaiable on Amazon(dot)com.  You can find other sources and materials by Googling the internet.Sawyer and MacPhee recommend olive oil treatment, which suffocates the lice.  It requires repeated application every four days for six or seven applications.  Its advantages are that it is non-toxic, good for healthy shiny hair, and it works - providing it is done properly (hair and scalp saturated) and repeated every four days for six sessions.  However, re-infestations are so probable that perhaps you could just as well opt for a continuous reapplication every four days, or maybe every Friday or Saturday religiously.TOOLS:Sawyer and MacPhee don't recommend the RobiComb, but they didn't actually try it, so their opinion on it don't count.  I have actually used it, and I can report, like others here, that it does work.  Whenever my school kids come home and report a bug in their hair, I begin treatment immediatly.The drawback to the RobiComb is that it is expensive.  If you are going to use the RobiComb, then each member of the family should have their own, and not share it.  That's also true of nit combs, hair combs, and hair brushes, pillows, caps, hats, hair bands, etc..  They should also use it everyday.  Not only that, but you should have a method of disinfecting the combs, bruches and tools you use on the hair, such as Barbicide or alcohol (but don't immerse the RobiComb in it.)The advantage of the RobiComb is that it can be carried and used anytime and anywhere without anybody really noticing -- such as waiting at a traffic stop, or just sitting around -- no mess, no smell, no pesticides to poison you, and no oily hair up in a shower cap for eight hours.The RoboComb emits a high-pitched tone when it is turned on.  You place the tips of the comb in touch with your scalp as you push it through your hair (Most adult lice and larvae will either be on your scalp, or close to it.  Eggs will be a just off the scalp firmly fastened to a hair shaft.)  The tone will be interrupted whenever the comb encounters alien life forms on your head.  That's the time to remove the RobiComb from your head and see what youv'e caught.  I always smash them with my fingernail to make sure they are dead.Some other things you will want to have is a good blow dryer for your hair with a high heat setting(s).  Head lice do not tolerate heat well, so after a shampoo, a good blow-dry session on high heat will kill a lot of them.  (be careful not to burn your scalp, or the children's scalp)  A shampoo and blow-dry sessio is also in order if you use the olive oil treatment.In addition, everything the hair has, or may have, touched (such as pillow cases, sheets, blakets, caps, hats, scarves, clothing, etc.) should be tossed into a dryer set to high heat (cotton) for twenty to thirty minutes.I don't use any chemical preparations for head lice, as they all can be toxic, especially for children, and especially because reinfestation is so probable, and head lice quickly becone resistant to them.All in all, the RoboComb is a fine product, that does work, and I would not hesitate to recommend it to my friends.

This government publication is available on-line for free (just Google the title)My original review was base on the relatively few "peek preview" pages available on Amazon.com.  Now that I have acquired a complete copy, and had a chance for a more comprehensive review,  I have substantially revised my comments.This historical tome covers US Army Corps of Engineer projects and organizations involved in the Middle East and Africa - from Morocco to Pakistan, and Europe to Somalia, and everything in between., from 1941 to 1991 - a period of half a century.  That was a fascinating era, with many major political shifts, both at home and abroad, and a fascinating read from both a historical and an engineering perspective.I  worked in this arena, under its various names and re-organizations, from the mid 1970's until the mid 1990's, some twenty-plus years, all told.  so I knew quite well many of the people mentioned in the later phase (Part III.)  Whatever names the effort and organizations went by, it was (and I presume still is) one of the most dynamic and capable organizations within the US Army Corps of Engineers.  I am proud to have been associated with it.The tome is an accurate, though necessarily condensed, rendering of the history of military construction in the Middle East and Africa. It is mostly a technical rendering of the projects and major personalities involved throughout the historical period covered.  But there are also revelations of some of the political infighting, and international considerations that effect such projectsThis tome would make a very good technical background for a movie.  What is missing are the interactions of the personalities involved -- affairs, betrayals, poor command decisions, personal conflicts between influential individuals, conflicts between the design engineers and the construction management staff, and so forth.  For example, few people recognize, even inside the Corps of Engineers, that the major reason the organization did not continue to get more projects from the Saudis, is that the command structure (Gen. Wells, and General Albro, in particular) made unilateral decisions that infuriated the Saudis.  And if that weren't enough, the organization retained at least a million dollars of Saudi money that they had no intention of ever returning (and used for years as a carry fund to temporarily fund new project prospects.)  I would bet that that million dollars is still there in the organization's pocket.The bottom line is that this is a great book for historians, history buffs, and those interested in that theater --  which is an accurate account of what in my professional career was a most exciting time.

Gorilla calls them wheel locks.  Most others call them locking lug nuts.  I bought two sets of these for my new pickup truck with 18" aluminum alloy wheels.  In my opinion, they are the best of the locking lug nuts.They don't really lock like a padlock or door lock -- you just have to use the proper key shape to engage the nut.  Gorilla makes thousands of shape variations, and you must have a registration number (comes with the package) to buy a replacement key.  This keeps the keys out of the hands of most thieves.I especially like the design of the rotating outside casing that prevent anything other than a proper key from engaging the special-shaped lug nut -- you can't get a wrench, locking pliers, or normal socket on it.  The space between the outer rotating casing and the lug nut is also extra narrow, so ordinary sockets and tools can't be used as a wedge.I install two per wheel, opposite each other to maintain wheel balance -- each with a different key to make it even harder for a thief (who might happen to have one matching key, but unlikely to have two that match.)I also purchased these on Amazon at a very good price.If you are not sure which catalog number to buy for your particular vehicle, visit the Gorilla-auto (dot) com web site's application page.  Except for replacement keys, they do not sell direct to the public, but all the info you might need for your application (and alternative designs)is there.All-in-all, a great product.  I would not hesitate to recommend them to my friends.

This is a massive, heavy duty hitch step - built to withstand impact from a ready-mix concrete truck.  You aren't ever going to break it.  It is fairly heavy -- maybe even heavier than hitch receiver it is attached to.  It is designed to be used as an attachment point to retrieve off-roader's from the predicaments they deliberately get themselves into (but can't 4-wheel out of.)I'm not that an aggressive driver, and for me it is a very convenient step I use a couple of times a day -- and as a heavy duty "bumper" to give tailgaters pause to reflect being so close to it.I also very much like the shape - like an arrowhead, that would inflict considerable damage to vehicles driven by idiot drivers foolish enough to tailgate me, or rear-end me at a stop-sign or stop-light.  I put some red reflective tape on the step so drivers behind me can see it better.All-in-all, a superior product - not for everyone, but unsurpassed ruggedness for those who need or want it.  I would not hesitate to recommend it to my friends.

I already have a black one of these for my black Mazda Tribute.  I  bought the red one this time for my shiny new red truck. These are very strong and very secure locking pins.  And they fit well into the receiver without needing a shim or rattling around. I also like the 3-D key, which is much harder to defeat than a flat key.All-in-all, a superior product at a good price.  I would not hesitate to recommend it to my friends.

This is a unique cargo net that not only is very functional and durable, but it is - bar none - the coolest looking cargo net I have ever seen.  I leave it on all the time, and have many compliments on the net, and inquiries as to where I got it.  I even got a big a big 4' spider to ride on it.The net is manufactured in two sizes for pickup trucks (large and small), and four colors (black, red, blue, and yellow.) There are also smaller versions for car-top racks, and a version for motorcycles. The only source I have seen that carries all variants of this product is Auto Anything (also best price.)For my pickup (Nissan Frontier, Crew Cab, long bed) I use the small size.  I also chose the red color to compliment the red color of my truck.To deter theft, I fasten the rear of the net with elongated security rings to the tailgate attachment points (supplied with the net.)  When I'm not actually securing a load, I hook the front of the net over the rear cross slat of my roof rack, which then forms a compound space curve over the bed.  I don't use the included hooks on the sides of the net because I already have attachment cleats permanently mounted.All in all, I am delighted with this product, and I would recommend it to my friends.UPDATE: Feb 2014I left this cargo net on continually for 18 months straight, constantly exposed to sun, rain, heat, and cold.  It held up pretty good all that time, but it eventually deteriorated enough that I finally took it down, and will be replacing it (with another Spidey Gear Cargo Net.)

This is supposedly the TracFone successor to the very popular LG 800G TracFone.  So if you are familiar with the LG 800G, then perhaps the best way to think of this phone is as the WiFi/3G/plus version of the LG 800G.  It is already available in some WalMart stores, and now on Amazon.  Check out the Turk Forum for actual pictures of the bubble pack.It is NOT a smart phone, and doesn't run Android.  But if it is anything like the LG 800G (which is one damn fine feature phone), it will be a runaway hit with the otherwise minimal phone use crowd that TracFone attracts.What it has (that the venerable LG 800G it replaces does not) is WiFi and 2G/3G data. And it has all the well-executed built-in widgets (Music Player, Audio, Picture Viewer, Video Recorder, Voice Recorder, Calendar, Notepad, Tasks, Stopwatch, Calculator, Tip Calculator,  Unit Converter) that came with the LG 800G, incuding a 2 MP camera.  In addition, the LG 840G has an external microSDHC card capacity up to 32GB, versus 4 GB for the LG 800G.Sorry - no GPS.  But you might be able to hook it to an external GPS if (and that is a big IF) you can find a Java app to process the GPS output.  I don't offhand know of such a Java app.  But then again, I was a long time in realizing their was a java app for facebook.The touchscreen on the LG 840G is larger (3.0") than the LG 800G (2.8" -- 320x240 pixels).  No info yet on the LG 840G screen resolution.There is a 180 page user guide (90 pages in English, 90 pages in Spanish), which is quite an improvement on the next-to-nothing user manual for the LG 800G.The LG 840G comes with triple minutes for life.It is too early to tell if all the LG 800G fanatics will migrate to the LG 840G.  But based on the high popularity of the LG 800G, I betting the LG 840G will be a hot seller.  If you are a minimal cell phone user, better get your TracFone version before they are gone.  If you are a moderate to heavy cell phone user, you might do better with the Net10 or Straight Talk versions.EDIT (26 Dec 2013):The Lg 840G continues to be THE most popular feature phone.  It is the most popular cellphone purchased on Home Shopping network (HSM.com), and the most viewed and commented on Turk Forum. Its staying power comes from its relatively low price, triple minutes for life, sensitive touchscreen, WiFi, Bluethooth, and 2/3G data capability, as well as the many well-executed built in features included.

This review is for the Curt receiver 13241 application to my 2012 Nissan Frontier Crew-Cab Long-bed SL.I cut the box the receiver came in to lay flat so I could use it as a mat to lay on.This is my second Curt hitch receiver.  The first was for a Mazda Tribute.  As expected, this receiver is massive, accurately made, and finished well with a thick coat of black powder coat.This is a heavy item (for me) weighing in at 45 pounds.  Still, it was easy to put on by myself, and I am 70+ years old.  The bolt holes were accurately drilled, and the Nissan came with weld nuts already in place.  The six bolts came with thick conical washers, which are designed to exert pressure on the bolts as they are tightened.  All it took was lining up one bolt hole and start a bolt, then do one bolt on the other side.  The rest is easy.  Probably the hardest part, besides getting the first bolt on, was torquing the bolts to 65 foot-pounds.  There was one bolt partially obstructed by the exhaust pipe, that required a knuckle joint on the socket wrench.That's all there was to installation. the only tools you will need are a 3/4" socket and driver (or 19mm), a 6" extension bar for the socket, a knuckle joint, and a torque wrench set to 65 foot-pounds.  You could just use a 3/4" (19mm) box wrench.On the Nissan Frontier, the receiver was jut a little inside the rear-most edge of the rear bumper, with maybe less than 1/2" clearance below it.  I set a 2" hitch into the receiver with no problem.  However, a Texas "tailgate" hitch cover, which extends 3" beyond the hith cove shaft, would not fit because the rear edge of the bumper interfered (the receiver was recessed a little too much under the bumper.)All-in-all, the Curt hitch receiver more than met my expectations, and I would recommend it to my friends.

I have had the VHS version since it first came out.  But I no longer have a functioning VHS player.  I would have preferred a BluRay version with 5.1 sound, but it looks like DVD with stereo is it for this now classic Sci-Fi spin off from Babylon 5.

These air filters are specified as the OEM air filter recommended for my Craftsman variable speed self-propelled lawn mower, which has a 190cc Briggs & Stratton engine.I had not changed the air filter for a couple of years, blowing it "clean" with compressed air instead.  But you can never really blow the filter completely clean, and it eventually plugs up enough to affect engine performance.  So I was in desperate need of replacement air filters when I ran across these.  the price for a single filter is kind of pricey anywhere you look, but the five pack was very well priced, so I jumped on it.The bottom line is that these filters fit perfectly, and result in the engine starting with one pull again.  I am very satisfied with this product and would definitely recommend it to my friends.

I was introduced to this type of exfoliating wash rag so many years ago in the most pleasant way - by my then Korean girl friend.  Just to see it hanging on the shower now brings back very pleasant memories of oriental baths and showers for two - it almost brings tears to my eyes.  There is nothing like a back scrubber that is alive and beautiful.But, I digress.  Back to the cloth - these exfoliating wash rags are very common in Asia, but often very hard to find locally in the US.  I am glad to see so many offered by Amazon.com.  This one is huge, area wise, and should last a very long time.  While it says "super hard weave," when it is wet, I find it just right for me - not to soft, and not to hard.  It is long enough so that you can also easily use it by yourself on your back, and even on the bottom of your feet.  They are perfect for those with flaky, dry skin -- they remove dead skin without harming the live skin underneath - as long as you aren't too aggressive with it.  And it is gentle enough to use on your face - but again, don't be too aggressive with it.Parents who use these on their children should not use pressure, because used too aggressively can damage a child's skin.  It would better to allow the child to wash themselves so they could adjust the pressure to suit themselves.All in all, a great product, at a good price.  The only thing better would be a beautiful Asian back scrubber to apply it.  I would highly recommend this too my friends.

What attracted me to this shower caddy was its price - a very good value for the functionality offered.It is made of steel wire covered with a rubberized coating.  As long as the coating remains in intact, the steel is protected.  It is sturdy enough for a couple of shampoo bottles, soap bars, and wash rags or back scrubbers.  You wouldn't want to hang too much off it though, like a full-sized wet towel.  How long it endures just depends on how rough you are with it.  It should last for years under normal use.This is a small caddy, about 18" tall, 10" wide, and protrudes about 4" from the wall when in place.  It has a shallow basket for bottles, over a double-bent rack for soap and other small items, and two hooks on the bottom.  It is near the perfect size for what I wanted - a little extra shelf space, and a couple of hooks, without being obtrusive.  It complements the soap dish and bottle holder already built-in to my shower wall.The rubbery plastic pipe hanger lock (included) is a must if your shower pipe neck is significantly slanted downward like mine is.  The lock works very well.  You might not need it if your shower pipe comes straight out of the wall.  If a cover exists on the water pipe where it protrudes from the wall (which is s typical plumbing installation), then the top of the rack may protrude that much further off the wall if you use the rubber lock.  That was the case for me, but the small outward incline it produced was so slight as to be negligible. Most people will not want to remove that wall cover, because it hides the hole for the water pipe, which isn't always as neat as it could be.The rubbery plastic suction cups (two included) are removable and relocatable, so you can adjust their location to avoid seams and grout lines. They work best located at the bottom of the rack, and are mainly intended to keep the caddy from swinging sideways. The best time to apply the suction cups is when the shower wall is wet (they will stick better.)  If you have trouble sticking them, use  little soap on them.I put both suction cups on one side of the rack because the built in soap dish on my shower wall prevents me from placing a suction cups on the other side.  That is not a fault of the caddy, however, and the suction cups do the job they were designed to do - keep the caddy from swinging sideways.All in all, the caddy works well for me, satisfies a need, for a reasonable price.  I would certainly recommend it to my friends.

These plugs are two or three cuts above an ordinary lawn mower spark plug.  They are specified for my Craftsman, high-wheel, read-drive, variable speed lawn mower.  I bought two.  I finally did a long-delayed engine tune up -- changed oil (Mobil-1), new spark plug, new air filter, and adjusted the variable speed drive. Now I have to run to stay up with the mower at full speed.I am impressed with the performance and would recommend this product to my friends.

This is the perfect size and shape oil drain pan for my motorcycle, which holds just under 4-quarts.  It is wide enough to catch the drip at both the drain plug and the oil filter.  I wouldn't advise any smaller capacity.  The corners are recessed making it very easy to neatly pour the oil out into a bottle for disposal.I very much like this product, and i would recommend it to my friends.

I use Mobil 1 oil, so I like to use Mobil 1 oil filters also.  They are pricey, but I like the peace of mind that comes with it's one year warranty.  This one is for a car engine, but I use it on my motorcycle -- because it is more readily available, and because it is about half the price of the motorcycle-specific one.I like this product,have confidence in it, and I would recommend it to  friend.

My bike is a 1987 Honda Shadow VT700C with 76,000+ miles on it.  I have been using Mobil-1 oil in it since I bought it new 25 years ago.  When it was new, I used 5W30, at about 50,000 miles I switched to 10W40, and last oil change I went to Mobil-1 high mileage.  Still the engine clatter seemed to be getting worse.  So I was looking for some Mobil-1 20W50 oil, which is also recommended in the owner's manual for hot climates.When I saw this V-Twin Mobil-1 20W50, I whistled at the price - fifteen bucks for a single quart -- two or three times the cost of regular Mobil-1 oil. Still, maybe that was what I needed for my aging engine.  So I bought case of 6 for sixty bucks - which works out to ten bucks a quart.  Later I saw WalMart also carries this, and it comes in two grades - regular for about eight bucks, and advanced for about ten bucks.  What Amazon.com is selling is the Advanced grade, and the price is comparable to WalMart, and no taxes, plus free shipping.I am very impressed with this engine oil.  Engine clatter has all but disappeared.  The bike sounds and runs much better.  It is pricey oil, but it is worth it.I would heartily recommend this oil for any v-twin, and especially for all aging older engines, V-twin or otherwise.

I have had Magic Jack for a number of years now.  I've used it with a dial-up modem and with broadband.  MagicJack will work with a dial-up modem in the US pretty well, but Fax on a dial-up modem will generally result in dropped lines.  MagicJack should really be used with a DSL line or better.  Once I switched to broadband, I couldn't tell the difference in call quality, and the Fax worked fine.  In fact, if I didn't already know I was talking through MagicJack, I wouldn't be able to tell -- its is very good voice quality, even from MagicJacks located overseas, providing they are connected to the internet on a DSL line or broadband.MagicJack used overseas and plugged into a computer on a dial-up modem won't work very well.  The slowness of a dial-up modem, and delays in data packet routing will result in dropped lines.  If you are going to use a MagicJack overseas, make sure the computer you plug it into is connected to the internet by broadband or a DSL line.When MagicJack Plus first came out, you couldn't transfer your existing MagicJack time to it.  So I didn't get one.  But just recently, MagicJack reversed that policy, and now you can transfer your remaining MagicJack time to MagicJack Plus.  I've now switched over to MagicJack Plus.MagicJack Plus doesn't need a computer -- it plugs directly into an Ethernet or wireless hub.  But the Plus can also plug into a computer using a short USB cable (supplied).  The plain MagicJack only plugs into a USB port on your computer.If you like having a splash screen dialer with all your contacts and call history on your computer and at your fingertips, you can use either the plain or the Plus plugged into a computer.  If you plug the Plus into a Ethernet or wireless hub, you won't have that on-screen splash screen dialer with contacts and call log -- unless the phone you are hooking the Plus up to independently provides that.I find the MagicJack Plus gets up and running faster -- near instantaneously.  On my computer, the plain magic jack takes a few minutes to boot itself, and I have to reboot my computer often.  When the computer is down, so is the plain MagicJack.  The Plus can always be removed from the computer and plugged into the hub without skipping a beat.MagicJack is going to discontinue offering the MagicJack plain in another few months will only offer the Plus.  MagicJack periodically has sales and significant discounts, especially for existing plain MagicJack customers.  MagicJack offers connect time by the year, and has a five year plan that includes a good warranty and relacement feature in addition to cheaper time overall.  I use the five year plan myself, because it results in the cheapest overall cost.All-in-all, I very much like the MagicJack Plus, and I would heartily recommend it to my friends.
A rugged, non-lethal solution for crowd control, human or otherwise.  I would hate to get smacked with this thing. The 54-inch length provides a very significant reach advantage for the user.

This is a Dandy's, or Fancy Dan's, cane - the type used by Fred Astaire or Gene Kelly in the movies.  It is a very pretty cane, yet masculine, and suitable for a black-tie affair. This type of cane is intended more as a dress accessory -- like a musician's baton, a magician's wand, or an officer's swagger stick, rather than a workhorse.Underneath it's pretty exterior, though, is a rugged carbon-fiber construction, which makes it very strong and durable -- suitable as a whacking stick, if necessary, which is why a cane was carried in the bygone era when men carried canes as a matter of course.The dimpled, shiny, solid  aluminum head can be unscrewed, so you can change the head to suit yourself, assuming there are other heads available. In my opinion, the shiny head that it comes with is a perfect match.There is a rather small rubber tip on the end, which is perfect for those who will probably be carrying the cane much more than actually leaning on it.It is very light in weight, yet very strong due to the carbon fiber construction.  That is what attracted my attention.  I bought this cane primarily for my 9-year old daughter as a walking stick.It is quite long as a cane, but a perfect length as a walking stick for a 9-year old.  Even if I was the one using it, I wouldn't cut it shorter.My daughter loves it, and for a change, won't be handing it over to me on our walkes because it got too heavy for her half way through the hike.All in all, it is a very good buy, well made, well-priced, and very nice looking.  I am very happy with it, and I would definitely recommend it to my friends.

Pretty good sword cane, as sword canes go -- made in India, according to markings.  It is a heavy cane, weighng more than my four-foot rosewood hiking stick.The blade is carbon steel, and has considerable spring to it, indicating the blade has been well tempered.  I didn't want to test the flex limit of the blade, but it appears to be sufficient to be a useful weapon.  The handle is solidly mounted on the blade.  I did not detect any play or looseness.The blade is 29" long, which is really long for a cane sword. That might not seem like a lot, until you see it in person. Add another 5" for the handle. That gives the bearer a very long reach against a mad dog, bear, coyote, wolf, or a human attacker.The blade surface appears to have been highly polished, and I detected no hint of rusting. The point of the blade is elongated and well-formed for easy penetration. The edges of the blade are sufficiently beveled to take an edge, but as it comes it is not sharp enough to cut you by just running your fingers or hand down the edges.  A slashing blow from the blade as is would leave a nasty bruise but probably not cut through the skin or clothing.  The long, thin blade design is mainly for stabbing and trusting, not slashing. For slashing, you would want a much wider blade (but then it wouldn't fit into a cane.)You could sharpen the edges, but if you do, I'd only put a concave edge on it, which requires specialized technique, but preserves the strength of the blade and puts a more durable edge.  If you do sharpen the edges, you might want to install across guard to keep your fingers from slipping onto the blade while thrusting.  The sharpening process might allow rust to form on the edge, but you could oil the blade to prevent rust from forming. I can't tell by just looking if the edges have been hardened to hold a really sharp edge.The "scabbard" or body of the cane is heavy duty, weighing as much or more than the sword. It has a small rubber tip on the end, which I particularly like, because it doesn't detract from the gracefully simple design. By itself, the scabbard makes a formidable whacking stick. So you have two weapons in one -- In your right hand a sword, and in your left hand a whacking stick (or vice versa).In summary, this is a nice-looking well-made, heavy cane with a very long (for a sword cane)decent sword for emergency use against an attacker with no more than a knife, or a shorter sword cane.  But it isn't something you would take to a competition sword fight.There is one con -- the button for unlocking the sword from the scabbard-cane is small and very stiff.  Pressing on it requires so much force that it hurts my thumb to do it.  On the one hand, that's good as an in-home safety measure to prevent kids from releasing the sword (my 9 and 12 year old's can't open it), but on the other hand, I have to use a penny or a folded business card over the button to release the sword, which makes it difficult to access the sword when I might need it most in a hurry.  I eventually pressed on the top of a button snap, which was enough so it doesn't hurt my thumb to press it hard.All-in-all, a great sword cane.  I am satisfied with it, and I would recommend it to my friends.

This light comes very handy. It is easy to turn on and it shuts off in five minutes if you don't turn it off. It has a soothing ambient light. My daughter loves anything with Sofia on it. So this light fits her daily life seamlessly. She cannot be happier with this.

These two kinds of olive oil are virgin cold pressed. One  (Cornicabra) has peppery taste and the other one (Arbequina) is more smooth and mild. They provide good contrast and fit different purposes. I found that I like both of them. I use Arbequina for salad and Cornicabra for meat dishes. They all work out well.

We recently updated our computers to 64 bit, our Claris intraoral camera won't work with it at all. I called Sota Imaging. They said that they don't have a 64 bit driver for it. A new camera will cost me $2,500. I am in computer field. I know these cameras are way over-priced to start with. I then researched about which these China-made cameras work with XDR, the imaging system we use. Luckily this camera works perfectly by simply plugging it in. Even the capture button works! The image quality is much better than our 7 year old camera. I cannot be happier. I can get an even cheaper camera from eBay. But this is good enough. There is no point to spend time to try to save tens of bucks after I have saved thousands.

This booster seat is big and wide. I like the latch connectors. It keeps the booster seat in its place. The wings add protection to side impact. The height adjustment is convenient and functional. My complaints are mainly centered around this big and wide part. My daughter is 44 lbs, which is above the lower limit of 40 lbs. But it seems that she needs another booster seat inside this booster seat. The base is too wide for her. Also the big, flat, wide base doesn't quite fit into our bucket leather seat. This booster seat works best with flat back seat. I believe it works even better with captain seats in mini vans. Because it is so wide, be prepared you can only seat either two people or two car seats in the back. If you are O.K. with that, this is a great car seat.

First of all, this is a cradle sheet, not a crib sheet. Please check the size (18 x 36) before you buy it. It is very soft and in its natural beige linen color. I take its words that there is no dyes or bleach or pesticides. For sensitive skin of newborns, it is one less things to cause rashes or eczema.

I purchased several lightening Apple cables for my iPhones and iPads.The major problem is the wires near the connectors will exposed if I curl the cables for storage.I just could not find cables matching the quality of the original ones. I pay a premium price for this cable. I would say you get what you pay for. The cable is very sturdy. The build quality is good. I don't see any problems in curling it up into a small bundle for storage. The connection and contact are good just like my original Apple cables. Also it comes with colors matching your phones. If you are looking for a high quality cable, you may consider this.

This is a well designed feeder for large breed dogs due to the size of the cups. It has three heights as advertised. I found this is quite economic to use from puppies to adult dogs. If you have small or medium size dogs, then you will find the cups are way too big even you can lower the height of the feeder. Overall, this is quite useful. I only wish the quality and design was better. It is very practical to use, but not much other than that.

This is a good quality window mount. The suction cup works very well. There is a dial you can turn to lock in to suck the cup in. I found it is very sturdy. It works very well as a window mount. The dashboard mount doesn't work for me. The glue of the mounting plate is not sticky enough. After I attached the mount and my cell phone, it just fell off. So don't count on the dashboard mount.

You do a Google search for organic Goji berries, you will know that the price of this product is quite competitive. The berries are a little bit moist and sweet. They taste fresh. Goji berries are a very commonly used ingredient for Chinese herbal medicine. I don't know since when it becomes a choice for healthy food. You can buy dried Goci berries for one third of the price at Asian Grocery Stores. But they are usually dry and with preservatives like sulfur dioxide. If what is on package is true, this one is free of preservatives and is organic. But they are all from China. You pay a premium price for the safety and freshness of them.

This is a very good quality keyboard judging by how much you paid. If you are using this with a Windows PC, you will find that  number lock (NumLk) is always on which is indicated by the LED light above "1" on the upper right hand corner. You need to hit fn and NumLk keys to turn it off. That is because Most PC BIOS has number lock on by default. You need to set it to off. When PC boots up, watch for which key to hit to get into BIOS. Go through the menu to turn it off. You will not have number lock after that.

I have been using scrub from St Ives St Ives Scrub, Even & Bright Pink Lemon & Mandarin Orange 6 Ounce. It is inexpensive and effective. But I don't use it daily since it is a bit harsh to use it everyday. This Neutrogena scrub is just like all their other products. It is very mild and refreshing. I would say it is a borderline scrub. Don't expect it to remove the dead skin in a couple of washes. It is more of stimulating your skin. The scent is very light and pleasant. My only complaint is that it is too watery. It spills out easily. They probably should package it in a pump not a tube.

I have several Bluetooth speakers. I am lucky enough to compare the sound quality. This one is one of best among them comparable with FUGOO Style - Portable Bluetooth Surround Sound Speaker Longest Battery Life with Built-in Speakerphone(Silver). But this one is cheaper. The fist impression is that it is elegantly designed. The only thing I don't like about the exterior is the sharp edges. It edges other things in my backpack.This speaker has all special features a latest Bluetooth speaker has: NFC pairing, charging other devices, e.g. your cell phone, and auto power off (very important). You can also use it as Bluetooth receiver like Belkin Song Stream Bluetooth Music Receiver for your stereo.Overall, this is an inexpensive high quality, feature packed speaker. I highly recommend it.

I have been using Dial Kids Body Wash, Peachy Clean, 12 Ounce bought at Target. for my 3 year old Recently I just tried this baby wash from Cetaphil. I think it better than the one from Dial. It has a richer and smoother lather. After rinse, my daughter's skin feels clean and moisturized. I also like the scent. It is light and fresh. I also have to mention that it is much cheaper than Dial. It is 61 cents per oz v.s. 91 cents per oz. I think I am going to switch over for good.

This is like a coffee machine for babies. You can use the default settings and only turn the dial for bottle size. The choice between warm and room temperature is a nice feature. The water is only heated when you make the bottle. Some other brands will keep the water warm, so it saves time. But I prefer heating the water when needed. I am afraid that warm water will  cause bacteria growing. My only concern is that I cannot stick a brush to clean every corner of the water tank. Other than that, i am happy with it.

We have a couple of hooded towels for my daughter. The "hood" part is more for fun than function. This one is no exception. She likes it and plays with it a lot. The quality is O.K. I don't see any difference from other towels. I wish it was thicker. Price is good. Overall, this is a good buy.

I don't use cologne often. The scent is not light and refreshing. I don't feel that I am wearing something overpowering. My wife likes it. The package is elegantly packaged. the price is right. Overall, this is a very good gift set for men.

This is a very unique toy. You attach it to the car window. Your baby will have a good time while you are driving. It can be activated by touching the tummy or shaking the wrist rattle, which you attach to your baby. The idea is very cleaver and creative. But the volume cannot be adjusted. It is a little bit annoying to hear those silly songs over and over again. I also wish the "lion" can be a little bit cuter. Replace it with a monkey, for example. You also have to keep in mind that the suction cups won't work if you have blinds.Oh. One more thing. The wrist rattle is nothing magic. The toy is sound activated. The wrist rattle generates loud enough sound to activate the toy. You speak to it louder, it will be activated, too.

My daughter has a hand-me-down dress-up doll from Melissa & Doug, Melissa & Doug Hailey & Hannah Magnetic Dress-Up Dolls. It is similar to the one in the link though not exactly the same. She likes it a lot. I thought this one will add be fun to her, too. As a parent, I am disappointed in the design and the quality. The clothing pieces don't fit as well as the ones from Melissa and Doug. The thing disappoints me most if the cheap plastic bag. It is hard for my four-year-old to put the dolls into the bag. Those cheap plastic buttons are just impossible for a four year old to manage. On the other hand, the box from Melissa & Doug is spacious and sturdy. Both products are similarly priced. I will recommend you to check them out and make your decision.

I cannot think of a very compelling reason to have a wrist strap for a DSLR. But if want one, this is very good. Due to the weight of a DSLR, you are not going to dangle the camera around your wrist like a compact camera. The wrist strap is more likely to serve as an insurance in case the camera drops out of your hand. The design is very clever. You don't feel being strapped. It is very comfortable. But once the camera drops, the weight will fasten the strap around your wrist. If you need one, this would on the top of your list.

I tried many many products for auto interior surfaces. They all did a decent job. This product works as well as other products. The big difference is that it is dry to touch. It is a big plus for us. I don't have to worry about getting my clothes dirty. I am very happy with the result.
Have used for many years.  Only remover that works well for me.

I've been using the "Magic" version of this product for several years with much satisfaction.  I don't think I've ever used one of these to the point to where it needed to be replaced, but...  I keep them everywhere, and like them so much I often give them away to friends and relatives (and like ink pens, they just go missing in action :)  So was time to stock back up and I thought I give these a try.  Well in every way to me they appear to be the same as the Magic ones as to size, quality and ability to quickly clean glasses (no scratches or lint), phone and tablet screens.  I like that you are offered more color choices and the price is about half.  They do Not come in individual little pouches like the others (which I liked very much for convenience), they do come in a big zippered pouch as per the photo another posted with their review of 02/10/15.Another big plus is these are supplied by a small business owner which is good to support when they offer a great product at a great price, but you can't do that unless they support their product.  Guess what I didn't even have a problem but I got an email from Eco-Fused thanking me for my order and promising that they totally backed their product and to contact if my order was not correct in any form and they would make it right. That's a good pro active step that others would do good to follow.I'm satisfied.I would recommend.I will buy again.

I have been looking for several years to find better replacement bulbs for our built in microwave that sits above our stove as serves double duty as range hood with lighting and ventilation.  Eureka!  These are the ones! The old incandescent bulbs burned extremely hot using 80 watts (more than all the other bulbs in 4 other rooms combined).  Never felt comfortable leaving them on for a night light because they were so hot and used so much energy.  Have seen this size LED bulbs offered for a while but there is never enough description to make me feel comfortable as to âwill they fit and workâ.  They not only fit, but they fit better.  The old ones took the entire available space in screw in/out making the task to change out a bulb more difficult than it should have been.  These fit perfectly with plenty of room for easy installation with zero modifications.  My wife and my preference for the cook top area lighting would have always been a daylight white light, but you donât have a choice with the incandescent, just the standard yellow/warm white.  We were excited and very pleased with our choice of the daylight white for our purchase of these led bulbs (if you prefer the yellow/warm white you can still get your choice too).Now we leave our microwave light on high 24/7 for cook/counter top lighting and night light lighting.  Cool 8 Watts vs hot 80 Watts.  Stated life expectancy for the incandescent bulbs was 1000 hrs and never lasted more than 5-600 hrs tops based on many burnt out bulbs requiring time consuming replacement maintenance.  These donât have a stated life expectancy that I saw at this time, but I assuming any led bulb would be rated in the 10-50,000 hrs range.  So Iâm thinking now that we are running these 24/7 that if we get around 10,000 hrs that will give us a year between changes, so time will tell as we just recently installed.  While these leds are rated about 20% fewer lumens than the incandescent, to us they appear to be brighter upon initial install than the originals.  Iâve noticed with the house Cree bulbs that they seem to be brighter to begin with and then dim down a bit over time, which could just be a perception thing.  Our microwave light has full power and dimmed settings and these are not supposed to be dimmable with an incandescent dimmer, but ours dimmed fine, with no perceivable flicker to me (wife says she might see faint flicker dimmed but not sure), so I just that is a hit or miss event.  However, dimmable is not something that matters to us at 4W full power per bulb and cool to the touch bulbs, so we leave them at full power 24/7.  Iâm not an electrical engineer, but I suspect that burning led bulbs dimmed without an led dimmer would likely shorten their life, so for us why even go there.While the packaging is more than adequate to insure safe arrival and storage, it is not glitzy retail packaging.  The manufacturing appearance quality on my inspection seems much better and higher than the name brand retail packaged product.  I was very impressed.  We are very very pleased.If you too are looking for a better choice for your intermediate base incandescent microwave bulb, these led bulbs are the wise upgrade to go with.If you are concerned about will they fit and work for you, I am including some photos that would have helped me and should help you feel better about your choice.Update 09/12/2015  Reducing to 3 stars as they only have lasted 4 months.  Gradually more and more of the 80 tiny little leds have burned out, that now at about 40% gone they need replacing already.  Probably will stay with them, but disapointed.  Update just so you know what you might expect.

This is a lesser quality Cree bulb.  Uses 1.5W more than their original bulb, almost as much as CFL.  Built cheaper without the heat sink.  Loss of heat sink reduces life/warranty by 2/3, but cost by not even 1/3.  If you want less expensive go with CFL.  If you want better value, go with the original Cree LED bulbs, not the 4-Flow.

Quality is OK, but at this price and from this manufacturer, I expected more.  I wear a size 12-13 shoe so large foot, but the fit was still large and saggy from first wear onward.  I worn the woolen black canterbury dress socks for years with 5 star satisfaction so thought I'd give these a try for causual.  Big mistake! Disappointed and definitely would not buy these again.

Worked well to begin with for several months.  Then Keyboard lag (letters/numbers type show up after delay or are skipped after delay) developed intermittently, then more frequently.  At first you'll think it's you, but as problem lingers and becomes more and more annoying, you run Googles for "Keyboard Lag"  and discover it's an old old problem going back many years for the MK520.  You still think well maybe it's the other folks and you can get your's back up to speed.  Well you've been careful not to change from the original USB slot for the sender receiver, only trying swapping out batteries, just in case, but now you start down some of the "maybe" fixes.  You try a USB extender to get the sender/receiver extremely close to your combo, you try setting your usb port to never sleep, don't have a USB3.0 port so not that, you try Turning on Filter keys in Ease of access, go through all the check list you can find and give up.  Realizing that most tech support is lousy but having good experience with Logitech of many many previous years you think, well I'll give that a shot.  They respond (after a few) days with standard scripted "your fault, not a known problem (which is totally BS) no nothing reply that is typical of the tech support we've all come to know and dread, ending with a "let us know if we haven't solved your problem, and when you do that goes off into la la land never to return.  So if you kept your wired keyboard somewhere you go back to using that (the mouse works fine so you don't have to put it up).  Wouldn't recommend you buy the MK520 if you intend to use it as long as your system last. Have heard lot of other poor comments on MK520 after checking, so not just a few of us.  I've heard Wireless computing doe not have the problem but I can't afford theirs for home use and have a few good comments on the Adessos, so might try those after I tire over using the wired keyboard.

Very pleased. I was sceptical as to quality if the tools would even last one go around.  On the chance that they might vs the cost to have links removed from my wife's many less expensive fashion watches, I gave it a shot.  Used almost every tool in the kit first day and not a one failed or shows any indication of problems.  They definitely aren't jeweler's quality tools, but who would be expecting that for the price.  I don't see how I'll ever wear these out for home use.  Just on one Fossil watch it paid for itself with the watch back removal tool so I could get at the battery, then there is a little battery lifter tool that is much better than any tiny screw driver or the like you might have tried used to remove watch batteries (by the way Amazon is the place to get your watch batteries) and then I used the link pin driver tool and link pin no mar hammer to shorten the watch by my wife's desired link.  I am the hero today because of the kit.  It comes in a clear plastic case, which for me will be what I store the tools in for future needs.  There are several little screw drivers and other tools I did not use today.  There is a tool for pry off watch backs if a watch has that method for accessing battery, needle nose plyers that are just fine to use for this intended use, a pair if intricate needle nose tweezers for moving around tiny parts if you need to (or they are great for removing splinters too).  Anyway.  I love these and can't believe the value for the home user.  Amazon carries these same tools under various parts numbers at various prices, so be sure to check for the best priced option.

Would not fit Royal-Canin cans.Outer size was too large.Inner size was too small.Did test on standard human food cans, and they do fit those,but I wouldn't feel comfortable that the material is safe for human food.Nothing great here quality wise either.I should have just bought the ones at my local pet store.

100% interchangeable in fit, size and function.  Yes, these are washable and that is nice.  I clean wash mine up to where they appear new to the eye.  BUT, I have found you should change out for a new one about every 4 months. Finally there are DeCaf Flavored coffee choices other than the standard 3 offerings of: Hazelnut, Vanilla, Vanilla/Hazelnut.You may or may not love these coffees, but here you have a chance to sample before you buy the 4 full boxes.Coconut Caramel Chocolate Cookie CrunchDouble Chocolate BrownieMaple Cinnamon French ToastSnickerdoodle (cinnamon, vanilla and cookie dough)I found the rich delicious taste and pleasant aromas to be exactly what I have been looking for, and loved them all.Biggest problem is right now they are not offered in full boxes here on Amazon.In the United State I have only found one source online, located in Texas, for these wonderful flavors, and their supply while priced fair, is always limited.  I am buying these in boxes as they become available and enjoying the heck out of them.If you drink De-Caf in the single serve brewers and would like to try a little flavor variety, this is the way to go.

Depends on how you will use.For most the money clip will be a big plus.  The magnet is very powerful.But for me it was too big for my use.  The money clip makes it almost as thick as a wallet.I don't carry cash anymore, just wanted thin passcase to carry Driver's Licence, Insurance, 3 plastic cards.It does that quite well.  I knew the money clip would probably be a problem to me prior to purchase so no complaints there.I cut the money clip off and remove the second magnet in the main wallet with an exacto knife.That made this be what I wanted although not straight from mfg that way.Nice window for Driver's Licence/ID on one side.3 slots for cards reverse side.Pouches in between for a couple of misc items if you wish.I'll probably purchase another in a couple of years if this one gets too worn.

Good idea - too bad the Blue Birds don't know it.  Cats got prior baby birds before they could fledge.  Couldn't do anything about the neighborhood cats so thought I'd give this a try. Didn't do much for me on Kindle Fire HD.  Deleted it from device and deleted it from Amazon as I don't want to ever download again.  Got the Clean Master Free App and it did the job.

Bought to renew some old digital thermometers.  The 392s made them both good as new.  Supplier was SwatchBattery, which shipped very promptly and I had 2 days after ordering.  Energizer for some reason won't put a readable date code on their batteries.  Mine had AZB and "appear" to be fresh.  Silver Oxide batteries have a 3-5 year shelf life so you are generally OK regardless.  These (aka LR41) are also in many children's toys that are not a constant drain type of use - the light of my grandson's police car for example is powered by one of these as it only comes on and stays on while he presses the button.  Also (OEM version LR41s)are in many of those greeting cards that play a tune, if you'd like to revive an old one.  And of course they are in some of the less expensive costume watches  :DMy local battery specialty store offers their store brand of this for $6 each and I would have to drive to pick it up.

Best scale yet.  Easy to read. Accurate.Results repeatable after several other people weigh.Excellent value.  I'm glad I chose this one.

Totally equal to OEM cartridge performance and quality in my experience.  These are not refilled or remanufactured cartridges, but brand new.  I have purchased these several times. The typical Brother printer can be had for $60-$100, but the OEM replacement cartridges will cost you $50.  It's just not logical to buy anything but these.  When the printer finally fails you won't be sad that you have $30-$50 in cartridges left over that you can't use.  Just take the money you save and buy yourself another Brother printer and none-OEM cartridges here on AMAZON.  Just do the math and you'll never buy another brand printer or OEM cartridge, nor will you be angry at the money you spent on printers and supplies again.  This is definitely the way to go.  Be Happy!

What?Kindle Fire HD of 13 months is better than current HDX version, so WTF?I have had the android version side loaded from 1Mobile since day one, but it would be better if we KFHD users didn't have to do that. I love my KFHD, but based on lessons learned like this, next time around I'll be getting a more widely supported regular android tablet so my apps can be current and I don't have to go extra steps and jump through hoops to see if they will run on a sometimes yes and sometimes no hybrid android operating system like my KFHD.Very irritated at both DISH and AMAZON over this app that that's not available for my KFHD at the Amazon app store.Sometimes it seems both companies have numb skulls working just to anger their customers.Love the quality of their products - dislike the genius that comes up with such nonsense (must be Dilbert's boss).

My 7 year old Chihuahua had a  Kyjen brand version of this called Funny Fleece Lil Buddy from the time he was a pup.  It was his number one favorite toy that he has always cuddled himself to sleep with.  Kyjen quit offering the Lil Buddy several years ago and i stocked up because it was such a great quality product.  My on hand supply finally exhausted. Woe is we!  Well this is not anywhere near that product, but it is far and a away the closest thing I'm found and he has accepted it as a substitute, so I'm happy.  So glad this was available.

I had used Duracell previously in Mail Chime (ASIN B00103FDDU) and been very satisfied with the life and the simple and plain date code / expiration date on the Duracell.  I have to change out the Duracell twice a year, so I thought I'd see if the Energizer had a longer life.  These Energizer only lasted a few days before failure.  They were new and sealed in package with Use by date of September 2015.  Based on Duracells having expiration dates about 3-4 years out, I thought this was odd and contacted Energizer.  Energizer indicated the A23 batteries have a 3 year shelf life and that my package was made in December 2012, would expire in December 2015 and should be used by September 2015.  I wish they would print something like that or more consumer friendly on the package.  So my batteries were reasonably fresh and I don't know why they failed so quickly.  Switched back to the Duracell version and they work fine, so I'm sticking with them for my application.  Both the Energizer and Duracell batteries came from the same Amazon merchant.

Just another "Blended" meh decaf Kup for the Keurig system. My wife and I, like millions of Seniors medically require a decaf coffee. During the holidays we had younger guest and needed non-decaf for them, so I picked up the 100% Arabica Colombian for them. It had wonderful aroma, so much so that I went off the wagon and had a cup (or 2 or 3). That coffee was wow in so many ways. The aroma as I said draws you to it, the the taste is so rich and bold, but not strong and not bitter, as other coffees. The Gevalia 100% Arabica Colombian non-decaf coffee is the absolute best coffee I have ever had from a K-Kup. So that is how we purchased 3 boxes of decaf to try (decaf not available in stores in our area). I now know that "Blended" means - our worst beans in combination to cancel out the others' bad qualities as best we can to get rid of them. This decaf was almost identical to every other "Breakfast Blend" for the Keurig machines. (I've used and kept the same Keurig brewer since 2006).  Lacking in aroma, richness and boldness of taste and bitter to the palate. Makes you just want to spit it out. Since it is so like the other "Blends" we'll try to use it up, but won't be buying this "Blend" ever again. Definitely would not recommend you waste your money with premium price for low average product - just go with whatever "Blend" you've been buying and save some money. Maybe someday one of the roasters will realize what a huge market they are missing by only offering decaf in their Blend, plus a Hazelnut and a Vanilla. Big Big demand waiting to be met with a product in decaf that has the WOW! of the Gevalia 100% Arabica non-decaf Colombian coffee.

The short curved blade is just like the great paring knife your granny had.  I buy the Rada knives with the black resin handles because I throw them in the dish washer.  They are available in a bushed aluminum handle that is just like granny's - but must be hand washed as the dishwater will quickly put a black oxidation on the aluminum.  If you choose the brushed aluminum handle, hand wash and store in the paper sheath the knife ships in you probably can hand it down to your grand kids.  If you don't have time for such, go with the black resin handle and you'll still get many many years of usable service from this great product.  They seem to stay sharp forever - don't try to sharpen one or you'll likely ruin it.  Best of all they are the best at PARING - best apple peeler and potato peeler I've ever used.

It's OK.  Watch is nice with many functions.  Functions not the most user friendly to try to use.  Display hard to read and back light is very brief - both I assume are because of the extremely long rated battery life.Best thing is the band and the water tightness.  Band is extremely rugged for active young people and they actually just keep it on even when in the pool.  The band ruggedness and none cutting feature is preferred by my son, who is a policeman.The water tightness is something you'll love it you have folks that would take it to  the pool or wear in inclement weather sporting activities.

So after the change I gave it several months to see if it would get better or if I became used to the new and improved TWC app.  Instead I grew to dislike it more day by day.  Found and tried this WeatherBug App.  Much better - better graphics, better information, better everything and advertisements are much less intrusion, in fact the ads are displayed so nicely and out of the way that I actually find myself looking at them frequently.  This WeatherBug App is a great improvement and a Win for everybody.  Highly recommend.  I use the App on my Kindle Fire HD.

Grandma thought this was coolest greatest thing ever - grandson thought it was meh! and just went on the toy heap - doesn't get much play time - I'd say pass on this for most kids as they expect so much more these days

It isn't logical I suppose - but twice the slices make a smaller apple more filling than a large one - we bought the large premium apples for years (which were great) - but you can get more a more filled feeling from a smaller bag apple with the 16 slices this gives you - also the large premium apples may be too large and may require too much force for you unless you are husky - if you are using a regular corer/slicer now figure this one will take twice as much force - the attached swing piece that pushes the slices on through and the core on out is more useful than you might imagine.

3 Yr Old grandson loved it - especially the sword of course - naturally everything is very durable except the sword which if flimsy - good for play time - would work well in a child's theatrical scene - or serve as a Halloween costume - in some photos some of the parts look white, but they are silver if that makes a difference to you.
Very large file produces great graphics - fun to play - you need to give yourself some exploration time to discover and enjoy all the features -
After 3 years of trials, I'm convinced and have converted all my AA & AAA home devices to Eneloops.GREAT VALUE

Natural non heat processed salt, loaded with about 75+ trace minerals. White processed table salt is almost all sodium chloride except for 2-3% toxic anti-caking agents and it has been heated to super high temperatures that change natures intended cell structure for salt making table salt even worse for your health.  Himalayan salt is the natural way to go.  Do some internet searches and check it out for yourself.  My wife and I have used Himalayan Salt for a couple of years now and our belief is that it has benefited us greatly health wise (we are both in mid sixties), plus we much prefer the taste on our food.

Was looking for something to make retired life a little easier for the two of us. Many things we prepare for meals are heated in the microwave (or can be), but often that requires one or more utensils that need to be washed, dried and put away.  These have been fantastic. Food items that need heating or cooking can be cooked in these and served right to the table. The base container's white base looks nice on the table as a serving dish.  Great too for the leftovers that you'll serve a second time during the week. Freezable (but will freezer burn due to air space above food after short period) and microwavable type 5 plastic. Seems to seal air tight.  Indentations in the top and bottom make for stack-able storing with no slip sliding. Good to take to social functions where you don't want to have to make sure you get your dish back. We have also found these great for storing and organizing all types of things from tools, crafts, flower bulb storage, grand kid projects, etc.
Great quality product that is comfortable and does what it is suppose to do.Extra Nice to have them delivered to your front door.

My batteries were full 3V hot - Energizer batteries are made in both China and, as mine did, Indonesia - Energizer does not date code these batteries in a way the consumer can read, but Lithiums are good for a 7-8 year shelf life - You can call Enerizer to find out about the code they do print on the battery when you receive if you have any concerns, which is crazyville to me, but that's the way that it is with them on this product - Mine had date code AB which Energizer said meant "manufactured in February of 2013 and has an 8 year shelf life, and the use by date will be 2021" - about as hot and fresh as you could possibly expect I think.My batteries came from MYBATTERYSUPPLIER which has always shipped my AMAZON battery orders same day and supplied current product.

Was looking for something to make retired life a little easier for the two of us.  Many things we prepare for meals are heated in the microwave (or can be), but often that requires one or more utensils that need to be washed, dried and put away.  So we gave these and the 38oz rectangular version a test with an order of each to see how they would work for us.  They have been fantastic.  Food items that need heating or cooking can be cooked in these and served right to the table.  Great for the leftovers that you'll serve a second time during the week.  Freezable (but will freezer burn due to air space above food after short period) and microwavable type 5 plastic. Indentations in the top and bottom make them stack-able with no slip sliding.  Good to take to get togethers where you don't want to have to make sure you get your dish back. We have also found these great for storing and organizing all types of things from tools, crafts, flower bulb storage, grand kid projects, etc.  Like I said these were a test for our idea of finding ways to may our retired life a little easier (or course would be good for busy households as well).  We love everything about these containers function wise.  But the price is a bit high to just throw away (actually recycle)  as we wanted to do in our situation to get out of a cleanout/wash/dry/putaway chore and black is not the prettiest color to serve from - so...  To get the cost down we went VERSATAINER NC-729 in white (AMAZON B0037XL5S8) to get the white color and the cost down to less than 32¢ each delivered for these round ones (the rectangular version less than 38Â¢). We would have stayed with these Reditainer (actually TriPak model MT0750) had they been offered at bulk pricing (and in the white we prefer for home use).

Bought from "sold by Amazon". Billfold received was not as images shown.  Very disappointing.I had billfold as shown in images of product for more than decade and was very satisfied.Image shows embossed logo which was as my old version.Item received has a plastic logo that sticks out and is uncomfortable for the hip pocket.The plastic logo breaks which adds to the problem.Image shows passcase with two card slots on front.What you receive has plain front and back, with no card slots.Product received appears to be same item as a $9 version also on Amazon, so got ripped on price as well.I threw my old worn out version away and this was also a Father's Day gift that I wanted, so I can't return it.First time I've ever felt taken advantage of from a "sold by Amazon" purchase.From now on I'll be leery of even that comfort level in a purchase.Based up what I received, which was not as the images shown, I definitely would not recommend this item.-Follow up 06/15/2013Item apparently cannot be provided as per images shown.However, Amazon has resolved my disappointment in the item provided not being the same as the item shown in a satisfactory manner.

Read and followed enclosed directions.  Then programmed - which takes maybe 15 seconds.  Tested and Bam! worked first try.  Mounted with two screwed provided which took about 2 minutes. (The install might take longer if you have hard wood and need to drill a pilot hole, so add that to my install time if you do.) I couldn't be more pleased with the ease of programming and operation of this keypad.  None of these are super heavy duty, but this one is much tougher built than others.  Unit appears to be waterproof with no openings for entry points on the upper part front or back.  9-Volt battery (supplied) compartment on bottom front.  Keys appear to be sealed to prevent water entry around them.  The keys are of nice size and protrude so you are sure which one you are pressing.  The key pad lights up when pressed.  So to use in dark, just press any key to get the keypad to light up, then enter your chosen 4 digit code and press enter.  This works because whether in dark or daylight, only the last four keys pressed before entry are used. The cover has a detent to keep it locked up and out of your way while you are entering your code. Means a lot when your eyes are not so good and your fingers aren't as nimble as they used to be.  With good eyesight and youthful fingers, you could flip the cover up part of the way, enter your code + Enter and quickly be on your way. Closes with just a press of Enter key without a code.  I like everything about this keypad.I did contact LiftMaster about their other two units, the 387LM and 377LM.  My understanding is that they will all work with Purple 315MHz openers. The 387LM being a generic model offered for 5 frequencies to cover almost ever door opener brand, but it is not as heavy duty and I have friends and family with that version and the slide up cover is aggravating in ease of slide and them getting it to stay on.  The 377LM is pretty much same as the 877Max, but only works on Purple 315 MHz.  My understanding is that that LiftMaster will discontinue the 377LM when all product is gone, offering the 877Max instead which works with all Liftmaster openers from 1993 to present.  You can control more that one door opener with the 877Max if you have them.  Several other features also on this unit if you need them.

This product works as well as possible with the govt allowable signal strength.  I first placed the receiver in where it had a clear line of sight through window to mailbox, which happened to also be a "spot" near a DSL modem, TV, dish receiver etc.  The inside white receiver box didn't like the interference there at all.  I don't know if it was one of the items or a combination.  When it didn't work, I moved it to another clear line of sight location where there was no other electronics nearby and it worked like a charm, but it was not in a location that was easy to see and it didn't fit in the dÃ©cor either.  So I thought I'd try other locations in the house.  The receiver liked everywhere except near electronics.  So I moved it to my second choice of convenient to see locations it worked.  The location was my last try because I thought it least likely to work because the line of sight is blocked by a brick outside wall and to interior walls.  That location is where it has remained and it has worked without fail.  Another thing that I have that is supposed to be a problem is that I have a Heavy Duty Aluminum Mailbox - the type that wouldn't dent if hit with a baseball bat.  The receiver has a wire sticking up about a foot for an antennae and is plastic, not so stylist.  Receiver requires a wall outlet plug for power connection.I am more than satisfied with the Mail Chime and there does not appear to be any other product to compete, so either this one works for you or you are out of luck.  That's how I saw the situation and think you should measure your expectations along those lines.  The Mail Chime is just going to work for some people like myself that it probably shouldn't and maybe not for some others that you might think it would.  There are just so many variables from location to location that determine whether it will work.  Since it is electronic most of the sellers do not accept this product back.  I bought as a "Ships from and sold by Amazon" so that I could return if it did not work for me.  As to this device and for the ability to return if it doesn't work for you, my opinion is that you should only purchase as the "Ships from and sold by Amazon" option.  There is not much to go wrong on this so I would think it should last at least 5-10 years. When the battery does someday need changing in the mailbox send unit, (I checked it out before I installed) it's going to be a 2-5 minute piece of cake no hassle deal. I think if this product interest you that you should try it and go for it based of my results. Last thing... Mail Chime does have an audio "chime", but you can adjust it to high or low volume or in my case, I only wanted to see the "red notifier light", so I turned the volume off. That's a good choice to have for all the different needs folks would have.***Update:  Unit has been "buggy" during it's short life.  After few months starting to not work until send unit was removed and shaken vigorously to free up tilt switch.Send unit signal strength grew weaker and weaker (I did indeed, keep constant "fresh" batteries installed).  Unit finally failed beyond ability to Rube Goldberg fix attempts to get it back work.  Super happy with to begin with.  Liked less and less as time passed.  After 6 months not work effort to try to return, you have to pay charges to ship it back and an additional $15 on top of that cost.  Makes "warranty" replacement after 6 months cost more than 50% of value, which I consider beyond reasonable cut off point to pay out for a "warranty" item.

Too expensive for quality.  Works fine for short time - a few weeks to a few months.  Then it begins to quickly deteriorate.  The backing begins to stick to desk top surfaces and will lift off the finish ruining the area of desk that was under mouse. After it has your desk surface stuck to the back the pad doesn't stay in place.  Then it begins to curl inward toward your desk top.  Then then plies begin to separate.  I paid more for this because I expected more. It's not a lot of money to most folk I guess, but it was to me.  I don't mind paying more when I can get good quality and forget about it.  In this case, I should have just got several of the old cheap kind I guess.  They wouldn't have ruined my desk and I could have afforded to throw them away every few months for the same amount this one cost.  You just don't know these days about products.  Makes you wonder if they ever test these products in the real world in actual conditions.

ES File Explorer works just like Windows "My Computer" does to allow you to navigate you Kindle Fire HD's files.  You'll need a file navigator to install side loaded apps not available on Amazon and this App, sure is the easiest one to use that I've tried.  This is such a necessary App I am surprised that the Kindle Fire HDs do not come with a file navigation method.  Also easy to use to clear out junk left over in your Kindle Download file that you probably don't realize is there.  I got it free, but if there was a charge and I knew it would work as good as it does, I certainly would pay a reasonable fee to purchase.

The company doesn't realize how important it is to keep what remains of their customers engaged.  This App "might" work on some Android devices, but it surely doesn't do much on a Kindle Fire HD.  Now since there are currently about 3 million KFHD users, and the primary purpose of a Kindle is a Reader, you would logically think that the first order of business for a Newspaper that has ceased publishing 4 out of 7 days and is only digital those days would want to have their product in the hands of the area customers with Kindle "Reader" devices in order to get better results for their advertisers.  Of course the Birmingham News hasn't found themselves in their current business state because someone was thinking with logic and acting with common sense follow through actions. It certainly is something that somebody better wake up too Soon!

AKA Levitron Model R52-PJ226-00W.  This midway size is typical in current new home construction. Made well.  You should pick up some Wall Plate / Wiring Device Electrical Spacers such as Amazon's Gardner Bender GSP-04 to allow for proper spacing fit on the Decora / Wall Timer Switch Outlet.  The spacers will provide exact proper fit and you will not break the wall plate (although I can't imagine how you can break it anyway).  I installed this product with the spacers for use with my Intermatic ST01 Self Adjusting White Wall Switch Timer.  I am well satisfied with all.

I checked my own info and that of three friends that have moved.  Returned two year old+ incorrect data on all.  Thus, not reliable for people searches.  Worked fine on my Kindle Fire HD, but I am deleting the app as being useless to me.

Very disappointed.  An excellent job of writing skills put to very poor use.  The book starts off reasonably interesting, enough so that you read on and on, hoping it will soon move on and get to business.  It just never happens and I just finally had to give it up at the 80% read point.  The book is devoted to opinions about why every director of the FBI, in Kessler's opinion, has failed miserably as Bureau head, and has been solely responsible for every miss step and failure ever to occur. On the other hand he tries to make a case for why the field agents bad decisions at critical moments at events such as Ruby Ridge, Waco, etc should not be held against them.  The book reads more like a rant.  Tale after tale, accusation after accusation are not sourced, so obviously they get nowhere close to a fact.  An example:  Vincent Foster committed suicide because Hillary Clinton hurt his feelings (not factual on any known or stated basis - thus, just gossip from unknown or fabricated source).  All the Witch hunts of the leadership and defense of the field agents, might have been a better read if it were titled in a way to indicate that was the road you were going to be taken down.  The time certainly was not well invested in providing any hint of any Secrets of the FBI.  I'll give another of his books a try, but if it fails to deliver like this one did, then I'm closing the door at 10%.
The Ads Free version is lot of entertaining fun for when you need to fill in some time or just clear your mind.  Youngsters and oldsters will enjoy.

Michael Giacchino has been busy of late, having scored four films that were released a month or two apart this year, with Jupiter Ascending, Tomorrowland and Inside Out being the others, along with Jurassic World, and all of them are incredible efforts. I would say, from my point of view, his score for Tomorrowland was his best, with Inside Out right behind (and i have listened to all of them on CD), but my favorite might be Jurassic World, only because he incorporates John Williams' mesmerizing theme from Jurassic Park, which always brings a tear to my eye in how beautifully composed it is.What makes Giacchino's score stand tall, though, isn't the returning theme, but his own variation of "Jurassic."
