His theme for Jurassic World can be heard in "As the Jurassic World Turns," in the opening minutes before Williams' theme comes in the last minute. Variations of Giacchino's them can be heard later on, especially in "Gyrosphere of Influence." Like with all of Giacchino's scores, there's a massive sense of wonder and magic, or in this case, discovery. He also adds a good deal of horror elements with the track "Indominus Wrecks," just a little over two minutes in, where intense piano and strings have your heart pumping as fast as the unfortunate characters in the film. But, the track "Nine to Survival Job" really gets me, as it's the music that plays over the final moments of the movie, and if you've seen the film, the last minute of the track brings pure happiness after a brilliant return 14 years later. I love the "Jurassic" films, even the absolutely awful third movie, but because they're not just action blockbusters. They're adventures, and we rarely get real adventure films. Even Tomorrowland, which I'll review at a later time, was a bold and completely original adventure that Giacchino helps bring to life in the best way possible. Just listening to this soundtrack brings nothing but nostalgia-fueled happiness. I hope i wasn't the only one, and i hope the scores for The Lost World and Jurassic Park III are re-released in lieu of Jurassic World's overwhelming success.

Michael Giacchino has a very distint style in how he creates a world of musical soundscapes that defy imagination. Like John Williams, who he is often compared to, Giacchino almost always has every score conducted wit a full orchestra, and rarely uses synth or electronics. Here, with "Tomorrowland," he squeezes in the smallest amount of synth, takes a full orchestra and creates what I would call his masterpiece. "Tomorrowland" is a strange beast, of which has received a mixed response from critics and a more positive response from audiences, but one thing that helps bring this boldly original sci-fi adventure to life is the score.Full of fun thrills, adventure and heart, Giacchino embraces the unknown and embodies the theme of "Tomorrowland" in his music; the soound of a better tomorrow. In the opening track "A Story About the Future," it starts the score with a loud, quick and playful tune to set the scene for the titular place. "A Prologue" is more sinister sounding, helping to build the mystery and unknown qualities of the film's journey. "You've Piqued My Pin-trest" is another playful sounding track as a young Frank Walker is thrown head-first into adventure, with "Boat Wait, There's More!" being the follow-up moments. It's "Edge of Tomorrowland" everything changes for Frank and for the audience, as Tomorrowland is shown in its literal shining glory. I could go on, but I'll stop. The score is timeless. Sure, it just came out, but everything about it screams gorgeous masterpiece. When was the last time a completely original sci-fi adventure movie was released? I can understand a few reasons why some people weren't huge fans, but I didn't see any narrative stumbles at all. The second act was slower and the third was extremely fast, but they should have been to begin with. You have the truth-revealing middle frame, where everything is laid out for the audience and the characters, then the third act is where they act on these reveals and answers to impossible questions. I just wish people didn't listen to critics and saw the film for themsevles. I guess originality is truly dead; remakes, reboots, prequels and sequels are all people care for now.

Band of Brothers and The Pacific, two ground-breaking, emotional, triumphant and phenomenal series that cover two sections of World War II; the European Theater and the Pacific Theater. produced by Steven Spielberg and Tom Hanks, both shows are considered to be not only two of the best representations of WWII in terms of filmmaking (I say filmmaking because, while they're seen as miniseries, they're basically extended movies), but incredible in every way possible, from the direction and writing to the acting and the production values. Saving Private Ryan, arguably the best WWII film, pales in comparison when looking at these two works. I won't detail their synopses, since information can be found pretty much anywhere, but i'll talk about their merits and the differences between the two.Band of Brothers, an emotional powerhouse that puts you in the shoes of Easy Company dropping into Normandy from the skies, with a group of men that fight not just for the world and their country, but for each other. With gripping performances from Damian Lewis, Donnie Wahlberg, Kirk Acevedo, Ron Livingston and a slew of other actors throughout the series. What makes Band of Brothers even more incredible, though, isn't just the production, visuals, or direction, but how you come to love nearly every character, including the small parts as they all come together and fight in such a horrific and gruesome war that defied reason. The Pacific differs from Band of Brothers not just in it focusing on the Pacific Theater of War instead of the European Theater, but that it lessens (just a tad), your love for the characters to show the effects war has on the psyche, the sheer brutality, relentless terror and violence. You still come to love and feel for characters, just not as quickly. Also, The Pacific does have the feeling of being grander and bolder, but not better. Both miniseries are brilliant, haunting, epic and outstanding in every department, with both outdoing one another in a single area.The blu-ray box set has some of the best video and audio technical specs to ever be on blu-ray, and if you do not yet own either series, this is a must-own. It also comes with a bonus feature that doesn't come with either series separately, called "He Has Seen War," a 54-minute documentary that's extremely well-put together and informative. Here's to hoping Spielberg and Hanks team up again with HBO to deliver one more WWII series that focuses on the North African campaign of WWII, as it could complete their World War II Saga, similar to Clint Eastwood's Battle of Iwo Jima film saga.

Directed by the Spierig Brothers and Starring Ethan Hawke and rising actress Sarah Snook, Predestination is adapted from the Robert A. Heinlein story, "-All You Zombies-," a story that deals with time travel and the predestination paradox (i'd look it up; it would take up the whole review to explain in detail). Hawke's character meets the Unmarried Mother, a customer at the bar he tends, and the bartender shows his patron something unbelievable; he's a time traveler, a temporal agent who's sole purpose is to find the Fizzle Bomber, and change human history.Predestination is not the first film of its kind, but it certainly is original, even if adapted from a previous work, as it expands on Heinlein's story, bringing to light new elements and details, while still keeping a great deal away from the viewer's eye. The film is superb in every way, bringing both entertainment value and cinematic value into a short and sweet sci-fi thriller. The Spierig Brothers, who previously directed Daybreakers, are in top-form, carefully weaving together their screenplay with their focused and unflinching direction, creating a tense, and unknowing atmosphere as the characters move through different times. The acting was very brilliant, with Sarah Snook being the stand-out among the cast, but not topping completely Hawke's performance, which is one of (if not the) best performance he's given. The production and visual effects were surprisingly incredible for such a low-budget film, and there was never a moment where the film seemed out of its depth. Honestly, i really think these two brothers should stick with science fiction, because their delivery of Predestination couldn't have been done any other way without either straining the plot, revealing too much or a number of other problems that could arise.Predestination is a true sci-fi film, and if you are not a fan of anything science fiction related, do not watch this. If you like a good mind-bender, a thriller that keeps you guessing or a simply well-made movie, look no further. This is a must-see and a must-own. Preferably the blu-ray; the picture and sound when compared to DVD are unparalleled.

The Order: 1886 is the newly released Playstation 4 exclusive game that centers around the Knights of the Round Table, formed by King Arthur, in an alternate history timeline, where the knights keep the world safe from half-breed monsters. Through the miraculous discovery of Blackwater- a mysterious liquid that extends lifetimes- the knights continue to fight this on-going war, even though humans have been on the losing side since the beginning. The way the game is structured plays out like a film, and through this, comes a very theatrical and bold musical score.Composed by Jason Graves (with Austin Wintory co-composing The Knight's Theme), the soundtrack for The Order: 1886 is magnificent on multiple levels. Graves has a very unique sound, that of which is easily heard here though the use of eerie strings, pulsating percussion and haunting choir vocals. But, in comparison to past works, his score is less horror-based (like Dead Space and Tomb Raider) and more emotional, more character-driven. You can spot some recurring themes in the tracks, but what sticks out is his propensity to use violas and violins to create the atmosphere, only here they're more quiet; almost somber and tragic, whereas in Dead Space they were terrifying and heart-pounding. When it comes to intense action tracks, Graves is in top-form. "Commandeered" is one of these tracks, creating a smooth but intense rhythm that helps to create one of the game's finer action moments where Sir Galahad and his knights commandeer an airship. The one track that stands out the most, though, is "The Edge of Sanity." Epic, tragic, pure brilliance all rolled into this majestic piece that starts off with a dark and quiet voice, but builds into a bold, raging, courageous work of art that can be placed against any heroic act at a time where, it seems there can be no hope left.The soundtrack for The Order: 1886 is a must-own if you are a fan of Jason Graves' music, video game soundtracks, or scores from composers like Hans ZImmer, Ramin Djawadi, Brian Tyler, James Newton Howard, Bear McCreary or even Mark Snow. Jason Graves is becoming a bigger name in the video game scoring department, and hopefully will branch out and do a movie or TV show, because his music is superb!

Ramin Djawadi is no stranger to action music, but the way he delivers is very unique, whether it be the quiet build to a pulsing electric sound like in "Person of Interest," or heart-pounding percussion and loud choir voices like in "Game of Thrones" and "Dracula Untold." Djawadi has made a very peculiar name of himself along side popular composers like Hans Zimmer (his mentor), James Newton Howard, Brian Tyler, Harry Gregson-Williams and Bear McCreary, and here with "Safe House," Djawadi channels a more familiar sound and overall score in albeit a fast and pulsating way.The score is very similar to the scores of John Powell's "Bourne" films, using almost no synth and a whole lot of traditional instrumentation, mainly with percussion. So, unless you're a fan of action scores, intense orchestral music or any of the composers listed above, i'd give this soundtrack a listen before buying it, as it's very similar to scores like "Green Zone," "The Bourne Supremacy," and "Unstoppable."

The Call of Duty franchise is an interesting one in that, while they release a game annually, the series is always met with criticism (most of it pointless from gamers who call the series crap). After the massively underwhelming installment that was Ghosts (what is seen as a Michael Bay-esque video game), we are graced with the first game from Sledgehammer Games in the series, Advanced Warfare. In the review, i will only talk about the campaign, as i am not a multiplayer gamer. But from what i've seen, the exosuits have created a massive change for first-person online gameplay.The campaign focuses on Jack Mitchell, a former Marine who, after losing his best friend and fellow Marine Will Irons and his own arm, he is given a place at the Atlas Corporation, a private military contractor owned and operated by Will's father, Jonathan (portrayed by Kevin Spacey). Here, Mitchell is given a new arm, and a new purpose; to honor Will's memory. But, when the KVA, a new militia group led by the mysterious 'Hades,' attacks around the world, Atlas steps in to stop him, with Mitchell and his new team leading the charge.That's as far as I will go in revealing the story, but after playing the game multiple times, i must say this is the best Call of Duty to date. Like Call of Duty 4, the campaign in the game sets up a new trilogy, and actually cares about story-telling and not generic blockbuster-fare of cinematic events and massive explosions. What captured my attention, was the amount of detail that was poured into the story, the gameplay and the realism, even though it was futuristic. And that's when i see the name of the man behind the curtain; Mark Boal. The Hurt Locker and Zero Dark Thirty, both films written by Mr. Boal, boasted realism that one expects to see in a documentary about war, coupled with emotional ties to the characters, all of which is definitely present in Advanced Warfare. The dialogue, the script, everything about Advanced Warfare screamed a more action-packed blockbuster version of Zero Dark Thirty, but i didn't fully know it until i watched the credits. Now, i'll say the campaign isn't game-changing in any way (mainly due to an ordinary conclusion/third act), but because of how well-written it is, how invested they were in creating such life-like characters and a truly horrific situation that reaches extremely brutal heights, Advanced Warfare has given me faith in the series again. Now, the gameplay itself is extremely smooth; the exosuits are brilliantly designed, the gunplay is polished, and the graphics were top-notch, with the cutscenes looking like an actual feature film.I've always liked Call of Duty, but i don't call myself a fanboy, as i find many disappointing things about the series (whether it's the emotionless plot of the first Black Ops, or the somewhat convoluted plot of Black Ops II, as well-written as it was). Either way, Advanced Warfare is the beginning of a new trilogy and a great one that boasts realism, fantastic characters and a simply good story that looks like it should be a movie franchise, or an HBO miniseries.

2Guns is the action-comedy starring Denzel Washington and Mark Wahlberg about two undercover operatives (DEA and Navy SEAL Intelligence) who discover a secret operation between the CIA and illegal drug trade after stealing millions from Mexican drug-kingpin Papi Greco (Edward James Olmos). The film was smart, fresh, dryly witty, violent and very lovable, and the musical score from Clinton Shorter (District 9) helps to shape the fun, atmospheric setting of the film.Having composed, conducted and helping perform the score himself, Clinton Shorter's score is often times upbeat and offbeat, matching the characters, their convoluted conflict with the CIA, drug cartel and crooked military operatives, and the friendship that develops between the two leads. With the uses of acoustic guitars, synth, and drums, the soundtrack to 2Guns is certainly one to check out, but isn't for everyone. Also, it's a short soundtrack, being just under 40 minutes long.

Bear McCreary is truly a one-of-a-kind composer, and is the composer who is dominating the musical soundscape of television. With shows like The Walking Dead, Battlestar Galactica (and the spin-off Caprica), Defiance, Da Vinci's Demons and Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D, the man certainly knows no limits. And now, he's taken on another television series that requires both a different tone, and a different sound, both of which he masters immediately. He brings the Scottish-sound, the vocals of Raya Yarbrough, and his traditional use of ethnic instruments as well as sweeping orchestral sounds in a near-perfect soundtrack.The soundtrack is a must-own for fans of McCreary and of anyone who likes instrumental scores, but i must say, it is an unfinished product. Until Vol. 2 is released (CD being preferred if you ask me), this is only half of the masterpiece Mr. McCreary has crafted.

Gravity is a mixed bag. It is far from a masterpiece, which is what many have been calling it. I won't go into the synopsis since it's been covered a dozen times over, i'll get right to it. Gravity is absolutely beautiful. Alfonso Cuaron's direction is marvelous and supreme, Steven Price's musical score is hauntingly epic and the visual effects are top-notch. But, the script and characters? Not even close to astonishing. I've seen people raving about the acting and how emotional this film is, but in all honesty, i thought this film was one of the most emotionless films ever made. Sandra Bullock's Ryan Stone was annoying, stupid and extremely unrealistic, and George Clooney's Kowalski felt like he was just there to fill in the space of a male lead (which is funny, since he doesn't have much screen time). Then, the script is decent at best. It does nothing new for the science fiction genre, or for drama, the dialogue is mediocre, and the story has been done before in other films and even in TV, just not to this extent. What i will give to Cuaron, though, is how he uses symbolism and themes like birth, rebirth and evolution (the most famous scene being Stone floating in zero-G, symbolizing a womb).I don't hate Gravity, but i refuse to call it a masterpiece, for that it is not. But i will not deny the film's beauty and technical achievements in filmmaking, especially the extended 'long-shot' sequence at the start of the film.

From Paris with Love is an action movie from the director of Taken about a low-level CIA operative (Rhys-Meyers) who gets entangled in a terrorist plot when he teams up with the unorthodox agent Charlie Wax as they foil the terrorists' plans to bomb the US Embassy.Honestly, I really don't know why this movie failed at the box office. John Travolta was in his element and at his best in a role that was a mix of Pulp Fiction's Vincent Vega, and Castor Troy from Face/off. He was ecstatic, crude and wild as Charlie Wax, but easily his most entertaining character as well. Rhys-Meyers was good as James Reese, being a funny counter-part to an already funny, bad-ass and witty lead in Travolta. The script was not Oscar-material, but you don't need an Oscar-script to have a great action movie. Pierre Morel's directing here seemed inspired by the Bourne films and the new Bond films, but I think it was on purpose, which actually helped the film a lot.They really need to make a sequel or two to this fine, outstanding action-fest. Charlie Wax is easily on Travolta's top 3 characters, and the film itself was just a fun and refreshing action movie that doesn't have a lot of CG or digital effects (CG isn't bad, but in an action movie you shouldn't need a lot).4.5/5 Stars

The main Uncharted trilogy is easily the greatest video game trilogy of all time so far, and always will be one of the best. The games literally play out like interactive adventure blockbuster movies, and the experience is one-of-a-kind. We're given a slew of incredible characters, truly memorable writing in the story and dialogue, and ground-breaking graphics.In Uncharted: Drake's Fortune, we're introduced to Nathan Drake, a treasure hunter who is searching for his long lost ancestor, Sir Francis Drake, who supposedly came across the lost city of El Dorado, after finding his coffin empty at sea. So, embarking on a quest to find El Dorado, Nate teams up with his life-long friend Victor Sullivan and a reporter named Elena Fisher, who just can never keep her nose out of trouble.In Uncharted 2: Among Thieves, Nate discovers that Marco Polo found the ancient city of Shambala, or as some call it Shangri-La. Once again, Nate embarks on a quest to find a lost city, but this time, he has something far greater to be aware (and afraid) of. The war criminal Zoran Lazarevic, former Soviet intelligence, is also searching for the fabled city, and that an old friend of Nate's is working for him. Fighting through waves of mercenaries with tanks, a helicopter and battling on a train, Nate soon discovers that some treasures are never meant to be discovered.The Uncharted saga is one of the most well-written and created stories of all time, not just in video gaming. If they adapted Drake's Fortune into a movie with a great director and writer(s) attached, it could and would be able to match both the Indiana Jones saga and The Hobbit/Lord of the Rings sagas, for being creative, complex, focused and well-realized. In terms of gameplay, the first game does have a few bugs that are annoying, but do not take away from the great experience, as for a game that was released in 2007, it was and is highly impressive.

The World's End is easily the best comedy I have ever seen. When five friends get back together after twenty years apart, they return to their hometown of Newton Haven to do The Golden Mile; 12 pubs, 60 pints. But when they return, they begin to realize changes, and soon discover that their home has become something else, and that the people they once knew are something else as well...Edgar Wright has truly crafted the greatest comedic trilogy on the planet with the Cornetto films. First, we got Shaun of the Dead; a romantic comedy with gory zombie violence. Then, we had a buddy cop comedy with Michael Bay-esque action sequences. Now, we have The World's End; a classical alien invasion movie, with a comedic King Arthur at the center. But, in comparison to the first two, I wouldn't say World's End is better or worse because, it is the end. The World's End, like Wright said, "Is a thematic wrap-up." We've followed these style of characters and the comedic rolls through the years, and we get to see them off in a blaze of glory (literally). Simon Pegg and Nick Frost, though, were easily at their best, with Frost sometimes stealing the show in this installment. The soundtrack was fun, really helping fill the screen with intensity and energy. Surprisingly, the action sequences are among the best I've seen for any movie, with stunts coordinated by Brad Allen from Jackie Chan's martial arts team. Even the visual effects were top-notch, especially when we get to see the robots as robots.In the end, The World's End really is the perfect send-off for fans and watchers of the Cornetto trilogy. And for those just jumping into The World's End, I suggest watching the first two beforehand because, that way, you can appreciate this one more (if you like Wright's style of dry, witty humor). Honestly, I've never felt better after leaving a movie at the theater; The World's End really shows the importance of friendship, and why we love movies in the first place.5/5 Stars*****

Gears of War 2 is a truly remarkable and epic game that takes the Gears saga to a more emotional and heartfelt level of intensity and awe. So, in order to convey the grand scope and scale of the second installment, Epic Games recruited Steve Jablonsky (Transformers, Battleship) to score this sequel, and the others from then on. With Gears of War 2, Jablonsky offers a sort-of quiet patriotism to the grandeur of the game. This is very well noticed in the main theme, "Armored Prayer" which plays in the sequence where COG officially goes to war, leaving the city of Jacinto. Now, while I love Jablonsky's work, being able to convey electronics and orchestral sounds/choir together, but this score in particular was missing a bit of emotion, and at times even, it would get slightly repetitive. Now, this isn't necessarily a bad thing, but here, if they repeated a more emotional theme with the intense pounding of drums and trumpets, and the haunting choir in the background, this would have easily been the best video game score of the year.So, in the end, it's a must-own for anyone who likes Steve Jablonsky or video game music, but for those who also like movie scores or instrumental music, listen to samples and clips first, because some may be turned off by this heavy, hard-hitting soundtrack.4/5 Stars****

Battleship, directed by Peter Berg (The Kingdom, Friday Night Lights), gives us a sci-fi action blockbuster about our attempt to contact extra-terrestrials through the use of a giant, super-powered satellite. These alien creatures respond, but when one of their ships is accidentally destroyed when it flies into a satellite, they set up their ships and begin the offensive, believing this to be an act of war.Battleship was far from great, but it was a fun, entertaining blockbuster that was better than both Transformers sequels. Steve Jablonsky, who scored the Transformers trilogy, returns to the action blockbuster with Battleship, which is (in my opinion) better. Now, Transformers does have memorable themes, but Battleship is a very unique listening experience. He blends both orchestral sounds and electronics to shape the atmosphere of the film. Some of the sounds in the score are actually sounds made by the alien ships in film, too. What is really impressive, though, is how these random sounds and electronics come together so fluidly, and with rhythm. My favorite track on the disc by FAR is #10, Shredders. It is both intense, and haunting with the deep bass and electronics.Battleship is not for everyone, but I highly recommend it to those who love movie or video game scores, or someone who likes action-packed music.4/5 Stars****

The Raven, directed by James McTeigue (V for Vendetta) comes a fictional but somewhat accurate portrayal of Edgar Allan Poe, and of the time period when he spent his final days hunting a killer. No one really knows what happened to Poe the days before his death when he was reciting the name "Reynolds" over and over before his heart stopped. This movie offers one theory, and it's a very intriguing one.John Cusack plays Poe, a drunk who now sees his potential being wasted by the masses and a newspaper publisher, where some of his short stories get published. But when murders begin to happen as depicted in Poe's stories, a detective named Fields arrives to address the situation, and work with Poe to find the murderer.The Raven is, honestly, one of the best thrillers I've seen in a while. It doesn't rely on heavy visual effects, but still makes very good use of some CG (a shootout in the forest, and some nasty gore). McTeigue's directing is superb, I would even say slightly better than V for Vendetta (definitely more-so than his actionfest, Ninja Assassin). Cusack was surprisingly great as Poe, who was not necessarily the action-thriller hero you would expect, with the hero being Luke Evan's Fields, more-so. Evans was great, and while his character wasn't given a lot of background, he was still a likable and interesting character. Alice Eve was good as Poe's love interest in the film, who gets entangled in the game when she is kidnapped by the killer, giving Poe incentive to help. The musical score by Lucas Vidal was impressive, offering something that sounded like a haunting mix of Sherlock Holmes (Zimmer's score) and Knowing (Marco Beltrami). The cinematography was very good, being shot in impressive locations like Belgrade and Budapest. The script, while not award-winning, was very memorable and well-written. There were a few cheesy moments of dialogue during conversations between Brendan Gleeson's character and Cusack, but mainly the script was great at building the eerie atmosphere, and following through on a mystery that wasn't predictable.The Raven is one of the most underrated thrillers of all time, and it really should have done much better at the box office. I just hope this isn't the last time McTeigue does a period-piece thriller, because he would be great to adapt Dan Simmons's novel, Drood.

The Cabin in the Woods, directed by Drew Goddard, tells the story of five college students headed out to a remote cabin for spring break. Like most slasher/horror films, these teens begin to exhibit the standard clichÃ©s. But this is all a ruse; deep below the earth, a facility monitored and controlled by a secret organization watches the five from all angles, subjecting them to whatever horrors are released. Will these students survive long enough to uncover the mystery?Drew Goddard and Joss Whedon (creator of Firefly and Dollhouse) crafted a true horror gem with "Cabin," taking all the horror movie clichÃ©s and turning them on their heads. Goddard's direction really helps to create the foreboding and eerie atmosphere that is filled with terror, and laughs? That's right. Laughs, and a lot of them. Joss Whedon brings his creative genius with dry, witty humor to the big screen. And while the humor is absolutely hysterical (I died laughing a few times), the scares are there too. The script was cinematic gold. The characters were perfectly written, nothing ever felt rushed or cut-down, and it played out with such skill and admiration for a genre that had become crap, with what Whedon calls "torture porn" (aka, the Saw franchise, the Hostel films, etc.). The Cabin in the Woods is filled with gory violence and kills, too, but at least the film itself has a complex story and intelligent characters. The visual effects, surprisingly, were and still are top-notch for a low-budget film, combining CG and practical effects. The musical score by David Julyan (The Prestige, Insomnia) was superb, and the acting was great, especially Fran Kranz and Richard Jenkins, with Jenkins playing one of the engineers within The Facility.The Cabin in the Woods is easily one of the best horror films of all time not for re-inventing the slasher or what scares it had, but for the mind-bending and thoughtful story that was a homage to H.P. Lovecraft and all great horror films, their creatures and abominations. On a final note: Beware, movie-goer, for your understanding of Unicorns is wrong.5/5 Stars*****

Greg Edmonson, who previously scored the first Uncharted game, returns in even greater form in the sequel, Among Thieves. Blending an array of orchestral sounds, with East Asian sounds to help create the game's atmosphere and showcase the locations, Edmonson crafts a masterpiece of a score that I can compare only to some great scores with it setting such a high standard for video game music, with comparisons to Gladiator, Blood Diamond, and Raiders of the Lost Ark.With "Nate's Theme 2.0" there isn't much that's different from the first theme in Drake's Fortune, but the percussion is a little heavier. "Bustin' Chops" is a great action-packed piece, but it's the track that follows that is one of the most beautiful musical tracks of any movie or video game score. "Reunion," this track is the embodiment of greatness. The scene in the game when this track plays is more depressing than the track sounds, but the track itself is an emotional powerhouse. "Breaking and Entering" is another slow moving track that isn't really emotional, but helps to set a scene, as if it were painting a picture of obstacles to come.I'll stop there with track analyses, but what I don't care about with the CD release, is why the bonus tracks (that weren't in the digital release) are out of order. Because technically, the track "The Heist" would take place before "Bustin' Chops," and the track "Tunnel Vision" comes before "Train Wrecked." It just bugged me a bit, because when you listen to them in order with the bonus tracks it does sound better. Either way, this score is a must-own for anyone who listens to instrumental/classical music, or video game/movie scores. Edmonson is a true musical genius

The Thing is not a remake, but a prequel to John Carpenter's cult classic of the same name, where an alien being crash-lands on Earth after a supposed malfunction in its ship. The year is 1982, and a Norwegian team stationed in Antarctica have just uncovered the ship, and the frozen occupant. Recruiting the help of paleontologist Kate Lloyd, the financier of the discovery Dr. Sander Halvorson and his assistant Adam Finch then escort her to the dig site. But after they recover the creature and celebrate, things take a turn for the worst when the being awakens after thawing out, and begins killing the crew one by one. But the Thing doesn't just kill them, it assimilates them, becoming them. So, how do you fight something you can't see?Directed by Dutch filmmaker Matthijs van Heijningen, Jr., The Thing is a surprisingly well-made prequel that does the original justice, but not in the best way possible. If this prequel wanted to really define the greatness behind The Thing, it would have been longer, taken different twists and turns, but ultimately end at the same conclusion. Instead, it plays out a lot like the original film. When I mean a lot, I mean some of the scenes play out almost exactly like they did in the original, like when the Thing attacks the group after they try to help one of their own, revealing itself to be the injured party. Now while this isn't bad, it still would have been better if they did something more original. The acting was superb all-around, especially the slight show-stealing Lars, played by Jorgen Langhelle. The visual effects were overall good, having some truly award-worthy effects, and some run-of-the-mill effects that were alright, but kept the effects from ranking along side films with some other great CG the same year (Cowboys & Aliens, Real Steel, and Super 8). Though the scene that deserved an award just for the awe-inspiring feeling it produced was the shots of the alien craft starting-up. The effects were and still are some of the best, which is kind of surprising for a $35 million movie. The script was good, nothing award-worthy but living up to the original, and Marco Beltrami's score was just great. Keeping the same theme (which appears in the end credits) from the original, Beltrami creates a haunting and eerie sound-scape that is very memorable and spine-tingling.Honestly, I really don't get why this movie bombed at the box office. Was it because of the theatrical trailer? Did people actually listen to the critics when the movie came out? If so, that's sad. If you have seen the original or like science fiction/thrillers, get this. I'm not sure that there are many movies that can or have had a prequel treatment that's as good as this.4/5 Stars****

I never would have thought Brian Tyler to score an Assassin's Creed game, but boy was I surprised when I listened to his soundtrack. Tyler is a very good composer, having done big blockbuster films like Iron Man 3, Timeline, Fast Five and the upcoming Thor: The Dark World, but he's also done a couple video game scores, his best being Modern Warfare 3, which was good but not great. Here, Tyler continues the theme for AC with a Pirates sound similar to that of Klaus Badelt in Pirates of the Caribbean, but with a little more creativity. I personally love the second track the most (Pyrates Beware), which sounds incredibly epic and tense. While I don't think Tyler is as masterful as Lorne Balfe or Jesper Kyd, he proves himself to know source material in this great addition to the Assassin's Creed saga.My own personal problem (previously addressed with the Assassin's Creed Revelations soundtrack) is the availability. I will not purchase an only mp3 score, having no use for mp3 downloads. I love collecting CD's and having the physical copy there for my stereo, to listen to in the car on the way to school or work, and then to look at the phenomenal artwork and the credits, the people who made this score possible. So, while this is a truly great soundtrack, I won't waste my money on something I don't use.

These replaced the straw for my 32oz tumbler that I use all the time. The straws get fairly disgusting after a short while, even with regular washing. You have to really clean in the straw. I now have several options for replacements, as well as spares if one is being washed. They fit perfectly and look like they'll hold up nicely.

This book was a classic story of love and miscommunication. While it didn't reinvent the wheel, it was an enjoyable read.Jared and Sheridan were well-developed characters. Sheridan had a lot of heart and soul behind her, some of which you didn't really learn about till later in the story, just as Jared was finding out. Jared is a classic football star, preoccupied by women throwing themselves at him, until he finds himself knocked flat on his a$$ by Sheridan. He's immediately smitten and they get thrown into a whirlwind fake marriage...that doesn't stay fake for long. While they have zero communication skills (and thus, several cases of mistaken understanding), they quickly fall in love and have to figure out how to make it last forever.The plot was fun, the characters well written. There are two books that follow this one, but I don't know if I'll be reading them. I didn't feel much of a connection to Willow and Nick, the main characters in the next book. Still, this one was a good read, well worth my time.

I've used this lotion for years and I've loved it for just as long.I initially tried it for a brand new tattoo. Truly fragrance-free, sensitive-skin lotion is harder to come by than most people think. There are a thousand of them on the market, but there's always a bit of something irritating in it. This is the one I tried and it's absolutely perfect. No fragrance whatsoever. The actual lotion is very light and not at all greasy.It worked great on my tattoo. I use it on my face regularly. It's safe to use on any part of your body without working about it being irritating.I'll definitely continue using it in the future.

I've been using the regular Biore strips for years and I've always liked them. They keep my nose soft and remove dirt and grime that have attached itself to my face, but I've never really been dependent on them. Really, I use them only when I remember or when I notice some out of control blackheads. They've definitely never left my face less greasy (unfortunately).I've read a lot about the power of charcoal and have used it in several different mediums, so I was excited to try out this one. These strips work exactly the same as the regular Biore strips. I didn't notice a difference in my skin between the regular ones and the charcoal ones. They did leave behind a black residue, which scrubbed right off. My nose is still soft and clean.While I didn't notice a difference, I think I'll continue using these over the others for a while. The fact that charcoal has been proven good for ridding the body of toxins makes me want to continue using them for this reason only. Who knows if it makes an actual difference, but I like the idea that it does.

Taste-wise, I like this powder a lot. It tastes like basic chocolate, and I don't find it to be a very fake flavor. It doesn't taste overly chemical-ly. It mixes great with milk in order to make awesome smoothies. It mixes smooth every time (chunky protein powder ruins everything!).As far as the actual healthy properties of this powder go, it's not so great. If you go about it without reading the nutritional facts, you'll be fine. But once you start reading the label and realizing that it doesn't 100% add up...you may feel differently. I know it's jam packed with fake chemicals, most likely, so I'm hesitant to buy it again in the future. It's low carb, so that's awesome. But the chemical additives ruin it for me.I'd consider buying it again in the future, because of the taste alone, but if I can find a different, healthier alternative, that's definitely what I'll be buying next time around.

While this book sounds a little shallow on the outside, once you start reading it, you'll quickly learn that the author knows her stuff.I would recommend this book for any older teen or 20-something that wants to live a financially-healthy life. As one of those 20-somethings, I know how easy it is to feel like you have your $h*t together. Unfortunately, as time goes on, situations pop up, and you feel like you know less and less. It seems really simple at first, but then you have to learn how to buy your first house, start a retirement account, build a savings account and an emergency fund, invest some of your money, fight for a promotion and raise. It's overwhelming at best.That's where the author comes in. She talks about all of these subjects in a very blunt, real, informative way. She doesn't talk down to you. She doesn't expect you to know the terms, and so she explains them. And my favorite part: she swears throughout. I'm always a sucker for some good, well-placed profanity.Anyway, this book is a lot more comprehensive than you might expect. Chapters include:* Stop Smiling and Nodding: Embrace the Rich B!tch Attitude* Hello, It's a Marathon AND a Sprint: Get a Grip on Your Future* Your New LBD: Create a Little Budget Diary That Fits YOU* Put a Roof on it: Home is Where Your Stuff is* Eat, Pray, Drive: Transportation, Food, Insurance, and Other Essential Expenses* Get That Monkey Off Your Back: Paying Down Debt* Lock It Up: Saving Sucks, but So Does Being Broke* Work It, Bitches: Put Your Career in Overdrive* Aging Gracefully: You Will Get Older--Do it in Style* Make it Grow, Baby, Grow: Investing is Just Not That Serious* Being Under, Over, and on Top of "The Man": Rich B!tches in a Man's World* Bringing it Home: Your Life is Your BusinessI'll definitely be interested in reading further books from this author in the future.

I think this case had a really great concept behind it, but the execution just isn't what I was hoping. I think it would be great when I go out and do things (where I might not have a charger readily available), but not for every day use.First off, the charging cable it comes with is WAY too short. I haven't looked around to see if I could get another with the same connectors that is longer, and I'm sure I could, but the fact that it comes with a tiny cable is just ridiculous to me.The case seems rather flimsy. The top "bumper" is not very tall, so I think if I were to drop my phone (which happens more often than I'd like to admit), it would shatter the screen. There is little to no protection in this case. The plastic seems like it's rather weak, like it could fall apart with just a little usage.I find the on button on the back of the battery pack to be too easy to press.For reasons unknown, I cannot get this case to charge when it is plugged in to the computer. It works great when connected to the wall outlet, though.I do think the case is rather aesthetically pleasing. It looks nice, but needs a little more work done before it is something that I use on a regular basis.All in all, the case is just okay. I'll be keeping it and using it occasionally, when I think the battery pack will come in handy, but I don't think I'll be using it on a regular basis. It's just too chancy when it comes to protecting my phone.**Note: I was provided this item at no cost in exchange for an honest review.

I've seen more and more products lately that contain charcoal and I've been itching to try them. When the opportunity arrived to try this particular bar, I jumped at the chance. I've used Biore products off and on my whole life, but never really with any regularity. I think I'll be using this bar for a long time.First off, the scent was pleasing, if a bit surprising. Once I looked carefully at the ingredients, I located the source: peppermint oil. The smell was pleasant, but I wasn't really prepared for the little bit of eye burning that came with it. I know this is common with peppermint oil, so it didn't really shock me, but I wasn't expecting it. There's no warning on the box about keeping it away from your eyes, which really did surprise me. There probably should be. Some people are more sensitive to the peppermint oil than others.I really do love the feeling this bar leaves behind. I keeps my face soft. Even on days when I forget to moisturize, I don't get a dry, flaky face. Instead, it stays soft and silky all day, which is SO nice. I am also noticeably less greasy, which I'm very appreciative of. I haven't noticed a huge difference in pores or blackheads, but the difference it makes in my skin alone is well worth it.

When you think "desk fan," you think of something tiny and weak, but better than nothing on a hot day.This fan beat out expectations in a big way.It's actually quite well made. It's fairly sturdy plastic that seems like it will hold up for quite some time. I'm not so worried about breaking it, so it can be moved around my desk as necessary.It puts out quite a good amount of air circulation. There are different speeds available and the highest is quite strong. You don't have to be sitting right up close to it for it to be effective.While it does come with the USB plug, it also comes with a regular AC adaptor, which I think would work better. I'll be using the AC adaptor more regularly, I think.All in all, I was very pleasantly surprised by the fine quality of this fan. It's not some cheap piece of plastic you'll have to replace time after time, which is refreshing.

While the whole "stepbrother taboo" didn't originally attract me to the book, it was the plot. I'm a sucker for a couple who hates each other and must learn to tolerate each other, only to fall completely in love.Brynn and Nate have great chemistry. I wasn't so sure at first because she spent a lot of time basically mooning over him. It was very naive and innocent and it honestly kind of drove me nuts. But that quickly went away as they had to interact. As they began to actually learn to be friends, I started to understand the attraction. They were a great pair.From the beginning, the relationship between Brynn's mother and Nate's father is obviously going to end in flames. When it finally did, I felt like it was a bit rushed. Suddenly all these things were happening at the end, a sort of snowball effect. The end of their relationship, as well as the dark moments of Brynn and Nate's relationship, all seemed to fly by as you approached the end. I wish it had gone by a little slower, maybe.As far as the whole "stepbrother taboo" thing goes, I just don't get it. It shouldn't even be a taboo. The parties are not related by blood. They didn't grow up together. They're literally meeting each other as adults and learning how to be family, as well as more. Doesn't seem very taboo to me.All in all, though, I enjoyed the book. I'll be picking up more from this author in the future.

A HORRIBLE belt that was not worth the money. Within 6 months, the face of the belt near the buckle had worn away. Happened on both the black and the brown sides. Just threw it in the trash. Good riddance!

"Parables of Jesus" is a congenial and loving attempt to provide the cultural context for the parables of Jesus  -- which (truth be told) can be enigmatic. But they are always pithy. Jesus didn't elaborate or explain his meaning. Unlike this illuminating yet wordy video.Jesus did not give motivations to the priest and Levite who passed by wounded man on the way to Jericho. But our narrator does. Jesus dispenses with the Prodigal Son's waywardness in a few words: "he squandered his inheritance on a life of dissipation."  But the video  shows him as a rube being cheated by greedy locals and expands at length on his lavish parties. Jesus tells us how a man who found a pearl of great price sold everything he had. The DVD goes into detail about his negotiations with the seller, and his selling off of his paintings, pottery and furnishings.Maybe this is carping. There are valuable insights. For instance, the Prodigal Son's demand of half of his father's estate was equivalent to wishing the old man dead. Indeed, the DVD has the effect of taming Jesus's parables -- of reducing them to lovely life lessons. But the parables are as radical in our day as they were in his. Selling everything you have was meant literally, not spiritualized into doing whatever it took to get into heaven. Try replacing the despised Samaritan with a Taliban or ISIS fighter and see how "sweet" the story really is. And the tale of the dishonest steward was a call to Jesus's disciples to be as clever and creative in their pursuit of the Kingdom as the crooked are in pursuit of patrons."Parables of Jesus" is well-meaning and provides easy lessons for committed Christians. But mature Christians who seek more than comfortable nostrums would be advised to look elsewhere.

I adored "Eats, Shoots and Leaves," Truss's fun and educational tour through the misuse of punctuation -- but only for the noblest of reasons: to understand its proper usage. "Talk to the Hand" promised to give the same treatment to rude or insensitive language. But I found it a bore. The humor was pale to the point of disappearance. And Truss's point -- that the linguistic lubricants of yore  (the 'thanks yous" and "pleases" of our forebears) were all but  extinct -- was lost on me. I agree that hearing polite speech from a corporate recording has none of the charm of a personal response, but her implication that human speech has devolved into a series of linked eff-words was overdrawn. There's no question that the public language of today has more than its share of words that were considered taboo fifty years ago. But Truss makes no allowance for the welcome loosening of many of society's former strictures. As the eclipse of the corset gave way for female organs to breathe, so has the loosening of language given many the ability to express themselves freely without feeling they were transgressing with every earthy expression or split infinitive. Despite the many encomia from literary giants gracing the back cover, I'd give this one a miss.

I stumbled upon this film while looking for ammo against those who see 9/11 as an inside job, perpetrated by the US government to get the public riled up for a war in Iraq. Using plenty of archival footage of the building of the WTC and the attacks, the film shows how the building was constructed, the decisions that went into its design  and the vulnerability that these gave it to attack from fuel-laden jets.The most affecting interview was with the architect who moved so  such of the building's structural support from the building's interior to its outside framework. His admirable desire to save weight led to his choice of two materials -- easily blown-off fireproofing and sheet rock rather than concrete walls -- that contributed to the weakening of the structure's steel trusses and effectively blocked access to emergency stairwells.As an introduction to the structural issues that caused the collapse of North and South towers, "Why the Towers Fell " is incomparable. Use it as your guide to understanding what really happened on 9/11, from the men who designed and built the towers.

Author and historian Barbara Tuchman gives us a dense, but interesting book in "March ofr Folloy." The best sections provide behind-the-scenes looks at the personalities and thought-processes behind two great convulsions in American history: the British reaction to colonial ferment in America, and our nation's entanglement in Vietnam.Tuchman portrays the aristocracy Britain as being wedded to its need to show strength against the colonies, informed  by an aristocratic preoccupation with keeping the colonies in their place.She also shows how he colonists' insistence in being represented in Parliament made so little sense: the average British citizen was not represented in Parliament either! By its thick-headed and ham-handed actions, the British government all but guaranteed that America would break away. It's fascinating to imagine what might have happened to America's hopes for independence had the King and his court been ruled by the wise, rather than the rash.The Vietnam conflict was informed by a need for the US to project post-WWII strength against the newly ascendant Communist sphere. But the US never grasped that the Vietnamese would see  us as just another white colonizing power like the French. While we had legitimate concerns about the ease with which communism was spreading in the 1940s and 1950s, we were hamstrung by our politician's dread of being the ones to have "lost" another county to communism. That gave free hand to absolutist commie-haters, and made it impossible to kind of flexible approach that might have allowed us to deal with the subtleties of that conflict.Tuchman's take on the Trojan war was kind of silly, though. It's one thing to dissect history, and another to analyze fiction as though it were history.
These pub glasses are strong and hefty, and can handle the brutal punishment of being muddled for mojitos. Love 'em!
OITNB is a subtly hilarious take on life in a federal women's prison with all its sexual and racial tension, pettiness and incompetence. A great adaptation of a fine book.

This is not the most powerful vac out there, but it does the job. It is super light and has the only two attachments a small home vac need: a floor head and crevise tool. And the heads renmove easily, making the vac into a had vac. Combine these features with an easy-to-hang design, and you habve the perfect small apartment vaccuum.It's not vac to easily scour deep crevices, like those between old floor boards, but did I mention the popcorn kernel test? The vac picks up large kernels, with just a twist of the handle needed to allow the head to pass over the kernel. Not bad for 20 bucks!

There is no book that can satisfy the obsessive search for details that locals crave about the Boston Marathon bombings. But "Long Mile Home" is a start.Focusing mainly on 5 individuals -- Heather Abbot, wounded at the Forum Restaurant;  Krystal Campbell, killed by the first blast; race director Dick McGillivray; Mass General surgeon Dr. David King; and police officer Shana Cottone-- authors Helman and Russell take us from the preparation for the marathon through the bombing to the lives of the participants and their families as they struggle to move forward.For a series of events that took place over only 5 days -- from the running of the Marathon on Monday, April 15, 2013 to the capture of the last Tsarnaev brother on Friday the 19th -- there is a vast expanse of ground to cover -- especially for Bostonians who were glued to the media for the whole time, who know the area and who have played the events over and over in their minds. Helman and Russell did a good job of digging up the tangled backstory of the Tsarnaevs, who fled Russia's fractured economy and dirty politics for a better chance in the US. We get sketches of each of the book's main subjects, including Krystal Campbell, the promising young women who is no longer available to speak for herself. But 300 pages is hardly enough room to cover every aspects of a story that directly drew so many into its web. The week included the bombings themselves, the frenzied attempt of bystanders and first responders to save lives, the heroics in local surgical suites, law enforcement's search for clues, a presidential visit to the wounded, a dead cop at MIT, a car hijacking followed by a wild firefight in Watertown, the historic shutdown of the Boston area, followed by the apprehension of the main suspect. Given the breadth of the task, the authors can't be faulted for not including every detail.But they include some fascinating glimpses behind the scenes. Of Watertown's David Henneberry, obsessive about caring for his boat, upset that two of the paint rollers he used to guard the craft from scratches, were inexplicably on the ground. Of police called to a shootout, arriving from all directions and firing towards each other. Of the mental calculations of Danny, carjacked by the Tsarnaevs, as he tried to escape. Of the frustrations obstacles and possible mental illness that might have Tamerlan to contemplate striking out at America.  Of the painful decision to amputate the healthy portion of an injured leg in order to improve mobility later.If I have one critique, it's that the book often pulls back from the more horrifying or intriguing details. You won't find mention, for instance, of the gruesome exposure of Jeff Bauman's tibia that was splashed over TV screens nationwide. Krystal's last moments, captured on film from a local building, are shrouded in gauze and indirection. Victims Martin Richard and Lu Lingzi get scant mention. You won't hear about the red lasers from sniper rifles dancing of Dzhokar Tsarnaev's head and body as he balanced on the side of the boat he had made his hiding place. You won't find out who yanked him off the boat or how. There is no mention of the raft of conspiracy theories that fouled the internet after the bombing. This reticence might make sense from the perspective of a local journalist, who needs to stay on the good side of the public and of tastefulness. But for those steeped in the basics of the case, and are familiar with its images, there was surprisingly little new to learn.But no matter. Journalism being the first draft of history, "Long Mile Home" lays the groundwork for future works of more depth and detail. It sets down a marker for those who would spin wild tales of government incompetence or nefarious misdirection. And it makes clear that Bostonians are four-square solid behind the victims of the bombing, committed to honoring their sacrifice and protecting their privacy, and uninterested in having their local tragedy turned into fodder for curiosity seekers and conspiracy freaks. There is much, much more to say about the Boston Marathon bombings -- including whether the Watertown search was well-executed and how uncoordinated fire nearly cost the lives of three Boston area cops. But that is for another day. Let the focus for today be on those who suffered and on their epic journey to regain some measure of peace and wholeness.For all who suffer and struggle, and in memory of Krystal, Lu, Martin and Sean.

Wes Anderson has made a few great films (Whale and Squid, Moonrise Kingdom) and some real sweet stinkers. IMHO, neither audiences nor actors seem to understand which is which -- and what sometimes makes his films great to watch. The Grand Hotel Budapest Hotel is not exactly a stinker, but tries to be so much more than its writing and direction allow. Its all-star cast is split between those trying to make every moment grandly ironic (Ralph Fiennes in particular) and those just playing it straight. Fiennes's every line is delivered as though he expects  it to reverberate with Comedic Greatness. Instead, he brought so much attention to his delivery that the story and his character were often lost in the dazzle. The movie's visuals also try too hard -- the girl with a Mexico-shapped birthmark (ha!); the out-of-place Pakistani lobby boy with his title writ large on his cap (ho!), the funicular trundling up to the hotel (hee!). These are presented with so much comedic "ta-da!" that they lose any chance of being charming.Many will love "The Grand Budapest Hotel," not becuase it's all that funny or great, but because they know they are supposed to. Expect the knowing laughter to be loudest at the start, and taper off as the movie winds down.

Nathaniel Philbrick has done it again, with "Bunker Hill," the story of the beginnings of the American Revolution. With occasional forays into the French and Indian War of the 1750s and other pre-Revolutionary events, Philbrick covers the period between the Boston Tea Party in 1770, and the Battle of Bunker Hill in 1775. That gives a chance to cover a wide swath of well-known US history, including the Battles of Lexington and Concord, the Boston Massacre, and the Tea, Stamp and Intolerable Acts  -- all of which flames up hottest in my little corner of the world, Boston, MA. But Philbrick doesn't relay dry historical facts. He brings to life the great personalities of the time  -- firebrand Sam Adams and his cooler cousin John, a barely-controlled George Washington, dandified John Hancock, bewildered General Gage and his more combative replacement General Howe -- as well as many lesser-known (and often mythologized) figures of the period. Paul Revere gets scant attention, presumably because his small though critical role has been covered adequately elsewhere, notably in David Hackett Fisher's "Paul Revere's Ride."  But Philbrick's lively prose and keen eye for the telling detail make history jump off the page, letting the reader visualize events in exciting and often terrifying colors. Concord and Lexington come to life vividly, and you experience every emotion, from the horror at seeing Concord "burn" (a house accidentally caught fire while the Brits were burning caissons, and they helped put out the blaze), to the white hot fury after the Regulars opened up on them at the North Bridge, to the patriot's confusion after they crossed the Bridge and realized the import of their actions, to the scandalous hatchet slaying of a wounded Regular, to the wild and lethal chase back to Boston that left nearly as many patriots dead as their British prey.But if there's one tragic hero in the book, it's the relatively little known Doctor Joseph Warren. A whirlwind with a busy medical practice, he managed to be a mover and shaker in colonial Boston and served on the Commitee of Correspondence whish kept the flame of resistance alive in Massachusetts . A young widower (he was only 34 in 1775) he may also have been active in the boudoir as well. Philbrick introduces us to his public amour, Mercy Scollay, and to the teenage "incognita pregans" that he and his friends kept under wraps. When the Battle at Bunker Hill finally got under way, Warren wanted to be nowhere but in the thick of the fight, and there he died, rather brutally as it turns out.Philbrick does not insult the reader by giving a sanitized version of history. There are heroics aplenty, of course, as doughty New Englanders (with some more timid exceptions) built in one night a breastworks right in the teeth of the British Navy. And the effort to build pre-fabricated defense on Dorchester Heights was not only a feat of daring, but one of well-thought-out engineering and military prowess. Once on the Heights, the Patriots, by then led by Washington, could not only bombard the besieged city of Boston, but the British fleet that protected the town and its community of British troops and Tories. But for every deed of valor, there were follies aplenty. Building on Breed's Hill (the actual site of much of the fighting) was not as smart as building on nearby, taller Bunker Hill. And there was no unified command structure during the battles. Though this might have helped the Patriots, as the Brits might have been confused by the uncoordinated (and therefore unpredictable) attacks they had to withstand. And there was plenty of cowardice as well, with leery patriots leaving the battle field prior to the battle and failing to reinforce it when needed. At the end of the day, however, the British had suffered nearly 50% casualties. Enough to make them realize that they were not up against a gaggle of bumbling farmers, but with a force to be reckoned with.History, as taught in school and echoed in patriotic speeches, seems about inevitable events. But "Bunker Hill" will show that great events, even those with storied histories, depend on the cumulative actions of men of determination and action, and that chance -- a changing wind that brings the sound of digging to an alert officer, the happenstance of a general reluctant to fight -- can play large roles as well."Bunker Hill" is a masterful work of history that expertly threads the needle between hagiographic nonsense and hypercritical carping. It's a treasure!

Jessie Crockett's "Drizzled with Death" follows in the footsteps of her marvelous "Live Free or Die" by thrusting rural New Hampshire folks into the very maw of death and peril. Well, one of them anyway. The unfortunate Alanza Speedwell is a cranky, land-razing so-and-so who mysteriously lands face-first into a stack of flapjacks at a pancake eating competition. Dani Green, the young and unmarried daughter of a local maple sugaring family, is appalled at the death, not only for Alanza's sake, but because it might implicate her family's maple syrup as poisonous and put her folks out of business. She needs to find the killer, and fast!Complicating matters is the escape of a truck load of zoo animals, which (aside from providing some comic relief) pop up at all the wrong times and places. Not to mention the human fauna-- which includes a skeptical (but ripplingly handsome!) fish and game official, a lovelorn, New Age mom, a peekaboo mountain lion,  a roadkill taxidermist and enough midnight skulking about to fill a bookcase of Peyton Place novellas."Drizzled with Death" grabs you like a walk in the New Hampshire woods -- starting out as ordinary until each leaf works its magic to mesmerize you. Jessie's women are as scrappy and ornery as her men are old-timey and blustery, making for a combustible mix of chase and rejection that contrasts with the book's bucolic setting. Jessie's New England  setting--with its sugar sheds, Granite-State-shape bottles, wood stoves and maple-topped hills--makes for a wonderful backdrop to Dani's derring-do. The north country's foliage-covered knobs and dales are beautiful to look at, but they shield mysteries and perils beneath their leafy boughs!Expect a thick outpouring  of lovers' misunderstandings and suspects galore. And I bet you won't know whodunnit until Jessie reveals the truth! "Drizzled with Death" is a fun, suspenseful read, seasoned with Jessie's trademark wit, tight plotting and memorable characters.

I wish that the furor over Reza Aslan's book, "Zealot," had never occurred. The outage over a Mulim writing a book about Jesus was a huge distraction, and set up the kind of phony battle lines that our culture is famous for. On one side, the conservative and Islamophobes who hated the book on principle because of its author's religious identity. On the other, the atheists and the kind of reflexive liberals who support whatever their enemies hate. In the middle are those like me who hope to read the book on its own merits.And while those merits are well-deserved, they are too often shaky.The main thesis of Zealot is that Jesus of Nazareth was very much a person of his own era. Like many others in his day, he was antagonistic to the economic inequities that were becoming more pronounced in first-century Galilee. Like many others, he looked upon the Roman occupiers as signs of evil times in Israel. Aslan wants us to believe that Jesus, while not an armed rebel leader, was a Jewish nationalist bent on removing the Romans fro m Israel. It's this thesis that, In the end, he fails to prove.Along the way, however, Aslan treats us to many aspects of 1st century life that are generally unknown to casual believers, and which are worthwhile keeping in the mix when we try to understand Jesus and his times. He will also introduce readers to aspects of New Testament scholarship and history that are shocking to the lay worshipper, yet are (for the most part) well established among non-fundamentalist scholars. While he has a tendency to embrace the most shocking scholarly hypotheses  (no Joseph!) and accepts or rejects the historicity of certain gospel traditions in his own unique manner, his opinions are not out of line with what many scholars say about Jesus and the first century world.In the first century, the ancient subsistence farming economy was breaking down under the pressure of increased taxation from the Romans. Small shareholders found it increasingly difficult to  maintain themselves in an economy where 50% of their earnings were siphoned off to the Romans, to local landowners to pay off debts, or to the Temple treasury in Jerusalem. Add to this the local political instability. When kings like Herod the Great were in power, they hired lavishly from the local peasantry to build and to decorate their new cities. When kings died or were overthrown in revolts, these artisans and other workers were out of work, unable to return to failed farms and unable to find new work.Aslan does a nice job of explaining the Temple economy, which required Jews to sacrifice animals (which cost money) in order to fulfill their religious observances. He does skate the edge of anti-Semitism by calling the priestly class, and their money changing network,  "moneygrubbers." But to the average illiterate and impoverished Jew, with no other recourse for forgiveness of sins and removal of impurity, the machinery of the Temple's sacrificial system was ruinous financially. It might well be that this led people like Jesus to wonder whether  it was also empty spiritually.Aslan tries hard to draw a straight line between the Jesus of the gospels and the various messiahs and rebels that sprouted up during this time period. He thinks that when Jesus asks his disciples whether they have swords (they produce two) this makes him a bandit leader. He takes literally Jesus's statement that he came not to bring peace, but the sword. He claims that "Render under to Caesar" was a political statement about returning the land to Jewish ownership. And he makes too much of the short, violent scuffle in Gethsemane when Jesus was arrested. Yet though it's doubtful that Jesus welcomed the Romans into Israel, there is a great deal of subtlety here that Aslan does not bring up. For instance, Jesus's command to turn the other cheek is hardly the kind of advice a Rome-hater would proffer. And neither is his advice to walk two miles with the soldier who pressed him to carry a load for one mile. If Jesus wanted Rome to go, it was God who would make that happen. And that is a critical difference between Messiah Jesus and all the other messiahs of his age.Aslan is correct in his statements that Jesus foresaw a reversal of fortune in the near future. (Read Luke's "Magnificat" if you want to get an idea of how radical was early Christianity!) Jesus saw the Twelve disciples as judges who would rule over the twelve tribes of Israel. He saw himself as the Son of Man, a conquering figure drawn from the Bible's eschatological tradition. Aslan is correct that Jesus offered a critique of the Temple system, at a time when the Temple leaders and Roman overlords were in uneasy alliance against rebels and others who would cause disturbances. And he is correct in seeing Jesus's cleansing of the Temple - with its direct physical action against the money changers - as the action that precipitated his arrest and death. Finally, he is completely on target by noting that crucifixion was a Roman punishment, not a Jewish one. It was reserved for political crimes - sedition, rebellion, treason and revolt.While Christians have complicated and overthought Jesus's teaching in order to make him seem too other-wordly,  Aslan has gone too far the other way, making him too ordinary. For Jesus to have been seen as a threat to Rome and the Temple did not require him to advocate physical violence against them. Given the cruel and suspicious times, it was enough that he was actively planning to rule Israel, after God intervened in history, in place of the Romans. An ethical teacher and self-styled prophet, whose healings taught the peasantry that God was on their side, didn't have to raise a finger or an army to seem like a threat to established power. Merely by publicly standing against them, rather than sinking into safety and anonymity, Jesus drew too much public attention to himself and had to be dealt with. Pilate's writing on Jesus's titulus -- "King of the Jews" -- was a cruel joke,  something that Aslan thinks the Romans, those spawners of satirists and bawdy poets, were incapable of.Though "Zealot" contains a great deal of scholarship, the book has serious faults. Aslan minimizes the range of opinion within biblical scholarship.  One scholar might reject the birth narratives as entirely spurious, while another finds some or much truth in them. Aslan, for instance, goes farther tha n most in suggesting that Joseph, Mary's betrothed and Jesus's step father, did not exist. He suggests that Mary was an unwed mother, which has some possible support in Jesus's opponents calling him "Son of Mary." But though this is a legitimate hypothesis, it's hardly the consensus of scholars. Aslan is also somewhat arbitrary in his rejection of gospel verses that he doesn't like. Gone are the trial before Pilate, the infancy narratives (Jesus was born in Nazareth) and even a synagogue in Jesus's hometown (though he later backtracks and suggests that there might have been a room devoted to the Torah). And he is maddenigly contradictory. The Jews of Jesus time were mostly illiterate, yet Jeses seems to have been familiar with Scripture, and his disciples enough so to immediately bring to mind that Jesus as being "zealous for the law" when he cleaned the Temple. Most unforgivably, though, for Aslan and his editors, he commits some serious errors of fact. He thinks the Sea of Galilee was salty, when it is an inland, fresh-water lake. He confuses James the son of Zebedee with James the brother of the Lord. He claims (in opposition to actual archeological finds) that Jesus was nailed through wrists (OK , so says the possibly-forged Shroud of Turin) and ankles, which don't have the same bone structure as wrists! And that Jesus  carried the crossbeam of the cross (most scholars agree on this) but that it was attached to an upright laid on the ground, which was then hoisted up into position. Though these errors not consequential to his thesis about Jesus as a religiously-zealous Jewish nationalist, they do point to a rather slapdash creation for what should have been a very careful analysis.For all its shortcomings, Aslan's "Zealot" is not a bad book. It is certainly not an attack on Christianity or on the person of Jesus. And, taken with a grain of salt, it will expose readers to controversies about Jesus's life that scholars have been wrestling with for years. The book is the continuing effort, by people of goodwill twenty centuries after the death of Jesus, to make sense of a figure of immense complexity and seeming contradictions. I don't agree that  Aslan's Jesus is as "compelling, charismatic and praiseworthy" as the Christ worshipped in churches. But taken with an element of caution and skepticism, it does sketch a story of his times that is richer and more robust than the watered down Jesus of sermons and popular culture.

John Lewis, Georgia congressman, Civil Rights hero and last remaining speaker from the 1963 March on Washington, gives us the first installment of the story of his life and activism in "March:  Book One." Lewis grew up on a small farm in Georgia, and hoped to be a preacher. He preached to the chickens which were in his charge. But the zeitgeist of the era pulled him toward the new movements to obtain civil rights for blacks, putting him into contact with Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. and his efforts to use nonviolent means to open up busses and lunch counters to all customers. The story focuses on the sit ins held at various Montgomery, Alabama stores, and shows the raw hatred and intolerance that were the norm in the South prior to the 1960s. Lewis acquaints us with some of the lesser-known light of the movement, like lawyer Jim Lawson and Diane Nash and with the training that the protesters endured (being spit on, called names and physically threatened) to toughen themselves up and remain non-violent. Lewis is not shy about showing the divide between older blacks like Thurgood Marshall, who advocated a less confrontational approach to desegregation, and younger blacks who were impatient for justice.The book's black-and-white panels give he story a sense of age and weightiness. But it's the gravity of the subject and the living witness of John Lewis that give the book its punch and makes the story so compelling. This all really happened, within the memory of the author and of many readers."March: Book One"  is the story of a people on the move to reclaim their dignity and value in the context of a viciously racist America. I devoured the book and am dying for the sequel!

"Girl with No Name " tells the fascinating tale of Luz Marina, a 5-year-olf girl kidnapped from her Columbian home and left in the jungle to die. Somehow, with the help of a troupe of capuchin monkeys, she survives for several years before being found by a couple of game hunters and brought to the city. Her tale of survival is amazing. Almost too much so. When he eats bad seeds, an elderly monkey pushes her to a stream and forces her to drink water until she vomits up the poison. After that, she basically lives in a bucolic dream, eating what the monkeys eat, sleeping where they sleep and generally living in a child's paradise of colors, lights and never-ending play.About a third of the way through the book, I started doubting the story was real. It seemed incredible that a child could live so easily in a jungle in which indigenous people had to work so hard -- building fences and hunting and crafting containers, etc. The child never had  a toothache or cold or childhood disease. The perfect life.But it seems that a kidnapping, even in a dangerous country like Columbia would have made the news somewhere. Not to mention the mafia activity that the author claims she witnessed, including an explosion that destroyed a bridge and killed two boys. Not even the convent that sheltered her is asked to show records of her stay. And the ghostwriter who prepared the manuscript only relies on her own interior sense that Luz was telling the truth."The Girl with No Name" makes for an action-packed read. I read it voraciously to the end. But it would have been even more amazing had it not seemed like a fantastic story concocted by a former street kid to account for a real history she chose not to remember.

20 years on, this film is s till gripping. It's wonderful to see Johnny Depp and Leonardo DiCaprio in their youths. Leo is great playing Arnie, a retarded teenager with the irritating and dangerous habit of running off to climb the town water tower. Depp is Gilbert, Arnie's big brother and protector, who is stuck in his mid-western town. He lives with a grossly overweight mom, a former local beauty who started overeating when her husband died years before. Gilbert two sisters also share the home which is literally and figuratively weighted down with grief and inertia.WEGG is a sadly sweet story about trying to cope with the stigma of shame in a town that is losing its old time values. A Burger Barn is coming to town and a new food chain is luring customers away from the old family businesses. Yet there is pride and loyalty, Even scenes which might be funny -- the family car tilting to starboard with Mom in the passenger seat--are so loaded with pathos that you don't dare laugh. As is the family name. The Grapes have experienced so much tragedy and loss that their name doesn't even register as comical.A beautiful story of love, loyalty and dreams of escape.

Demi's "Joan of Arc" is filled with art inspired by medieval stained glass and by the Books  of Hours of famous dukes of the era. The plates are brightly colored, with splashes or silver and gild that shimmers off the page like those precious metals.
