But the story of Joan--she of the voices, the armor and the stake--paled by comparison. There are too many place names and personages for what seems to be a book aimed at young children. No mention is made of the scandal of Joan wearing men's clothing until the final scenes in which she is condemned for the practice.  There is no explanation of what a Dauphin is, or who the Burgundians were. And some might be put off by the book's Catholic slant. Finally, the map in back of the book names  cities not mentioned in the story, misses an opportunity to show Joan's movements, and (quelle horreure!) misspells "CompiÑgne," the place of Joan's capture.The story of Joan is one of courage and honor under pressure.  Her times were  complex, violent and strangely pious to many modern readers. Unfortunately, aside for the majestic artwork, Demi fails to find the right balance that conveys that complexity with deftness or a simplified and comprehensible version for younger readers.

I loved the Nation, Terry Pratchett's reflection on death, chance, the gods and beer. In the mid-19th century, after a tidal wave devastates a South Seas island, Mau (a local boy), Daphne (a marooned white English girl) and a motley assortment of islanders, must work together to rebuild their lives. Mau is assaulted by conscience-like voices of the grandfathers, ancestors who badger him about his failings.  Daphne is haunted by the death of her mother and baby brother. Naturally, these two opposites attract and help each other to survive the harshness of their new surroundings.Pratchett really gets into Mau's head. The boy is haunted by the demands of the ancestors and the gods, but in a rage that they did nothing to prevent the killer wave, or at least warn him about it. He comes to rely on himself, and his motto "Does not happen" -- his insistence that there is no fate, only the unwillingness of people to allow evil to happen. This stance takes Mau pretty far and goes a long way toward making a decent life for the islanders.The book relies non deliberate revisionism to drive home its point about the inherent worth of all people. While there is a great deal of casual racism by certain evil characters who come to the island, the place is a social paradise, where anyone who wishes to contribute can. The old world, with its gender, class and racial distinctions, was largely washed away with the tsumani. Still the islanders, especially Mau, struggle with the fact that "trouser men" (whites) have so much technology, while he and his people have so little. Is he unworthy? Cursed? Not smart enough? Pratchett's solution to this conundrum is clever and ennobling, if not historical.The Nation is another in a long line of Pratchett's brilliant and funny musings on the follies and saving graces of the human race. A delight from its drowned beginning to its bittersweet ending.

Whether you were a big fan of the Carl Sagan's "Cosmos" series when it came out in 1980, or like me, you somehow missed most of it, not realizing its brilliance, this DVD is a must-see. It's wonderful how well the productions values have stood up over time. Carl Sagan, with his corduroy jackets, hushpuppies, turtlenecks and trademark long 1970s-style hair, is the consummate narrator of his own writing. His thinking, put into sound by his clipped, bass tones, is clear and accessible without being patronizing. But the star of the show is really the Cosmos of the title, and the numerous scientists that brought it to our understanding. Johannes Kepler (who determine the planetary laws of motion), Christian Huygens (who, among many other things, determined that Saturn's rings did not touch the planet), Albert Einstein (whose laws of relativity bring order to the oddities of the very fast) and Hypatia of Alexandria (who ran the famous library there) all merit prolonged segments. Sagan also gives homage to the ancient Greeks and Ionians, the practical merchant people who gave science its first boost. Democritus (who posited the existence of atoms) and Aristarchus get big mentions. Great thinkers like Plato are derided as "mysticists," people who preferred thought to experiment and cogitation to involvement in the real world. Pythagoreans, entranced by supposed relationship of numbers and ratios, actually suppressed the existence of irrational numbers (like the square root of 2) because it did not fit their dogmatic schemes about the universe. With these, Carl is not pleased.Sagan uses Cosmos to teach about the universe, but also to proselytize for his strongly held scientific convictions. One, that the growth of the storehouse of knowledge is good, and that science is the best way to achieve it. Two, that human beings evolved from previous creatures. Three, that the universe is unimaginably large, complex, dangerous, yet comprehensible. Four, that the wonders and varieties within the natural world are accessible to the human mind, and they do not require the involvement of a creator. The minerals of Earth, for instance, are not created "de novo" where they are found. Instead, they were cooked in stellar furnaces, and spewed into intergalactic space when the stars blew up. Life on Earth began with amino acids, spewed into the seas by the work of lightning reacting with the primeval atmosphere of methane and ammonia. Self-replicating chemicals organized into more and more complex forms until life began, and continued evolving for billions of years. Sagan's Cosmos is one of randomness and accident leading to the enormously beautiful and complex structures - galaxies, stars, planets, life - that we experience today. For Sagan, these facts are a reason for wonder. Coming years before today's culture wars over creationism and evolution, there's a kind of innocence in his presentation. One wonders how such sentiments would play in today's polarized and science-phobic culture.The breadth of Cosmos is staggering. It covers the evolution of life, the possibility of life on other words, the lifecycle of stars, birth and death of planets, relativity and time dilation, the development of the elements, the variety of planets and moons in our solar system. Sagan does a bit a self-promotion for his own ideas as well. He helped develop informational disks that were attached to the Voyager spacecraft as they explored the outer solar system. He was instrumental in determining the surface temperature of Venus. He is a relentless promoter of planetary exploration and interstellar travel.But overall, Sagan is a teacher. The Cosmos series is serious science but is accessible to 6th graders. Sagan goes to great pains to make his language and great ideas understandable to those without science backgrounds. And his images -- a galaxy rising over the ocean of a distant planet, the brilliant explosion of a nova, the extinction of life on Earth by a bloated and dying sun - are as beautiful as they are educational. Sagan's prescience about global warming (the same thing that is cooking neighboring Venus) and his fears that humankind need not necessarily survive our use of atomic weapons, make him a clear-sighted and far-seeing observer of nature and of the way human beings manipulate it, perhaps beyond our ability to correct for our errors.Cosmos is a triumph on so many levels. It is a work of art, weaving together the strands of music, history, art and science into a brush that paints the universe in colors that are vivid and enticing. The shame is that Sagan, dying at age 62, had so little time to spread his ideas. What he would have made of the world wide web, of the Hubble telescope and of personal computers. But Cosmos lives as his greatest legacy. A work of passion and thoughtfulness that is unsurpassable.

Robert Clasby has taken playing with toy soldiers to the next level. He recreates battlefields by cutting and pasting images of re-enactors onto computer-enhanced photos of the battlefield itself. This technique yields a fairly accurate picture of how the battle might have appeared in its day. The work that went into these images is amazing. Clasby's use of photographic perspective is spot-on, with smaller figures receding into the background.  The text is terrific, and is interspersed with scenes of Gettysburg taken in the aftermath of the battle. But a couple of drawbacks limit the book's success. First, the posed images seem rather lifeless and clean. The soldiers are dressed in period gear, but they don't show much emotion. Ranks of fighting men calmly walk onto a battlefield in which their brethren are hammering away at each other. The dead are shown, but blood is kept to an absolute minimum. The second drawback is the lack of maps. You would have to understand the topography and compass directions of Gettysburg very well in order to match them with the excellent written descriptions that Clasby provides.Drawbacks aside, I find myself drawn back to the book. "Gettysburg: You are There" might not get you as close to the fire and furor of the battle of Gettysburg as you'd like, but it is a fascinating approach that could be successful, if the kinks were worked out.

Jeff Chu is well-positioned to explore the intersection of homosexuality and Christianity. As a gay man and the grandson of a Chinese Baptist minister, he understands each world from the inside. "Does Jesus Really Love Me?" is a sensitive and intelligent exploration of the many ways that American Christians have dealt with homosexuality. Chu himself lives the contradiction. In spite of having lost church relationships over his homosexuality (his mother cries for him every night) he has maintained a faith in God in spite of the wounds he carries.Chu's search runs the gamut of Christian reactions. He spends time with members of the Westboro Baptist Church, the most publicly and virulently anti-gay church. Amazingly, he comes to like them as people, even while rejecting their radical stance. He interviews the leadership of Exodus, the group best-known for trying to get gay Christians to stop being gay. At the other end of the spectrum, he speaks with Christians who have resolved the tensions between their faith life and their sex life by rejecting faith altogether. Chu is unique, I thinks, in allowing each of these groups and individuals to speak for themselves, even when what they say conflicts with his own experience.Aside from homosexuality, there are few topics that pit a fundamentalist understanding of the Scriptures against present-day lived reality. The variety of responses that Chu chronicles are both amazingly creative as well as heartbreaking. There is the couple (the husband is gay and knows it) who go on trying to have a married relationship even though the wife knows her husband is not physically attracted to her. They love and respect each other, even though something fundamentally important is missing from their lives. There is the gay man who has decided that he will lead a celibate life, even though that leaves him lonely and isolated. And many more. You have to admire how hard these folks want to love God, and who have contorted their lives drastically to allow them to feel worthy of that love. Chu has done a wonderful service by exposing the difficulty and stress that many deal with over the issue of their homosexuality. That he has done so without polemics and without judgment is an achievement in itself."Does Jesus Really Love Me?" is wonderfully-written and heartfelt look at an issues that will be with us for a long, long time.

The narrator, never named, is the classic 7-year-old unpopular kid. A loner who always has his head in a book, he is the sad kid who has no one come to his birthday party. After his parents financial fortunes wane, they take on borders, one of whom kills himself. This leads him to meet Lettie Hempstock, an 11-year-old who lives on a farm at the end of a lane, with her mother and grandmother. Soon, the trio's weird talent for knowing what people are doing and thinking becomes obvious. Soon the boy is whirled into a terrifying supernatural adventure that pits him against dark forces and personalities.Gaiman is an expert at putting helpless kids in harm's way. And of getting them out gain. But "The Ocean at the End of the Lane" is NOT a kid's book. It deals with marital infidelity, suicide, nudity, loneliness and terrifying supernatural forces. It IS, however, a wonderful read and brilliantly original, like most of Gaiman's work. He know now to break through the patina of what we call reality, unveiling the dark and writhing forces beneath. Longtime Gaiman fans will recognize familiar themes in his writing - the scary monster-mother from Coraline, the three-faced goddess from the Sandman series and the unlikely bravery of timid children. But he packages these expertly into new forms."The Ocean at the End of the Lane" brings we readers into the impressionable mind of a frightened seven year old, letting us re-experience the chthonic darkness and magic possibility which the world holds for the young.

As a longtime despiser of FOX News, I was titillated about this seemingly tell-all book about the inner workings of the organization. But while the book is well-written, funny and suspenseful, it ultimately does not deliver. Joe Muto, desperate for a job after graduating with a film studies degree from Notre Dame, lands a job as a lowly production assistant at Fox. In spite of his liberal misgivings, he eventually works his way up to Bill O'Reilly's show. In truth, the only interesting tidbits about Fox are that O'Reilly, though an imperious yeller, really has a talent for putting on a highly-rated TV show. He works hard, dictates the show off the top of his head, and leaves early to spend time with his kids. Even Muto likes him.Other than that, there's little firsthand info about Palin (she walked by his desk once), Hannity, Rove (who Muto finds wonkish yet likable), Beck or the rest of the Fox regulars who appear on the dust jacket. Muto comes across as an immature twirp who inadvisably and inexplicably leaks some banal backstage Fox video materials to Gawker, leading to his eventually firing."An Atheist in the Foxhole" is hardly sure to solidify Muto's career as a writer. If all he has to offer -- after 8 years inside one of the nation's most slanted news organizations - is this batch of tiny scoops (newsflash - Fox is cheap and it likes blonde bimbos as anchors!) then it's hard to imagine him as a hard-hitting journo where real investigative skills are required.

"Occupy" is a slight book that won't give you much insight into the issues that drive the Occupy movement. It basically records a pep talk by Noam Chomsky to the Occupy protesters, with a little Q&A and some pictures thrown in. If you are new to the movement, you won't learn how our legal and banking systems are tilting away from the people they are supposed to serve. You will learn that Noam Chomsky is revered by the movement, but not why. To me, the most interesting part of the book was a piece by the National Lawyer's Guild giving protesters tactics for dealing with cops and courts.For staid middle-class folks like myself who are sympathetic with the sometimes-obscure goals of Occupy, this book did not sell me on the movement. The lack of clear goals and eschewal of leaders have always been problems, and they were not cleared up here. The references to obscure economics and social planners did not speak to my concerns. The cover, reminiscent of Soviet posters, was not designed to appeal to the ordinary Americans, presumably a necessary target of any mass movement. And the photo of a protester holding a cartoon of someone (George W. Bush?) tossing a paper airplane into the World Trade Center was perplexing at best and offensive at worst."Occupy," with its toxic language and images is not the book you'll want to use to persuade your friends and family to join the movement.

The TV version is what happens when you strip of Terry Pratchett's trademark wit from his work, leaving the little more than plot events. And then it twists those plot events into a banal morality play with a love story tacked on. The show did a nice job with the surfaces, providing a true-to-Discworld version of the city of Ankh-Morpork and its denizens. But beneath the surface, nothing.It's understandable that the book's many characters would have to be pared down to a representative few. But give we fans a break with the plot! Gone was Pratchett's anti-corporate message. In was a Scrooge-like change of heart subplot that took over the film and made Moist von Lipwig shed his conniving ways (which Discworld readers know is nonsense). Gone is much of the suspense of the novel. As when Moist forges his way into bad-guy Reacher Gilt's table at a swanky restaurant. In the book, you knew Reacher was coming at any moment. In the film, it's just an unhappy coincidence that he shows up. And providing narration for half the film was silly, and a missed opportunity to include Pratchett's writing voice.Terry Pratchett's work is more than the sum of its plot points. This "Going Postal" hit its visual marks well, but missed the wit and soul of the original.

I have underestimated Alan Colmes. As the network's token liberal, he usually gets the worse end of "debates" on Fox News. I have thought of him as an amiable straw man - there to float preposterous liberal ideas that could be easily batted away by the likes of Bill O'Reilly and Sean Hannity. His nebbish looks added to the impression of liberals being squishy and weak. But Colmes knows what he  stands for and what he is talking about. "Thank the Liberals" is a very long litany of the great work that liberals and progressives have done for this nation, from its very beginnings. Colmes argues that the Founders were in themselves liberals. They rejected the conservatism of a king/tyrant who determined the fates of all, in favor of a liberal doctrine that gave primary value to the opinions and rights of all citizens. The Constitution and Bill of Rights enshrined liberal ideas like being able to publish whatever you wanted, meet whoever you wanted and not be forced to worship against your conscience.Colmes then trots out a familiar list of rights that have been championed by liberals, and that have expanded notions of liberty. If you are not a slave, are a woman who can vote, a child who does not labor in a mine or a man who can end the work week after 40 hours, you have liberals to thank. Truly, the list of positive goods sponsored by liberals is extremely long.For this liberal, much of this was rather old news. But I did appreciate Colmes's step-by-step analysis of certain liberal victories, like overturning sodomy laws in Lawrence v. Texas, abolishing anti-miscegenation laws in Loving v. State of Virginia, and providing constitutional protections to accused Guantanamo terrorists in Boumediene v. Bush.Unfortunately, "Thank the Liberals" is not a title that conservatives are likely to pick up at a bookstore. They really should. But for liberals, the book provides a "brief for the defense" that might come in handy the next time Fox-watching Uncle Mike comes loaded for liberal bear at Thanksgiving.

UA is another brilliant offering from Terry Pratchett in his Diskworld series. The snack-happy wizards from Unseen University are caught up in the town's mania over "Foot the Ball," a soccer-like sport that is one part sport and two parts urban uprising. Pratchett brings his trademark wit to bear on popular sports as well as the world fashion. The story revolves around Mr. Nutt, a mysterious and brilliant goblin who works as a "dribbler" in the candle vats beneath the university. Hilarity ensues when the cosmically beautiful (and dimwitted) Juliet attends a fashion show at Shatta, a high-end dwarf fashion boutique.  She ends up wearing a beard and modeling dwarf clothing made of the new, chic substance -- Micromail (does not cause chafing!) - causing a sensation.UA gives us a hilarious mix of Ankh-Morpork's citizens (humans, werewolves, wizards and the wily Lord Vetinari) in a mix of love, athletics, thuggery, the redemption of history's errors and the cooking of pies. Not to be missed!

David is back on familiar terrority with "Let's explore," telling stories about growing up with his absurd family in North Carolina, peppered with a few fictional character treatments and some grotesquerie. Some of the material is funny - the letter written by a woman to the woman (now crippled in a car accident! Ha ha!) whose husband she stole. Some are poignant - the story of how David's dad gloried in the athletic achievements of other people's kids. But many are misanthropic at their core. There is a fine line between humor and hatred, and David straddles that line more and more as he gets older. He also manages to slip in one story that is grotesque - in this case, shopping for a stuffed barn owl (gruesome enough) for boyfriend Hugh, and stumbling across the skeleton of an African pygmy in a texidermist's shop. "It would have been disturbing to see the skeleton of a slain Pygmy in a museum, but finding him in a shop, for sale, raised certain questions, uncomfortable ones, like How much is he?"What is delicious about the sentence is the suspense as David leads us to think he is ambivalent about the ethics of buying a hunted human being's bones. What is delightful is the way he levers off into the unexpected finale. What is creepy is that we are led to share in a his casual disregard of this human being's tragic history.David is still very readable and sometimes funny. But it's harder and harder to accept that his stories are taken from his real life, and that drains much of the pathos out of them. His elfin and ingÃ©nue persona, once so pitiful and funny, is cracking, exposing a dark and ugly heart of cynical cruelty.

TOTL has everything that a suspense thriller needs - great writing and acting, exotic locales, weird characters, tragic losses, love and awesome plot twists. The New Zealand hinterland is the setting for a search for a missing 12-year-old girl. Her dad, a longhaired brutal alpha-male woodsman living on a compound, is a natural suspect in the disappearance. A female detective, a former townie, comes to the lake to be with her dying mother. She is battling memories of a brutal attack from years ago, and throws herself into the chase for the missing girl, along with the town's lazy and incompetent police force. Meanwhile, a commune of psychologically wounded women sets up camp on land owned by the alpha male.  Throw in a former pedophile, assorted trashy barflies, and mysterious source of date rape drugs, and you have the makings of a complex and compelling show. Great performances by Elizabeth Moss (the returning detective), Peter Mullan as the compound chief and Holly Hunter as the leader of the women's commune.

Caution: spoilers ahead.You can write a book that reimagines the story of a beloved hero or heroine, that turns myths about them on their head, and yet provides deeper insights into their character. Then again, you can write a book that merely inverts everything that you know about such a character, turns their virtues into failings and teaches us nothing about them. "Testament of Mary" belongs in the latter category.In ToM, Colm Toibin gives us a scant 81 pages that are long on Mary's self-pitying reflections about her life, short on insights about her and Jesus, dismissive about Jesus's mission and full of bizarre details and anachronisms. Toibin's conceit is that Mary was traumatized by the crucifixion of her son. No doubt. But since there is no resurrection in his book, just followers claiming one, there is little to solace her grief and pain. She inhabits Ephesus, lonely among those who do not speak her language, enduring visits by her male keepers, and loitering around pagan temples. Mostly, she mopes and complains, knowing that her real and ordinary life is being transformed by those who wants to make her son into something she knows he was not.The Jesus that Mary describes in ToM is a miracle worker, to be sure. He raises the dead, changes water to wine and walks on water. But his mother is unimpressed. To her, Jesus is a pompous jerk who likes to talk, "his voice all false and his tone all stilted, and I could not bear to hear him." He pals around with rabble - "a group of misfits, who were only children like himself, or men without fathers, or men who could not look a woman in the eye. Men who were seen smiling to themselves, or who had grown old when they were still young." His teaching are the late-night ramblings of fools. "When my son would insist on silence and begin to address them as though they were a crowd." This Mary not only seems to hate what happened to Jesus, but seems to hate her son as well.Unbelievebly, she prays to the many-breasted goddess Artemis, and has a silver idol of her in her living quarters. Her male guardians - it sounds like John and Luke - keep trying to foist their theological beliefs about Jesus on her. She will have none of it. In spite of her, they write a gospel about Jesus that is full of lies. She scoffs at their claims that by his death he saved the world. "When you say that he redeemed the world, I will say that it was not worth it." Holy Mother of God, indeed!With so much material on the market about the world of 1st century Israel, Toibin's errors and anachronisms are unforgiveable. His homes have kitchens, at a time when food preparation was an outdoor activity. Lazarus is buried in the ground, not in a rock tomb. To Toibin, a caravanserai is a moving group of travelers, when in actuality it is a hostel for travelers. Bizarrely, he has Christ pushing and pulling his cross down the street in an hour-long procession to Golgotha. His trial of Jesus is pre-staged, with "everyone" knowing how it will play out days before the arrest. And the idea of Mary, a devout Jew, praying to an idol is just ludicrous. At the very least, it demands an explanation that never came.Any interest in "The Testament of Mary" is a testament to the iconoclastic appetite of moderns to deal with the religion by rejecting everything about it. Christian stories are made tame and dismissable by claiming, without evidence or thought, that they are based on lies. There is no God, Jesus was just another misguided religious fanatic and the Church is only a place for pedophiles and pinheads. This I know, for Old Mary told us so.Luckily, dealing with the Christian scriptures is not a binary exercise - you don't have to accept them at face value or reject them wholesale. Mary can be an inspiring and even graced figure while allowing some poetic and symbolic latitude to the Bible's and the Church's otherworldly depiction of her. Toibin may see himself as adding to the conversation about Mary. But his book betrays a desire to discredit her, the son she bore and the Church that grew around his memory and continued presence in the lives of believers.

I'm still pregnant so I haven't "worn" this yet but wanted to at least start a review because I think there may be serious sizing issues. I went to the Belly Bandit website and used their size calculator. I entered my measurements for 33 weeks and it said get an XL. I entered the same measurements for 34 weeks and it said large. I did both weeks because there is some discrepancies with my due date. I ended up ordering the large, thinking that it's better to be a little tight than too large, especially given how quickly I'll shrink after the baby is here...well the large came and it's huge! I'm 35 (or 36) weeks and I can actually wear it!  So even ordering down when in between sizes is clearly not enough. I imagine this will work for about a week and then I'll need the medium. I'll update once we get there, but heads up, even if you are at the tip top of a size range, you still may benefit from ordering another size down...

So I know the color says "neon pink" but these are no where near the color that was on my screen (and I've never had this problem with amazon before).  On my screen, the shoes were PINK. Bright, but still very obviously pink. What we got in the mail was borderline hot orange, maybe coral?  Very neon. They are cute shoes, and the quality that one would normally expect from Carter's appears to be there, and sizing was accurate. Just not the color we anticipated, otherwise I would have given 4 or 5 stars.

The steamer seems to do the job - not as good as our full sized Jiffy Steamer, but we expected that with a travel sized one. Easy to use. It does spit a little water here and there (I was VERY careful not to tip it as per the instructions) so just don't steam your clothes 2 minutes before you need them.

Stool was badly scuffed from being shipped in a plastic bag instead of an actual box, but functionally it looks like it will work great. Very sturdy for my 5, 3 and 1 year olds. Wide enough to give them a good footing while standing on it, and the gripper feet should help keep it in place.

We used to love this moisturizer - it was so cool and soothing and not greasy at all. Now while it has the same cool, soothing, non-greasy feel to it, is gives both me and my husband a rash! We bought another jar just in case it was a bad batch and we are still having the same problem...we put it on and within 15 minutes both our faces are red and blotchy and have a slight burning feel. We don't use soap on our face so there is no chemical reaction happening or anything...I don't know if they changed their formula or what, but I am so sad to have to start the hunt for another moisturizer now :(

These were really cute in person but unfortunately we had to return due to ordering the wrong size. My daughter has another pair of Carters dress shoes (ballet flats) that are size 10 and fit "perfect" - these were too short.  A word of caution - the part around the toes is wide - shoes almost always tend to be tight for her, and these were almost too lose. We decided to return for another style in hopes of a better fit.

More comfortable than the NEOtech maternity belt I bought for $25. The back piece on this one isn't quite as high (the other brand keeps digging into my waist and hips because it's too long).  This is great for standing, but when you sit it will start to bunch a little. I use it mostly when I know I'm going to up and moving around a lot, otherwise I'm happier without it. Quick to put on. Comfortable even against my skin. At $13, I am really impressed how much like it. It is light support and alleviates (but does not completely eliminate) my lower back pain and my pelvic (pubic) pain. Highly adjustable so I do see how it would fit a wide range of sizes.4/2 update: After wearing this for a couple weeks I finally had to stop. It never stops moving! I am constantly adjusting it and I finally just decided I would rather deal with the pelvic and back pain than constantly adjusting this thing. Dropped to a 3 star rating - still "works" just uncomfortable.

Bought for our 3 year old's bed. It's not nearly as loud as some reviewers made it sound, but it's not completely silent, either. That said, most of the sheets we own aren't silent, either. I would say the noise level is on par with inexpensive cotton sheets. Yes, it makes noise, but it's not nearly loud enough to wake you (or keep you up for that matter). It's thin and not noticeable under the sheets. As for waterproof - we've had one accident that I caught within a few minutes - no leaking! So far, worth the purchase.  Glad we went with this over the more expensive options. My final purchase decision was based on reading the negative reviews and how almost every single one had a response from LinenSpa. The other brands I researched did not. It says a lot to me when a company reads reviews and tries to make things right with a customer...

Very comfortable! Size 3Xfit my 6'2'', large chest/shouldered husband perfectly. The strap that goes around the neck is very soft so there is less chaffing than we had with the cheaper "canvas" straps on the first sling we tried (which was also so small it barely came to his wrist). Only complaint would be that after a few weeks the velcro did start to lose it's "stick" just a little.

Bought this for my husbands fractured collar bone, in combination with a sling. I do not see how you could ever get this on by yourself...especially if you are using it for an injury.  By the end of the day his underarms are a little tender. Definitely follow the advice of other reviewers and wear over a thin shirt if you do decide to purchase. We didn't find that he got much relief from pain and it didn't really seem to stabilize his clavicle, even though we had the right size. Probably would be decent for improving general posture, but I wouldn't count on this if you're using it for an injury.
Loved this heartwarming storyOh sweet love and family look forward to reading more from this great author. Loved it
Fabulous read
Amazing book loved it

Sweet and lovely story of finding love back home. Fiona has a successful business in LA but when she is caught in a traffic jam with a handsome  stranger her world soon changes. Getting invited back home for her class reunion Fiona and her three best friends enjoy the weekend. They also decide that they all want to move back home and re do an old building that was near and dear to them. Fiona also never expected to bump in to Trip again the mysteriously hunk from the LA traffic jam. After all these years is being back home where Fiona belongs? Can she and her three best friends really all go back to where is all started.

This book was a real tough read for me. At times i felt as though i was reading two different books. I was super excited to read about a poor boy and rich good everyone loves those types of stories, but this one just didn't do it for me. The story line was good so it git thumbs up for that however the characters seemed to be a bit outdated to my liking.I would still like to read more from this author!

I really liked this book a lot. the characters were very current with today's society. Who doesn't love a bad boy. Lily has been down on her luck losing her job, apartment and boyfriend. trying to move on she takes a waitress job at a small diner and tried to save some money. All she really ants to do is cook. Kincaid the bad boy ventures in the diner pretty regular and finally the two start talking and one things leads to another. Both characters bring our the good in one another. It will really take you on a roller coaster of a ride with all the raw emotions that unfold. A great one to read for sure.
Awesome book
Fabulous love it

Although I did not read the other books leading up to this one it was not hard to follow. I can say i really enjoyed this book the characters were very real. Rand is a hot shot wealthy business man that takes what he wants. Dani is a con artist always willing to take a risk! When their worlds collide sparks fly. Can Dani risk everything she has and accept what Rand is willing to give her? Can Rand open up to Dani and reveal that he too is willing to take a risk? Be sure to check out this book and the other in this series.

A wonderfully written book of family loss, love, bitterness and happiness. I look forward to reading more of this series. Susie Q has just moved east to Georgia for a chance of a new beginning. She loves to cook and found herself catering for a very large family the Walkers. In walks Eric Walker he takes pride in his ranch and vows he has no room for love or does he? So much has gone wrong in the walker family with the death of his grandfather things start turning upside down. Family turns against family and things start going wrong at the ranch. Eric finds himself more and more needing Susie's comfort and the same goes with Susie needing Eric. Will the family be put back together? Will Susie and Eric find that happily ever after? Be sure to pick up this first book in the Walker Series today!

This was a great read and I learned to much about the Montgomery family that I did not have to start from the beginning. In this book it is about Summer and chance to show her brother Zach and the rest of the family that she too can be just as good as they can. summer has always been in the shadows while her brothers were off helping with the company. Finally get her foot in the door she vows to that she to can succeed. taking off for a small trip to Alaska where her brother Zach and her love interest Ethan who is her brother's best friend are suppose to do a big climb becomes a little bit more than she bargained for. She has always had a thing for Ethan but knew she should keep her distance because her brother would go crazy. But their is just something magnetic that keeps pulling them together. In this book you will find, love and triumph a great summer read.

This is the first book of the Beckham series that I have read and I can't wait to go back and start from the beginning. I do feel that if you picked up iris to read you would get enough of the back story to understand the series. I love everything about mail order brides, Osbourne left nothing out on this book. The characters are so likable and lovable and just downright humbling. When Iris arrives as the new Dr. in Nowhere, TX with her side kick Edna Petunia Blue she gets started right away with a local rancher's daughter Mallie who has broken her arm. Francis is a widower with three small children all under the age of 10. After meeting the new Dr. he seems to be a bit smitten with her and so do his girls. A sweet story of love and romance one you won't want to miss out on.

lovely story of friends to lovers. Jamie has always had a thing for Dean but nevr took it much further than friends. Back at home with her parents and working as a swim coach she finds herself wanting more. She loves creating and all aspects of art. Dean who loves photography slaves away at his fathers shop, because soon it will become his own. He becomes torn between his love of photography and fulfilling his fathers dreams of him taking over. A weekend away is what both Dean and Jamie need. Will it be too much for them? Will they be able to stay friends. Be sure to check out this great loving story.

Loved this book so much! Of course I have a thing about sports related books especially anything to do with football!In Forward pass Shay has an infatuation with Joe Montana I mean who didn't but he isn't the only Joe she day dreams about. growing up she would tag along with her brother and his best friend Joe. Joe was a fabulous football player in school and in the NFL. When Shay returns home from New York she is so happy to go back home to her brother's house that they share. Come to find out her brother has someone else that will be sharing it with her Joe. The connection and chemistry Shay and Joe have is undeniably hot although they do a lot of bantering they really truly seemed to care for one another. Will falling for Joe be everything Shay wants? Will Joe be able to settle down with just one girl. be sure to pick up this football inspired book today!

If you like sexy steamy and hot books then this book must be on your list to read. Cardello definitely turned up the heat level in this one.Sarah a writer from Rhode island decided to take a little road trip to see her friend in Texas. Knowing that she lived at the Double C Ranch she though she would surprise her. What she didn't realize was that she was surprising the wrong person. Scantly clad Sarah was found bu Tony Carlton rugged and handsome horse trainer. Come to find out Sarah went to the wring Double C ranch. The tension between the two is crazy good. They both don't know weather to love or hate one another. Will Sarah be able to write the kind of book she is aiming for? Will Tony be able to open his heart up again? Be sure to check this one out.

Super cute love story of love found. Megan just trying to get away from life finds herself in a small little town broke down. Finding a house with lights on she decides to get some help. Being thrown to the grown and ripped of her sandal she ends up at the local Ogre's house in Lone Tree. Brandon who is a workaholic and considered to be not that friendly takes Megan in and helps her out. The bantering between the two is great and comical. This story is like the saying you can't judge a book by it's cover. I think that is what Megan thought of the so called Ogre. A wonderful story that you wont be disappointed about.

A wonderful Cowboy book. This is Jess' and Cole's story.Jessalyn Alcott (aka Star) was just getting ready to leave for Whisper Creek to attend her friends wedding when she got a note in the mail that she had inherited some money. Not wanting to go back to her past she tried to forget about it. Jess grew up in a broken home her mother and Aunt were very abusive to her as well as her mother's array of men that came and went. Trying to get on with her life as a yoga instructor and new name was coming back to haunt her. Though she truly did love Whisper Creek her friends and the horses she knew that she could never make this her home. Cole a handsome cowboy had his own struggles of where to fit in. He always wanted to go to medical school but never made it. Could this be his chance to go after his dream. Although both Cole and Jess had a past Cole still had strong feeling for Jess.. Just when Cole thinks he is making progress with Jess she quickly slows things up. Not wanting to reveal the whole truth to Cole and her friends Jess gets quiet scared. She doesn't want to lose their friendship. Can Jess overcome the hurt she endured as a child? Will Cole leave the ranch and pursue medical school? be sure to check out this book in the Whisper Creek series. You wont be disappointed.

My rating on this book is a 3.5 star. I have always loved reading Ms. Ridgway's book. However this book just didn't suck me in like her other ones. I just lost interest early on. I do love that this book had a HEA.Angelica had always been a rich kid growing up that was until tragedy struck and she was left homeless. Needing to find a place to live and a job she started working at the local hardware store. Brett is a handyman and loves to fix things up. The chemistry between Angelica and Brett is wonderful. I truly wish that this book would have peeked my interest. Maybe next time.

Phoebe is suspended from her real estate job in La. She finds herself booking a trip with her best friend Maya to Fools Gold for some relaxation. Upon arriving to Fools Gold Phoebe didn't expect Maya's ex step brother Zane to be so handsome. There was just something about him that put a little pep in her step. Zane is a busy rancher trying to raise his brother Chase the right way until Chase got himself and the ranch into a little trouble. Zane was beyond angry at Chase for putting on the website that they were booking cattle drive tours. Bound and determined to make sure Chase worked his fingers to the bone he decided to go on with the tour. Zane didn't know how he felt about the city girl being part of the drive, but one thing he did know was that is was going to be a long one. During the cattle drive they overcame a few obstacles with the tourists and the relationship between brother and a new fond love. This book was about family,forgiveness and fighting for what you want.It is really amazing that Mallery keeps on writing fabulous book in Fools Gold.

Loved this book so much. A fun, sweet and comical book for sure. When Andrea answers an ad for a job in the paper she is excited until she finds out what it entails. Deciding not to accept the offer she tries a different approach and fails again. Knowing that she needs the money she goes ahead and accepts Blake's proposal and begins right away. Know that she had a knack for this type of job she gets started by pinning things to Pinterest that may appeal to Casa Nova Blake's palette. The more and more Andy works on trying to find Blake a trophy wife the more she finds him a bit more attractive. When things start to progress Andy decides to matters in her own hands and tries to seduce Blake only to be laughed at. Will Andy succeed in finding Mrs. Right? Can Blake finally see that the woman of his dreams is standing right in front of him? Like I said the book is comical and will keep you laughing and yelling at the characters. A fabulous read.

What a wonderful love story.  When the Queen tries to work her matchmaking skills with her assistant to get her grandson married off to the perfect girl. Things go a little different. Trent was on board to go along with his grandmother wishes that was until he truly noticed her assistant Cyn. Trent just couldn't get her off his mind and concocted a scheme to get her to fall for him. With a successful campaign done Trent just had to let his grandmother see that his heart belong to the girl next door. This book was simply sweet.

Fabulous read by Ruth Cardello. Who ever said rules are not  meant to be broken is a fool. In this love story Gio is a powerful man that can have any woman his heart desires. He thinks he can wham bam and thank you mam and then move on. that is until he met new security officer Julia Bennett. All she wanted to do was get her job done and do it well until scanning the monitors she finds someone trying to break into a desk and Whack!! she lets him have it. Who knew that whack to Gio would knock some sense into him and he would change the way he ogled women. I love the spunk that Julia had she was determined that she was not a piece of meat that could be bought she wanted to work and make a name of herself by herself an with no one else's help. these two are good for each other they are complete opposites the chemistry is undeniable. Loved it!

This book was a great read. Hard to put down. The chemistry between Isla and her new boss Xander was electrifying.I loved that the author displayed Isla as a fiery redhead with lots of gusto. She knew how to please a man both in and out of bed and she was determined to stand her ground. Just be warned this book has lots of dirty little secrets.
this was a fabulous series that i loved and will reread again!
Another great part to this series. I will definitely re read this series! Bentley and Ceci were great together.
I was so glad to have this added novella to the series, a perfect way to end it.

Grace is not your typical skinny girl that all the men ogle over she is a more well rounded girl next door. Noah is the handsome grandson of Agatha who employs Grace. When Noah comes home to find his fiance in bed with someone else he knows she is not the one. How will his grandmother take the news as she loves his fiancee. One rainy night Grace happens upon Noah and his Brother and sparks began to fly. Can Noah really truly have feelings for Grace? will grace dreams finally come true for nailing Noah. Be sure to check out this sweet and romantic book.

This book was simply delicious. Sweet and romantic with a bit of a family twist. The book is based on a lost or stolen chocolate recipe that has made two families dislike one another. That is until Er Nurse Alex and NYC Firefighter Mike cross paths. If you believe in signs this book is just right for you. I loved it.

another fabulous chocolate book. in this book Chloe a magical chocolate master finds herself inheriting an old apartment building. When disaster after disaster happens in the old building she really doesn't know who to turn to. Her friend thinks she needs a man and helps her find just the right one. Along come Ethan the man behind wanting to demolish the old apartment building and their worlds turn upside down. You will love this book

This book was most definitely on the steamy side. It was a great read with a great story line. Sabrina is a dancer in school and also has an abusive boyfriend. Caston is considered to be Mt Hollywood. he can have any girl at anytime. The first night that he notices Sabrina at a dance recital he knows she will be his next Hollywood Sweetheart. upon finally getting up close and personal with Sabrina at a frat party Caston becomes her hero and rescues her from more abuse of her now ex boyfriend. Both Castona and Sabrina have baggage in the closet and they both try very hard to be each others rock. Only time will tell if the two can be perfect for one another. This is going to be a great series!

Although this story had a great story line it was a bit on the confusing side. There were a lot of twists and turns as well that didn't seem to quite fit. Kate Sparrow is considered to be an evil brat according to her sister and the headlines. Upon boarding the cruise ship for her sisters wedding all heck breaks loose. Trying to keep herself safe from her father and his "friends" she becomes friends with Daniel Collins who is considered to be wealthy and a Dr at that. he in turn becomes her babysitter and tries to keep her out of harms way. This book was packed full of mystery, suspense and romance. i too had a hard time trying to figure out why Daniel's ex girlfriends were all on the same cruise ship as well as the inherited necklace. but over all the book was great.

This is a great short love story about two old high school friends who meet up again at a ski resort. Bothe Scar and Jules had a troubled past and they helped each other get through their last year of high school. Then they went there separate ways. When Jules goes on vacation with her mom and sister she bumps into Scar again. Can they start all over again being just friends or will then getting stuck in the snow ignite a passion that has been burning for years. Can't wait to read the next book Cheater Anonymous.

Fabulous read. This book will have you laughing your head off. In this book Kelsie is set up on numerous dates by her mom and her friend. Not only is going out with them she tries to escape at each event which puts her in some compromising situations. not wanting to fully give her heart away again as she was divorced a few years ago. She decides to use these dates as a way to get her first book out published. Never did she think that she might truly find a real man that is worth risking it all again. Cole is a firefighter and he is ready to hose down Kelsie when he first meets her. It seems that he appears and is her rescuing hero on every date. Can Kelsie give into the handsome firefighter and let her guard down or will she continue to hold onto her heart and never let it go? Looking forward to reading more about Nanci and her B.O.B. collection!

Loved this book so much. Ms. Albright had me in tears laughing so much. The characters were built to be so lovable. I just want to move down the street with these ladies and become BFF's. This book is full of down home southern charm and sass. My favorite thing about this book is that the women were full of spunk and didn't back down. Looking forward to reading many more by this author.

What a fabulous book. I didn't want it to end.When motorcycle riding Magda got the call that her father was in the hospital she had to go back to Whispering Springs to help. Not really wanting to because she didn't want to run into her old flame Reno, but she had no choose. Magda vowed to her father that she would stick around until he got himself better so that meant one thing she needed to find work. Reno's parents asked to be his housekeeper. Although a bit leery of the situation she knew she needed a job to keep her busty while her father healed. The tension between her and Reno was so thick you could cut it with a knife. They both really had feelings for one another just afraid to do anything about that was until the snow storm came. Could Magda risk giving her heart away? Can Reno bite the bullet and let Magda know he really loves her? Be sure to check book #5 of The Montgomery mavericks out to see what happens you wont be disappointed.

This book was a bit different for sure. Right up the ally of Singled Out and all the other MTV reality love stories. the book was filled with a lot of innuendo's which made for some funny scenes. Poor Christine all she wanted was to get what all the smut books imply the Big O.... She never thought writing a statement would land on with her own reality show on MTV let alone get exactly what she wanted. At times the book felt a bit rushed and thrown together but it was a great read with a twist.

This book was great. It starts right where Twisted by Desire left off.Nikki shocked when she finds out she is pregnant and knowing that her future husband Jeff didn't really want kids she is torn on what to tell him. Knowing that she has been with her ex and still has some feelings for him she starts freaking out that it could be his. Most off this book is about Nikki and Jeff's getting ready for the wedding and new baby. Looking forward to the next one.

This book was exactly what I needed. I was hooked from the get go.I love military type books especially one when the Solider's have a heart. In this book Army Sergeant Colten Taylor comes back home after six long years. He is totally caught off guard once he sees Rachel Madison his old flame. Rachel is determined not to let Colten in on her hidden secret that is until he finds out himself. Can Colten and Rachel rekindle the love they had for each other once? Can Colten set aside his demons that he is dealing with long enough to figure out that this is where he belongs with Rachel? I love that Rachel is a strong willed character in this book. She is not afraid to fight for what she wants and she can dish it our pretty good. If you are looking for a great military read this one is for you!

This book was a bit interesting to say the least. I typically don't read too many Ya books. But this one was well written. I felt so bad for Polarity Weeks attending a new school and being made of because she was a bit on the poor side. her world got turned upside down when the school found a naked picture of her floating around the social networks and that the she knew all about it. One day she woke up at  her house the next she was in foster care. She pleaded with everyone that she and her parents had nothing to do with the picture but everyone else thought they knew better or did they? her only friend through this was Ethan he was a sweet boy and tried to help Polarity get to the bottom of things with this incident. polarity was a very strong girl for her age and very mature which made like her character even more. At times I know she felt battered and a bit bewildered by her mom but she loved her mom and understood her mom's sickness. a great book for middle to high school. This would make a great book for them to learn about bullying too.

All I can say is this book is  "muy caliente"!!! It was hot, sassy and oh so spicy! Such a great quick read. I love how the author makes the characters come alive.  Veronica thought just for one night she would re-invent herself and see where the night takes her. Diego is sweet and romantic and a big tall drink of water. Can Veronica keep on with her charade of new identity or will she finally confess to Diego? Will Diego accept the real veronica. Be sure to find out when you pick up your copy of New York Minute.

Arrived in great time. It fits well, it's just a little lose, but it has held up well and since I carry my note in my bag all the time, it projects it really well. The stand is not very sturdy, and the flap where I sick the cover into is coming apart. But for the price I'm pretty satisfied.
It's made pretty cheaply. It does work, but retracts on its own sometimes. Considering it was so inexpensive I wasn't too disappointed. Wouldn't purchase again or recommend

I put this on my note 8.0 son as I got it. It's great!  Actually makes the s pen feel more like writing on paper. Workout it, it felt like writing on glass, I know Duh, but made my writing more sloppy, like writing in a chalk board.

Bcuz I scar easily and had some surgery, my Dr told me to take 1000 mg of vitamin e everyday. I like the fact that I can get all 1000 in pill. The NOW brand is great and usually less expensive than other natural brands. I find it for less expensive here than in the health food store, even with shipping.

Purchased to try making a cleanser comparable to Mary Kay's old extra emollient cleanser that was the ONLY product I've EVER used that kept my SUPER dry skin from being dry, but at the same time not feeling clean and not greasy at all. I had read that Albolene cream was comparable... It isn't, so I tried adding glycerine and beeswax, a little better. Then I tried adding this sodium pca and still can't get right consistency of after feel. If anyone reading this has come across this same dilemma and found something comparable, please post here.
I got this cuz it was recommended for detox and well being. Didn't feel any different, just noticed stool greenish tint

I got this bcuz it said it was good for scars. I just had a melanoma removed from my cheek and reconstructive surgery. I've been putting it on my scar and it appears to be flattening out. I'll update with progress. I got it along with the Watts hyaluronic moisturizing serum, My extremely dry dehydrated skin is staying most all thru the day and looking more fresh, dewy and glowing. I put the glycolic on 1st then this serum over it, then my moisturizer. A little squirt covers my whole face neck and decollete.

I got this along with the Watts hyaluronic glycolic serum, bcuz it said it was good for scars. I just had a melanoma removed and reconstructive surgery. I've been putting it on my scar and it appears to be flattening out. I'll update with progress. But the rest of my extremely dry dehydrated skin is staying most all thru the day and looking more fresh, dewy and glowing. I put the glycolic on 1st then this serum over it, then my moisturizer. A little squirt covers my whole face neck and decollete.

I purchased this item about 8 months ago. for my cell phone.  I LOVED it.  It would charge my phone 4 or 5 times without needing a charge.  All of a sudden a month or so ago,  it won't even give me 1 charge.  After plugging in the phone and pressing the button,  all 4 lights light up,  then I get about 25% charge and it's dead.. press the button,  no lights. I just contacted Anker and left comment.  I hope they have a solution.  If they do,  I'll give it 5 stars.update 03.02.14: sorry I didn't update sooner.  I emailed Anker and told them about the problem. They emailed me right away, asked for the model# and my address. They sent me another charger and didn't make me go to the post office and pay to return the old one. Then they emailed me a week or so later to make sure I got it and to see if it was working properly.  I emailed them back thanking them for their awesome c.s. and told them that it's working great. I get 2 or 3 charges on my tablet or several on my phone with 1 charge. I not only would do business with Anker again, but I highly recommend them, their products and their c.s. is 2nd to none.

I really like this product. Only problem, there were a few bubbles that I COULD NOT get out, no matter what...hence 4 stars. I really like the non glare and even if it gets dirty, it doesn't slow down the touch screen action. I liked the way the s Pen felt, more friction like a pen on real paper. Writing on the glass was like not as much control. Will definitely purchase again. I wish they made one for my Skyrocket phone. The protectors I got for that get draggy. Btw order came in good timely manner

Bought mine here on Amazon back in 2009 and am still sleeping on it.  It does keep its cool feel throughout the night.  Subsequent to purchasing this Iso-Cool pillow, I did try, for about a week, one of the much touted $100.00+ Tempur Pedic side sleeper pillows that was allegedly a freebie when I bought a top of the line Tempur Pedic adjustable bed.  What a mistake that has been.  Hate the bed and didn't like the pillow.  Buying a Tempur Pedic bed has proven to be the worst purchase I have ever made in my entire adult life.  Back to this pillow.  When it finally bites the dust I will most likely buy another one unless something else has come along that is better.
They are velcro, they stick to the surface I needed to use them on and so far are working fine.
They are velcro, they work for my needed purpose and were a good price.

Although described as being "Large", the bones are pretty small.  That said, my Yellow Lab seems to really like them.  I did notice right away when I opened the bag that these bones don't have the same overwhelming odor to them that the other Blue Buffalo Bones have. Just wish they were bigger since I feel I must now keep a closer than normal eye on his treat chew time just in case he tries to swallow a not chewed well enough too large of a piece whole. Perhaps an extra large or jumbo size will be forthcoming from Blue Buffalo in the near future for those of us who have larger pets.  Given my YL's after chew reaction, guess he rates these bones as four paws.

Watched most of it on one of the cable channels but there were so many blasted commercials (sometimes as many as 8-10 or more in a row) that it was hard to maintain continuity of thought.  Plus during one episode there was a totally unnecessary local interruption regarding some politico happening that could have been easily forgone!  Be that as it may, we enjoyed the acting and the story line was relatively well written although it did stray pretty far from historical facts numerous times to accommodate Hollywood's version of Tut's exploits.  There were several scenes displaying nudity but they were tastefully handled and not dwelt upon.  Was a bit surprised the censors approved the miniseries for prime time.  Plus, we always enjoy Mr. Kingsley's performance in pretty much anything he appears in.  All in all, a pretty good piece of entertainment.

Emits a nice soft white light.  Like the fact I am saving energy and money by replacing all the incandescent energy guzzling, heat producing bulbs throughout the house.  Will buy again when and if needed.

As with all Blue Buffalo products that I have purchased through the years, my Yellow Lab gives this flavor a four paws rating.  He's been on an almost exclusive diet of both Blue Buffalo kibble and treats since he was a puppy.  Now that he is well into his senior years, I want to keep him as healthy as possible for many more years to come.  The ingredients used by the manufacturer appear to be well researched to assist in doing just that.  He's still very active, gets regular good health/wellness yearly exam reports, his vision is still very sharp and I firmly believe he can hear a flea hop outside in the grass as well as smell it when that flea lets wind!  All joking aside, I believe Blue Buffalo products are, although a bit pricey, about the best plus they are made right here in the USA.

Needed a pair of bookends that wouldn't continually be sliding apart letting my taller cookbooks fall down when one was removed for use.  Decided to give this item a try.  They work beautifully.  So glad I noticed this item on amazon since I had been unable to find a reasonably priced pair in any of the local bookstores and/or big box stores.

Had purchased same set some years back and used it until it literally fell apart and no amount of duct take would hold it together anymore.  Something must have changed in manufacturing process since this newly purchased set felt very flimsy and even the plug in connector did not fit the same phone jack that had been used with previous set.  Plug was too large.  Sent it back.  Not usual Panasonic quality I have come to depend on for a number of years.
Bulbs emit a nice soft white light.  Like the fact I am saving energy and money by switching to LED bulbs throughout my home.

Sheets fit my Twin XL Temper Pedic mattress quite well.  Unlike any of my other more expensive microfiber sheet sets, these don't feel warm next to your skin (Goodness knows I don't need any added warmth since the darn mattress makes one hot enough!) and have an almost silky feel. I don't like the fact that they are made in China (Shame on you Amazon) nor the fact that even after two washes, once on a cool gentle cycle with Woolite and once on a warn gentle cycle with Persil, and low heat drying in both instances, sheets have yet to lose hardly any of their wrinkles.  They came out of the package looking like the folds and creases had been ironed in thus pretty much setting the creases and other wrinkles caused from folding the sheets tightly so as to fit in a pretty small plastic zipper bag.  I don't see anything about having to iron these hummers to get the wrinkles out.  Oh well, what can you expect from a product made in China. Will not be buying again.

This is far superior to the metal with powder coating sink protector that I have been using that invariably began to rust after being in use only a short time.  It also fits my SS sink much better and doesn't hike up the side of the sink when I place a single pan or dish on it to hand wash.  Given its' physical makeup, should be more cost effective than coated metal ones.  So far, I like it.
Used same/similar product to wash fruits and veggies when stationed overseas where in some areas cleanliness in handling is not oft practiced.

Although these are presumably intended for the smaller breeds, my Yellow Lab loves it.  He gets one with his monthly heart worm preventative pill and one with his other weekly med he has to take for his allergies.  Never an ort is ever left in the bowl.  I find these small containers to be much more realistic to use than opening a larger size can of wet food and having "leftovers" to contend with.  I don't feed my YL a lot of wet food given the fact that no matter what the brand, something in wet food tends to irritate his allergies.  Vet seems to think it is the preservatives used in long term packaged items.
Nice low calorie snack for mid morning/mid afternoon coffee break.

Received a coupon to try one of these widgets free when they first came out.  Thought what the hey, it's free so nothing ventured, nothing gained.  Tried one and liked it.  Been buying refills ever since.  I do hope these turn out to be the original configuration units.  I do not like the new generation with the round disc refill.  You can't see when the liquid is empty and new disc needs to be fitted.  The new generation is supposed to blink when the round paper like disc needs replacing.  The red light didn't come on on mine and when I opened it up to check, paper was dried up and curling.  Hey, Johnson & Johnson, if you give us a product that works, why mess with it?  New and improved isn't always better.  If these turn out to be the new round disc configuration, I plan on donating them for the animal shelter workers to use during our high humidity mosquito infested months.
It does appear to help in reducing the joint pain.

Although pricey and the fact that it ships from Europe, I found these descaling tablets to be the "cat's meow"!  They cleaned my Tassimo coffee maker beautifully and were a breeze to use.  I liked how the tablets worked so well that I have already reordered multiple packs given it takes a while to receive them from "across the pond".  So glad I stuck to the Tassimo Bosch brand for my Tassimo brewer since one of my neighbors locally purchased a different, much cheaper brand of descaler in a powder form.  It failed miserably in cleaning her brewer and now her relatively new K machine doesn't work properly.  In this case, the old adage of "You get what you pay for" really applies.  Highly recommend these descaling tablets.  P.S. The accompanying literature did state these tablets will work in most all brands of brewers.

Although stated as being an interface to 3.5Mm sized connectors on various items, this generic was too large to fit my item albeit manufacturers description cited 3.5Mm as being the connector size.  Sent this item back and went to a local big box store and purchased (at a slightly higher price) an interface that fits perfectly.

As with all seasons to date, stories are well acted and the cadre of recurring actors blend well thus making the "family" side fairly believable.  Ahh but Tom Selleck is the real glue of the series.  If we had a few more common sense real life police commissioners like the persona Selleck projects, many of the police departments that are in today's (negative) news headlines might find themselves vastly improved.

These are probably the best dish towels I have ever used.  So far, they truly are lint free which is very important to me as I entertain quite often and want my glassware in particular to be both water drop and lint free when I place them on the serving trays/table.  They beat the heck out of the DII brand (also sold here on amazon) as well as others I have tried.  I hope they maintain their lint free quality in the future especially after being washed a number of times.  These towels are also very absorbent and soft.  So far I like them.  Not too sure why the price was jacked up nearly triple right after I purchased mine in late Oct 2015 but if they are ever offered at the same or near same price as I initially paid, I will buy again.

Sent this item back due to overtly extreme poor quality.  The pan had numerous flaws presumably from an inferior manufacturing process.  I own a number of Nordic Ware products, including several of their other various shaped bundt pans, but this is the worst bundt pan I have ever seen.  It is so flimsy that you can literally, with the gentlest exertion of pressure, compress the sides inwardly.  There were grooves and other deformities in bottom and sides of pan.  Cannot recommend this particular Nordic Ware Bundt pan.
It's an air diffuser, it works and is adjustable.  What else can one say.

Tschibo coffee is probably the finest coffee you can buy.  This Feine Milde is superb in that it makes a robust cup without any bitterness or the oily taste that some coffees leave in your mouth.  Got to be attributable to the fact that Tschibo only uses premium coffee beans.  If you have a coffee bean grinder, suggest you buy the Feine Milde in the whole bean bag and fresh grind every time you brew a pot.There is nothing like a fresh ground brewed cup of coffee!  Tschibo brand is the number one favorite coffee sold in Germany.  Try it and you will be hooked.

Caught part of the conversation on TCM and knew I wanted to see the entire show.  Mr. Osborne's comments at the beginning of the prime time shown movies adds so much enjoyment to the movie being commented on.  It is too bad he can't present a commentary on each and every TCM movie showing.  For me, a lifelong fan of TCM and classic movies, having an insight to events that occurred during both the making of a movie and its' stars adds invaluable viewing enjoyment.  If and when he leaves the host chair, it will be a tremendous loss to both TCM and us fans.  Glad he himself could be the star of such a program and receive such well deserved accolades.
What can one say?  It is a filter, it fits, appears to be exact replica of original part and appears to do the job.

After installing EXACTLY per instructions, lowered shower wand to normal position for showering (NO undue pressure exerted!) and when water was turned on it spews out the back of the ball joint part.  If the shower wand is put back up in upright position (as shown in the amazon site picture), water doesn't spew out but does drip.  Hello seller - is this normal or did I get a defective part???  Looks like I will have to send it back.  Otherwise I really liked the hose and selected spray setting.  Bummer.

Was looking for a spot cleaning cloth that didn't have a strong chemical smell to it but would get the job done.  Decided to give this one a try.  Glad I did.  Although the wipes do have a bit of an odor, the odor is not to the extent that you need to "wear a gas mask" just to use them.  The one wipe used easily removed some dried in days old nose bleed drops, chew bone drool left behind by my Lab as well as some dark grease spots tracked in by the cable guy.  Cleaned areas dried quickly and the aforementioned odor dissipated completely within a very short time.  Will definitely buy again.

Purchased these to replace contractor (build) installed clear globe vanity lights in all bathrooms.  Love the difference the soft lighting has made.  Can also tell the difference in the amount of heat generated by the old incandescent bulbs versus these LEDs.  Brightness has not been compromised even though these LED bulbs are only 40 watt equivalent and they are replacing 60 watt incandescent.  Amazing how LEDs can provide so much light yet only require an "nth" amount of electricity.  Will definitely buy again when and if needed.

Was recommended by Vet.  Have noticed a bit more spring in his step so to speak of my aging Lab.  Have no trouble in dosing.  Must taste OK to him.  As long as it helps keep my baby healthy and overt results are tangible, will continue to buy.

My Nativity set is the 21 piece set that my children purchased for me several years ago.  I own almost 100 pieces en total of the Willow Tree collection.  Like one reviewer mentioned, watch for sales since some pieces are a bit pricey.  I lucked out on a number of pieces including the free standing tall Angel Stars (got the pair for $20.00) at a shop that was going out of business.  Be sure to check the bottom of pieces you are buying to make sure they are real DEMDACO Willow Tree pieces since I have seen pretty good copies being made by a rip off company trying to capitalize on the DEMDACO Willow Tree popularity.

Especially like it use it to drain fat from gravy starter fixings when cooking pork roasts since they tend to be fatty in nature.  Also the OXO good grip handle makes it much easier to maintain a firm grip on the container thus precluding accidental spilling of hot liquid/fat onto the cook!

Some of the best tasting food (ever!) comes from being cooked in cast iron pans and skillets.  Lodge makes the best.  They are high quality and are made right here in the U.S.A.  See my other reviews for different Lodge cast iron items that I own and use daily.

Have used these same pieces extensively for over fifteen years with no problems, even with the lids.  I did put one of the smaller bowls in the microwave with the lid on it (loosened of course) and noticed that the underside of the lid did have some tiny clustered bubbles in one place when I took it off of the bowl.  The lids do say right on them that they are both dishwasher (top-shelf) and microwave safe.  That was the first (and last) time I had ever put one of the lids in the microwave.  I have a made for the microwave cover that I always use when heating foods.  Doesn't appear to have affected the lid's performance since it still seals tight.  My set must be from the era when Corning still manufactured Pyrex since the glass has no tinted hue as mentioned by other reviewers and mine do say Made in the U.S.A.

Bought a number of various cast iron pieces when amazon had their "four for three" program.  Food cooked in cast iron just tastes better than when cooked in other types of pans/skillets.  Plus, we've used them in the grill when preparing certain meats to get that grilled flavor without having a messy grill rack to clean up.  You also don't lose meat due to pieces falling through a grill grid.  And, if you are campers like we are, bacon and eggs, hash browns etc., cooked over a campfire in cast iron skillets makes for really delicious eating!  I especially love to cook beans in the dutch oven.  While my hubby and sons are out fishing or hiking, I put the beans on and simmer them slowly all day.  Add some corn bread baked in one of my cast iron skillets...Yum!  (I cook these dishes the same way at home).  Can highly recommend Lodge cast iron products.

I've been using mine going on five years now with no problems.  I have never experienced any type of metal bits, pieces or shavings when opening any size can like some have reported in their reviews.  After all this time and having opened a sizable number of cans (we are a family of four), the opener blade is seemingly still as sharp as the day I took it out of the box.  Can recommend this product.

These Mall Walker shoes are awesome.  Hubby has been wearing this brand/style for over fifteen years.  According to him, they are very comfortable and his feet don't sweat in them as they do in some of his other pricier similar type shoes.  They also seem to wear very good i.e., the pair he is currently wearing is about seven years old and have a lot of miles on them as he wears them exclusively when walking our Lab.  They walk approximately four to five miles every day, weather permitting.  For the shoe itself, I give a FIVE STAR RATING.The ONE STAR is for the inconvenience I've had to endure of having to box them back up, go through the amazon return process and get them up to the UPS store for ship-back.  All this due to the fact I was sent OBVIOUSLY WORN SHOES.  I don't mean just tried on shoes but shoes that had been worn to the extent that there were deep creases in the leather on top of both shoes plus one shoe had dirt (and a small pebble!)  in one of the profile ridges along the bottom as well as dirt on one side.  Never, ever in all my years of ordering shoes have I ever received an obviously worn pair.  Bummer.  I repeat the shoes are great and will order again, if available, and when needed.

The terry-cloth like material is so thin that you can literally see through it in some places.  Used to lift cookie sheet with baked cookies on it from hot oven and nearly dropped whole sheet due to heat penetrating mitt almost immediately.  Cannot recommend.  BTW product says it is made in Turkey.  Duh!

Whether playing a dramatic, semi-comedic or really rotten person role,  Max Schell was always at the top of his game.  My husband and I had the distinct pleasure of meeting and conversing personally with him at a book signing in Darmstadt Germany in 1997 where he read excerpts from and commented on his autobiographical book "Das Rebell" (The Rebel).  He also answered audience questions regarding some of his acting roles, his life in general and about his sister Maria who had such a tragic life and ending.  His answers or comments were loaded with both direct to the point personal comments and feelings as well as really funny and entertaining ones.  When speaking of his sister he became quite nostalgic but didn't dwell on his sadness about her.  He was a soft spoken man seemingly quite humble at times and extremely friendly.  He was surprised that there were several of us Americans in the audience since both the book and the entire presentation is/was in German.  (Was not a problem for us, both being fluent in the language).  After he found out there were Americans in the audience, he graciously took the time to translate a lot of his spoken word for their enjoyment as well.  He seemed to prefer these smaller type audiences, there were about 100 people semi-circled around him, so the setting felt quite intimate.  During the subsequent book signing, he took extra time when one of us Americans came forward for him to sign our books and wrote a personal note to each of us, by name, before signing our books.  He mentioned to us how grateful he was to his American audiences for fostering his career throughout the years.  I must say that even in 1997 the vestiges of age and declining health were becoming quite obvious.  It was with sadness when I read of his passing.
