However, as with all of our truly great stars, they will be with us as long as their films exist.  As for this film, his role is one of the rotten characters that you love to hate.  We first see him as millionaire Jewish entrepreneur Arthur Goldman living in a Manhattan penthouse where he disses on everything from baseball, the Papacy, ex-wives to his family's extermination at the hands of the Nazis.  After he is arrested by Israeli agents and charged with being one of those self-same Nazis, we see him begin to morph into the sociopath character of Adolph Dorf, Commandant of the concentration camp where his family was allegedly exterminated.  No more spoilers.  This is a tense, on the edge of your seat type of movie almost from the git-go.  If you like these types of movies, you'll love "The Man In The Glass Booth".

What can one say about two of the most iconic actors of our time and the horror genre movies they made.  Although Vincent Price did become most famous for his horror movie offerings, he was known to be, by all accounts, one of the kindest, gentlenest, and most generous actors on the Hollywood scene during his lifelong tenure in the movie world.  He was also a gourmet chef, painter and writer of poetry.  I saw the "Tingler" when I was just a kid and it scared the pants off of me.  That campy thing (by today's standards) reminded me so much of the lobsters my dad would catch over on the coast and bring home that for a long time after seeing that movie I wouldn't eat a lobster for fear it was really a "Tingler".  It didn't help any either that I was sitting in one of the wired seats that would "tingle" every time that thing was on screen.  I can laugh about it now but when you are a kid.....I've enjoyed watching all of the movies on this DVD and although dated, they are still enjoyable.

I received my mattress pad today and thought it seemed fine.  It felt smooth and soft and looked like it would go on easily.  As I do with all new bedding, I washed and dried it on low.  But when I put it on my bed I could see that it was now incredibly lumpy.  As I ran my hand over it, some of the lumps were soft but some felt very hard and I knew that would be uncomfortable to sleep on.  Feeling through the cover of one of the hard lumps, it felt like it had some sort of a string in it.  I cut a small hole and started to pull out the polyester fiberfill.  No wonder it felt hard!  The fiberfill was twisted, knotted, hard and a complete mess.  I pulled it all out of the square and threw it away.  Something like that should never be used in bedding.  Since I have washed this I cannot return it but I would advise other people to think twice before purchasing this.

I very much enjoyed this delightful small book.  In the introduction, the author states the book's purpose "...to offer friendly advice that might help one achieve the look, attitude and general sophistications of that beacon of style and intelligence known as the Lady...A chapette is...a woman of refined qualities that are reflected in the way she looks and the way she acts; a lady with a considerate yet freethinking attitude and a taste for retro fashions."  This small book covers retro and vintage fashions, hair styles, makeup (along with interesting and little-known trivia facts) and also covers relevant music, literature and film.  Etiquette and entertaining are also discussed.  The book is illustrated with charming drawings reminiscent of the 50's and written with humor and wit.  Since it is 80 pages long, it doesn't delve into great depth on any one topic but rather presents an excellent overview.  I tried to find other books by Daisy Loveday, but I think the name may be a nom de plume because the Publisher's page states that the text is by Chris Turton.  The book is published in the U.K. which is apparent in the spellings and some of the words (i.e., "boot" for "trunk") but that only adds to the book's charm.  It would make a wonderful gift.  Incidentally, I see that there is a companion book for men "How to be a...Chap" available here on Amazon and I plan on picking that up as well.

This is a very lovely, dainty watch.  The band was a tiny bit snug so I put an extra hole in it and now it fits perfectly.  It doesn't show up well on the website, but the face of the watch case has a very pretty bevel around the edge of it, which makes it sparkle even more.  I took off a star because it can be a little difficult to read and I frequently have to move my wrist around to read the time, depending on the light.  I would recommend this watch, but if it is important to you to see the time at a quick glance, then I would suggest another choice.

I never thought I would be writing a less than five star review about an Anne Klein handbag.  I have purchased a couple of them and they are of excellent quality.  However, I was disappointed in this one.  I purchased the petal pink, and the tan rattan weave in the front of the bag clashed with the color and looked very odd.  White rattan might have looked better, in my opinion.  Worst of all, when I lifted the bag by the rattan handles, I heard a loud creaking noise.  The rattan rubs against the PVC and creates this sound whenever the handles are moved or touched.  I knew it would be very annoying, so I returned this handbag.

I like this blush and the cute packaging.  The color "Ladylike" is very light so I need to brush it on a few times for it to show; I don't mind because I would rather have a "buildable" blush than one that goes on really heavy the first time.  It looks really natural on me and lasts until I take it off at night.  I have a very fair complexion and it works well, but I don't know if I would recommend this light shade for someone with a medium or deeper complexion because it might not show up enough.  Also, just to let you know, it does not come with an applicator so you need to use your own blush brush.  This is not a problem for me but some people prefer an applicator with the product.

I have dry skin on my hands and many hand soaps and detergents make them even dryer.  This Milk Protein and Honey by Softsoap is the only product I have found (so far) that I can wash my hands with that doesn't dry them out.  In fact, I recommended it to a friend and she had the same good result with it.  Of course I use hand lotion regularly, but with this hand soap my hands stay moist and smooth.  I have even used high-priced department store hand soaps that didn't work as well.  I hope they never stop making it!

I have had swollen ankles for several years and gradually the skin around them became very dry, hardened and thick.  My dermatologist recommended a cream with 20% urea.  Udderly Smooth with 20% Urea has worked very, very well for me.  I apply it twice a day; once after my morning shower and once in the evening.  I have read (and my doctor told me)  that urea can soften the fingernails so I am careful not to get any on my nails.  I use a spatula to apply it to my ankles and wash my hands afterwards.  In just a couple of weeks my ankles have improved immensely.  Another thing I like about Udderly Smooth is the packaging.  So many products come in tubes, and when you have used a lot of the product you then have to cut the tube open to get out the rest.  This plastic jar is so easy to use, and you can see exactly how much you have left. Needless to say, I will be purchasing another jar soon.

This lovely cross looks like a cherished heirloom, and I have received several compliments on it.  Although it doesn't show up too well in the picture, it also has pretty sparkling crystals.  It comes in a beautiful dark green gift box from the Vatican Library.  The only thing I would change about it is that it does remain stationary on the chain, so sometimes I have to adjust it a little because it doesn't automatically swing to the center like a pendant that could move freely would do.  However, that is a very small point and I am very glad I purchased this exquisite pink rose cross pendant on the beautiful chain.  I love wearing it.

This pin is absolutely darling!  It is very well done, down to the slightest detail, and is quite a conversation piece.  It is just the right size - not so small that it goes unnoticed but not so large that it is overwhelming. I purchased it for myself but it would also make a wonderful gift, as it comes in a lovely aqua gift box and matching velveteen bag.
Easy to use, works very effectively and smells great!
I use these for when I'm cooking things like bacon, which can splatter, or when I'm spraying a strong cleaner.  They are a wonderful safety device and fit comfortably.

What a beautiful gift - for you or someone special!  First of all, it arrives in a tasteful dark blue gift box.  There is no writing on  the box (except for the UPC code on the bottom) so if you just wanted to put a bow on it and give it to someone that would be all right.  Inside it fits in a special styrofoam mold so it will arrive safe and unbroken.  The rose is separate from the vase so that if you ever wanted to put a real flower in the vase, you could.  It is pretty, romantic, and for the price, can't be beat!
Pretty, sparkly earrings.  Not too long or too heavy, just right!
Very pretty pendant - just the right shade of pink!  Good quality chain, looks even better "in person".

The spiral binding and hard cover make it easy to write in if, for instance, you are sitting in bed or don't have a desk or table in front of you.  The pages have generously-spaced lines which make it easy to read what you have written.  I like the biblical quotes at the bottom of each page.  My favorite thing is the cover.  I love rain and I like umbrellas.  And to me, the picture has a lot of meaning.

When I buy things at the store I like to give the clerk the exact change.  When I kept coins in my clutch wallet, they were hard to reach, difficult to see, and took a while to get out.  I never wanted to do it if there were other customers in line behind me.  With this clear plastic purse, I can easily see what I have, and in addition it opens very wide making for easy accessibility.  It's a cinch to get the exact change.  Also, this purse has no gaps so coins don't fall out (I had a similar one a few years ago, from a different seller, and coins kept slipping out because the frame didn't meet).  It's amazing how such a small, utilitarian item can really simplify my life.  I'm so glad I got it!

The last thing I needed was another tote bag, but when I saw this adorable retro poodle I just couldn't resist.  There is something about the umbrella and the pink ribbon that shouts "1950's" and even the leopard print lining seems a little retro.  It has a long shoulder strap but since I don't wear shoulder straps I put the straps on the shortest holes to make it easier to put over my arm or carry in my hand, and I will probably trim off the longer strap length.  The inside has two cell phone pockets and a zipper pocket and there is a cute heart-shaped zipper pull.  It is a fun, whimsical tote and one I am sure will start a lot of conversations!

I love Planter's Cashews, and loved them even more when Amazon offered them at a much better deal than I get at the grocery store, plus a 20% coupon!  They are tasty, delicious and also make a good hostess gift if you are going to dinner at someone's home.  Sometimes I heat them for a few seconds in the microwave which brings out the flavor.

This beautiful Betsey Johnson cosmetic bag is practical and well-made as well as gorgeous.  The zipper goes from the bottom of one side to the bottom of the other, making it conveniently open wide and yet it has a gusset so things won't fall out.  The sequins are dazzling but they don't feel "rough" on your hands.  I love the gemstone lining, and the cute bow zipper pull.  The only problem with this bag?  I can't decide whether to give it as a gift as planned or keep it for myself!

This pin is much prettier than the picture!  I purchased the burgundy because I wear a lot of black and thought it would show up better than the black brooch, although now that I've seen it I may order the black one too.  It is very sweet, and unlike the picture where it looks like it has a matte finish, it has a bright shiny glaze.  It comes in a beautiful pale aqua gift box (the same color as the gift boxes from that famous jewelry store starting with a "T"!)  I collect brooches and I love tea, so this darling little teapot was a natural choice for me.  I think it would make a great gift for many people.  I've purchased from this seller previously and I've always been amazed at how I receive a product that looks like it should cost several times what I was charged.

I received this fragrance tonight and it was tightly cellophane-wrapped from the factory, obviously new and unused.  So you can imagine my surprise when I removed the flacon from the box and saw some kind of dark matter or sediment floating in the liquid.  It obviously happened at the factory - perhaps the bottle was not clean?  Anyway, I had been eager to try this fragrance because it has received some wonderful reviews, but if the Quality Control where this is made is that careless, I don't think I want to try another bottle.  I've never seen anything like that before in a brand-new bottle of fragrance, and I disposed of it in the trash immediately.

A very pretty brooch, not too big and not too small.  Will garner many compliments for the wearer.  Comes in a nice gift box, and would make an excellent gift because it will go with any color outfit.

This is a pretty pin and will look especially nice in autumn.  I do wish the "topaz" stones had a little more of the yellow-gold color I associate with that beautiful gem, but the pin is still nice and would certainly make a lovely gift.  Golden topaz is the birthstone for November (although it is also shown as citrine because real golden topaz is prohibitively expensive) so if you know any ladies born in November I'm sure they would appreciate this brooch.

What a darling pin, and in such a lovely gift box.  Yes, it can be worn for Halloween but I also think it would be appropriate for the entire autumn season, from September through Thanksgiving.  It is very well-detailed and of excellent quality.

I want to give other shoppers a heads-up.  I ordered the "Carnation" which on my monitor appears as red.  The color I received was a brick color, reddish-brown and not what I wanted.  I did not take the bag out of the plastic wrapping but it did look very nice, as far as the hardware was concerned.  I am sure it is of excellent quality like the two other Anne Klein bags I own, so it was really only the color that was the issue.  Amazon, as always, was very gracious about me returning it.  But I did want to let anyone else out there who wants to order a "red" bag know that they may not receive the color they were expecting.

If you like romantic blues, greens and purples, you will love this dress with it's beautiful impressionistic roses.  It is well-made, very comfortable, and washes like a dream.  I highly recommend it.

Beautiful, rich colors, perfect for autumn.  The tapestry print is so well-done that the fabric looks almost three-dimensional, like velveteen or brocade.  The dress is made in the USA and the stitching and everything about it is of top-quality.

First of all, I want to alleviate anyone's concerns about this large bottle of fragrance being only about one-third the cost of what you would pay in a department store.  There is nothing wrong with it, it is the real deal, and it arrived in perfect condition in it's box wrapped in cellophane.  I don't know how Amazon can give us such great bargains, but I'm glad they do, and I'm happy to save the money to spend on other things!I've used this fragrance, on and off, for several years now, and I really love it.  It is a gourmand fragrance and smells warm and sweet.  If you have a sweet tooth (like I do) you will probably like Fancy also.  When I first spray it, there is a slight whiff of grapefruit, very refreshing, and then it dries down to a cozy delicious caramel.  It also lasts for a long time.Now, there is something else I want to say about Fancy; I've read comments and reviews where people have said that this fragrance is "only for young women" or "not for anyone over twenty-five".  Well, I am a mature woman, love Fancy, and have received many compliments when wearing it.  If someone wants to live by rigid  "perfume rules" that they have created, that's fine with me - it's their life.  Maybe they like having a lot of rules.  But personally, I think if you enjoy a fragrance, and other people around you like your fragrance, you should wear it.  And I want to encourage any lady out there, of any age, to give Fancy a try if you haven't already.  It is truly a great scent!

A few years ago I developed a condition where my right eye "cries"  because of a blocked tear duct.  Unfortunately it has not responded so far to medical treatment and I have been on - until now - a desperate search for a soft, comfortable handkerchief.  I cannot tell you how many handkerchiefs I have purchased in the last few years and they were all disappointingly rough.  Yes, I washed them, over and over, trying to soften them up, but that didn't work very well.  Well, I am happy to tell you my search has ended, thanks to My Hanky!  They are cloud soft, and oh-so-comforting and absorbent.  What a relief!  In addition, Mr. Marino (the inventor) enclosed a personalized note and a brochure detailing the amazing story of how he came to develop these handkerchiefs.  My handkerchiefs came packaged in a pristine white box with gold lettering and a gold elasticized bow tie on them, so they are completely gift-ready if you want to order some as presents.  And Mr. Marino, thank you for making the ladies handkerchiefs special, with the dainty pink edging on them.  They are lovely as well as practical and I can feel proud carrying them in my purse and taking them out anywhere!

The beauty of this necklace and earring set - and the very affordable price - completely amazed me!  Yes, it is a different color than on the website, which appears as bright blue and green pearls, but it is every bit as lovely if not more so.  The pearls are in stunning pastel shades of light blue and light green, and the necklace - which looks even prettier in person - sparkles with crystal beads.  I plan on ordering a couple of more sets for Christmas gifts.  It doesn't come in a box, but at this price I wouldn't expect one.  If you are sitting on the fence about these, I would recommend ordering them before they sell out!

I used to own a leather wallet given to me by some Brazilian friends. Itâs lasted me at least ten years, it hasnât fallen to pieces (or shown any damage), and has developed a nice patina.So why would I want to retire that wallet and change to this Aprince model?One reason. Old age. My old age.Iâve passed my three years and ten, and now I have to live in a wheel chair. This chair reclines when I want to relax, but anything in my pockets falls out, like coins.The old wallet has no provision for storing coins, but the new Aprince has provision for them. Itâs nothing fancy, just a pocket with no means of closing like a zip, but the coins are forced to lie flat. And that keeps them safe.The wallet is well-built of leather and is larger than my old wallet. That means that it can store 24 credit cards, along with bills and a space for your driverâs license.Iâm so pleased with my new wallet I wrote a song about the old one. Join in, youâll recognize the tune:Donât cry for me Brazil-ianaThe truth is, my coins all left meIt gave me a wild lifeAs I lost my penniesI could have spent themOn Seniors at Dennyâs.I was supplied the wallet in exchange for a review. Nobody said anything about a song.

Hereâs what â buy these. They work. They cost $50 for two.Hereâs why. You may be thinking of getting those âofficialâ hearing aids that only cost $5,000-$7,000. Donât.But I hear you cry, âThey cost 100 times more! They must be 100 times better.â Theyâre not.I went looking for the difference. AARP has a couple of pages on its web site called âWhy Do Hearing Aids Cost So Much?âAARP reports that manufacturers pay:Materials â $440Research â $1,320So that means that companies that sell two aids for $50 must be losing around $3400!I have some knowledge of the electronics industry, and these numbers are way higher than Iâd expect.I would estimate that materials cost $2 - $7. Research costs from $0, because chip manufacturers supply circuit drawings for free.Ask your doctor to refer you to a hearing consultant covered by your insurance plan. You may pay a little, but you could get a âfreeâ hearing test from commercial stores that are hoping to sell you multi-thousand dollar hearing aids.An ad for a worker in a commercial store requires they âhave strong selling skills but balanced with a passion to genuinely help people.âYou will almost certainly be sold a hearing aid like these â it increases the volume of upper range of your hearing â the part where you lose ability to hear the sound of consonants in conversation. With the lower range still audible, you regain your ability to hear whole words.Most hearing-impaired adults will be quite happy with this. Hearing loss is a naturally-occurring problem when you age.Around 50 million people in the USA report hearing loss, rising to almost half the population after 75. Thatâs almost as many that suffer vision loss, yet most of us use the corner drugstore or rock-bottom sites that make glasses of any prescription for $10-$40, like ZenniOptical. So try these hearing aids out. If they donât do the trick, go back and see your doctor. But for $50, theyâre worth the try.

I hate to tell you this, but if you hope to learn Android devices, this book is not for you. There isn't any book that will help make the slog to using Android much easier. And if you're thinking of using Apple equipment, I see no sign that it's any easier.Basically a tablet or computer is a simplified desktop or laptop. It has a slightly varying range of abilities, depending what the CPU is capable of. When I bought my tablet in early 2015, I was concerned to get one with GPS. Android had access to Google Maps, but not every tablet had the hardware to deal with this.I bought a ten-inch tablet for well under $100 (a ValuePad, IIRC), and I'm sure if you pay several hundred dollars you'll be able to run what you want from one of the flagship models. But it seems that the space for applications is one gigabyte total. That means certain things have had to have been simplified, and that includes the operating system. So don't expect any windows or drop-down menus.Several applications require you to press on one icon from a close-together group of four.To give you an example, you can read Kindle books, and you open those by tapping on the icons. But when you have to close them, you tap on an unmarked space below the title, and then a widow opens from the left with a small dark home icon, Press this and you return to the library view. Noy only is this not indicated to the user, there appears to be no guide anywhere  on-line.Hart-Davis's book will help you to use common screens, like how to check the battery level. But once you try to use less common actions, you're basically on your own. And even better, each make of tablets likes to put its own icons into the OS. My tablet has half-a-dozen "Child-safe" icons which I never use and can't remove.So although Hart-Davis runs up against all the faults of Android, it's as good as any other. I have several of his other books and have recommended them in Vine reviews.I have a reasonable knowledge of computer programming; I first put pencil to paper back in 1971, and I've taught how to program in several different languages. But I advise you not to get fooled by Android. It is more difficult than you think.

Ram Charan produced a book in 2009 (with Larry Bossidy) called "Execution." I was very impressed by this by this, and Charan's new book pleases me just as much.Charan identifies the activities of a company who decides to take on a major player -  or one even forced to compete with a larger business who's moving into the same area. He lists five areas where the company should be prepared. Some areas are like searching for possible competitors, while others are making sure that your company can easily deal with a change in focus.The stories of companies who thought that they were set for life covers a huge amount of businesses books. For instance, my new alarm clock is an "RCA," and my modem is a "Technicolor." My major regrets if I'm wrong, but I believe that these companies exist purely to license the company's name. In  fact, Wikipedia says about RCA and Technicolor "The RCA trademark is used by Sony Music Entertainment and Technicolor, which licenses the name to other companies such as Audiovox and TCL Corporation for products descended from that common ancestor."Like his other books, the situations are well-described and easy to read. Definitely worth reading.

I first discovered Tony Judt from his book "Postwar." This is a great book about Europe from the end of World War II, and as I was born and lived there from just before the end of the war until around 1990 I learned a huge amount about the politics and sociology of the time."When the Facts Change" is a collection of essays from 1995-2010 that includes some works on Europe, and others on Palestine. As usual Judt writes clearly on every subject he covers, and you'll find it easy to read. It's edited by Judt's co-historian and wife, Jennifer Homans, and she also added a foreword.You may not agree with every sentiment expressed here, but Judt's exemplary writing makes it a great book.

I'm a big Dead fan, and I feel sorry for those who think the band only plays plinky-plonk music for stoned hippies (although I'm sure you can introduce me to a fave band of your own). But I remember reading an interview with Jerry Garcia by an interviewer who though he'd "got it" when he told Jerry that the Dead "were all about drugs." Jerry corrected him by saying that the Dead "were all about the music."This book is largely about the music, although there are some drug references. Those references seem to be a bit old-fashioned since we've had plenty of tell-all autobiographies from rock stars, with detailed descriptions of their drug consumption.Kreutzmann tells his own side of the Grateful Dead story. His work as drummer is impeccable given the often free-form nature of the front men. I re-listened to a lot of those tracks and marveled at his ability to work in such tracks as "Dark Star." With his lack of experience with jazz drumming he still fit in very well.The last time I saw the Dead in the early 1990s, he and Mickey Hart performed a drum solo (a drum duo?) which took my breath away. They both performed a piece as versatile as the three guitarists, yet for most of the time keeping a heavy rhythm going on.Bill's book reads very well. I think you'll like it.

Welcome to the future of USB. I was looking through my boxes of obsolete stuff and found my first hub. One input, four outputs of blazing fast USB 2.0.Nowadays you need a power supply to recharge your mobile devices. Sure, they're supplied with a charger, but it usually powers one device at a time and requires its own wall socket. You can also plug into your computer's USB ports, but they don't supply enough power to charge the device quickly. You can hope that you'll have enough time to bring something, like a smartphone or tablet, up to charge to have enough time to make it run until you can charge it again.Do note that the charging ports only charge and do not transmit data, which is typical of this kind of device. Still, you have seven data ports which should be enough.One warning about USB is that you cannot daisy-chain hubs. Because I review a number of USB devices I've sometimes connected a hub into another hub. I had a problem with anything USB on my computer not working for about twenty minutes after the desktop appeared. Because I had a USB mouse and keyboard they didn't work either. I even reconnected them directly to ports on the computer, but nothing changed. Only when I sorted through all of my USB connections did everything return to normal.TP-LINK has a reputation for quality products and this hub didn't disappoint. It worked fine and caused me no problems while it was here. I recommend it.

I donât know why more people donât own laminators. A laminated sheet of paper is easy to find, will be rainproof out of doors, and can have a hole punched in it to make it easy to put on a hook. I have a bunch of nursing associates who come to my house to take care of me, and they can refer to my list of what to do without asking me all the time.Laminating machines cost from under $20 to several hundred dollars. The main difference is that it takes several minutes for the low-cost machines to heat up, whereas machines at the price of the Fellowes laminators take only a minute until theyâre ready to work. Fellowes claim that their laminators will resist jams, but often other laminators have jam release switches.You may want to laminate bigger sheets of paper than the letter and A4 sizes that almost every laminator can accommodate. 11 x 17 (double letter) and A3 laminators from many makers cost less than double the price of standard-sized machines and the pouches are a little bit more than twice the cost.Now you may be wondering, âOK, Iâm sold on laminating, but what did you find, good or bad, about the Fellowes machine?â Simply this â everythingâs good and nothingâs bad. In fact, I was so surprised with the ease of use and high quality, I read some of the other reviews here and discovered that just about everyone had the same reaction.So then I read some of the reviews of the cheaper models and discovered that everyone loves their laminator. But youâre sure to love this one, so get it for your business and keep a cheaper one for home.

This book, as so many other reviewers have noticed, is misleading in terms of what the cover promises. Unfortunately, reviewers can't agree as to what's wrong with it. It has too much math - it has not enough math. It doesn't do what it set out to do - it's a clear indication of how things are.Firstly, the title is wrong. The math in the book is negligible, and you don't even need to know anything about math to get Suzuki's arguments. If you accept his arguments that "A is because of X, Y, and Z," then you don't need to be able to follow the equations - leave that to the math-heads.As someone who was born abroad and who has only been an citizen for less than ten years of the thirty years I've lived here, I don't understand the constitution fetish of so many Americans. If you think it's so important today, can you imagine how the original framers would feel if you told them that the Constitution would last (with a few changes) for 250 years. Yes, there's a lot in it that's still important in the twenty-first century, but there's also a lot that had no real meaning after the first fifty years or so.If I were King (well maybe not King), I would suggest that every 50 years there be a Constitutional Conference every fifty years over a ten-year period where alterations would be argued and eventually put to a national referendum. (And my vote would go to the non-politically elected Supreme Court, with nine judges being being selected anonymously out of a pool of around 100.)Time to get off my soapbox, and move my car so there's room for the Tea Party to protest outside my house.  :)And the book? It's good that Suzuki takes on questions like "Why do we need an Electoral College?" and shows us that the simple answer isn't always foolproof. See his explanations and become the guru of any political discussion in your area.So memorize the arguments and when people say, "Why don't they . . .?" you'll be able to say "Why they Don't". Recommended for those despairing of sound-bite arguments.

The arrival of this adapter surprised me, but not as much as the price.Obviously the small size and the low price means that one of the big chip-makers has brought out a new adapter chip. All previous AC standard adapters were a lot larger than this, and usually had a cord with a USB plug on the end. This is the smallest adapter I've seen.As a replacement for my $65 adapter this worked just as well at a third the price. With AC standard routers now going for under $50, this means that you could add a three times faster complete wi-fi for under $70.This extra speed is necessary when you consider that people are downloading movies and using wireless gadgets, which were pretty much unknown a few years ago.Like most wireless devices, this adapter works with previous versions of the 802.11 standards. So, if cash is a problem (never happens in my house, of course), you could buy replacements for your 802.11n networks one piece at a time. Obviously you'll need an 802.11AC router and adapters, but pointing out to your significant other that "All we need is an AC standard router, and everyone on the network will get faster speeds" improves your chances considerably.I  must thank Sabrent for sending me this adapter in exchange for a review. It will go into my laptop and will improve downloads considerably. If I hadn't been sent a review product, I would have bought it.

America seems to have this on again - off again relationship with design. Since the 1920s Bahaus designs Europe has led the world in widespread design trends. That's not to say that everything in Europe is beautifully designed but it seems to that in the thirty years since I moved here I've seen very few houses that didn't have something that George Washington would recognize. American house design has many traditions from the past - houses that have columns across the front, hardware that emphasizes Victorian complexity - so much of it unnecessary.That's why I was so glad to see this book. Even though mid-century design has not become widely adopted, it has stood up to the sixty or seventy years to still appear modern yet part of the nature surrounding it. These houses are not cheap, and especially these days you can see high-end furniture. Each house described has a floor plan and many photos.The book gives justice to the the houses. If you're interested in architecture you'll have plenty to see and even more to think about.

Time was when USB ports were used largely for communications between computers and devices. There was one pin that gave out five volts, but to start with it didn't have enough power to run many devices. Before 2010, USB was suggested for charging mobile devices and since then USB has become the standard for charging portable equipment.Although you can use one of the USB ports on your computer, devices charge faster if you have a dedicated charge supply. Eventually these took the place of USB ports. These chargers don't send digital information - they have one purpose only, sending five volts at higher amperage than the on-computer USB ports. In a sense, they are chargers just like other chargers, but a USB cable sends the voltage to your device.Sabrent have put out a purpose-built charger for USB devices. It has the power to charge up to ten USB-charged devices. It has a power cable that attaches to the socket box at one end and the mains plug at the other, so when you get it all you need to do to get it working is to plug it into the wall and plug the USB cable that sends power to your device.In practice it works very well, charging far faster than many chargers supplied with devices. As a purpose-built charger, there is little to fault. It runs independently of your computers USB communications. I would like to say that with ten sockets it could be all the charger you'll ever need, but I have a very Rube Goldberg USB system with too many hubs. In addition, I have a set of headphones that need charging with USB, but most of the time they're not connected, so i get warning windows and sounds every time I power up, telling me that the computer cannot connect with a USB device  - the phones.So while you'll be able to use this for a long time for charging, probably some time in the next decade you'll be looking for a second one as the number of chargeable devices you own goes up and up. But until then this device will satisfy you, with its smart design, big capacity, fast speed, and looking like a well-made charger. Its as good as I can imagine.

Time was, if your windshield got dirty, you had to stop and get out and clean it. Then we got windshield washers (especially in NYC) and we could drive forever and still see. That was all most people wanted. Volvo added wipers and washers for headlights, but that was to get the mud off. Then we dropped glass headlights and moved on to plastic ones. Plastic was cheaper, lighter, and easily molded into shapes that blended into the body lines.That would have been great, but over a few years people noticed that their headlights were becoming less and less transparent. Although this discoloration looked like it was all the way through, it was just on the surface. For while people recommended cleaning with toothpaste, but this didn't work very well, and before long companies brought out restoration kits for predictable results.These kits really need a power drill, but if you have any kind of a cordless drill that should suffice. There are detailed video instructions on the 3M site (http://3mauto.com/products/headlight-restoration/3m-headlight-restoration-kit-with-tape-and-protectant-39098.html) and the actual process is quite quick and effective. Just change the pads to go from the most coarse through to the most fine. If you're thinking of selling your car, cleaning is a must.3m also includes a preservative coating to keep the headlight clean. I cleaned the headlights on the car of a friend of mine and she was ecstatic  about the difference in appearance and the amount of light the headlamps can put out. Definitely does the job.

Most people know the term âLOL.â Itâs in common use in emails, and stands for âLaugh Out Loud.â But there are various meanings to that term so it doesnât mean quite what it meant at the beginning. It can mean, âYour message wasnât funny, but Iâm protecting your feelings,â or âI might have smiled internally, but I donât remember.âMoving on, it can mean âI definitely smiled, but that was about all,â or âI made some kind of noise of amusement, but you could hardly hear it.â And finally, LOL can mean, âI laughed so loud, I was embarrassed because everyone around me noticed.âIâm warning you, because if you have a sense of humor like mine, that will be at least one LOL in this book of the final definition, so be prepared. Itâs just past half way through and it involves a glazier. Itâs almost as if Alexander McCall Smith had used 15 books to set us up for this situation, and he doesnât disappoint. So read at your peril.Thereâs obviously a lot more in the book, but it is all resolved by the end, with many interlocking stories going on. Mma Ramotswe  and Mma Makutsi run the Detective Agency with numerous cases, Mr. J.L.B Maketoni has to make changes at Speedy Motors, Violet Sephotho makes an unwanted appearance, and Charlie - well Charlie is always in trouble.My wife remarked that this book had a slightly sharper edge than some of the earlier works, and I felt it was slow to get up to speed, but these are minor criticisms. Yet again Alexander McCall Smith has sent us a âletter from homeâ so we can learn of the latest escapades of the lovable cast. And itâs just as good as the last 14, and you feel glad that you read it.

For a long time we used battery chargers to keep our batteries ready. Often, if a car or motorcycle wasn't used much, it would stubbornly refuse to start just when you needed it. Things are better these days, with an alternator keeping the battery much better charged than a dynamo, but even so you can find yourself with a poorly charged vehicle that won't start.Running a trickle battery charger full time can cut battery life considerably. The Battery Tender is a "connect and forget" device that will not harm your battery. With battery prices rising to over $100, you don't want to buy another one when you don't have to.Simply connect the Tender to your battery and then to the wall. This device will work anywhere in the world. The newer model will charge much faster than the old, and is reliable.You can connect this device to cars you use every day, or just once a year. The lights on the box give you an accurate idea of the condition of the battery, and connection is simple.A great idea for anyone who wants to avoid battery problems.

Fall is here, making me sad for the end of summer, but happy because this is the season of the Best American series. Anthologies like this are always interesting because if you donât like what youâre reading, a new article will come up in a few pages.So a lot depends on how well the articles are chosen, and in this case the selection is brilliant. You would have to subscribe to a large number of magazines to get these stories, and each subscription would be more than the cost of this book.As you read these articles you will wonder how much information on science and nature you have missed. I subscribe to the Scientific American and also read daily websites, yet all of these stories are new to me, and just about all of them are articles that I wish I read in the original.I read this book as fast as I read fiction by familiar authors, because the stories here are important. Some of them relate to my experience, like remembering experiences under anesthetic, and others show hidden dangers of genealogy research combined with DNA testing.The only story I had a little trouble with was that of a trapper who caught beavers and foxes. I felt it was a little âNature red in tooth and claw,â but then I thought that it wasnât good to hide myself away from this.If youâre the slightest bit interested in science and nature writing, you should get this book. You will be amazed at the range of subjects that prove interesting in ways you didnât expect. And, as an anthology, you donât have to devote an entire books worth of reading in one sitting.

Iâve had a Black & Decker toaster oven for a few years. This replaced my two slot old-fashioned toaster. Although it was sometimes difficult to set, it gave reasonable toast if you set it correctly. Thatâs why I was interested to see the next step up â this toaster oven which cost twice as much as my original oven.So is it worth the extra? Yes, I think it is. It does all the things that the original often did, and does them better. Most people who have used both say that the new oven gives quicker and more reliable slices of toast.It also has a convection oven, and my wife cooked a couple of pork chops which tasted good. The oven is about twice as large as the original, but if you put two of the originals on top of each other it would take up as much space. In terms of counter space, the new oven uses very little more space, and although itâs taller it has a flat top as opposed to the curved top of the original.Unless youâre really strapped for cash I recommend the new oven over the old. Itâs nice to know that once you get sorted out with the controls, you can almost guarantee that everything will be cooked as normal.Worth the extra money.

Years ago, I remember installing Windows for Workgroups 3.11 on my system. I now could network my system or even â gasp! â connect it to the Internet! But there was one extra purchase I needed, which was a router. Like most people of the time, I bought a Linksys blue box, and I started seeing them everywhere.At that time networking of any sort was only suitable for dweebs. Because networking started as something you did in mainframe computers, it needed a systems manager to set it up. The Workgroups version of Windows was the first OS that let you network your system without using a third-party program. At that time I thought that the Internet would never catch on because it was too complicated for the average user.As time went on and networking became part of the regular version of Windows, the process became simpler. The attraction of the Internet became enough so that people were ready to live with networkingâs complications. I can remember getting a Linksys wireless router, with two little antennae on the back, but it was a great feeling to sit in my living room and surf the ânet without apparently any connection to anything.Since then Linksys seemed to have dropped down in the scheme of things, with Japanese and local companies offering their routers. Whatâs also changed is that big companies have taken over Internet supply without anything like the service that the independent companies of the 1990s used to give.Now we have a resurgence of Linksys, with this model â the AC1200. As you can probably gather from the name, it has the new AC standard that transmits nearly three times as fast as the âNâ standard. Like most routers, it has four Ethernet ports along with a socket for USB â if youâve used an older Linksys router, youâll recognize the back panel.Itâs really easy to set up. You simply connect it to your existing network and follow the on-screen instructions. Although a CD is supplied, you probably wonât need it. If youâre thinking of upgrading to AC1200 you should do just fine.

I first came across Caitlin Moran when I reviewed her book, "How to be a Woman.' Modesty forbids but megalomania insists on revealing my reviewing of that book - the highest placed with over 100 "Helpful" votes.I looked in vain for some sort of "Thank You" for my review. A Rolls-Royce in my driveway, or even a few packets of McVitie's Chocolate Digestive Biscuits (sort of large Graham Crackers with one side thickly covered in chocolate). But nothing.So without any sort of a bribe (not that I'd accept them, but it would have been nice to eat Chocolate Biscuits in the back of the Rolls), I have to review this book. And unbribed, I have to say that this book is even better than "How to be a Woman."If you recall, Caitlin's first book was about her life, from around a thirteen-year-old to an adult. She's really broadened her scope with this book, which is about her life, from around a thirteen-year-old to an adult. The difference is that this story is the same, but largely fictional.In this book, she can use her imagination along with other people's experience. She goes to the pop record paper in London, gets a job writing reviews of bands playing in her local area, which she does without attending the concerts, but buy listening to their albums that she has to loan from the local library.Born Johanna Morrigan, she reinvents herself as Dolly Wilde, along with  a "Who-gives-a-F***" attitude. Of course, Dolly never was a virgin, but Johanna spends a great deal of time trying to get into bed with anyone - with everyone, in fact. She muddles through her sex life, but does have words of advice on how to deal with an incredibly well-endowed man. In fact, a "thing" which has to live in two post codes at once.Johanna has the solution to this. She advises doing it doggy-style and then crawling away from it, round and round the bed. The whole book is full of hilarious moments like this, and even better because she's writing fiction.If you've read her earlier book, you'll know what I mean. If you're new to Caitlin, buy it anyway.

You know how when someone mentions that you never see some kind of car anymore, and then it seems that this is all you see? I started looking for clip-on tuners when this one arrived for review, and I suddenly started seeing the giveaway of little black plastic pieces on every guitar I saw, be it on videos of performing artists and also on those of players in how-to YouTube shorts.But if you think about it, this makes perfect sense. <croaking voice> When I started playing guitar all we had </croaking voice>  was either plastic pitch pipes that you blew through to get the correct note for each string, or - luxury of luxuries - a tuning fork. Both of these needed a quiet place to tune, and you needed more than one person so you could actually hear the note as you tuned.Thanks to the miracle of computers we got boxes that would listen to the sound of our instruments and show us whether we were sharp or flat. Then they worked on taking the input from the guitar lead, and the boxes got smaller and became foot pedals. Now I have two multi-effects that show me whether I'm in tune or not.You'd think that with these tuners around, I would have the last word in tuning. But the last last word is here, with the clip-on tuner. This has numerous advantages over previous methods, the biggest of which is that it detects the accuracy of the note played by using vibrations of the instrument itself. That means no amplification is needed, so you can turn the volume knob of your guitar to zero.The second reason is that it is clip-on. I found that it worked almost anywhere on the headstocks of my Fender/Gibson/Explorer style guitars. If you're a Bedroom Warrior like myself, you can swap it from guitar to guitar - or, better still, get one for each guitar. D'Addario has priced this competitively, but last time I looked Amazon was offering two of these tuners for under $20 the pair.You can see the tuning indicator very easily whether this is mounted on the front or back of the headstock. You can also use this device as a metronome.One problem many people have is that tuning the instruments may not be possible if there's an out-of-tune instrument in the band (that can't be tuned easily, like a piano). This tuner can be reset over a wide range so that you don't have to tune by ear to the offending instrument. The tuner also has auto on/off as well as a manual button for that purpose, so you won't find your battery suddenly dead.I can see these tuners becoming part of guitars generally - the last last last word. But today you can have one of these - or a Peterson Strobe (admittedly, a professional instrument) for a mere ~$3300. If I were you I'd pass on the Peterson and get this one.

Around 1990, shortly after I had arrived in the United States, me and my wife were living in Ipswich MA.  Then, after one more landlord had sold out from under us, we heard that 26 ½ E. Street was for rent. Our friends nodded sagely, and said âOh yes, thatâs the Updike house.âOur new landlords lived in the larger part of the house, and the apartment we had was not so full of Updike memories. Eventually they showed us the rest of the house, including Updikeâs study. Although it was not large he had a great view of the busy part of Ipswich. We also saw the marks he gouged in the floor paint with his heels as he sought inspiration.But Updike had already made Ipswich famous by his book, Couples. Thinly disguising the town as âTarbox,â he wrote of a group of friends who not only played sports and socialized together, but also slept with each other. It was probably the first novel of its kind that described a life in âThe post-pill paradise.âUpdike came from a sleepy part of Pennsylvania, and life seemed worse when he moved from a small town to the country. But his mother was a would-be novelist (and got herself published in the end) and Updike was born a creator. He went to Harvard and soon gained a name there, and achieved a major aspiration â to be published in The New Yorker.Adam Begley has done a great job with this book. The New Yorkerâs Janet Malcolm described it âas if he was writing a novel.â But thatâs understandable given that Updike greatly described his life in his novels. Quite often, Begley quotes a paragraph from one of Updikeâs books or short stories, and then carries on in his own words.Updike was a clear-eyed observer of the human condition. As well as a whole series of short stories and several books he had two series â the Rabbit stories, and the tales of Henry Bech. From the first story, Rabbit Run, âRabbitâ Angstrom tries to break free from his life. Henry Bech is Updikeâs alter ego, but with an ability to fall into trouble at any minute.Updike became famous and his books sold very well. He sold the house to friends and moved to a much better house in Ipswich. His philandering led him to confess to his wife. She replied that she had been unfaithful before him. Eventually he left his wife, wooed the wife of the couple heâd sold his old Ipswich house to, and they became married.You may have come across Updikeâs work in the adaption of his novel âThe Witches of Eastwick.â This movie starred Cher, Susan Sarandon, and Michelle Pfeiffer as the witches, who are intrigued by a new man who moves into the large house in Eastwick. This man is Jack Nicholson who has a devilish way with the women.The front cover of the book shows a smiling Updike and what I take to be Craneâs Beach, where Ipswich meets the sea. If Updike turned to his right he would see the Crane house, which was used for the exterior shots in âThe Witches of Eastwick.âJust when I thought that I had lost touch with Updike, it turns out that he had spent a year in the town of Georgetown - the next town over. He died in 2009 in the tony town of Beverly Farms. I doubt you could read this book without wanting to read Updikeâs work. Thatâs how I felt after finishing it. Begley keeps the story moving and you donât want to give up. I highly recommend it.

I have had a condition that required me to have a bandage on my leg that was replaced daily. Every day a nurse visited and either used her own scissors or the household scissors we had.The household scissors were terrible. The nurse's scissors were much better, and came with a little plastic guard on the end of one blade to stop them accidentally digging into you.Just before the treatment was over I got these scissors, and everyone agrees that they are noticeably the best. You don't have to worry about the plastic guard falling off and getting lost, because one blade is bent over at the end, so the guard isn't needed.When the nurses came I got them to use these scissors, and they praised them constantly. They cut better and more accurately than the nurse's purpose-built scissors, and they also didn't stick to anything with adhesive.I wouldn't be surprised if the nurses were issued scissors exactly like this - I keep them in plain sight so I can see if they sprout little legs and run away.For around twelve dollars they perform exceptionally, and I'm sure the time will come when you need them in your home.

I think this book is attempting the impossible. But then I used to teach Office, usually without a book or notes.Word is perhaps the only application where you can know a little bit and still be productive. But I'll doubt you'll be able to do useful work in most of the other applications.That isn't the fault of this book. It appears to be a course book for classes - the major authors are the training company AGI. It explains what will start you off using Office, and does so clearly. The book itself is well-made, with lots of full-color illustrations and a CD of exercises.But unless you take further classes or study yourself at the intermediate stage, I doubt that you'll be the "go-to" person in your company for help with Office.So take a look at this book if you're aware of the limitations of Intro to Office books. Clearly a lot of thought has gone into this, and I doubt you'll find anything noticeably better.

I feel that this book is like having a really experienced professional by your side, able to explain things in simple ways you can understand. Not only that, but much of the advice given makes the book like a "Transform your Communication."Safety is to many people a boring subject. Marie makes it shine, and shows extremely clearly methods to communicate your goal. She has plenty of URLs showing successful techniques.I can't recommend this book highly enough - six stars wouldn't be enough. If you communicate in a business setting, you need to have it by you.

I just received this case after reading through dozens of measurements. My Nikon Coolpix 9300 fits inside with a little space, but not enough for the camera to slide about.It seems pretty well-made, and my wish was granted - to get a bag for a silly price. For a few bucks it will keep the camera from marks and scratches.So I sold my Canon A570 and my Panasonic FZ3, because the Nikon exceeded the specs of the two put together. and the Nikon, as a refurb clearout, cost as much as what I got from selling the other cameras.So hopefully the Nikon will remain pristine and keep its value in this case.

This is how the book starts."It's a Ground War, not just an Air War."I hope you all got that. The authors say "This the Most Important Thing we Learned."I rather think that this is a metaphor that doesn't really convey what they mean. As far as I can see, it means that scaling up excellence means either not giving the message a quick once-over to the troops. or not assuming that you have to involve and move everybody - or maybe both.Or maybe I'm just stupid.The rest of the book is extremely useful. Many organizations form around a small group of people are all in tune with creating excellence. Then their fame overtakes them, requiring a far bigger number of staff to hold the same values. Some succeed, some don't.Authors Sutton and Rao give plenty of examples of how to spread excellence. Like many of the indispensable business books before them, the price of the book is equivalent to only a tiny part of how you'll benefit.Definitely recommended.

I looked through this book, and found the numbers interesting.The numbers are based on hits on Wikipedia and Google. This seems an obvious way of ranking popularity, but I suggest you look at the Wikipedia Top 25 Reports. These show the Top 25 hits for the week, and it seems to me that only about five of them might be appearing here in a year's time.I think that people refer to Wikipedia when something happens that they don't expect. I imagine many more people would check the entry for Beethoven if their were reports saying that "Hitler was descended from Beethoven." Even well-known figures can have their blip of fame though no fault of their own.I would imagine that the most popular queries on Wikipedia are on people who don't have full info on their lives. And of course, we all have fixed ideas of our own on who is the most popular with us. And until there are sections on Wikipedia for all famous people in all cultures of the world, it will never be a totally accurate barometer. The authors picked on what appears to be the best bet for now.I think this book will be popular, nonetheless. Just be aware of its shortcomings.

I received two books this month to review, and they could learn from each other. Each one of them tries to put human catastrophes and human beings in some sort of order. This book starts off with an interesting premise â that the overall effects of certain disasters turn out to be on the positive side. Author Lomborg makes the case that the effects of El NiÃ±o a few years ago turn out to be positive.While the damages in this case were estimated at $4 billion, the benefits were as high as $19 billion. The benefits figure comes from estimating the positive effects of increased temperatures, leading to fewer deaths through cold and reduced heating bills. Other benefits of El NiÃ±o include reduced spring flood damage and fewer Atlantic hurricanes.Looked at in this way, it pays to look at calamities from all sides. Lomborg uses the gross domestic product of countries to arrive at a close figure of the positive and negative effects of events we see mainly from the minus side. Most of the areas he picks have a negative affect overall, so he thinks we should see the impact on a 150 year old period.He chooses the period from 1900 to 2050. Obviously the latter figure means that people have to project from current numbers. The news is generally pretty good. We are slowly but surely cutting out a lot of the reasons for people not realizing their potential, through illness or other problems. Yet we have to keep working at these issues.Bill Gates, in his 2014 letter from the Gates Foundation, says âI am optimistic enough about this that I am willing to make a prediction. By 2035, there will be almost no poor countries left in the world. (I mean by our current definition of poor.) Almost all countries will be what we now call lower-middle income or richer.â Such countries will be more ready to look at the first world and demand their share of its riches.But Gates also says âCalculating GDP is an inexact science with a lot of room for error and disagreement.â Lomborg tries to be very evenhanded with this, but his book eventually turns into a huge parade of charts and tables (often both on the same page). If youâre prepared to read the text (and avoid a few equations) you will get the message. Unfortunately, a quick glance at the book would convince most people that it is too academic to be understood.Thatâs a pity, because if this editor had taken a look at my other book to review called âWhoâs Bigger,â the message might have come through very clearly. This book ranks historical figures by their exposure on Wikipedia. The highest number of references puts them at the top of their rank. While authors Skiena and Ward acknowledge that this method may not be perfect, they quickly provide tables of popularity.Both books are published by Cambridge University press, but âWhoâs Biggerâ is clearly aimed at the most popular market. I think that had âHow much have Global Problems cost the World?â dropped its sights from academia to the general public, it would have attracted much more attention. And unfortunately, ecological problems deserve the widest audience.So if youâre the sort of reader who will occasionally plow through a book, you will get a lot of benefit here. Itâs just a pity that this book will probably remain obscure.

Edison was one of the foremost inventors of our time, and while subsequent inventions have changed the world, later inventors had the ability to succeed in only one area. That's to be expected given the explosion of knowledge, but to Edison each problem was a challenge that he could solve.The range of interests he had has probably never been surpassed. We know of his work with electric light and sound recording, but Edison's growing plants for artificial rubber and his manufacture of Portland Cement were unknown to me until I read this book. It's one thing to say, "Oh, that can probably be improved," and another thing altogether to invest large amounts of time and money as Edison did.Why I missed the last star for this book was because it steered well clear of controversy. I imagine that it will be sold in the gift shops of Edison-related sites, where people will be more interested in what the Man did, rather than the few areas where he failed. Author DeGraff has spent most of his life working on cataloging Edison's inventions, which is both an asset and a liability.The book fails to deal adequately with "The War of the Currents," which is largely presented as arguments on the best method of electrocuting rogue animals and criminals. The discussion and ramifications of AC versus DC generation of electricity are mainly ignored. Look up "The War of the Currents" on Wikipedia to get a truer idea of the issues involved.DeGraff does point out that Edison often believed that Technical Excellence would be more important than public opinion, which is why the records he produced for his gramophone (with no-name artists at excellent quality) were doomed compared to RCA's use of famous artists.The book is well-written, well-illustrated, and well produced. It certainly opened my mind to the lesser-know parts of Edison's inventing life, and makes it perfectly clear that he was not a lone inventor, but relied on his assistants.It's an interesting story, and one that every American should know.

When this pedal first came out, you could only select three effects at one time. That was soon changed to six at one time.Now the fifty or so effects have been increased to nearly 100. If you have the smaller number you can go to Zoom in Japan and download the rest. It would seem that even current pedals for sale only have the smaller set. It would also appear that the patches available from this download are now the same as those on the MS-100BT, the Bluetooth model of this pedal. You can't download tones at this time like you can with that model.All you'll need is a USB cord to connect the MS50G to your computer.Since I wrote this I bought and reviewed the Zoom G1oN Guitar Floor Multi-Effects Pedal. At around $50, you may well chose this over the MS50G.(The Zoom Japan URL is in the first comment.)

A friend of mine who is a well-known author recommended this book to me and Ginny was kind enough to send it. Unfortunately it landed on the mess that is my desk and vanished from site and thought for too long.Now Iâve rediscovered it and wished Iâd never lost it. This book is for everyone who writes, not just for the web. Iâm interested in writing presentations, and it works very well for that. Many books Iâve seen give vague instructions on how to engage your readers, but Ginny goes far deeper than that. She encourages you to think of how your audience is taking what they read.An example is the Mint website, where sheâs constantly reminding you of what your audiences think. People have many questions as they navigate the site, and you should be constantly aware to provide answers. Confused readers will eventually leave the website, still with questions. Similarly, presentation audiences will tune out if things arenât clear.Early on, Ginny points out the necessity of having personas, or sketches of the typical people who will be reading or hearing what you wrote. For each persona, you should consider how they feel after each of your statements. As your argument progresses, so should their thinking - in ways you can predict.But itâs not just general writing â Ginny explains in considerable detail what works on a website. All too often, sites assume that people will read large amounts of text and click buttons that say âMore Infoâ with no explanation why. Maybe you can recall when you stopped reading a website because it wasnât saying what you needed to know.As you can imagine, this is a very easy book to read. There are lots of illustrations that show both good and bad ways of imparting information. But the writing is so straightforward that you almost donât need the illustrations.This book is so important that I recommend it along with the two other books that Iâve relied on over the last few years. One is Bob Blyâs The Copywriter's Handbook, and the other is Steve Stockmanâs How to shoot Video that doesn't Suck. Both books, like Ginnyâs, give you vital guidance on things you probably didnât even think were important. Best to get all three books, and keep them where you work. You will definitely get your moneyâs worth.

I have considerable praise for this book. We have all kinds of strange ideas about creativity, and Burkus skewers them all. I guess I've seen some exposed before, but this is a comprehensive exposure of what too many people believe about creativity.However, I've only given the book four stars. Burkus needs to write a book called "The TRUTHS of creativity." He does refer to successful creative practices in places in the book, but once you read about the myths you need a direction to go in.The book is easy to read and understand, but at the end you may well be charged up to avoid creativity myths, but now you want to know what works. Burkus gives a lot of information about creativity at the Gore company, and a similar section in each chapter would help a great deal.So I hope the book sells well, and the publisher invites him to write a sequel to it. I'm sure it would be a runaway success.

This is one of the best books I've read in the last couple of years, and I've read some pretty good ones.If you're an armchair scientist like myself, imagine being invited to a dinner party. After the meal, dozens of scientists tell you how they feel on a particular issue, one after the other. At this party they tell you what scientific theory theory they like, and why. And they rarely use any deep scientific jargon, and if they do, you can pick it up from the context.You finish reading this book and thinking "Wow!" You learn that there are people light-years ahead of you in intelligence yet they can make it clear in a few pages what they're thinking about. Some people don't even need a page to express themselves. Just about every few pages you come across ideas that will blow your mind.This book comes from John Brockman, who runs a website called Edge.org. He uses the site to solicit responses to his question of the year. The answers come from people who are usually college professors and have written books, But there are other, better-known people, like Richard Dawkins, Jared Diamond, and Sherry Turkle, along with Nobel prizewinners like Frank Wilczek and Eric Kandel. The standard is uniformly excellent.Going back to that Dinner party - Brockman has done this before, and each time a book was made from it. You can read the contents of everything he's published on his web site, but I prefer reading a book.And I think you will too. Get this or one of Brockman's earlier books. I'm sure you'll have the same feelings as me and be really glad you read it.

Like many others here, I received this battery charger in exchange for a review. And of course, the moment I received it I had to go into hospital.I came back to find the opened package, so i was unsure of how to use it - especially since the "instructions" leaflet had no instructions.But here's how to use it. Plug your charger into the side input. When the battery is charged, take the same USB cord and plug the large end into the bottom. Plug the other end into your device. That's all.It's a great idea, because it's so small to carry that you'll never fear your device losing its charge. Sometimes it has more charge than the best-charged device.I wasn't put off by the sticker on the back. I see there's a smaller sticker on the actual charger that's sold. It isn't about what it looks like (although it looks pretty good), but rather that it performs when you need it. And it does.So don't worry about the negative reviews here. When you need it, it delivers.

Our cats like to go out into the Cat Cage, but most of the time we have to keep the door closed, so they put their paws up when they want to come back in. We're not allowed to let our cats out of the condo.I thought this would protect the glass against scratches, but it turns out to be something to put over wood. We have a cat Jungle Gym a foot away, so they sharpen their claws on that - or the couch cover. And this product is not for fabrics, so we have no use for it.I can see it being very useful where animals scratch at wood doors. In the meantime, our cats go out without damaging anything and almost rub noses with other cats and even wild turkeys.

I have written several reviews of travel books on places I've never been to.But this book is different. Around 1992 I took off from Los Angeles direct (or so I thought) to Melbourne, Australia. The 747 was packed, and sleep was difficult. That's why I was annoyed when we were told that we'd stopping at Auckland. It turns out that they wanted to spray the inside of the plane to get rid of any bugs we might have brought.So we were deplaned and went into part of the Auckland terminal. This was a an area about 50 by 100 feet, surrounded by shops and stores - none of which were open. We sat there for about half an hour in the dawn. I looked out and maybe saw a perimeter fence - in the dark and mist it was impossible to tell. When we left I still couldn't see anything.Thus I count this visit as my qualifications for discussing New Zealand, All I can say is that the place was worth visiting after reading this book. It deals with the three main reasons for going there, like a bunch of places that appealed to the frugal traveler in me. There's also a lot about The Hobbit movies, and the home of the world's best Sauvignon Blanc wine. The combinations of climates, and the strong Maori influence made me wish we could have spent a few days there.National Geographic has produced a guidebook that looks like a backpacker's guide, but it appeals to pretty much all kinds of travelers. There are plenty of color photographs and the intimation that you'll enjoy the place if you're prepared to be active. Many places need a hike to see them best.A nod of the head to Maureen, the Kiwi who was a roommate of mine in London. She introduced me to New Zealand pronunciation - the book gives some examples, like "Fush and Chups" for Fish and Chips. But she went ever further, referring to her friend "Pp." That's right, Pip lost her vowel. You breathed out and then closed your lips quickly.Kiwis strike me as similar to Aussies. Most have a good sense of humor (especially self-deprecatory) and are often very upbeat. So why not take a trip to New Zealand and see what it's like?Just make sure you get out of the airport.

I had to go into hospital suddenly (OK now) and came home to find someone had opened this package. I wasn't sure whether I had all the instructions and parts. After spending a couple of hours trying to set the speakers up, I realized that I needed a power supply,and finally found the one supplied.Sound finally flowed out of the speakers. My guess is that this sounds slightly better than the average, typical of Logitech products. Things are clear at the volumes I'm using (I have the speakers either side of my monitor) and I guess if you're looking for a speaker system at this price this is worth taking a look.My preference is for systems with a subwoofer (three boxes, in a 2.1 configuration) and the deep bass is missing from this system. However, for a few dollars more you can get a subwoofer system from Logitech. I'd advise that, unless you have little space for speakers, or you want something to tote along with a laptop.Logitech sells a range of computer add-ons and upgrades, and I find their stuff to be generally good. So take a listen.

Years ago, at a MacWorld, I met David Pogue, and attended an off-floor demonstration of HPâs first inkjets. The results were not very good. Pictures looked like the image on the front of a T-shirt that had been washed 500 times. I received a small teddy bear with its HP shirt for my attendance.These days we expect inkjets to give a pretty good representation of what we send to them. We expect them to be fast and accurate. We also expect them to have a scanner and copier built-in, and sell for considerably less than the early attempts. Many people are happy with printers that cost less than $50.As far as I can remember most of the inkjet and laser printers of the time used Canon mechanisms, and as time went on the inks and printer mechanisms improved. Of course, when printer manufacturers discovered that selling ink for a large amount meant that they could cut the initial cost of the printer, made it possible to pay much less.Incidentally, I see in one of the reviews here that the reviewer claimed that he never bought new ink cartridges, but rather a whole new printer. That was on the grounds that a set of replacement cartridges often cost more than half of a new printer.This might be a good plan except that most printers come with âstarterâ ink cartridges, which hold considerably less than full cartridges. If a starter cartridge gives you only a quarter of the ink in a full cartridge, then this method is a false economy. You end up buying four printers to get as much ink as you get in a full cartridge.So if you pay $60 for a new printer against $35 for a set of full ink cartridges, you end up spending $240 against $95 for buying new cartridges. Yes, you have three printers, but without ink cartridges theyâre basically worth nothing. So take that into account before choosing how to plan your purchases.This printer has a couple of things that I didnât expect in a machine costing under $100. First of all, it has duplex printing, which means you print on both sides of the paper at once. Thus if you have a 30 page document it will print on 15 sheets of paper. The other thing, apart from the growing use of Wi-Fi is the Air Print standard, which lets you print direct from your phone or tablet.Canon has raised the bar with this printer. Just like a printer without copier and scanner is getting to be a rarity these days, I think that duplex and Air Print will be necessary on all printers of this price. The performance in basic printer abilities is well up to par, and duplex at least will be used by just about every purchaser.My only criticism is that Canon says you will save up to 50% of your paper costs by using duplex. Only 50%? They could at least have printers that print on the edges of the paper to save you even more.But other than that, this is a good investment. Yes youâll have to pay for new ink cartridges eventually, but at least youâll be getting the same quality and not have a house filled with ink-less printers.

Time was, Lonely Planet books were in everybody's backpack as people found their way around the little traveled parts of the world. But lately, Lonely Planet has expanded its range to the armchair traveler with books that will never see a cockroach.The books that I've seen recently are aimed at the more affluent traveler, although the back-packers guides still exist. Some of these are simply upmarket versions for people who will arrange their trip long before their travel, and will stay in Western-style hotels.But this book is a coffee table book, yet it still has the ability of other Lonely Planet books to make you want to get up and go. There are dozens of photographs of the world, both natural and man-made, but with very little text. Some people will read a book like this and decide to take a trip to the sites that appeal to them, but most will just browse through the pictures.The pictures are very good. They may well be better than other pictures you seen of the same subject. They will appeal to people of all age groups. Some photos take up far more space than you see elsewhere.So yes, it's a coffee table book, but it may not be an end in itself. Some people will decide that they actually have to go to the places, but even if you don't, it's a very enjoyable read. If guests come and pick up this book from your coffee table, you will have a hard time getting them to put it down.I think you'll agree with me that this is a great book and well worth getting or giving.

I'm a 50-year veteran of not being able to play the guitar. I started in my late teens and have moments where I can play a bunch of chords, but I've never been able to get up on stage.That's why I was interested in reviewing this product. The trouble is, it's like reviewing seed packets. You have a month to say what's good and bad about things. Obviously, seeds take a while to grow, and it takes a while to build up the motor skills to play guitar.Rocksmith claims that 1,500,000 guitarists have learned to play through their method. I wouldn't be surprised - the method is well thought through and is light years ahead of what I was used to 50 years ago. 50 years ago you had to learn to read music, according to most books, and only then could you go on to learn to play ancient tunes that were out of copyright.Rocksmith has gone the other way. They recognize that most people who pick up an electric guitar these days want to play the songs their heroes play. That's why they include over 50 songs from the catalog of famous rock songs - no "Danny Boy" here. I think we can say goodbye to Mel Bay and Bert Weedon.And the advantage of computer learning is that it is much more interactive than paper books. Rocksmith tries to match your skills with its lessons. I'm hoping that it will understand my spotty knowledge and keep me working on the things I need. Since it includes a method of tuning your guitar, it seems suitable for the rank beginner.I won't be around my computers and guitars for the next two or three weeks, but when I return I really want to start the program properly. It definitely looks good, and there's a five week plan which I think I can manage, so when I return I'll be practicing and I'll report back.
